SUMMARY: Dr. Rachel Levine is the highest ranking, out transgender person ever to serve in the federal government. Her tenure at HHS ran concurrent with an explosion in state legislation targeting transgender people.

TITLE: Getting Sober-curious: why your friends (and maybe you) are going dry.
SUMMARY:
According to Pew – 79% of New Year's resolutions are about one thing: health. It's Been a Minute is kicking off 2025 with a little series called "new year, new me." We're getting into some of the big questions and cultural confusion around our health and wellness.

This week – many Americans are starting out the year by cutting out alcohol and going "dry." But overall, alcohol is getting less popular in general: according to Gallup, the amount of Americans that drink is down to 58% – the lowest number since 1996. And 41% of Americans who do drink say they want to drink less. Is alcohol on its way out? And what would it mean to live in a more sober culture? Brittany Luse is joined by writer and journalist Ana Marie Cox to get into how people are disentangling alcohol from their lives, and the lessons she's learned as a recovering alcoholic.

Interested in trying out dry January? Our friends at NPR's Life Kit have a newsletter just for the sober-curious. Sign up here.

SUMMARY: The White House says President Biden has now protected a total of 674 million acres of lands and waters — a record for any administration. This includes two new national monuments in California.

TITLE: Jimmy Carter's funeral services begin in Washington, D.C., today
SUMMARY: The next stop in former President Jimmy Carter's six days of funeral services is Washington, D.C., where he will lie in state in the U.S. Capitol through Thursday morning.

TITLE: What America's top economists are saying about AI and inequality
SUMMARY: Planet Money attended the annual meeting of American economists — and the most popular topic this year was artificial intelligence.

TITLE: Jimmy Carter's funeral services begin in DC. And, photos from the major winter storm
SUMMARY: Former President Jimmy Carter's funeral services begin in Washington, D.C., today, and NPR will have special coverage of the events. And, photos from the winter storm plowing through parts of the U.S.

TITLE: Tiny fish on ketamine may show how drug eases depression
SUMMARY: In zebrafish, ketamine causes changes a brain circuit involved in "giving up." That may help explain how the drug helps people with depression.

TITLE: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announces resignation
SUMMARY: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has announced he is stepping down ahead of this year's general election. He had faced mounting pressure to resign — from both allies and opponents.

TITLE: Orthodox Christmas takes on special meaning in Lebanon this year
SUMMARY: Many Orthodox Christians celebrate Christmas in January, not December. In Lebanon, Christians say the holiday is extra poignant for them this year.

TITLE: They were going to be doctors. Instead, they had to dodge bombs and flee war
SUMMARY: tk

TITLE: Biden Administration bars medical debt from credit scores
SUMMARY: The move, which comes less than two weeks before President-elect Donald Trump is set to take office, represents a challenge to the new administration.

TITLE: In a workforce transformed by war, Ukrainian women are now working in coal mines
SUMMARY: War has changed Ukraine's workforce, especially in heavy industry and mining. With men conscripted to fight the war against Russia, women have started working in traditionally male jobs.

TITLE: Jean-Marie Le Pen, French fiery far-right leader, dies at 96
SUMMARY: Le Pen was convicted numerous times of antisemitism, discrimination and inciting racial violence. But the nativist ideas that propelled his popularity remain ascendant in today's France and beyond.

TITLE: The U.S. says Sudan's rebel forces have committed genocide
SUMMARY: The Biden administration said the Sudanese Rapid Support Forces group and its proxies are committing genocide in a civil war with the country's military that has killed tens of thousands of people.

TITLE: A Dutch project publicizes the names of half a million suspected Nazi collaborators
SUMMARY: The names of some 425,000 suspected Dutch collaborators went online 80 years after the Holocaust ended, making them accessible to historians and descendants as the country grapples with its past.

TITLE: 2 bodies found in JetBlue plane's landing gear compartment at a Florida airport
SUMMARY: The bodies were located in the wheel well area at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. It's the second time over the past month that a body has been found in the wheel well of an airplane.

TITLE: New rules will ban medical debt from your credit report
SUMMARY: The move, which comes less than two weeks before President-elect Donald Trump is set to take office, represents a challenge to the new administration.

TITLE: Trump in news conference says 'all hell will break out' if Gaza hostages not released
SUMMARY: The president-elect made a similar pledge on social media in early December. His latest comments came during a wide-ranging news conference from Mar-a-Lago.

TITLE: Meta says it will end fact checking as Silicon Valley prepares for Trump
SUMMARY: CEO Mark Zuckerberg called the company's previous content moderation policies "censorship," repeating talking points from President-elect Donald Trump and his allies.

TITLE: NASA hedges its bets on costly Mars rock mission
SUMMARY: NASA has announced it is moving forward with several plans to return rock samples from Mars.

TITLE: A list of half a million names shines new light on Dutch collaboration with Nazis
SUMMARY: The names of some 425,000 suspected Dutch collaborators went online 80 years after the Holocaust ended, making them accessible to historians and descendants as the country grapples with its past.

TITLE: Florida judge blocks release of special counsel report on Trump cases
SUMMARY: Florida federal judge Aileen Cannon ordered the Justice Department not to share Jack Smith's final report until a federal appeals court resolves the legal fight.

TITLE: Man who exploded Cybertruck in Las Vegas used ChatGPT in planning, police say
SUMMARY: The highly decorated soldier who exploded a Tesla Cybertruck outside the Trump hotel in Las Vegas used generative AI including ChatGPT to help plan the attack, Las Vegas police said Tuesday.

TITLE: Wild weather brings snow to the South and Santa Ana winds to the West
SUMMARY: As the South prepped for snow and more cold starting Wednesday, residents in Southern California faced off with hurricane-strength winds.

TITLE: What to know about Trump and his keen interest in Greenland
SUMMARY: President-elect Donald Trump has said multiple times that the U.S. should buy Greenland, an autonomous territory of Denmark. The sparsely populated island is geopolitically important and mineral-rich.

TITLE: Life-threatening windstorm triggers wildfire in Southern California
SUMMARY: Southern California hasn't seen significant rainfall since last April, and a pileup of dry fuel in combination with the winds has the region on edge. A mandatory evacuation order was issued for the Palisades.

TITLE: Wild weather spreads across the U.S.
SUMMARY:
In Washington, D.C., the federal government is closed – as are most of the schools in the area. That's because the first major snow storm in about three years barreled in Sunday night.

Meanwhile, the Southern U.S. is preparing for another storm that could paralyze parts of Texas, Arkansas and Northern Louisiana.

And Southern California is preparing for "life threatening, destructive gusts" driving wildfires.

That's a lot of wild weather...so what's going on?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: Photos: Thousands in Los Angeles evacuate as wind-fueled Palisades Fire quickly worsens
SUMMARY: More than 30,000 people in Los Angeles County have been ordered to evacuate as the Palisades Fire blazed through the Pacific Palisades community, fueled by intense Santa Ana winds.

TITLE: Wild weather brings winds and fire to the West, snow to the South
SUMMARY: As the South prepped for snow and more cold starting Wednesday, residents in Southern California faced off with hurricane-strength winds.

TITLE: First international commercial flight since Assad's ouster lands in Syria
SUMMARY: The Qatar Airways flight landed at Damascus International Airport. Many passengers were Syrian nationals coming come for the first time in more than a decade.

TITLE: Los Angeles wildfires trigger evacuations and states of emergency declarations
SUMMARY: The city of Los Angeles declared a state of emergency Tuesday night as strong winds spurred the rapid spread of two wildfires in separate areas of the foothills on the northern edges of the city.

TITLE: Los Angeles wildfires trigger evacuations and state of emergency declarations
SUMMARY: The city of Los Angeles declared a state of emergency Tuesday night as strong winds spurred the rapid spread of two wildfires in separate areas of the foothills on the northern edges of the city.

TITLE: What to know about the wildfires spreading through Southern California
SUMMARY: Three wildfires are currently impacting Los Angeles and Ventura counties, prompting thousands of people to evacuate, schools to close and power lines to be shut off.

TITLE: Bezos' Blue Origin is nearing liftoff on the 1st flight of its newest, biggest rocket
SUMMARY: New Glenn, developed by the private space firm founded by billionaire Jeff Bezos, is on the pad at Cape Canaveral, Fla., and could launch on its maiden flight as early as Friday.

TITLE: Winter illnesses return with a vengeance
SUMMARY: The annual winter respiratory virus season is in full force. The number of people catching the flu is skyrocketing, while COVID-19, RSV and other respiratory viral illnesses are also rising.

TITLE: A looming 'demographic cliff': Fewer college students and ultimately fewer graduates
SUMMARY: The long-predicted downturn in the number of 18-year-olds is almost here. And it isn't just a problem for higher education. It's a looming crisis for the economy.

TITLE: 'Don't be boring!' How to cope with the social pressure to drink during Dry January
SUMMARY: What do you say to people when they ask you why you aren't drinking? How do you get your friends to hang out in places other than bars? We tackle the social conundrums of sober socializing.

TITLE: As winter storms strike, airlines scramble to de-ice planes and keep them flying
SUMMARY: A pair of powerful major winter storms is disrupting the U.S. air travel system this week. That leaves airlines no choice but to de-ice their planes before takeoff to keep them in the air.

TITLE: Survival of the luckiest? New study hints at the potential role of luck in evolution
SUMMARY: A new study on mice shows that luck in early life can determine success as an adult, especially when competition is high.

TITLE: How did surviving cancer shape your life? We want to hear from you
SUMMARY: Living through cancer can change you — it puts pressure on everything, from your relationships to your career to your sense of self. Share how it's affected you and advice you'd give to others.

TITLE: A wage hike for home health care workers in Nevada is proving game-changing
SUMMARY: After Nevada gave home health care workers a huge raise, from about $11 to $16 an hour, turnover in the industry fell sharply. Now, caregivers are preparing to lobby for another wage hike.

TITLE: The latest on the Southern California wildfires. And, Meta is ending fact-checking
SUMMARY: At least three wildfires have burned thousands of acres of land in Southern California. Here's what we know. And, why Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg is ending fact-checking on Facebook and Instagram.

TITLE: After Helene's floods, North Carolina tries to tame trauma's lasting damage
SUMMARY: Mental health professionals warn that the quality and level of mental health care people in western North Carolina receive in the coming months will be critical.

TITLE: Trump asks the Supreme Court to block his sentencing in hush money case
SUMMARY: President-elect Donald Trump is scheduled to be sentenced on Jan. 10 in New York. His latest legal move to block sentencing comes after a New York appeals court rejected a similar appeal Tuesday.

TITLE: The Southern California wildfires through the eyes of the community
SUMMARY: Destructive winds not seen for more than a decade are fanning multiple fires across Los Angeles and Ventura Counties. Tens of thousands of people have been forced to evacuate, schools across the area are closed, and power lines have been shut off in parts of the region to protect against further ignitions.

TITLE: Justice Department wants to release only part of its report on Trump cases
SUMMARY: Prosecutors dropped the two criminal cases against Trump after he won the 2024 election, and the final report by Smith may be the last chance for prosecutors to explain their decisions.

TITLE: Girl Scouts are retiring two cookie flavors (don't worry, your Thin Mints are safe)
SUMMARY: 2025 will be the last time you can buy Girl Scout S'mores and Toast-Yay! cookies. They join the ranks of many other discontinued flavors — RIP Mango Cremes with Nutrifusion and cheesy Golden Yangles.

TITLE: Here's where things stand for several major landmarks in the Los Angeles fires
SUMMARY: The fires raging across Los Angeles are putting some cultural institutions in danger.

TITLE: A record 24 million people now get Obamacare health plans. Will it last under Trump?
SUMMARY: Enrollment in Affordable Care Act health insurance plans has grown every year of the Biden administration, leading to a record high rate of people with insurance.

TITLE: How to get more movement into your screen-filled life. No gym required.
SUMMARY: Research shows that 5-minute walking breaks every half hour offset the harm of too much sitting. But that is easier said than done. These 5 tips can help you maintain movement throughout your day.

TITLE: What are the Santa Ana winds and how are they impacting the L.A. wildfires?
SUMMARY: Although the Santa Anas are a routine part of life for people living in southern California, the winds are particularly violent and destructive this time around, experts say.

TITLE: Is Democracy Holding Up in South Korea?
SUMMARY: Authorities in South Korea are continuing to try to arrest impeached South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol, following his failed declaration of martial law over a month ago. As the country continues to be mired in political crisis, analyst are studying the health of the country's democracy. And as our correspondent in Seoul tells us, they're drawing comparisons to recent events in the U.S.

TITLE: Wildfires displace thousands and ravage greater Los Angeles
SUMMARY:
Extremely dry conditions coupled with high winds have led to an explosive wildfire situation in southern California.

Multiple fires have erupted across the Los Angeles area since Tuesday. Tens of thousands of people have had to evacuate, and firefighters are struggling to contain the flames.

Adria Kloke is one of the of people who has had to flee. She packed up her belongings, along with her cat, and left her home in Pacific Palisades on Tuesday. Kloke shares her story with NPR.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: In D.C.'s bitter cold, a homeless shelter offers hot food and some hope
SUMMARY: NPR visited a homeless shelter in Washington, D.C., to see how residents and staff are faring during a cold emergency. The shelter is busy year-round, though the frigid weather brings in more people.

TITLE: What are the Santa Ana winds and how are they impacting the LA wildfires?
SUMMARY: Although the Santa Anas are a routine part of life for people living in southern California, the winds are particularly violent and destructive this time around, experts say.

TITLE: Fire hydrants ran dry in Pacific Palisades as a major wildfire raged
SUMMARY: Janisse Quiñones, CEO of the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power, said the fight to contain the flames has put immense strain on the system.

TITLE: As winter storms surge across the country, here's how one homeless shelter is coping
SUMMARY: NPR visited a homeless shelter in Washington, D.C., to see how residents and staff are faring during a cold emergency. The shelter is busy year-round, though the frigid weather brings in more people.

TITLE: 'Raining ash': Residents share how they fled the Southern California wildfires
SUMMARY: Tens of thousands of people have been ordered to evacuate amid the uncontained wildfires. NPR member station LAist spoke to members of the community about how they have been affected.

TITLE: The NHL postpones a game and the Lakers coach evacuates his family amid LA fires
SUMMARY: The fires burning across Los Angeles have affected tens of thousands of people, including athletes and staff for the city's sports teams. Pasadena's iconic Rose Bowl was under evacuation warning.

TITLE: Justice Department accuses 6 major landlords of keeping rents high
SUMMARY: The lawsuit arrives as U.S. renters continue to struggle. The latest figures show that half of American renters spent more than 30% of their income on rent and utilities in 2022, an all-time high.

TITLE: Japanese crime leader pleads guilty to conspiring to sell nuclear materials to Iran
SUMMARY: Prosecutors said samples of the alleged nuclear material was weapons-grade, meaning enough of it would be suitable for use in a nuclear weapon.

TITLE: Fluoride analysis triggers renewed debate over what levels are safe for kids
SUMMARY: A new study suggests a link between high levels of fluoride and lowered IQ. It's heating up arguments over fluoridating drinking water, which dentists say is critical for protecting teeth.

TITLE: More fires erupt in Southern California and spread to the Hollywood Hills
SUMMARY: Three new fires broke out in Los Angeles and Ventura counties on Wednesday. California Gov. Gavin Newsom said more than 7,500 personnel are helping in the response to the infernos.

TITLE: Imprisoned Belarus activist resurfaces after being incommunicado for over 700 days
SUMMARY: He was last heard from in February 2023. Since then, authorities haven't released any information about his condition and barred his lawyer from visits.

TITLE: U.S. stock markets close to honor former President Jimmy Carter
SUMMARY: The New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq will both observe Thursday's national day of mourning in a Wall Street tradition dating back to 1865.

TITLE: All 5 living presidents expected to attend Jimmy Carter's National Cathedral funeral
SUMMARY: President Biden is expected to deliver a eulogy to former President Jimmy Carter at the National Cathedral service.

TITLE: What's next for Canada? 5 questions will help decide the future after Trudeau
SUMMARY: "We're in a unique situation in Canadian politics," Shachi Kurl, president of the Angus Reid Institute, tells NPR. Voters need to replace a lame-duck leader — and cope with threats from Trump.

TITLE: Special ed students benefit from being integrated at school. It doesn't always happen
SUMMARY: Research shows including students with and without disabilities in the same classroom can benefit everyone. Two students with Down syndrome show what can be gained when that happens.

TITLE: A major winter storm will bring snow to the South. Here are tips from winter experts
SUMMARY: Southern states don't often deal with winter conditions, but New England does. New Hampshire especially has tips for how to prepare for a winter storm.

TITLE: Here's what's behind Russia cutting off its last gas line to Europe
SUMMARY: A decades-long Russian-Ukrainian transit gas deal to Europe ended on Jan. 1. For now, the most acute effects are being felt in a region called Transnistria, on the eastern edge of Moldova.

TITLE: Looking to have fun without alcohol? This guy has ideas that may help
SUMMARY: If you're looking for inspiration to stick with Dry January, or you're worried about the cancer risk linked to alcohol, you may want to check out booze-free gatherings happening all over the country.

TITLE: Wildfires upend lives in Southern California. And, Jimmy Carter's state funeral
SUMMARY: Wildfires drastically impact life in Southern California, destroying neighborhoods. Here's where things stand. And, what to expect from former President Jimmy Carter's state funeral today.

TITLE: Raging Los Angeles fires sweep into the Hollywood Hills; at least 5 are dead
SUMMARY: The multiplying fires have killed at least five people, forced widespread evacuation orders and burned tens of thousands of acres, destroying homes, businesses and cultural landmarks.

TITLE: Here's what's behind Russia cutting off its last gas line to Europe
SUMMARY: A decades-long Russian-Ukrainian transit gas deal to Europe ended on Jan. 1. For now, the most acute effects are being felt in a region called Transnistria, on the eastern edge of Moldova.

TITLE: Former President Jimmy Carter: The 'Fresh Air' interviews (Part 2)
SUMMARY: The 39th president spoke with Terry Gross in 1995, 2001 and 2005 about poetry, Sept. 11 and his concerns about how intertwined politics and religion had become. Carter died on Dec. 29 at age 100.

TITLE: Mail service is suspended, and trading floors are silent, in honor of Jimmy Carter
SUMMARY: Post offices are closed and mail delivery is suspended Thursday on the national day of mourning for former President Jimmy Carter. The stock market and some national parks are also closed.

TITLE: Billy Crystal, Paris Hilton, other celebrities share LA fire experiences, resources
SUMMARY: The California wildfires are burning in the middle of what's usually a busy awards season in Hollywood, home to many celebrities.

TITLE: At least 5 are dead in multiplying Los Angeles wildfires
SUMMARY: The multiplying fires have killed at least five people, forced widespread evacuation orders and burned tens of thousands of acres, destroying homes, businesses and cultural landmarks.

TITLE: PHOTOS: See the California wildfires' destructive force, in satellite images
SUMMARY: Satellite images show the extent of devastation from multiple wildfires burning in Los Angeles County after one day. The fires have killed at least five people and destroyed thousands of structures.

TITLE: Photos: See the California wildfires' destructive force, in satellite images
SUMMARY: Satellite images show the extent of devastation from multiple wildfires burning in Los Angeles County after one day. The fires have killed at least five people and destroyed thousands of structures.

TITLE: 'Like a bomb was dropped': Authorities warn of extensive damage as LA fires rage
SUMMARY: As firefighters battle five blazes and as hundreds of thousands of residents face evacuation orders, authorities are warning people not to turn to looting. They say 20 have been arrested already.

TITLE: World Health Organization head on bond with Jimmy Carter: 'I consider him my mentor'
SUMMARY: The World Health Organization leader worked with Carter for 20 years to fight the world's "neglected" diseases. After attending Carter's funeral, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus shared memories.

TITLE: 'He saved our lives.' A former US hostage reflects on Carter's legacy
SUMMARY:
Jimmy Carter's four years in the White House were largely defined by an event that took place halfway through his term.

On November 4th, 1979 Iranian college students took over the US Embassy in Tehran, and took 52 Americans hostage.

For the next 444 days, the Carter administration tried to secure the hostages' release. In April, 1980 they even commissioned a rescue mission that ended in failure.

While Carter was trying to end the hostage crisis, he was also campaigning for a second term. A year to the day after the Americans were taken hostage, Ronald Reagan beat Carter in a landslide.

The hostage crisis played a key role in Carter's defeat.

The Iranian Hostage crisis helped doom Jimmy Carter's presidency, but for some of the people he helped free, he was a hero.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: Lebanon chooses a new president after two years without one
SUMMARY: Lebanon's parliament chose the head of the country's armed forces, Joseph Aoun, to be its next president, a post that's been vacant since October 2022.

TITLE: Powerful winds fueling the California wildfires are expected through Friday
SUMMARY: Red flag warnings are in effect for parts of Los Angeles and Ventura counties, as the National Weather Service warns that powerful winds and low humidity will increase the risk of fire.

TITLE: What it is Like to Live and Report in Gaza
SUMMARY:
Israel has prevented international journalists from entering Gaza, which means getting information from the territory is difficult. NPR has relied on producer Anas Baba who lives in and reports from Gaza to be our microphone. In a conversation with NPR's correspondent Israel Daniel Estrin, we hear about the daily challenges Baba faces in Gaza.

For more coverage of all sides of this conflict, go to npr.org/mideastupdates

TITLE: Photos: Los Angeles wildfires threaten lives, homes and cultural landmarks
SUMMARY: The fires have forced mass evacuations. Firefighters are struggling to control a patchwork of deadly blazes that have killed at least five people and leveled entire communities.

TITLE: Trump loses Supreme Court appeal to block hush-money sentencing
SUMMARY: This was the only one of Trump's criminal charges to reach and complete a trial, making him the first former or future U.S. president to be convicted of criminal charges.

TITLE: Winter Storm Cora brings cold and snow to the Southern U.S.
SUMMARY: A major winter storm is expected to be the biggest in years as cold air moves in from the Arctic bringing snow and frigid temperatures across 20 Southern States.

TITLE: 'Pizzagate' gunman killed by police in North Carolina, authorities say
SUMMARY: A man who fired a gun inside a restaurant in the nation's capital after a fake online conspiracy theory motivated him to do so nearly a decade ago was shot and killed by North Carolina police.

TITLE: Alec Baldwin sues New Mexico officials over handling of 'Rust' shooting case
SUMMARY: Actor Alec Baldwin has filed a civil lawsuit for malicious prosecution and civil rights violations in the fatal shooting of a cinematographer on the set of the Western movie <em>Rust

TITLE: Jimmy Carter is no saint in my house
SUMMARY: For President Biden's legacy, we should look to late President Jimmy Carter's history in Central America.

TITLE: 10 people have now died in the wildfires spreading across Southern California
SUMMARY: The number of dead tied to the wildfires increases as local officials warn the toll will increase. About 180,000 people have had to evacuate.

TITLE: Hey, meat eaters. Your gut  health can rival a vegan's. Here's how
SUMMARY: Our guts are home to trillions of microbes that influence our health. A new study finds the key to a healthy microbiome is the variety of plant-based food in your diet, even if you eat meat.

TITLE: After 17 years, it's Hoda Kotb's last 'Today' show
SUMMARY: Craig Melvin, current news anchor and host of <em>Today's 3rd Hour,

TITLE: How these suburban moms in Ukraine manage grief by training to down Russian drones
SUMMARY: Women from a Kyiv suburb traumatized by a 2022 massacre by Russian troops joined a volunteer air defense unit to take down Russia's drones — and deal with their fears.

TITLE: TikTok is heading to the Supreme Court to challenge its U.S. ban. Here's what to know
SUMMARY: Lawyers for TikTok will argue that banning the app will violate the free speech of 170 million American users. The Justice Department will contend that the app is a national security risk.

TITLE: Trump set for sentencing in his New York felony conviction
SUMMARY: Trump on Thursday exhausted his last legal maneuver to stop the sentencing, after a narrow majority of Supreme Court justices declined to intervene.

TITLE: Q&A: CIA Chief on how the U.S. intel community handled Russia, China and Mideast
SUMMARY: In an exit interview with NPR's Mary Louise Kelly, CIA Director William Burns says he still thinks "there's a chance" for a ceasefire in the Israel-Hamas war.

TITLE: Her family thought they would return home the next day. Now, their house is gone
SUMMARY: Jinghuan Liu Tervalon packed a few documents, keepsakes and clothing before leaving her Altadena, Calif., home ahead of the fast-moving Eaton Canyon Fire. Her son returned to find rubble and ash.

TITLE: Who's in, who's out and who wants to rename the Gulf of Mexico? The quiz is back!
SUMMARY: This week, we tackle the Golden Globes, free speech, Girl Scout cookies, dragons and more. Add a perfect score to your New Year's resolutions!

TITLE: 10 people have died in the wildfires spreading across Southern California
SUMMARY: The number of dead tied to the wildfires increases as local officials warn the toll will increase. About 180,000 people have had to evacuate.

TITLE: Wildfire victims report looting. And, Trump set for sentencing in hush money case
SUMMARY: Southern California wildfire victims report looting after returning home to assess damages. And, President-elect Donald Trump is set for sentencing in a hush money conviction today.

TITLE: Inmates are fighting California wildfires in long-running and controversial practice
SUMMARY: California has turned to incarcerated firefighters since 1915. To those opposed to the use of inmates as firefighters, the system is seen as exploitative.

TITLE: Her family thought they would return home the next day. Now, their house is gone
SUMMARY: Jinghuan Liu Tervalon packed a few documents, keepsakes and clothing before leaving her Altadena, Calif., home ahead of the fast-moving Eaton Canyon Fire. Her son returned to find rubble and ash.

TITLE: What is the flame retardant that planes are dropping on the LA fires?
SUMMARY: As fire crews and air tankers work to block the wildfires' explosive growth, images of red clouds of fire retardant falling onto trees are common. What is it — and what's in it?

TITLE: 2024 was the hottest year on record. The reason remains a science mystery
SUMMARY: The official numbers are in: 2024 is the hottest year on record. Climate change is the main culprit. But there might be something else going on, too.

TITLE: There is one major gift Trump is inheriting from Biden: A good job market
SUMMARY: U.S. employers added more than a quarter-million jobs in December, according to the Labor Department. That's far more than forecasters were expecting.

TITLE: Firefighters battling LA fires make some progress, but harsh winds threaten gains
SUMMARY: Despite some progress, the biggest blazes — the Palisades and Eaton fires — rage uncontrolled as anxious residents receive alerts sent in error and face massive damages.

TITLE: Cancelled flights, stranded cars, no power: Winter storm slams swath of U.S.
SUMMARY: Atlanta has seen nearly 1,000 flights grounded, while more than 34,000 Arkansans have lost power.

TITLE: New photos show the volcanic plains of Mercury after a spacecraft fly-by
SUMMARY: The BepiColombo spacecraft flew less than 200 miles from Mercury's surface and photographed volcanic plains and icy craters.

TITLE: Venezuela's Maduro begins new term as US increases bounty for his arrest
SUMMARY: The US announces a $25 million reward for the arrest or conviction of Venezuelas President Nicolás Maduro, on same day he's sworn in for a third consecutive term.

TITLE: Is smoke in your home? Here's how to make an air purifier from a box fan
SUMMARY: A large area of greater Los Angeles had unhealthy air Friday, due to particulate matter from large wildfires. Here are tips for breathing cleaner air indoors if it's smoky outside.

TITLE: Canceled flights, stranded cars, no power: Winter storm slams swath of U.S.
SUMMARY: Atlanta has seen nearly 1,000 flights grounded, while more than 34,000 Arkansans have lost power.

TITLE: More than half a million students were out of school because of LA fires this week
SUMMARY: School districts in and around Los Angeles shut down because of the fires. That includes LAUSD, the second largest school district in the country.

TITLE: A small seafood restaurant turns into a national donation hub for LA fire victims
SUMMARY: In response to the devastating fires raging in LA, a small restaurant in Surf City USA has become a channel for big help — from locals to people across the country — to support their neighbors up north.

TITLE: Venezuela's Maduro begins new term as US raises arrest bounty
SUMMARY: The US announces an increased $25 million reward for information leading to the arrest of Venezuelas President Maduro on day he's sworn in for a third term.

TITLE: Biden extends protections for immigrants from Venezuela, El Salvador and Ukraine
SUMMARY: Close to a millions migrants will be shielded from deportation for up to 18 months.

TITLE: U.S. ambassador to Israel makes his final push for release of U.S. hostages from Gaza
SUMMARY: "We are going to do everything we can in this round to get all the American hostages, living and dead, out," Ambassador Jacob J. Lew tells NPR. His tenure as President Biden's envoy ends this month.

TITLE: Fox News headed for trial, again, over 2020 election fraud claims
SUMMARY: The defamation case brought by voting technology company Smartmatic against Fox News can proceed, a New York state appellate court rules.

TITLE: Is Trump's rhetoric on Greenland, Canada and Panama Canal a 'Madman Strategy'?
SUMMARY: The president-elect's undiplomatic talk in recent days of reclaiming the Panama Canal — and annexing Greenland and even Canada — have some experts comparing his strategy to Nixon's "Madman Theory."

TITLE: A look at how one family keeps traditions alive at a rodeo extravaganza in Colorado
SUMMARY: The 30th anniversary of the Mexican Rodeo Extravaganza at the National Western Stock Show is a celebration of pageantry and cultural heritage.

TITLE: Sam Moore, who sang 'Soul Man' in Sam & Dave duo, dies at 89
SUMMARY: Moore, the surviving half and higher voice of the 1960s duo Sam & Dave, died Friday morning in Coral Gables, Florida, due to complications while recovering from surgery, his publicist said.

TITLE: Why right-wing influencers are blaming the California wildfires on diversity efforts
SUMMARY: Prominent right-wing influencers are claiming that the response to the Los Angeles wildfires was hampered by workplace diversity policies. It's part of a wider strategy to discredit those policies.

TITLE: Amid the fires, LA is warning some residents the tap water isn't safe. Here's why
SUMMARY: Wildfires have a history of causing problems with the drinking water systems. In some affected areas around LA, officials are warning residents not to drink from the tap or even to shower.

TITLE: When  the power goes out, health risks rise
SUMMARY: From California to the South, tens of thousands of people are without power, due to fires and winter storms. Studies show health risks rise when the power goes out. Here's how to protect yourself.

TITLE: Bomb threats shadowed international reporters who covered Chinese celebrity dissident
SUMMARY: Reporters covering a Chinese dissident in Europe were targeted with bomb threats. An NPR investigation later found evidence the dissident was linked to con which included the specter of bomb threats.

TITLE: Opinion: When Jimmy Carter and I spoke about UFOs
SUMMARY: NPR's Scott Simon recalls a conversation he once had with the late President Jimmy Carter about the possibility of UFOs.

TITLE: 'He brought us back alive': A former hostage remembers Jimmy Carter
SUMMARY: Former diplomat Barry Rosen was a hostage during the Iran crisis. In an interview with <em>All Things Considered,

TITLE: An army of community volunteers springs into action as LA fires rage
SUMMARY: "It's wild. There's people out here that have just created a chain," said one woman who showed up to volunteer at a YMCA in Los Angeles' Koreatown neighborhood.

TITLE: Why are so many indigenous Panamanians contracting HIV — and dying of AIDS?
SUMMARY: The government provides HIV medicines free of charge. Yet in one indigenous territory, cases and deaths are increasing at an alarming rate.

TITLE: In a bitter fight for the Minnesota Legislature, Democrats have threatened a walkout
SUMMARY: A series of unexpected events after the narrow election has set up a power struggle in the Minnesota Legislature. Days before the legislative session kicks off, it's unclear who will take control.

TITLE: Photos: Southern California residents return to devastation as two major wildfires rage on
SUMMARY: More than 100,000 Los Angeles County residents remain under evacuation orders, and the threat of fire there is not over. New evacuations were ordered last night and strong Santa Ana winds are expected to pick up again today.

TITLE: As fires in Los Angeles rage, an already-hurting Hollywood presses pause
SUMMARY: The fires around Los Angeles arrived just as Hollywood's awards season kicked off. It's an ominous sign at a time when film and TV production is already down.

TITLE: A winter storm wraps up in the South, with travel delays and power outages persisting
SUMMARY: The significant winter storm had passed in the South by Saturday morning, but travel issues and power outages were still ongoing.

TITLE: Firefighters make progress on LA blazes, and alert system is changed
SUMMARY: Firefighters made progress overnight on almost all of the active fires, including the massive Palisades and Eaton blazes, officials said.

TITLE: Biden awards Pope Francis the Presidential Medal of Freedom with distinction
SUMMARY: The White House commended Pope Francis for his commitment to serving the poor, as well as advocating for peace and protecting the planet.

TITLE: USDA report finds Boar's Head listeria outbreak was due to poor sanitation practices
SUMMARY: A report released by the Department of Agriculture found that poor sanitation practices at a Boar's Head facility in Virginia contributed to the largest listeria outbreak since 2011.

TITLE: Strong winds pick up, increasing fire danger as firefighters battle LA blazes
SUMMARY: Large parts of Southern California are once again under wildfire risks as strong winds and dry conditions return this weekend through Wednesday.

TITLE: Jack Smith has resigned from the justice department, after submitting his Trump report
SUMMARY: Special counsel Jack Smith has resigned from the Justice Department after submitting his report on President-elect Donald Trump, amid legal wrangling over how much of the document can be made public.

TITLE: How one U.S. conservationist's work is helping to preserve Chile's wilderness
SUMMARY: Chile is set to gain its 47th national park early this year — largely due to the efforts of U.S. conservationist Kristine Tompkins and her organization.

TITLE: People are rushing to install solar panels before Trump becomes President
SUMMARY: Potential rooftop solar customers and installers worry the incoming Trump administration might try to eliminate a 30% federal tax credit. Some customers plan to install sooner because of that and solar companies are changing their business plans.

TITLE: Exit interview: DOT Sec. Buttigieg on infrastructure act and the road ahead
SUMMARY: In an exit interview with <em>All Things Considered,

TITLE: Kate Bowler wants to have more 'uncounted, completely-wasted, doesn't-matter time'
SUMMARY: On Wild Card this week, Kate Bowler opens up about how she wants to waste her time, her feelings about God and how she talks about death with her child.

TITLE: Kangaroo species went extinct in the Pleistocene. Research hops in with a possible explanation.
SUMMARY: In a mass extinction event some 40,000 years ago, Australia lost 90% of its large species, including nearly two dozen kinds of kangaroos. Two theories suggest why.

TITLE: 7 global buzzwords for 2025: From 'techquity' to 'climate displacement' to 'belonging'
SUMMARY: What words will be buzzing about in the global health and development hive in the year ahead? Our experts have nominations for your consideration.

TITLE: Southern California wildfires destroy or damage many houses of worship
SUMMARY: Faith communities in Los Angeles are trying to protect their homes and houses of worship from deadly wildfires. They are also trying to provide spiritual support for their traumatized congregations.

TITLE: L.A. is bracing for the return of more powerful winds as fires continue to burn
SUMMARY: As firefighters continue to battle blazes in multiple fires, more Santa Ana winds in the coming days threaten to increase fire risk.

TITLE: Why Los Angeles, America's most fire-ready city, became overwhelmed by flames
SUMMARY: In a city prone to large natural disasters, L.A. firefighters are widely considered to be among the best in the business at knocking down urban wildfires. But in the extreme conditions lately, experts say little can be done even to slow these modern fires.

TITLE: California governor says fires could prove the costliest disaster in U.S. history
SUMMARY: Gov. Gavin Newsom told NBC's "Meet The Press" he believes the fires will be the nation's worst natural disaster "in terms of just the costs associated with it, in terms of the scale and scope."

TITLE: On the way out: Transportation Sec. Buttigieg looks back on achievements, challenges
SUMMARY:
From handling crises in the rail and airline industries to overseeing the distribution of billions of dollars in infrastructure funding, Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg has taken on a lot over the last four years.

Now, his tenure is coming to an end.

Host Scott Detrow speaks with Buttigieg about what the Biden administration accomplished, what it didn't get done, and what he's taking away from an election where voters resoundingly called for something different.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: FEMA's administrator says more than 24,000 in LA have applied for assistance
SUMMARY: "People have lost everything," says FEMA administrator Deanne Criswell. More than 24,000 have already applied for assistance from FEMA, but Criswell says that number is certain to rise.

TITLE: Italy releases Iranian man wanted by U.S. over drone attack that killed 3 soldiers
SUMMARY: The release of Mohammad Abedini follows Iran's recent freeing of Italian journalist Cecilia Sala, sparking speculation that Sala may have been a bargaining chip.

TITLE: LA fire officials warn of a new round of wildfire danger with strong winds forecast
SUMMARY: LA County's fire chief said people in evacuated areas won't be able to return home until at least Thursday due to the next round of fire danger. Meanwhile, authorities are investigating more deaths.

TITLE: India kicks off a Hindu festival touted as the world's largest religious gathering
SUMMARY: Over the coming weeks, Hindu pilgrims with gather at the confluence of three rivers where they will begin a journey to reach Hindu philosophy's ultimate goal: the release from the cycle of rebirth.

TITLE: China's exports in December up 10.7%, beating estimates as higher U.S. tariffs loom
SUMMARY: China has raced to fill orders ahead of President-elect Donald Trump's promised tariffs on Chinese goods. Exports have surged in the country since the pandemic.

TITLE: See some of the most terrifying and dramatic pictures of California wildfire devastation
SUMMARY: These photos chronicle the catastrophic scale of destruction from wildfires in California that started on January 7.

TITLE: Weird weather isn't always because of climate change — but sometimes it is
SUMMARY: Sometimes, weather is just weather. And other times human-caused climate change had an obvious impact.

TITLE: The first full moon of 2025 is here
SUMMARY: This moon phase is nicknamed the Wolf Moon, which is rooted in Native American culture.

TITLE: Despite Trump's win, 'election integrity' activists still seek sweeping voting changes
SUMMARY: Republican voters say they trust the 2024 election was administered well, yet pro-Trump conservatives are pushing some sweeping reforms to voting systems.

TITLE: Our 25 most-anticipated games of 2025 including Grand Theft Auto 6 (maybe)
SUMMARY: Will GTA6 actually come out this year? Is a new Nintendo console coming? Huge games are creeping on the horizon, including a high-stakes Assassin's Creed title and Metroid Prime 4: Beyond.

TITLE: Is one drink a day OK? Here's what to consider
SUMMARY: On the heels of the Surgeon General's warning about the cancer risks of alcohol, there's growing consensus that less is better. But how much is enough? Here's what the experts recommend.

TITLE: Winds threaten the containment of wildfires. And, DHS chief reflects on his career
SUMMARY: Santa Ana winds are expected to pick back up, threatening the containment of Southern California wildfires. And, Homeland Security Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas reflects on his career.

TITLE: Israel and Hamas make progress in their ceasefire and hostage release talks
SUMMARY: Three officials said the next days would be critical for ending more than a year of fighting that has shaken the Middle East, but talks have stalled near the finish line repeatedly in the past year.

TITLE: As dangerous winds are expected to pick up, Los Angeles braces for new fires
SUMMARY: Damaging winds gusting between 55 and 70 mph are forecast, increasing fire risks across LA and Ventura counties over the next few days. More than 150,000 people are already under evacuation orders.

TITLE: Despite strict laws, Texas is awash in intoxicating cannabis
SUMMARY: Recreational marijuana is still illegal

TITLE: What to know about the Israel and Hamas Gaza ceasefire and hostage release talks
SUMMARY: The basic framework, officials familiar with the talks say, is an exchange of Israeli hostages for Palestinian prisoners, and a six-week ceasefire. Mediators are applying pressure on all parties.

TITLE: Judge Cannon paves the way for potential release of Part 1 of special counsel's report
SUMMARY: Cannon denied a motion by President-elect Donald Trump's former co-defendants who sought to block the release of special counsel Jack Smith's report on the election interference case.

TITLE: As recovery efforts in LA move forward, powerful new winds threaten progress
SUMMARY: Damaging winds gusting between 55 and 70 mph are creating "critical" fire risks across LA and Ventura counties through Wednesday, officials say. Evacuation orders are expected to rise again.

TITLE: Party City is closing. Share your special memory with NPR
SUMMARY: What would you say in a eulogy for Party City? Have you shopped at Party City for memorable costumes, decorations, party favors or classroom awards? NPR wants to hear.

TITLE: A Texas man is arrested in Indianapolis on a charge of stalking WNBA's Caitlin Clark
SUMMARY: The 55-year-old man sent the basketball star threatening and sexually explicit messages on social media, then traveled from Texas to Indianapolis to try to encounter her in person, prosecutors say.

TITLE: Biden puts AI and climate at the top of the list for Trump administration
SUMMARY: President Biden, 82, has focused on U.S. foreign policy for decades. As he leaves office, he said his team's work on artificial intelligence and climate was key for his successor to follow through on.

TITLE: The Power Struggle Among Palestinian Groups in the West Bank
SUMMARY:
There is a fight for power happening among Palestinian groups in the Israeli-occupied West Bank. The Palestinian Authority, which governs parts of the West Bank, has spent weeks weeks besieging the Jenin refugee camp. The tussle is also a fight over different visions for the Palestinian people.

For more coverage of all sides of this conflict, go to npr.org/mideastupdates

TITLE: A TikTok ban could hit the U.S. in days. What to know — and how to prepare
SUMMARY: Even if the controversial U.S. ban on TikTok does take effect on Jan. 19, the app won't automatically vanish from phones. Here's what would change, plus preparations and potential workarounds.

TITLE: California's wildfires may also be catastrophic for its insurance market
SUMMARY: California's insurance industry was already in crisis. Now the wildfires in the Los Angeles region may upend efforts to stabilize the market.

TITLE: Leslie Charleson, who starred on 'General Hospital' for nearly 50 years, dies at 79
SUMMARY: Colleagues are remembering the soap opera star for her "quick wit" and presence on set. She died after a long illness.

TITLE: What happens when wildland fire reaches the city?
SUMMARY:
"Wildfire" is the word we tend to use when we talk about what Los Angeles has been dealing with the past week.
But Lori Moore-Merrell, the U.S. Fire Administrator for the Federal Emergency Management Agency used a different word, when she spoke to NPR this morning.

She described a "conflagration." Saying they're not wildland fires with trees burning. They're structure to structure fire spread.

They may have started at the suburban fringe, but they didn't stay there. Which prompts a question: what happens when fire meets city?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: Fires in Los Angeles delay Oscar nominations once more
SUMMARY: Oscar nominations had already been delayed once due to the fires raging in Los Angeles. The ceremony itself remains scheduled for early March.

TITLE: Family remembers Victor Shaw, killed in the Eaton fire, for his bond with his sister
SUMMARY: Family members said Victor Shaw, 66, was shy and reserved in nature, but had a deep love for sports and a tight-knit bond with his younger sister.

TITLE: Special counsel in Hunter Biden case denounces president for criticism of the probe
SUMMARY: In a final report on his investigation, special counsel David Weiss said President Biden's criticism "undermines the very foundation of what makes America's justice system fair and equitable."

TITLE: A pitmaster and dedicated father died alongside his son waiting for help in LA fire
SUMMARY: Anthony Mitchell Sr. and his son Justin were waiting for help to evacuate on the day they died in the Eaton fire, family members said. Anthony Sr. was remembered for his devotion to his children.

TITLE: How soda is changing the world
SUMMARY: A new study establishes that soda consumption is doing ever more damage to health — with rising rates of diabetes in regions where soda-drinking is on the rise, like sub-Saharan Africa.

TITLE: Lawsuits allege power company involvement in LA wildfires
SUMMARY: Lawsuits allege the Eaton Fire was sparked by a SoCal Edison transmission tower. The company says they have not had a chance to inspect the scene yet. The ATF has only just begun the federal investigation into the fire's cause.

TITLE: Jack Smith's election interference report against Trump is out
SUMMARY: The report on federal charges against Trump for election interference in 2020 offers special counsel Jack Smith a last chance to explain his decisions after dropping the case.

TITLE: Special counsel Jack Smith stands behind Trump election case he dropped
SUMMARY: The report on federal charges against Trump for election interference in 2020 offers special counsel Jack Smith a last chance to explain his decisions after dropping the case.

TITLE: A tortoise survival tale: How Tiptoe escaped Southern California's wildfires
SUMMARY: For years, Tiptoe has been a beloved sight in Pacific Palisades, quietly tromping along sidewalks and growing a major social media following. But last week, he lost his home to wildfires.

TITLE: A new fire breaks out in Southern California as high winds threaten progress
SUMMARY: The Auto Fire adds to a string of deadly fires that authorities are still working to contain in Southern California.

TITLE: Trump's pick for secretary of defense is Pete Hegseth. Here's what to know
SUMMARY: Pete Hegseth, President-elect Donald Trump's pick to run the Department of Defense, will answer questions Tuesday in a public hearing before the Senate Armed Services Committee.

TITLE: 'The New York Times' takes OpenAI to court. ChatGPT's future could be on the line
SUMMARY: In three consolidated suits, publishers allege that OpenAI broke copyright law by copying millions of articles without permission or payment. OpenAI counters that the fair use doctrine protects them.

TITLE: How climate change is reshaping home insurance in California — and the rest of the U.S.
SUMMARY: Worsening wildfires are hiking up home insurance rates in California, the biggest market in the U.S. And as climate disasters increase across the country, other states are feeling the pressure too.

TITLE: RFK Jr. faces a complicated confirmation with some opposition on both sides of the aisle
SUMMARY: Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s views on vaccines and abortion rights are raising alarms across the political spectrum, as he's one of the more controversial picks for the president-elect's Cabinet.

TITLE: NPR shopped for 96 items at Walmart to track how prices are really changing
SUMMARY: NPR has tracked the prices of dozens of items at the same superstore in Georgia, including eggs, T-shirts, snacks and paper towels. Here's what got cheaper over the past year, and more expensive.

TITLE: This skateboarding economist suggests we need more skateparks and less capitalism
SUMMARY: A skateboarder presented an unusual paper at this year's big meeting of American economists.

TITLE: Special counsel Jack Smith says evidence against Trump was enough to convict him
SUMMARY: The report on federal charges against Trump for election interference in 2020 offers special counsel Jack Smith a last chance to explain his decisions after dropping the case.

TITLE: Special counsel defends Trump indictment in report. And, Israel-Hamas ceasefire nears
SUMMARY: Special counsel Jack Smith says evidence against President-elect Donald Trump was enough to convict him. And, an Israeli official says an Israel-Hamas ceasefire agreement is nearing.

TITLE: Voices from the new breadlines in Syria: Who's waiting? And why?
SUMMARY: Syria's new rulers faces one of their first serious challenges: bread lines. For Syrians, the long wait is a struggle — but for some, bread is a business opportunity.

TITLE: Two Marines spent years firing heavy weapons. Then came headaches and hemorrhage.
SUMMARY: Two Marines suspect that years of firing powerful weapons caused them to develop the same rare, and potentially fatal, brain condition.

TITLE: Israel and Hamas are close to reaching a cease-fire agreement
SUMMARY: Negotiators in Qatar are close to a ceasefire deal that envisions an exchange of Israeli hostages for Palestinian detainees, a six-week pause in fighting and eventual withdrawal of troops from Gaza in the final phase.

TITLE: As high winds bear down on LA, forecasters call fire danger 'about as bad as it gets'
SUMMARY: A large swath of southwest California is under a red flag warning, with winds expected to peak Tuesday and Wednesday. Authorities warn they could fuel the four existing fires as well as new ones.

TITLE: Israel and Hamas may be on the verge of a ceasefire. Here's what we know right now
SUMMARY: Negotiators in Qatar are close to a ceasefire deal that sees an exchange of Israeli hostages for Palestinian detainees, a six-week pause in fighting and eventual troop withdrawal from Gaza.

TITLE: How climate change is reshaping home insurance in California — and the rest of the U.S.
SUMMARY: Worsening wildfires are hiking up home insurance rates in California, the biggest market in the U.S. And as climate disasters increase across the country, other states are feeling the pressure too.

TITLE: NPR shopped for 96 items at Walmart to track how prices are really changing
SUMMARY: NPR has tracked the prices of dozens of items at the same superstore in Georgia, including eggs, T-shirts, snacks and paper towels. Here's what got cheaper over the past year, and more expensive.

TITLE: Watch live: Confirmation hearing for Pete Hegseth, Trump's secretary of defense pick
SUMMARY: Pete Hegseth, President-elect Donald Trump's pick to run the Department of Defense, will answer questions Tuesday in a public hearing before the Senate Armed Services Committee.

TITLE: Trump's 2nd-term foreign policy includes power plays in Greenland, Panama and beyond
SUMMARY: N.Y. Times journalist David Sanger says Trump's idea of America first is now less isolationism, more expansionism. He expects changes in the approach to Russia, China and the wars in Gaza and Ukraine.

TITLE: Drugmakers hiked prices for hundreds of drugs in early January
SUMMARY: January is a big time for drugmakers to hike prices. This year saw higher prices for 575 medications so far, including Ozempic, drugs for HIV, cancer and many others.

TITLE: Five things we learn about Pope Francis from his new memoir
SUMMARY: In Pope Francis' autobiography <em>Hope

TITLE: What is a 'Particularly Dangerous Situation' red flag warning and other wildfire terms
SUMMARY: Here's a guide to understanding "particularly dangerous situation" red flag warnings, containment, and other terms related to the devastating fires that have left much of the LA area in ruins.

TITLE: The Princess of Wales says her cancer is in remission
SUMMARY: The Princess of Wales revealed that her cancer is in remission after an emotional visit to the hospital where she received treatment last year.

TITLE: James Webb Space Telescope's 'little red dots' come into focus
SUMMARY: A cosmic object spotted by the James Webb Space Telescope has flummoxed astronomers. Now, a research team has studied hundreds of these "little red dots" and found clues about their identity.

TITLE: Two passenger jets came dangerously to each other in the skies over Phoenix
SUMMARY: The Federal Aviation Administration is once again looking into a close call at a major U.S. airport, after two passenger jets narrowly avoided a mid-air collision as they attempted to land in Phoenix.

TITLE: What's a 'Particularly Dangerous Situation' red flag warning and other wildfire terms
SUMMARY: Here's a guide to understanding "particularly dangerous situation" red flag warnings, containment, and other terms related to the devastating fires that have left much of the LA area in ruins.

TITLE: 2 passenger jets came dangerously close to each other in the skies over Phoenix
SUMMARY: The Federal Aviation Administration is once again looking into a close call at a major U.S. airport, after two passenger jets narrowly avoided a mid-air collision as they attempted to land in Phoenix.

TITLE: Keeping America Safe: CIA Director Burns reflects
SUMMARY:
On a shelf in his office at CIA headquarters, Director Bill Burns keeps a tiny scaled model of a house. It's the house in Kabul, Afghanistan, where Al Qaida leader Ayman al-Zawahiri was killed by a U.S. drone strike in 2022.

When NPR went out to interview him last week, Burns pointed to the exact balcony on which Zawahiri was standing. There was pride in his voice. The CIA had never stopped looking for the guy even more than two decades after 9/11.

But it was also a reminder of challenges, of adversaries that will outlast any single CIA director.

Now, as Burns wraps up four years running the Central Intelligence Agency, the challenges have multiplied and intensified.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: Why some doctors have started asking patients about their spiritual lives
SUMMARY: Indiana University's hospital system is pairing patients with local faith groups to ease feelings of loneliness and isolation. The unique new program comes as more doctors are seeing a need to care for patients' spiritual as well as physical health.

TITLE: The FDA calls for at-a-glance nutrition labels on the front of packaged foods
SUMMARY: The FDA wants front-of-package nutrition labels required on packaged foods. The labels would tell consumers if the product has Low, Medium or High levels of saturated fat, sodium and added sugar.

TITLE: How the War is Straining Ukraine's Military and Shaping its Children
SUMMARY: The city of Kherson in southern Ukraine is a key objective for Russia. Its military shells the city's neighborhoods daily and sends drones buzzing over the streets. We go out with a Ukrainian military unit that seeks to disrupt the Russians under the cover of darkness. And we also take a look at how three years of war have shaped Ukraine's children.

TITLE: No such thing as a free toilet: Starbucks reverses open bathroom policy
SUMMARY: The new guideline is a reversal of a 2018 open-door policy that was implemented after two Black men, who had not ordered anything, were arrested at a Philadelphia store.

TITLE: SEC sues Elon Musk, says he didn't disclose Twitter ownership on time before purchase
SUMMARY: The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission says Musk failed to disclose his ownership of Twitter stock in a timely manner before buying the site and underpaid by $150 million for shares he bought.

TITLE: South Korean law enforcement officers detain impeached President Yoon
SUMMARY: Yoon was brought into custody about three hours after hundreds of law enforcement officers entered the residential compound in their second attempt to detain him over his imposition of martial law last month.

TITLE: Dozens of survivors and dead pulled from abandoned South African mine
SUMMARY: The mine has been the scene of a tense standoff between police and miners since authorities launched an operation to force the miners out by cutting off food and water from the surface.

TITLE: 2 private lunar landers head toward the moon in a roundabout journey
SUMMARY: In a two-for-one moonshot, SpaceX launched a pair of lunar landers Wednesday for U.S. and Japanese companies looking to jumpstart business on Earth's dusty sidekick.

TITLE: Biden moves to lift state sponsor of terrorism designation for Cuba
SUMMARY: President Biden notified Congress of his intent to lift the U.S. label of Cuba as a state sponsor of terrorism as part of a deal aided by the Catholic Church to free political prisoners on the island.

TITLE: South Korean President Yoon detained after standoff over martial law decree
SUMMARY: Yoon and his ruling party supporters remain defiant against the insurrection charges. He is South Korea's first sitting president to be detained.

TITLE: Pistachio moguls and reservoirs: False water claims spread about California fires
SUMMARY: Influencers and politicians are spreading false narratives about water and the L.A. wildfires. These include the idea that farm moguls took firefighting water and an empty reservoir is part of a plot.

TITLE: U.S. watchdog sues Capital One, alleging bank cheated customers out of $2 billion
SUMMARY: The CFPB claims Capital One intentionally kept news of its higher-yield savings accounts from members with lower-yield savings accounts.

TITLE: Move aside BMI: There's a better way to define obesity, commission finds
SUMMARY: An international committee of scientists has proposed changing the way obesity is defined and diagnosed. The proposal adds more ways to measure body composition and fat.

TITLE: Trump will begin his presidency in delicate position, poll finds
SUMMARY: A new NPR/PBS News/Marist poll shows that Americans' support for President-elect Donald Trump's top priorities is split, despite his claims of a mandate for his agenda.

TITLE: Supreme Court to hear arguments on Texas porn law
SUMMARY: At issue is a Texas law that mandates pornography websites verify the ages of their users before they gain access to the material.

TITLE: Departing DHS Secretary Mayorkas contends he delivered border security in the end
SUMMARY: As DHS Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas prepares to leave office, NPR sits down for an exit interview. He tells us the border is more secure now than before the pandemic.

TITLE: These workers are aiding labor investigations. Will Trump let them stay in the U.S.?
SUMMARY: Under Biden, thousands of workers who experienced wage theft and other abuses have been granted protection from deportation and authorization to work so they can participate in labor investigations.

TITLE: Photos: Southern California pets receive aid from rescue groups
SUMMARY: A network of rescue groups are caring for animals affected by wildfires still burning in the Los Angeles area.  A multi-state operation is under way to help relieve local animal shelters.

TITLE: Trump's Cabinet pick for attorney general is Pam Bondi. Here's what to know
SUMMARY: Bondi is expected to receive broad support from Republicans but face sharp questions from Democrats who have concerns about whether she will protect the Justice Department from political influence.

TITLE: Lower nicotine requirements in cigarettes could be coming soon
SUMMARY: The FDA is expected to propose a new rule Wednesday that would mean cigarettes have lower nicotine limits to make them less addictive.

TITLE: Safety advocates fear Tesla will face less accountability for car crashes under Trump
SUMMARY: With Tesla CEO Elon Musk backing President-elect Donald Trump, safety advocates fear the incoming administration is poised to scrap a federal crash reporting requirement that Tesla calls unfair.

TITLE: First Black woman to serve in the U.S. Army Nurse Corps after desegregation dies
SUMMARY: Nancy Leftenant-Colon, who became the first Black nurse in the U.S. Army Air Corps after President Harry S. Truman desegregated it in 1948, has died at age 104.

TITLE: Trump cabinet nominees face hearings. And, coping with Dry January's social pressure
SUMMARY: Six of President-elect Donald Trump's cabinet nominees face confirmation hearings today. Here's whom to watch. And, how to cope with social pressure during Dry January.

TITLE: On Apache lands, progress in a long war against ticks and the disease they spread
SUMMARY: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever, the deadliest tick-borne disease in the U.S., is a big problem on tribal lands in the Southwest. A community-led response on Apache lands in Arizona is helping save lives.

TITLE: Trump's Cabinet pick for secretary of state is Marco Rubio. Here's what to know
SUMMARY: Among President-elect Donald Trump's Cabinet picks, secretary of state nominee Marco Rubio may face the easiest confirmation process.

TITLE: The secret to doing hard things and getting stuff done
SUMMARY: Some people team up with an "accountability partner" or "accountability group" to accomplish big goals or tasks. Here's how to set up a successful partnership.

TITLE: Daring to Dream: A reflection on America
SUMMARY: In celebration of what would have been Martin Luther King Jr.'s 96th birthday, pianist Lara Downes examines how musicians have followed in his footsteps, and faced the cost of taking a stand.

TITLE: Watch live: Confirmation hearing for Marco Rubio, Trump's secretary of state pick
SUMMARY: Among President-elect Donald Trump's Cabinet picks, secretary of state nominee Marco Rubio may face the easiest confirmation process.

TITLE: What to know about RedNote, the Chinese app that American TikTokkers are flooding
SUMMARY: With TikTok's days in the U.S. potentially numbered, many American users are moving to another Chinese social media app: RedNote, a heavily censored platform similar to Instagram. Here's what to know.

TITLE: Israel and Hamas reach a Gaza ceasefire agreement
SUMMARY: Israel and Hamas have reached an agreement on a multiphase ceasefire that commits them to end the war in Gaza, Senate Foreign Relations Committee Chairman James Risch said.

TITLE: What L.A. did right before the fires -- and why it wasn't enough
SUMMARY: Los Angeles has wildfire policies that are far tougher than many of

TITLE: Gaza and the moon make biennial most-endangered list
SUMMARY: The World Monuments Fund list seeks to raise awareness and funds to help preserve the sites it spotlights. Africa's Swahili Coast, Maine's lighthouses and Buddhist grottoes in China are also in peril.

TITLE: FBI background checks of presidential nominees, explained
SUMMARY: Confirmation hearings for Cabinet members nominated by President-elect Trump are underway. The FBI conducts background checks focusing on "character and conduct" of the nominees. What's involved?

TITLE: LA fires are still raging, but forecasters expect calmer winds in the coming days
SUMMARY: It was another day of fierce winds gusting to 65 mph in mountainous areas of Los Angeles and Ventura counties, but weather more conducive to firefighting operations is expected soon.

TITLE: John Deere faces U.S. lawsuit over farmers' ability to repair tractors
SUMMARY: The Federal Trade Commission and two states accuse Deere of costing farmers time and money by unfairly limiting software access and forcing the use of only authorized dealers.

TITLE: Invasive green crabs threaten West Coast ecosystems. One solution? Otters
SUMMARY: As invasive green crabs wreak havoc on California's estuaries, a new study has found that a restored sea otter population might be the solution.

TITLE: What LA did right before the fires -- and why it wasn't enough
SUMMARY: Los Angeles has wildfire policies that are far tougher than many of

TITLE: Inflation remains stubbornly high for many Americans. Could it get worse under Trump?
SUMMARY: Consumer prices rose 2.9% in December from a year earlier, marking the third consecutive monthly uptick in annual inflation.

TITLE: How do you ensure good luck on Lunar New Year? NPR wants to know
SUMMARY: The Lunar New Year falls on Jan. 29 this year. NPR wants to know what traditions you uphold to ensure good luck in the year to come.

TITLE: Ancient Celtic tribe had women at its social center
SUMMARY: Ancient DNA reveals that during the Iron Age, women in ancient Celtic societies were at the center of their social networks — unlike previous eras of prehistory.

TITLE: Trump's Cabinet pick for secretary of transportation is Sean Duffy. Here's what to know
SUMMARY: While some of President-elect Trump's Cabinet nominees faced sharp questioning this week, Sean Duffy received a friendly welcome in his confirmation hearing to be secretary of transportation.

TITLE: Here's everyone performing at the presidential inauguration
SUMMARY: Unlike Donald Trump's first inauguration in 2017, which reportedly struggled to book high-profile performers, several well-known artists will partake in this year's inaugural events.

TITLE: America's place in the world during a second Trump term
SUMMARY:
Confirmation hearings for Trump's cabinet picks are in full swing on Capitol Hill with a number of them appearing before the Senate this week.

Nominees including Pam Bondi, Trump's pick to run the Justice Department, John Ratcliffe, his pick to run the CIA, and Florida Senator Marco Rubio Trump's nominee for Secretary of State have all answered questions about what they'll do and what they won't do if confirmed.

Rubio and Ratcliffe will play key foreign policy roles under the 47th president.

Those are the people, but what do they tell us about the policy?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: Israel and Hamas Reach A Deal to End the War in Gaza
SUMMARY:
A ceasefire deal has been announced that would end more than 15 months of war between Israel and Hamas in Gaza. We learn about the details, how the agreement was reached and hear reaction from Israelis and Palestinians. We also look at what the war has meant for both sides and for the Middle East region.

For more coverage of this conflict and the latest developments, please come back to this feed. You can also go to npr.org/mideastupdates

TITLE: Will Lewis's first year at 'Washington Post': Cancellations, red ink and an exodus
SUMMARY: Subscribers and star journalists have fled the Post in its first year under CEO and Publisher Will Lewis. Now staff have signed a petition asking owner Jeff Bezos to intervene.

TITLE: After half a century in politics, Biden will bid farewell in an Oval Office address
SUMMARY: President Biden had once hoped to be giving a second inaugural address. Instead, he'll be saying farewell to public life, and trying to frame his legacy one last time.

TITLE: Flags to be raised for Trump's inauguration, despite half-staff order for Carter's death
SUMMARY: The president-elect had expressed concern that Democrats seemed happy to see the flag lowered during the inauguration ceremony despite the tradition of lowering flags after a president's death.

TITLE: Watch live: Biden bids farewell in Oval Office address
SUMMARY: President Biden had once hoped to be giving a second inaugural address. Instead, he'll be saying farewell to public life, and trying to frame his legacy one last time.

TITLE: After half a century in politics, Biden bids farewell in an Oval Office address
SUMMARY: In his farewell address, President Biden warned Americans about the rise of a "tech industrial complex" and unchecked abuse of power and wealth in the country.

TITLE: Jeff Bezos' Blue Origin launches massive New Glenn rocket on first test flight
SUMMARY: The rocket was supposed to launch Monday, but ice buildup caused a delay. It's built to haul spacecraft and eventually astronauts to orbit and also the moon.

TITLE: Pro-Stacey Abrams groups to pay record fine for breaking Georgia campaign finance law
SUMMARY: The two groups' current leadership admitted 16 instances of illegal activity in a consent decree and will pay a $300,000 fine, the largest in state history, according to the commission.

TITLE: How would RFK Jr. handle bird flu? His record on vaccines has experts on edge
SUMMARY: Trump's pick for health secretary has a record of attacking vaccines. In fact he's even taken direct aim at bird flu shots. Some scientists fear this doesn't bode well in case of a crisis.

TITLE: Trump's energy secretary nominee faces questions over climate posts and LA fires
SUMMARY: Trump's pick for secretary of energy, fracking executive Chris Wright, faced questions about a past social media post calling wildfires "hype."

TITLE: What happens after a wildfire destroys your home? A survivor has tips
SUMMARY: "What the hell just happened to my future?" — that's the immediate thought for many people when they learn a fire has destroyed their home, says consumer advocate Annie Barbour.

TITLE: The Transportation Department sues Southwest Airlines for alleged oft-delayed flights
SUMMARY: The agency is seeking civil penalties against Southwest Airlines, and also fined Frontier Airlines for its continuous delays.

TITLE: A need for speed: Several states are looking for ways to count votes faster
SUMMARY: Lawmakers in California and other states want to change vote-counting rules to speed up the process. One key question is whether counting can be sped up without sacrificing access to the ballot.

TITLE: Trump wants a quick end to the Ukraine war. That's a tall order
SUMMARY: The war has reached a critical point. A real peace seems unlikely, but a ceasefire is possible, most experts agree. The question is whether it can be achieved without placing Ukraine in further peril.

TITLE: Trump's pick for secretary of the Interior Department is Doug Burgum. Here's what to know
SUMMARY: Doug Burgum, former North Dakota governor and businessman is President Donald Trump's pick to be Secretary of the Interior. The confirmation hearing is scheduled for Thurs., Jan 16, 2025.

TITLE: We asked experts to grade Biden's job on education. They gave it a C average
SUMMARY: We asked more than a dozen educators, researchers, advocates and experts how they would grade Biden's education legacy. He got two F's, no A's and lots of votes in the middle.

TITLE: Local LA theaters bring puppets and movies to families for respite from fires
SUMMARY: Vidiots and the Bob Baker Marionette Theater teamed up to provide an escape from reality for families facing trauma and loss from the Los Angeles wildfires.

TITLE: Netanyahu delays ceasefire vote, claiming Hamas created a 'last minute crisis'
SUMMARY: The deal was set to be ratified by Israeli Cabinet on Thursday. But Netanyahu says, without specifying, that Hamas has gone back on several parts of the ceasefire agreement at the last minute.

TITLE: Why Netanyahu delayed an Israel-Hamas ceasefire vote. And, LA's wildfire prevention
SUMMARY: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu delayed a ceasefire vote today, alleging Hamas reneged on parts of the agreement. And, examining Los Angeles' wildfire prevention methods for the future.

TITLE: Conan O'Brien will receive the Mark Twain Prize for comedy
SUMMARY: "I am honored to be the first winner of the Mark Twain Prize recognized not for humor, but for my work as a riverboat pilot," O'Brien said in a release from The Kennedy Center.

TITLE: How the Gaza war has remade the Middle East
SUMMARY: What began as a battle between Israel and Hamas morphed into a much wider regional conflict that has reshaped much of the Middle East.

TITLE: As Trump inauguration nears, FCC chief dismisses complaints against TV networks
SUMMARY: Outgoing FCC chairwoman Jessica Rosenworcel has rejected petitions to rebuke four local TV stations. She says they were efforts to punish broadcast networks' coverage of presidential politics.

TITLE: A woman invented the rape kit. So why was a man given credit for it?
SUMMARY: Rape kits were widely known as "Vitullo Kits" after a Chicago police sergeant. But a new book tells the story of Marty Goddard, a community activist who worked with runaway teenagers in the 1970s.

TITLE: Biden issues an 11th hour executive order aimed at strengthening U.S. cybersecurity
SUMMARY: One of President Biden's final moves in office is aimed at shoring up critical infrastructure from cyberattacks.

TITLE: Ashley Moody, Florida's attorney general, tapped to fill Rubio's Senate seat
SUMMARY: Gov. Ron DeSantis praised Moody, who has served as Florida's attorney general since 2019, for fighting against policies he described as part of the Democratic Party's "woke agenda."

TITLE: 'Mr. Baseball' Bob Uecker, Brewers announcer and 'Major League' actor, dies at 90
SUMMARY: Uecker was the voice of his hometown team who after a short playing career earned the moniker "Mr. Baseball" and honors from the Hall of Fame.

TITLE: Russia tried to use the LA wildfires to spread anti-Ukraine propaganda
SUMMARY: Pro-Kremlin social media accounts and outlets have been spreading a baseless narrative that mansions belonging to Ukrainian officials burned down in Los Angeles.

TITLE: Giuliani fails to appear for federal civil trial, says case has been settled
SUMMARY: Former New York City Mayor Rudolph Giuliani was scheduled to be a witness in a case set to determine which assets he would have to forfeit after he lied about two Georgia election workers.

TITLE: Mortgage rates have climbed above 7%. Here's how we got here and what it means
SUMMARY: It's the first time since May 2024 that 30-year mortgage rates have hit that mark. High rates are adding to the affordability challenges many Americans are facing.
