TITLE: A new way to see what was for dinner 3 million years ago
SUMMARY: Analyzing the chemistry of some ancient teeth has revealed what human ancestors were eating around 3 million years ago.

TITLE: LA's wildfires prompted a rash of fake images. Here's why
SUMMARY: "It's not just that you're perpetrating a fraud" by spreading bogus images, expert Hany Farid says. The fakes also sow confusion about an ongoing catastrophe.

TITLE: Toyota's commercial truck company will pay $1.6 billion for faking emissions tests
SUMMARY: Hino Motors will plead guilty to submitting false emissions data to regulators for more than 100,000 heavy-duty trucks. The company will pay an array of fines, and fix some affected vehicles for free.

TITLE: Trump's pick for Treasury Secretary is Scott Bessent. Here's what to know
SUMMARY: Trump's promised tax cuts, and their potential consequences for the U.S. economy, took center stage at Bessent's confirmation hearing.

TITLE: Fed cuts were supposed to lower mortgage rates, but they're back above 7%. Here's why
SUMMARY: It's the first time since May 2024 that 30-year mortgage rates have hit that mark. High rates are adding to the affordability challenges many Americans are facing.

TITLE: Freezing temperatures are expected during Trump's second inauguration
SUMMARY: Monday's Inauguration Day is set to be the coldest in 40 years. The high temperature for the day is projected to be around freezing at 23 degrees, while the low for the day may drop to just 10 degrees.

TITLE: Trump's pick for EPA administrator is Lee Zeldin. Here's what to know.
SUMMARY: Democrats worry the Trump administration will roll back efforts to limit climate change.

TITLE: Will Israel's Government Ratify the Gaza Ceasefire Deal?
SUMMARY:
Just one day after the announcement of a deal between Israel and Hamas to end the war in Gaza, Israel's prime minister threatened to delay a cabinet vote to approve the deal. He later relented and scheduled a vote. To understand the politics behind the deal and how the U.S. will be involved in its implementation we hear from Aaron David Miller. He once represented the U.S. in peace negotiations in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

You can find all our reporting on this conflict at npr.org/mideastupdates

TITLE: Canadian man's home security camera captures the sight and sound of a meteorite strike
SUMMARY: Joe Velaidum's home security camera captured the instant a meteorite smashed against his home's brick walkway. The video is thought to be the first recorded sound of a meteorite's direct impact.

TITLE: The immigration journey: How long does it take to feel like an American?
SUMMARY: What does it take to feel like an American - and to be treated like one? Several communities shared their perspectives on the immigrant experience.

TITLE: Cancer deaths are declining, but diagnoses are rising especially among younger women
SUMMARY: The American Cancer Society's report shows a mix of lower death rates and rising cancer incidence rates for some groups, especially younger women.

TITLE: ICE estimates it would need $26.9 billion to enforce GOP deportation bill
SUMMARY: An internal document from Immigration and Customs Enforcement concludes it would be "impossible" for it to enforce the Laken Riley Act without significantly more resources.

TITLE: Trump's challenge: where to house millions of immigrant detainees
SUMMARY: One of the biggest hurdles to carrying out Trump's mass deportation plans is where to house the millions of people who are in the country without legal status. As many prisons and detention centers are already overcrowded, what options are there?

TITLE: Trump nominee to lead HUD says the agency is failing in its mission
SUMMARY: Scott Turner pledged to make HUD programs more streamlined and efficient. He declined to say whether he would oppose major budget cuts to the agency if Trump proposes them again.

TITLE: Will we finally see an end to the war in Gaza?
SUMMARY:
At the time we publish this episode, Israel's government has yet to accept the terms of the long-negotiated and hard fought ceasefire deal announced yesterday.

The deal is still on, but the quarreling over the details demonstrates how difficult it is to keep the agreement on track.

On Thursday morning Israeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu delayed a cabinet vote on the deal, accusing Hamas of "reneging" on parts of the agreement.

A Hamas official said on social media that the group is committed to the agreement announced Wednesday.

After more than 15 long months, tens of thousands dead, and close to 2 million people displaced, will we finally see an end to the war in Gaza?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: SpaceX launches its Starship rocket on latest test flight but spacecraft is destroyed
SUMMARY: After launching on Thursday, the Starship rocket caught the booster back at the pad but lost contact with the ascending spacecraft as engines went out. Officials for Elon Musk's company confirmed that the spacecraft was destroyed.

TITLE: Angelenos who didn't have to evacuate are experiencing survivor's guilt from fires
SUMMARY: Most people in L.A. did not evacuate -- and many have survivor's guilt. Katia Riddle discusses with Ailsa strategies for Angelenos who are navigating this complicated emotional terrain.

TITLE: A look back at Deb Haaland's time as the first Indigenous cabinet secretary
SUMMARY: The nation's first Indigenous cabinet secretary is wrapping up at the Department of Interior. It's unclear how many of Deb Haaland's reforms will remain intact under Trump.

TITLE: China's population falls for a third straight year, posing challenges for its economy
SUMMARY: Rising costs of living are causing young people to put off or rule out marriage and child birth while pursuing higher education and careers.

TITLE: Court sentences former Pakistani leader Imran Khan to 14 years in prison
SUMMARY: Khan has denied wrongdoing and insisted since his arrest in 2023 that all the charges against him are a plot by rivals to keep him from returning to office.

TITLE: Some Los Angeles homes made it through the firestorm. Here's how
SUMMARY: Houses are still standing in the burn zone in Los Angeles, ones that made it through the fires. Experts on the ground are finding those homeowners made some key preparations.

TITLE: Trump's cabinet pick for Homeland Security is Kristi Noem. Here's what to know
SUMMARY: If confirmed, Noem would lead the department poised to be at the center of Trump's immigration policy priorities, including any deportation efforts, visa changes and border security.

TITLE: A polar vortex is set to grip much of the U.S. What does that mean?
SUMMARY: Bundle up and prepare: People living "basically anywhere from the Rockies eastward" will see extremely cold temperatures over the next several days, a meteorologist says.

TITLE: Development is taking a toll on Florida's precious springs
SUMMARY: The state has been slow to adopt rules to protect Florida's endangered springs. While a boom in residential construction has increased the amount of groundwater being taken from the aquifers.

TITLE: What's next for Kamala Harris
SUMMARY: Inauguration Day marks the first time in more than 20 years that Kamala Harris will not be in public office. "It is not my nature to go quietly into the night," she told allies on Thursday.

TITLE: What question stumped a Trump cabinet pick? Find out in the news quiz!
SUMMARY: If you've paid attention to the coming inauguration, TikTok drama and the Princess of Wales' health, you'll do pretty well this week.

TITLE: Biden shortens sentences for nearly 2,500 people, setting a record
SUMMARY: Democratic lawmakers had urged President Biden to use his clemency powers to address disparities in sentences for offenses involving crack cocaine.

TITLE: Why Australian Open live streams look like Wii tennis — and what it means for sports
SUMMARY: The Australian Open's animated tennis livestreams are making a splash. U.S. leagues have used similar technology to put Simpsons on the football field and superheroes on ice skates.

TITLE: U.S. electricity demand is set to explode. That will make it harder to cut climate pollution
SUMMARY: Analysts say the country will burn a lot more natural gas in the coming years to meet soaring electricity demand, potentially locking in decades of heat-trapping emissions.

TITLE: Israel's security cabinet approves Gaza ceasefire and hostage deal
SUMMARY: Israel's security cabinet has voted to approve a ceasefire deal to end the fighting in Gaza. Full cabinet approval is expected later today.

TITLE: Next steps for Israel-Hamas ceasefire deal. And, polar vortex to envelop the U.S.
SUMMARY: The Israeli security cabinet meeting to vote on a ceasefire deal with Hamas, which was delayed yesterday, is set for today. And, frigid temperatures are expected to envelop much of the U.S. next week.

TITLE: Medicare targets 15 more drugs for price negotiations -- including Ozempic
SUMMARY: On its last weekday in power, the Biden Administration has chosen the next batch of drugs up for price negotiation in Medicare.

TITLE: How will Trump's return to the White House change the face of global health?
SUMMARY: When Donald Trump returns to the White House, he's expected to issue a series of orders with far-reaching impact on global health — from abortion services to support for the World Health Organization.

TITLE: The surprising reason why the Park Service won't count folks at Trump's inauguration
SUMMARY: The National Park Service stays out of the debates about crowd sizes — including for President-elect Donald Trump's inauguration.

TITLE: Food pantries are bracing for more demand if the Trump administration cuts food aid
SUMMARY: The first Trump administration tried to scale back who gets food benefits, and allies aim to try again. Food pantries say they're already busier than ever.

TITLE: Fire at one of the world's largest battery plants forces evacuations in California
SUMMARY: A major fire erupted south of San Francisco at the Moss Landing Power Plant, forcing hundreds to evacuate. So far, the fire has stayed in the facility, which stores thousands of lithium batteries.

TITLE: Watch live: Senate confirmation hearing for Kristi Noem
SUMMARY: If confirmed, Noem would lead the department poised to be at the center of Trump's immigration policy priorities, including any deportation efforts, visa changes and border security.

TITLE: Trump and China's Xi speak by phone as Supreme Court issues TikTok ruling
SUMMARY: The Trump-Xi phone call came hours before the Supreme Court on Friday upheld a U.S. law that effectively bans TikTok<strong>

TITLE: Supreme Court upholds TikTok ban, threatening app's existence in the U.S.
SUMMARY: The decision resolves a long-running legal dispute between the Department of Justice and TikTok. But experts say President-elect Donald Trump will now have considerable sway over the platform's future in the U.S.

TITLE: Biden says the Equal Rights Amendment is law. What happens next is unclear
SUMMARY: To come into effect, the constitutional amendment would need to be formally published or certified by the National Archivist who has declined to do so in the past. What happens now is unclear.

TITLE: Trump's inauguration falls on MLK Day. That overlap is pretty rare
SUMMARY: Trump is only the third president to be sworn in on Martin Luther King Jr. Day. Due to the particulars of the calendar and the Constitution, the two events won't overlap again until 2053.

TITLE: Biden's Medicaid director shares lessons learned and concerns for the program's future
SUMMARY: Dan Tsai discusses how he ran Medicaid under Biden, and his fears for how Republicans might try to change the program.

TITLE: CNN liable of defamation for story on 'black market' evacuations from Afghanistan
SUMMARY: A Florida jury found CNN defamed a security consultant in a story that suggested he was charging "exorbitant prices" to evacuate people trying to flee Afghanistan after the U.S. withdrawal in 2021.

TITLE: Ohio's Lt. Gov. Jon Husted to fill U.S. Senate seat vacated by JD Vance
SUMMARY: In making his announcement, Ohio Gov. Mike DeWine said he wanted a "workhorse" in the U.S. senate who would focus on Ohio as well as the rest of the country.

TITLE: Immigration is a lifeline for Nebraska's economy. But Trump's mass deportations pledge is a looming threat
SUMMARY: Nebraska is one of the top meat producers in the U.S. It also has one of the worst labor shortages. The incoming Trump administration has promised mass deportations on an unprecedented scale. We asked Nebraskans what that could mean.

TITLE: Pepsi accused of illegal pricing deals with 'a large, big box retailer' in U.S. lawsuit
SUMMARY: The Federal Trade Commission is suing Pepsi, alleging it has rigged competition by offering unfair pricing deals to a big retailer at the expense of smaller rivals, resulting in higher costs for shoppers.

TITLE: President-elect Donald Trump moves inauguration indoors, citing frigid temperatures
SUMMARY: President-elect Donald Trump announced Friday that he will move the inauguration ceremony indoors as Washington, DC prepares for record low temperatures. The ceremony will now take place inside the Capitol rotunda.

TITLE: Newly discovered poems show Virginia Woolf as a fun aunt
SUMMARY: A researcher — who was looking for something else — stumbled onto two poems by Virginia Woolf. The silly, punny, quickly drafted poems were written for her niece and nephew sometime after March 1927.

TITLE: CNN liable for defamation over story on Afghanistan 'black market' rescues
SUMMARY: A Florida jury found CNN defamed a security consultant in a story that suggested he was charging "exorbitant prices" to evacuate people trying to flee Afghanistan after the U.S. withdrawal in 2021.

TITLE: Immigrants drive Nebraska's economy. Trump's mass deportations pledge is a threat
SUMMARY: Nebraska is one of the top meat producers in the U.S. It also has one of the worst labor shortages. The incoming Trump administration has promised mass deportations on an unprecedented scale. We asked Nebraskans what that could mean.

TITLE: A planet parade of Venus, Saturn, Jupiter and Mars shines in the skies this month
SUMMARY: All month, Venus, Saturn, Jupiter and Mars will appear to line up and be bright enough to see with the naked eye in the first few hours after dark. This weekend, Venus and Saturn get especially cozy.

TITLE: Justin Baldoni has sued Blake Lively, Ryan Reynolds for $400 million
SUMMARY: Baldoni, his studio Wayfarer, and their publicists are alleging civil extortion, defamation and a slew of contract-related claims about the film<em> It Ends With Us.

TITLE: Zyn nicotine pouches can be marketed in the U.S., the FDA says. What does this mean?
SUMMARY: The FDA said "an extensive scientific review" found the products were found to pose lower risks of cancer and other serious health conditions compared to cigarettes and smokeless tobacco products.

TITLE: Air traffic controllers rush to divert aircraft after Elon Musk's rocket explodes
SUMMARY: Debris streaking across the Caribbean appeared to cause confusion and delays.

TITLE: CNN settles lawsuit after $5 million defamation verdict
SUMMARY: CNN settled with a security consultant after a Florida jury found the network had defamed him in a story that suggested he was charging "exorbitant prices" to evacuate people from Afghanistan in 2021.

TITLE: A Dangerous Ride on Top of a Train in Mexico
SUMMARY: The incoming Trump administration has promised sweeping deportations of undocumented people and little empathy for those seeking refuge in the U.S. Despite that, migrants continue to make the dangerous journey north through Mexico to get to the U.S. border. We hop on a freight train with some migrants to find out why.

TITLE: 'The birds are back.' Resilience in the ruins of the Palisades fire
SUMMARY:
Will Rogers State Historic Park is a vast stretch of natural space in the Santa Monica Mountains. It's a treasure to Angelenos. People get married there, picnic there, and have kids' birthday parties on the great lawn.

The park's namesake, Will Rogers, was a vaudeville performer, radio and movie star, and was known as America's "cowboy philosopher."

His nearly century-old ranch house is the park's centerpiece. It's survived a near miss with wildfire before. Last week, as firestorm engulfed large parts of Los Angeles, this piece of American history was reduced to rubble.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: A South African horror story: illegal mining stand-off draws to an end
SUMMARY: In South Africa a months long stand-off between police and illegal miners in an abandoned gold mine comes to end, with close to 80 found dead in grim recovery operation.

TITLE: More than 40 Pakistani migrants feared drowned off African coast
SUMMARY: Pakistan said that the boat, carrying 80 passengers including some Pakistanis, had set off from Mauritania on their way to the Canary Islands.

TITLE: Russian attack kills 4 people in Kyiv
SUMMARY: Russia attacked the Ukrainian capital with a barrage of drones and missiles Saturday, leaving at least four people dead, while industrial sites in Russia were set ablaze by Ukrainian strikes.

TITLE: Private firefighters are helping out in L.A. wildfires. It raises ethical questions
SUMMARY: Insurers are deploying private firefighters amid the Los Angeles wildfires. Are they an added bonus for all — or only for those who can afford them?

TITLE: In Lebanon, these Palestinian refugees sew designs from a homeland they've never seen
SUMMARY: In a workshop in an infamous refugee camp in Beirut, Palestinian women practice an ancient art form — as a livelihood, and also as therapy. The designs come from a homeland most have never seen.

TITLE: These are the U.S. citizens held hostage in Gaza
SUMMARY: Seven of the nearly 100 hostages held in Gaza are U.S. citizens, several of whom are confirmed dead.

TITLE: A California fifth grader interviews his firefighter father
SUMMARY: Cian Lawlor's father was dispatched to the Palisades Fire just over a week ago and he's been working it ever since. The 11-year-old had some questions for his dad.

TITLE: Hate cooking? 3 mindsets to make it less of a chore
SUMMARY: Even if you dislike cooking, you still have to eat every day. Here's how to gain more confidence in the kitchen and think outside the box when it comes to meal prep.

TITLE: Trump's return recalls when inaugurations have been more than ceremonies
SUMMARY: Presidential inaugurations are by definition historic acts, but when we think of past Inauguration Days there is clearly a hierarchy of historical pop.

TITLE: After major 2024 defeats, the Democratic Party searches for a new direction
SUMMARY: The Democratic Party begins 2025 with several looming questions. Among them: who will lead its national party apparatus, and how it will handle President-elect Donald Trump's second term.

TITLE: One longtime Gaiman fan on where we go from here
SUMMARY: Pop culture critic Glen Weldon says he can't separate the art from the artist. But in light of the sexual abuse allegations against Gaiman, he will separate himself from the author's future work.

TITLE: Beyond red dye No.3: Here's what parents should know about food colorings
SUMMARY: Food companies have two years to get red dye No.3 out of their products. But other synthetic dyes have also raised concerns, because of behavioral issues in kids. Here's what parents need to consider.

TITLE: Is the air quality index actually useful right now?
SUMMARY: The air has improved in the LA region as firefighters get blazes under control, but there are questions about how safe the air actually is.

TITLE: More teens say they're using ChatGPT for schoolwork, a new study finds
SUMMARY: According to the survey, 26% of students ages 13-17 are using the artificial intelligence bot to help them with their assignments.

TITLE: Private firefighters are helping out in LA wildfires. It raises ethical questions
SUMMARY: Insurers are deploying private firefighters amid the Los Angeles wildfires. Are they an added bonus for all — or only for those who can afford them?

TITLE: Opinion: Great writers on Los Angeles
SUMMARY: NPR's Scott Simon reflects on the wildfires in Los Angeles, and the words of writers who were drawn to the city.

TITLE: Readers share wishes for 2025: Be kind to each other and Earth! Learn from birds!
SUMMARY: We asked our readers to make a wish for 2025. If even one of these wishes comes true, the world will definitely be a better place!

TITLE: Beyond red dye No. 3: Here's what parents should know about food colorings
SUMMARY: Food companies have two years to get red dye No. 3 out of their products. But other synthetic dyes have also raised concerns, because of behavioral issues in kids. Here's what parents need to consider.

TITLE: In India, a police volunteer is convicted of rape and murder of a trainee doctor
SUMMARY: A court found a police volunteer guilty of the rape and murder of a 31-year-old trainee doctor, a crime that sparked protests and hospital strikes amid concerns over lack of safety for women.

TITLE: With TikTok's future uncertain, creators ponder life without the app
SUMMARY: Barring a last minute sale by its Chinese parent company, TikTok could soon go dark in the U.S. Now, creators on the Chinese-owned platform pay tribute to it — and talk about what's next.

TITLE: U.S. pays $590 million to Moderna to speed up development of bird flu vaccine
SUMMARY: The public health risk remains low, but bird flu variants have proven to be unpredictable, which is why the virus is a top priority for the federal government.

TITLE: 'The hydrants up here are dead.' Radio traffic shows how LA firefighters lost water
SUMMARY: NPR transcribed more than 2,000 hours of radio communications from the LA fires. It shows hydrants going dry and first responders fighting the fires despite scarce resources.

TITLE: South Korean court orders formal arrest of President Yoon over martial law decree
SUMMARY: South Korea's impeached president, Yoon Suk Yeol, faces possible imprisonment over his declaration of martial law last month. The formal arrest comes days after he was apprehended.

TITLE: Trump says he'll likely give TikTok a 90-day extension
SUMMARY: President-elect Donald Trump spoke on the possibility of delaying a ban less than 24 hours from when the social media app is expected to shut down.

TITLE: Trump's border czar says immigration raids will begin next week, including in Chicago
SUMMARY: Prospects of a raid in Chicago come just a few weeks after Trump's border czar Tom Homan visited the city and threatened to prosecute the mayor if he did not cooperate.

TITLE: TikTok is offline in the U.S. after Supreme Court upholds ban
SUMMARY: The app had more than 170 million monthly users in the U.S. The black-out is the result of a law forcing the service offline unless it sheds its ties to ByteDance, its China-based parent company.

TITLE: Outgoing Interior Secretary Deb Haaland hands off closer ties with Indian Country
SUMMARY: Deb Haaland, the country's first indigenous cabinet secretary, used her term at the Interior Department to make what activists say is irreversible impact in recognizing the painful history of the government's treatment Native Americans

TITLE: Deadline passes without Gaza ceasefire going into effect
SUMMARY: The deadline for the start of a ceasefire in the Gaza Strip passed as Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Hamas had provided the names of the three hostages it was set to release on Sunday.

TITLE: Gaza ceasefire begins after delay as Hamas names hostages to be released Sunday
SUMMARY: A long-awaited ceasefire in Gaza began after a three-hour delay as Hamas named the three female hostages it plans to free later on Sunday.

TITLE: Steve Bannon says MAGA populism will win — as Trump is surrounded by billionaires
SUMMARY: Former Trump adviser Steve Bannon says he doesn't believe the president-elect will listen to "tech oligarchs" over the right-wing populist movement that helped him secure another White House term.

TITLE: Cleaning up after the LA wildfires is dangerous. Here's how to protect yourself
SUMMARY: The ash and debris created during the burns could be loaded with dangerous materials. Experts suggest taking care.

TITLE: Many doctors don't discuss sex after cancer. But survivors wish they would
SUMMARY: Questions about sex and intimacy often go unanswered for people with cancer. It's a glaring problem, especially for the growing number of young people being diagnosed.

TITLE: 33 hostages are expected to be released by Hamas as part of a ceasefire with Israel
SUMMARY: There are men, women and children on the list of 33 to be released from Gaza. Two are U.S. citizens. Israel is set to free hundreds of prisoners in exchange for them.

TITLE: Trump's 2nd term represents hope for the right and fear of a dark era for others
SUMMARY: President-elect Donald Trump's inauguration comes at a pivotal time in American history. Insulated from controversy, Trump will enter the White House more prepared than when he first won in 2016.

TITLE: This Virginia program helps former foster youth get degrees, at any age
SUMMARY: Great Expectations was designed to help people who grew up in foster care get their two-year degrees. And unlike many programs for former foster youth, there are no age limits.

TITLE: Ceasefire goes into effect in Gaza, Israel says, after initial delay
SUMMARY: The Israeli government announced the ceasefire with Hamas would take effect at 11:15 local time, nearly three hours after the originally scheduled time for hostilities to cease.

TITLE: Why Trump's tariff promises will be hard to keep
SUMMARY: President-elect Donald Trump has said his tariffs will raise revenues, boost U.S. jobs, and help stop the drug trade. But some of these goals are at odds with the others.

TITLE: Biden pardons Virginia House Speaker Don Scott, Black nationalist Marcus Garvey
SUMMARY: President Joe Biden pardons five people and commutes the sentence of two others who "made significant contributions to improving their communities."

TITLE: Trump's 2nd term brings hope but also fear. Here's what he's promised to focus on
SUMMARY: President-elect Donald Trump's inauguration comes at a pivotal time in American history. Insulated from controversy, Trump will enter the White House more prepared than when he first won in 2016.

TITLE: TikTok is back online in the U.S., following Trump's promise to pause the ban
SUMMARY: The president-elect said he will issue an executive order Monday to delay the ban while he brokers a sale. The app has returned on web and mobile, but is not available in Apple and Google's stores.

TITLE: Joe Biden's complicated legacy
SUMMARY:
When he ran for office in 2020, President Joe Biden vowed to turn the page on then president Donald Trump. But it's Trump who is returning to the White House for a second term in office.

We speak with NPR's Asma Khalid, who covered the Biden administration, on the legacy he leaves behind.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: 3 freed hostages arrive in Israel as tenuous ceasefire with Hamas holds
SUMMARY: Romi Gonen, Emily Damari and Doron Steinbrecher crossed into Israel on a military transport after being driven out of Gaza City in a Red Cross vehicle, Israel said.

TITLE: Heavy snow and frigid temps put 70 million in the U.S. under winter storm warnings
SUMMARY: Residents along the East Coast, from the Northern Plains to the tip of Maine, are bracing for several inches of snow on Sunday followed by dangerously cold temperatures.

TITLE: Social Vidoes: Far from the front lines, Ukrainians fight a war to preserve their culture
SUMMARY: In the Transcarpathia region, some locals embrace a traditional lifestyle and cultural identity. After surviving Soviet threats, now they fear Russian President Vladimir Putin seeks to erase their culture.

TITLE: Trump rallies at Capital One Arena in preview of inauguration
SUMMARY: Trump took the rally as an opportunity to preview several of his Day 1 actions, including on border security, energy, and ending the Biden administration's diversity, equity, and inclusion efforts in government agencies.

TITLE: Local meteorologists could face layoffs amid new initiative with The Weather Channel
SUMMARY: The new initiative will be rolled out across 27 stations and feature "additional visual storytelling capabilities," Allen Media Group says.

TITLE: Social Videos: Far from the front lines, Ukrainians fight a war to preserve their culture
SUMMARY: In the Transcarpathia region, some locals embrace a traditional lifestyle and cultural identity. After surviving Soviet threats, now they fear Russian President Vladimir Putin seeks to erase their culture.

TITLE: Photos: Families reunite as the Israel-Hamas ceasefire takes effect
SUMMARY: After 15 months war, a ceasefire between Israel and Hamas took effect on Sunday morning.

TITLE: First Israeli hostages and Palestinian prisoners freed in ceasefire deal with Hamas
SUMMARY: Israel released 90 Palestinian prisoners and detainees in exchange for three Israeli hostages held in Gaza as part of the ceasefire deal that went into effect this morning.

TITLE: At least 80 people killed in northeast Colombia as peace talks fail, official says
SUMMARY: Officials said the attacks happened in the Catatumbo region near the border with Venezuela, following the government's failed attempts to hold peace talks with the National Liberation Army.

TITLE: Trump promised dozens of actions on immigration on Day 1. Here's what we know
SUMMARY: Trump campaigned on border security promises, and he and his allies argue that his electoral win is an endorsement of his upcoming actions on the issue.

TITLE: With fewer protesters and a renewed focus, activists plan for a second round of Trump
SUMMARY: President-elect Donald Trump takes office Monday and Democratic organizers are not seeing the mass-scale opposition they witnessed in 2017. So, they're adjusting with a focus on Trump's agenda.

TITLE: Inside Trump's Inauguration Day: How, when and what to watch
SUMMARY: President-elect Donald Trump will take the oath of office at noon followed by a presidential parade, signing ceremony and inaugural balls.

TITLE: Prince Harry's case against Rupert Murdoch's British tabloids goes to trial
SUMMARY: A trial begins Tuesday over complaints filed by Prince Harry and a senior British lawmaker against Rupert Murdoch's tabloid newspapers. The trial carries high stakes on both sides of the Atlantic.

TITLE: What to know about Ohio State, Notre Dame and college football's championship game
SUMMARY: That the Buckeyes and the Fighting Irish, two of the sport's most storied teams, are squaring off in the title game is a TV executive's dream — and a fitting end to the first-ever 12-team playoff.

TITLE: Village People founder says everybody can enjoy their music, Republican or Democrat
SUMMARY: Victor Willis of the Village People says their music is for everyone, defending the group's choice to perform at Trump's inaugural celebrations as a message of inclusivity.

TITLE: What to know for Trump's inauguration. And, a Civil Rights icon remembers MLK Jr.
SUMMARY: Today is Trump's Inauguration Day. Last night, during a rally, he reiterated promises to sign executive orders. And, Atlanta Civil Rights icon Lonnie C. King recounts a historic moment with MLK Jr.

TITLE: How a stranger's kindness taught a mom to be a 'more accepting person'
SUMMARY: After Virginia Squier's young daughter accidentally boarded a train without her, a stranger stepped in to help.

TITLE: Biden pardons Fauci, Milley and members of Jan. 6 panel
SUMMARY: President Biden said the pardons are not an "acknowledgment that any individual engaged in any wrongdoing" but rather protect individuals from "unjustified and politically motivated prosectutions."

TITLE: Austin Tice's mother returns to Syria in search for son
SUMMARY: For the first time in a decade, Debra Tice, the mother of missing American journalist, Austin Tice, returns to Syria to find news of her son.

TITLE: All of the Day 1 executive actions Trump has announced so far
SUMMARY: Trump is expected to sign a slew of actions relating to immigration and other issues.

TITLE: Follow NPR for Donald Trump's Inauguration Day coverage
SUMMARY: Follow NPR's live special coverage of Donald Trump's inauguration, including his swearing-in ceremony and inaugural address, beginning at 11 a.m. ET. Here's how to watch and listen.

TITLE: Former head of Planned Parenthood Cecile Richards has died
SUMMARY: Cecile Richards, the longtime activist for women's rights and former head of Planned Parenthood, died Monday after battling brain cancer.

TITLE: News site focused on Elon Musk to launch
SUMMARY: Musk News, a new twice-weekly news site, will focus on the billionaire and Trump advisor's influence and actions over the course of the new presidency.

TITLE: Trump plans 10 sweeping actions on immigration and border security on Day 1
SUMMARY: Trump campaigned on border security promises, and he and his allies argue that his electoral win is an endorsement of his upcoming actions on the issue.

TITLE: Trump to make historic move towards revoking birthright citizenship
SUMMARY: Trump wants to reinterpret the phrasing of the 14th Amendment to mean that the federal government would not recognize automatic birthright citizenship for children born in the U.S. to parents without legal status.

TITLE: Key moments from Trump's inaugural address
SUMMARY: President Donald Trump's second inaugural address gave clues about what Trump will focus on — and how he sees the country.

TITLE:
Snoop Dogg and others face heat for performing at Trump
s pre-inauguration ball
SUMMARY: The rapper Snoop Dogg has been taking criticism for performing at one of President Trump's pre-inauguration events over the weekend.

TITLE: A conversation about MLK's legacy, and a second Trump administration
SUMMARY: Monday marks both the observance of Martin Luther King Jr. day and the inauguration of Donald Trump as our 47th President. We reflect on this with scholars Tressie McMillan Cottom and Eddie Glaude.

TITLE: Trump reinforces use of his 'Remain in Mexico' policy
SUMMARY: The policy, which was created and implemented during the first Trump administration in 2019, resulted in tens of thousands of migrants waiting for extended periods in Mexico.

TITLE: Snoop Dogg and others face heat for performing at Trump's pre-inauguration ball
SUMMARY: The rapper Snoop Dogg has been taking criticism for performing at one of President Trump's pre-inauguration events over the weekend.

TITLE: The Wars Trump Inherits
SUMMARY: As President Trump takes office he inherits two international conflicts in which the United States is deeply involved. On the campaign trail he said he would be able to end the war between Russia and Ukraine. Last month he said there would be "hell to pay" if Hamas and Israel did not reach a ceasefire and hostage release deal before he assumed office. A temporary and fragile ceasefire began on Sunday.

TITLE: Trump taps 19 Fox pundits, personalities and producers for second term
SUMMARY: President Trump has proposed 19 former Fox News hosts, journalists and commentators for senior positions in his second White House term.

TITLE: Strong Santa Ana winds hitting fire-ravaged Los Angeles -- again
SUMMARY: Nearly two weeks after the start of two of the most devastating wildfires to hit the Los Angeles area, Southern California is under an extreme fire risk warning again.

TITLE: Texas could join Louisiana with a law to require the Ten Commandments in classrooms
SUMMARY: Similar proposals are in multiple states after a court ruling in 2022, though opponents say the move would impose one religious view on people with different religious traditions

TITLE: Trump plans to declare a 'national energy emergency.' What does that mean?
SUMMARY: President Trump is making energy a top priority on his first day in office, pledging to declare a national emergency – which no president has ever done before. The implications aren't clear.

TITLE: Trump promises new names: 'Gulf of America' and 'Mount McKinley'
SUMMARY: President Trump pledged to change the name of two natural landmarks in his second inaugural address. Can he do that?

TITLE: Trump to make historic move toward revoking birthright citizenship
SUMMARY: Trump wants to reinterpret the phrasing of the 14th Amendment to mean that the federal government would not recognize automatic birthright citizenship for children born in the U.S. to parents without legal status.

TITLE: It's America's 'Manifest Destiny' to plant a flag on Mars, Trump says
SUMMARY: Trump says Americans should look to the stars, by sending astronauts to Mars.

TITLE: How Trump's inauguration speech length compares to previous presidents'
SUMMARY: Trump's second inauguration speech came out to 2,885 words — considerably longer than his 2017 address, though shorter than the off-the-cuff remarks he gave to supporters after being sworn in Monday.

TITLE: Biden's FBI director expressed 'vehement' opposition to Peltier commutation
SUMMARY: Indigenous activist Leonard Peltier was convicted of killing two FBI agents in the 1970s.

TITLE: What to know about Trump cryptocurrency meme coins
SUMMARY: The meme coins yo-yoed in value as Trump took office. Here is what you should know about the coins and cryptocurrency's future under the Trump administration.

TITLE: Migrants left in despair at the border as asylum system shuts down
SUMMARY: The CBP One app has provided nearly 900,000 people with asylum appointments since January 2023, contributing to a drop in illegal border crossings.

TITLE: PHOTOS: What we saw on Inauguration Day
SUMMARY: On the day of President Donald Trump's second inauguration, thousands of supporters gathered in Washington, D.C. Take a look at what our photographers captured.

TITLE: Trump offers long-promised pardons to some 1,500 January 6 rioters
SUMMARY: On the campaign trail, Trump regularly featured the stories of Jan. 6 defendants he labeled "hostages" and "patriots."

TITLE: Trump revokes Biden's order for federal agencies to promote voter registration
SUMMARY: President Trump has reversed an executive order by former President Joe Biden that calls for federal agencies to promote voter registration.

TITLE: Trump is back and ready to change America
SUMMARY:
Donald Trump returns to Washington newly empowered.

The Republican party has remade itself in his image. The Supreme Court has granted him sweeping immunity for his official actions. And, unlike last time, he narrowly won the popular vote.

And Trump is prepared to exercise his new power almost immediately. He's pledged to sign an unprecedented wave of executive actions – many of which will be challenged in court.

These actions include one making it U.S. policy to recognize only two biologically distinct sexes – male and female. And his administration would end birthright citizenship — a right explicitly protected by the Constitution.

President Donald Trump's executive actions could make fundamental changes to some of the foundations of American government.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: Trump seeks to end telework for federal workers
SUMMARY: President Trump has signed an executive action ordering federal agencies to bring their workers back to the office full time. Roughly 1.1 million federal employees are telework-eligible.

TITLE: Trump rescinds Biden's census order, clearing a path for reshaping election maps
SUMMARY: President Trump revoked a Biden-era executive order that affirmed the longstanding practice of including the total number of persons residing in each state in a census count used for election maps.

TITLE: Trump declares U.S. will withdraw from the World Health Organization
SUMMARY: The newly inaugurated president has announced his intention to terminate U.S. membership in the U.N.'s global health agency.

TITLE: Trump signs executive order to pause TikTok ban, provide immunity to tech firms
SUMMARY: The order follows TikTok going dark for about 14 hours after the Supreme Court upheld a law prohibiting the service from operating in the U.S. unless it breaks away from its parent company in China.

TITLE: Trump orders end of humanitarian parole for migrants of four countries
SUMMARY: Under the Biden administration, migrants from embattled countries could apply for entry due for humanitarian reasons, without having to attempt to cross into the U.S. illegally.

TITLE: Ohio State defeats Notre Dame 34-23 in college football championship game
SUMMARY: Ohio State dominated most of the night, and all through the playoffs

TITLE: Taliban announce release of two Americans held in Afghanistan in a prisoner exchange
SUMMARY: Afghanistan's Taliban government announced on Tuesday the release of two Americans in a prisoner exchange.

TITLE: PHOTOS: President Trump attends several balls to close out Inauguration Day
SUMMARY: Trump closed out his appearances at both balls with his signature dance to the Village People's "YMCA," who performed the song live at the Liberty Ball.

TITLE: Trump is withdrawing from the Paris Agreement (again), reversing U.S. climate policy
SUMMARY: President Trump issued a barrage of orders Monday targeting Biden-era initiatives on global warming. The decisions come on the heels of the hottest year ever recorded.

TITLE: Ex-Georgia prosecutor on trial for hindering Ahmaud Arbery's murder investigation
SUMMARY: Former district attorney Jackie Johnson is accused of interfering with the police investigation into the shooting death of Ahmaud Arbery, nearly five years after he was murdered while jogging.

TITLE: Key actions from Trump's first day in office. And, insights from the inaugural speech
SUMMARY: After President Trump was sworn into his second term yesterday, he kept many promises and implemented key orders. He also undid several of his predecessor's actions. Here's a breakdown.

TITLE: Saber teeth in predators evolved many times. Did it lead to their extinction?
SUMMARY: A new analysis suggests saber teeth were highly specialized for puncturing prey, ultimately at the cost of durability.

TITLE: Murdoch's News Corp offers Prince Harry settlement to resolve years-long lawsuit
SUMMARY: Rupert Murdoch's team made the offer to resolve the hacking suits from Prince Harry and a British lawmaker as a trial was to begin. A settlement could help <em>Washington Post

TITLE: Trump orders end of humanitarian parole for migrants of 4 countries
SUMMARY: Under the Biden administration, migrants from embattled countries could apply for entry for humanitarian reasons, without having to attempt to cross into the U.S. illegally.

TITLE: Jules Feiffer, Pulitzer Prize-winning cartoonist and playwright, dies at 95
SUMMARY: Feiffer was best known for illustrating the children's classic "The Phantom Tollbooth." His loopy lines left a lasting mark on art, literature and film.

TITLE: Trump's pick for U.N. ambassador is Elise Stefanik. Here's what to know
SUMMARY: Elise Stefanik was a key defender of then-President Donald Trump during his impeachment proceedings and she later grilled university presidents over what she described as antisemitism.

TITLE: Chicago immigrant residents are in Trump's sights. The mayor says he'll defend them
SUMMARY: Chicago Mayor Brandon Johnson says the city will defend residents "whether you're undocumented, whether you are seeking asylum or whether you're seeking a good paying job."

TITLE: A rare blizzard blasts the Deep South, as arctic air brings a hard freeze
SUMMARY: A winter storm prompted a National Weather Service office in Louisiana to issue a first-ever blizzard warning. The storm is causing dangerous conditions from Texas to North Carolina.

TITLE: At least 66 people killed in a fire at a ski resort in northwest Turkey
SUMMARY: A fire raged through a popular ski resort south of Istanbul early Tuesday. The deadly fire broke out during a school holiday when the area's hotels are packed.

TITLE: Trump is signing a flurry of executive orders. Here's how those work
SUMMARY: Trump is kicking off his second term with a flurry of executive actions. Here's a look at the three main types — orders, proclamations and memorandum — and how they typically work.

TITLE: Democratic AGs sue over Trump's order to end birthright citizenship
SUMMARY: A group of 18 state attorneys general signed on to a lawsuit filed Tuesday seeking to block the administration's move, describing it as unconstitutional.

TITLE: A rare blizzard blasts Gulf Coast, bringing first snow in years to parts of the South
SUMMARY: A winter storm prompted a National Weather Service office in Louisiana to issue a first-ever blizzard warning. The storm is causing dangerous conditions from Texas to North Carolina.

TITLE: FDA allows standalone use of nasal spray antidepressant Spravato (esketamine)
SUMMARY: The FDA says esketamine, an antidepressant derived from the anesthetic and party drug ketamine, can now be prescribed on its own. It was approved in 2019 to treat severe depression.

TITLE: Photos: From Texas to Florida, a rare winter storm brings historic snowfall
SUMMARY: Heavy snow, sleet and ice are making travel conditions treacherous across the region, stretching from Houston into the Florida panhandle.

TITLE: Palestinians Return to Their Homes in Gaza
SUMMARY:
A fragile ceasefire has been in place in Gaza since Sunday, bringing an end to the fighting between Israel and Hamas at least temporarily. Some Palestinians are feeling safe enough to return to homes they fled during the way. Our producer in Gaza returns to the southern city of Rafah, the site of an intense bombing campaign. There, many are returning to their homes to find utter destruction.

For more coverage of all sides of this conflict, go to npr.org/mideastupdates

TITLE: Trump administration strips schools, churches of immigration enforcement protections
SUMMARY: The memo rescinds a Biden administration guideline that created "protected areas" consisting of places where "children gather, disaster or emergency relief sites, and social services establishments."

TITLE: Will all new federal buildings look like ancient Rome now? Not quite.
SUMMARY: Among his day one actions, President Trump is reviving his first-term efforts to promote classical architecture for federal buildings.

TITLE: Trump's federal health website scrubs 'abortion' search results
SUMMARY: The most "relevant" results that come up in a search of "abortion" on HHS.gov, the website for the federal Department of Health and Human Services, are several years old, from the first Trump administration.

TITLE: Democratic attorneys general sue over Trump's order to end birthright citizenship
SUMMARY: A group of 18 state attorneys general signed on to a lawsuit filed Tuesday seeking to block the administration's move, describing it as unconstitutional.

TITLE: Bishop confronts Trump during sermon at inaugural prayer service
SUMMARY: At a sermon preached to President Trump at Washington National Cathedral, Bishop Mariann Budde asked him to "have mercy" on people who are "scared," including LGBTQ children.

TITLE: Breaking down the executive actions Trump is using to govern
SUMMARY:
President Donald J. Trump began taking decisive steps to implement his agenda hours after being sworn in.

In the day since he's once again become President, Trump has signed more than 200 executive actions aimed at delivering on campaign promises such as lower energy prices, mass deportations and an end to birthright citizenship.

There's been a deluge of actions, orders and pronouncements during the President's first day. From tariffs to immigration to the January 6th pardons – we breakdown everything down.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: Chicago's immigrant communities brace for immigration crackdowns
SUMMARY: President Donald Trump has said immigration crackdowns will begin soon. It's not clear where, but in recent days Chicago has come under the spotlight. Immigrant communities in the city are bracing.

TITLE: Trump pardons dark web marketplace creator Ross Ulbricht
SUMMARY: Ulbricht operated the anonymous digital marketplace known as Silk Road when law enforcement arrested him. The pardon fulfills a campaign pledge Trump made to Ulbricht's Libertarian supporters.

TITLE: Affidavit by Hegseth's ex-sister-in-law makes new claims about his behavior
SUMMARY: Hegseth was voted out of committee Monday along party lines. The Senate is expected to take up his nomination soon; it is unclear how these new allegations will alter the trajectory of his nomination.

TITLE: Trump's executive order resumes executions, after Biden dialed them back
SUMMARY: <em>The Department of Justice will seek the death penalty for capital crimes "committed by an alien illegally present in this country." Lawyers say the order could be difficult to enforce.

TITLE: Trump defends his decision to pardon January 6 rioters
SUMMARY: Trump said those prosecuted for the attack on the U.S. Capitol had served long enough, and he sought to shift criticism to a set of preemptive pardons issued by former President Joe Biden.

TITLE: Trump administration puts federal diversity, equity and inclusion staff on leave
SUMMARY: Employees in the programs will be placed on paid administrative leave. Agencies have the next few days to submit reports on how they are complying with the orders, including plans to fire them.

TITLE: Prince Harry settles with Murdoch's British tabloids as trial is about to begin
SUMMARY: Prince Harry has agreed to settle his lawsuit against Rupert Murdoch's British tabloids. The deal ends a years' long battle to hold the newspapers accountable for invasions of privacy.

TITLE: Fire risk and strong winds continue in Southern California with rain on the horizon
SUMMARY: Southern California was forecast to face more dangerous winds on Wednesday, but could get some badly needed rain this weekend, which could create new challenges like toxic ash runoff.

TITLE: Harvard agrees to adopt a broad definition of antisemitism to settle two lawsuits
SUMMARY: Several other schools have recently settled similar lawsuits, and suits are pending against others, including the University of Pennsylvania and Columbia University.

TITLE: Ukraine says Russia hunts civilians with attack drones in the front-line city Kherson
SUMMARY: Ukrainian officials say Russia is using drones to target civilians in Kherson. Some Russian soldiers appear to be bragging about the deadly attacks on social media.

TITLE: Rebuilding Gaza will be a massive project. Here are 5 things to know
SUMMARY: After more than 15 months of relentless Israeli bombardment, Gaza has been left in ruins. If last week's ceasefire holds, rebuilding could take decades, cost tens of billions of dollars and present overwhelming obstacles.

TITLE: Doug Collins, Trump's nominee to lead the VA, vows to work across the aisle to help vets
SUMMARY: Senators from both parties did push Collins about how he will solve problems that have plagued the VA for decades, like delivering timely health care and protecting whistle-blowers.

TITLE: Some Trump voters express reservations with his sweeping Jan. 6 pardons
SUMMARY: One Trump voter told NPR he supported pardons related to the Capitol attack, but has a tougher time reconciling pardons for rioters who were violent with police.

TITLE: What to know about protecting your cat from bird flu
SUMMARY: A few cats have died from bird flu after eating raw food. And some raw pet food products have been recalled. Here's what to know about the risks to your fur babies, and how to keep them safe.

TITLE: Peeing is contagious in chimpanzees, study suggests
SUMMARY: <em>A new study finds that captive chimpanzees may sometimes catch the urge to pee from other chimps.

TITLE: Trump strips immigration enforcement protections. And, Hegseth battles new claims
SUMMARY: Trump's administration has cleared the way for arrests in schools of people suspected of being without legal status. And, Pete Hegseth battles new allegations before receiving Senate confirmation.

TITLE: "TaxTheSuperRich" is a protester motto at the Davos forum. Would that end inequality?
SUMMARY: The World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, is underway this week — and there are calls for taxing the extremely rich to address global inequality.

TITLE: When Ichiro retired, his records felt "small" compared to the emotional moments
SUMMARY: Ichiro Suzuki's career was full of hitting streaks, All-Star Games and Gold Glove awards. But all that paled compared to moments with fans like his farewell at the Tokyo Dome in 2019, he said.

TITLE: Trump threatens Russia with tariffs and sanctions if it does not agree to end war
SUMMARY: It is unclear how much impact economic penalties would have on the Russian government, since they already face various sanctions imposed by the previous administration.

TITLE: Another casualty of Israel's war in Lebanon: Efforts to save endangered turtles
SUMMARY: Lebanese volunteers are anxious to get back to sea turtle conservation on southern beaches that were off-limits to civilians when fighting escalated between Israel and Hezbollah.

TITLE: Trump's energy emergency is a gift to fossil fuel firms. It's likely headed to court
SUMMARY: President Trump signed a "national energy emergency" that gives his administration new powers to boost fossil fuel development around the country.

TITLE: Federal health agencies told to halt all external communications
SUMMARY: In a memo obtained by NPR, acting health secretary Dorothy Fink forbade staff from public communications on most matters until Feb. 1, unless they get express approval from 'a presidential appointee.'

TITLE: The waiting stinks, but Sydney may soon enjoy the aroma of its 'corpse flower'
SUMMARY: The flower's Latin name translates as "giant, misshapen penis." But it's better known to locals as "Putricia." Royal Botanical Garden Sydney has even set up a livestream in anticipation.

TITLE: Congress clears GOP-led immigration enforcement bill, with Democrats on board
SUMMARY: The House voted 263 to 156 to approve the Laken Riley act, sending the measure to Trump for his signature. The measure would make it easier for federal immigration officials to detain and deport those without legal status who are charged with specific crimes.

TITLE: DOJ threatens to prosecute local officials for resisting immigration enforcement
SUMMARY: In a new memo, a Justice Department official seeks to realign the department's positions on immigration with President Trump's executive actions — and threatens local officials who don't cooperate.

TITLE: Does Hamas Still Rule Gaza?
SUMMARY: Israel vowed to remove Hamas from power when it went to war in Gaza, following the attacks on Israel in October, 2023. With a temporary ceasefire in place we're able to see if they've reached that goal and it seems Hamas is still deeply entrenched in Gaza. We'll hear more about who is taking charge as the dust settles and what the future of governance in the territory might be.

TITLE: Netflix raises monthly fees after a record jump in new subscribers
SUMMARY: The company says it added 19 million new subscribers during the last quarter of 2024, fueled by live events and new shows. Netflix is also raising subscriptions by $1 to $2 per month in the U.S.

TITLE: Assessing Trump's claim that U.S. pays 'unfair' share of dues to WHO
SUMMARY: While signing the order to end U.S. membership in the World Health Organization, the President spoke of the disparity between contributions from the U.S. and China. Here's how WHO funding works.

TITLE: When Ichiro retired, his records felt 'small' compared to the emotional moments
SUMMARY: Ichiro Suzuki's career was full of hitting streaks, All-Star Games and Gold Glove awards. But all that paled compared to moments with fans like his farewell at the Tokyo Dome in 2019, he said.

TITLE: They made a post-apocalyptic Sundance film. Then their homes burned
SUMMARY: The zombie apocalypse film <em>Didn't Die

TITLE: Bishop Mariann Budde tells NPR 'I won't apologize' for sermon addressing Trump
SUMMARY: The Episcopal bishop of Washington spoke with NPR to discuss her sermon addressing President Trump and why she asked him to have mercy.

TITLE: RFK Jr. plans to keep a financial stake in lawsuits against the drugmaker Merck
SUMMARY: RFK Jr. plans to keep collecting referral fees in lawsuits against the drug company Merck even if confirmed as HHS secretary, according to new filings with the Office of Government Ethics.

TITLE: U.N. chief warns gangs could overrun Haiti's capital without additional support
SUMMARY: U.N. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres said in a report that gangs in Haiti could overrun the capital, leading to a complete breakdown of government, without additional international support.

TITLE: Postcards From The Border aims to challenge dominant portrayal of U.S.-Mexico border
SUMMARY: Challenging perceptions of the US-Mexico border: A new Texas art project uses music, photos and storytelling to highlight the the rich cultural tapestry beyond headlines of migration and enforcement

TITLE: In a surprise, U.S. colleges saw higher enrollment last fall
SUMMARY: The number of students in undergraduate and graduate programs rose above pre-pandemic levels for the first time.

TITLE: Trump calls DEI programs 'illegal' and 'immoral'. Here's how he's ending them
SUMMARY: President Trump has issued sweeping executive actions swiftly ending diversity, equity, inclusion and accessibility programs within the federal government. Already, the work is underway.

TITLE: Stick with us: Why the internet is obsessed with one of the simplest tools known to man
SUMMARY: "Stick Nation" is a worldwide movement that thrives on irreverent, fantastical and downright wholesome descriptions of sticks.

TITLE: This scientist studies climate change. Then the Los Angeles fire destroyed his home
SUMMARY: Climate scientist Ben Hamlington works on understanding the impacts of climate change. Losing his house in the Eaton Fire has given that work new meaning.

TITLE: Couples wed as landmark same-sex marriage law takes effect in Thailand
SUMMARY: Hundreds of same-sex couples tied the knot across Thailand on Thursday, as the country becomes the first in Southeast Asia to legally recognize equal marriage.

TITLE: This economist survived a wildfire. Now she's taking on California's insurance crisis
SUMMARY: An economist's harrowing escape from fire, and her big ideas to rescue California from its insurance doom spiral.

TITLE: Watch: 2025 Oscar nominations come out this morning
SUMMARY: Comedians Bowen Yang and Rachel Sennott will announce the nominations for the 2025 Academy Awards on Thursday morning. Nominations were delayed twice due to the fires in Los Angeles.

TITLE: Trump's plans to crack down on immigration. And, Oscar nomination announcements today
SUMMARY: President Trump's promise to crack down on immigration is moving forward today in two ways. And, Oscar nominations will be announced today after delays due to the Los Angeles wildfires.

TITLE: Blasts from military weapons may injure the brain through its blood vessels
SUMMARY: When military personnel fire certain powerful weapons, they may be exposed to blast waves that damage blood vessels in the brain.

TITLE: Trump wants to end birthright citizenship. That's easier said than done
SUMMARY: One of Trump's executive orders moves to end birthright citizenship, a right enshrined in the Constitution. Here's what you need to know about the legal principle and its possible future.

TITLE: See the full list of 2025 Oscar nominations
SUMMARY: Emilia Pérez raked in the most nominations Thursday morning, followed by The Brutalist and Wicked

TITLE: Stick with us: Why the internet is obsessed with one of the simplest tools known to man
SUMMARY: "Stick Nation" is a worldwide movement that thrives on irreverent, fantastical and downright wholesome descriptions of sticks.

TITLE: In Syria's Golan Heights buffer zone, residents fear Israel is making a land grab
SUMMARY: After the ouster of Syria's longtime leader Bashar al-Assad last month, Israel's military has taken up a new post in the demilitarized buffer zone created in Syria after the 1973 Arab-Israeli war.

TITLE: Trump taps conservative media critic to lead global news agency
SUMMARY: President Trump plans to nominate a conservative critic of the mainstream media, L. Brent Bozell III, to run the U.S. Agency for Global Media, which oversees Voice of America.

TITLE: Trump's entry into crypto opens new doors for those seeking political influence
SUMMARY: Bloomberg investigative reporter Zeke Faux says the Trump family crypto business offers anyone seeking favor with the new administration a legal way to send money directly to the president.

TITLE: President Trump's suspension of asylum marks a break from U.S. past
SUMMARY: Lee Gelernt with the ACLU said the action goes "way beyond anything that even President Trump has tried in the past."

TITLE: National Institutes of Health cancels scientific meetings after Trump directives
SUMMARY: An email obtained by NPR says NIH employees are subject to a travel freeze and offers of employment are being rescinded. Scientists worry about disruptions to critical research.

TITLE: Senate confirms John Ratcliffe as Trump's CIA director
SUMMARY: John Ratcliffe, former director of national intelligence during President Trump's first term, has been confirmed by the Senate to lead the CIA — the first person to have held both jobs.

TITLE: U.S. judge temporarily blocks Trump's birthright citizenship order
SUMMARY: The ruling bars U.S. agencies from implementing the order to end birthright citizenship for children born to migrants in the U.S. temporarily or without legal status while the case is under review.

TITLE: Trump tries to erase Biden's health legacy with early executive orders
SUMMARY: Trump issued a flurry of executive orders and other actions on health care this week. Other than signaling he intends to reverse many of Biden's moves, the orders will have little immediate impact.

TITLE: National Institutes of Health cancel scientific meetings after Trump directives
SUMMARY: An email obtained by NPR says NIH employees are subject to a travel freeze and offers of employment are being rescinded. Scientists worry about disruptions to critical research.

TITLE: Ford recalls nearly 273,000 Bronco Sports and Mavericks for battery problems
SUMMARY: A manufacturing defect in the vehicles' 12-volt batteries can cause them to stall at low speeds, or not restart after stopping. The automaker will fix the flaw for free.

TITLE: Adults with ADHD live shorter lives than those without a diagnosis, a new study finds
SUMMARY: A large study of 30,000 adults diagnosed with ADHD in the U.K. found women with ADHD died  roughly nine years younger than women without a diagnosis. Men had about a seven-year shorter lifespan.

TITLE: Costco's shareholders overwhelmingly reject anti-DEI proposal
SUMMARY: Costco's shareholders voted overwhelmingly to reject a proposal from a conservative think tank aimed at getting the company to roll back its diversity hiring practices.

TITLE: When Oscar got it wrong
SUMMARY:
What do Babygirl, Singing in the Rain and Apocalypse Now have in common? They've all been overlooked by Oscar voters.

Some Oscar blunders fall into the category of snubs - others show a failure to recognize films that will endure.

Now sometimes, these critiques are a matter of movie taste. Sometimes, they're a broader matter of representation – raising questions about who the movie industry chooses to celebrate or ignore.

The Academy Awards have made some truly epic misses over their long history.

Two of NPR's film regulars dig into those times when the Oscars got things very wrong, and what that tells us about the art, culture and business of the movies.
