TITLE: One of the Jan. 6 defendants has turned down Trump's pardon
SUMMARY: Pamela Hemphill, who pleaded guilty to a single misdemeanor charge and spent 60 days behind bars for her role in the Capitol riots, says she no longer believes the lies President Trump promoted.

TITLE: Ford recalls nearly 273,000 Bronco Sports and Mavericks for 12-volt battery problems
SUMMARY: A manufacturing defect in the vehicles' 12-volt batteries can cause them to stall at low speeds, or not restart after stopping. The automaker will fix the flaw for free.

TITLE: Purdue Pharma and owners to pay $7.4 billion in settlement of lawsuits over OxyContin
SUMMARY: Members of the family who own OxyContin maker Purdue Pharma, and the company itself, agreed to pay up to $7.4 billion in a new settlement to lawsuits over the toll of the prescription painkiller.

TITLE: Novak Djokovic retires injured from Australian Open semifinal, as some fans boo
SUMMARY: Tennis star Novak Djokovic was booed by some sections of the crowd after retiring injured from his Australian Open semifinal against German Alexander Zverev.

TITLE: Progress is made on a huge fire north of LA as new fires erupt in Southern California
SUMMARY: Evacuation orders were lifted Thursday for tens of thousands as firefighters slowed the spread of a huge wildfire in mountains north of Los Angeles, but new blazes erupted in San Diego County.

TITLE: Trump mandates assassination records be released for the Kennedy brothers and MLK Jr.
SUMMARY: Congress passed a law in 1992 requiring the documents surrounding President Kennedy's assassination to be released by 2017. Though, the release has been held up by national security concerns.

TITLE: The U.S. is trying to unravel a hacking plot that targeted climate activists
SUMMARY: The U.S. claims the hacking was commissioned by a lobbying firm working on behalf of one of the world's biggest oil companies.

TITLE: 'Ugh. Do I have to?' Honest questions about cardio, illustrated
SUMMARY: If you're in the camp of folks who are dragging their feet to start working out again, this comic is for you.

TITLE: What did Donald Trump throw to his inauguration crowd? Find out in the news quiz
SUMMARY: Plus: Who got Oscar nods? What's Prince Harry up to? Who's watching Elon Musk? Is Barron Trump a cryptobro?

TITLE: Trained dogs working inside hospitals help ease burnout among health care staff
SUMMARY: Some hospitals are bringing in dogs to spend entire shifts with doctors and nurses. The trained canines help staff cope with the stress of their work amid high levels of burnout.

TITLE: Experts warn about the 'crumbling infrastructure' of federal government data
SUMMARY: Unstable federal funding puts at risk the government statistics used to track the U.S. economy and population, officials and data users warn. That's before any cuts by President Trump and Congress.

TITLE: Trump has tossed a lot of Biden policies. But there's one AI measure he wants to keep
SUMMARY: President Trump says he likes Biden's idea to open up federal lands for AI data centers. His White House is looking for ways to ensure U.S. dominance in the sector.

TITLE: Trump to visit disaster zones. And, why he says DEI programs are illegal
SUMMARY: How President Trump wants to use disaster relief funds as political leverage. And, why he says DEI programs are illegal and wants to end investigations into military extremism.

TITLE: 5 years after Fang Fang recorded Wuhan lockdown, 2 of her books are being translated
SUMMARY: Chinese author Fang Fang posted notes online while being quarantined in Wuhan. They became <em>Wuhan Diary

TITLE: Why is China loaning pandas to the D.C. zoo? A brief history of panda diplomacy
SUMMARY: Friday's debut of new pandas at the National Zoo in D.C. is the latest chapter in a long tale of "panda diplomacy" between China and the rest of the world.

TITLE: 'Ugh. Do I have to?' Honest questions (and answers!) about cardio, illustrated
SUMMARY: If you're in the camp of folks who are dragging their feet to start working out again, this comic is for you.

TITLE: Cancer affects your life for years after diagnosis. Here are survivors' stories
SUMMARY: Medical advances mean many more people are surviving cancer and living for years or decades with its after effects. Here's how they are navigating life after treatment.

TITLE: Hamas has named the next 4 hostages it will release as part of ceasefire with Israel
SUMMARY: All four hostages are female Israeli soldiers. They are expected to be released Saturday in accordance with a ceasefire agreement with Israel that's halted fighting in the Gaza war since last weekend.

TITLE: The U.S. just experienced its slowest annual sales of homes since 1995
SUMMARY: The market sputtered amid high mortgage rates, high prices, and homeowners with lower rates who have no plans to move.

TITLE: The debut of new pandas in D.C. marks the latest chapter in China's 'panda diplomacy'
SUMMARY: Friday's debut of new pandas at the National Zoo in D.C. is the latest chapter in a long tale of "panda diplomacy" between China and the rest of the world.

TITLE: Trump travels to visit disaster zones in North Carolina and California
SUMMARY: President Trump is taking the first trip of his term on Friday to North Carolina and California, visiting communities grappling with recovery from natural disasters.

TITLE: As Israeli troops exit Lebanon, villagers hope to return home — or what's left of it
SUMMARY: Israel is slowly withdrawing from Lebanese villages it occupied, as part of a ceasefire deal. Lebanese residents waiting to return to their villages say the Israeli military has destroyed nearly everything.

TITLE: Trump says he wants to overhaul FEMA as he travels to North Carolina and California
SUMMARY: President Trump is taking the first trip of his term on Friday to North Carolina and California, visiting communities grappling with recovery from natural disasters.

TITLE: Oath Keepers founder barred from D.C., U.S. Capitol unless judge signs off
SUMMARY: Rhodes was convicted by a federal jury of sedition conspiracy in connection with the attack on the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. President Trump pardoned him on Monday.

TITLE: Here's how Trump's pause on wind projects could threaten jobs and climate goals
SUMMARY: A Trump executive order temporarily pauses leases and permits for offshore and onshore wind projects. Wind advocates say an offshore wind freeze could threaten states' climate goals and jobs.

TITLE: Local governments across U.S. signal they won't aid Trump migrant crackdown
SUMMARY: Local government officials around the U.S. signal they won't assist — and in some cases they'll actively oppose — the Trump administration's efforts to conduct a massive deportation of migrants.

TITLE: Photos: See the pandas official return to the National Zoo
SUMMARY: Giant pandas Bao Li and Qing Bao are out of quarantine and in the spotlight. After a three month wait and 8,000 mile trip from China.

TITLE: Trump officials empower DHS to expel migrants allowed under 2 Biden programs
SUMMARY: Immigration officials would have authority to quickly expel migrants temporarily admitted via the CBP One App and a separate program for certain people fleeing Cuba, Haiti, Nicaragua and Venezuela.

TITLE: Trump wants to label drug cartels terrorist organizations. Here's what that means in practice
SUMMARY: The full implications of designating the cartels as terrorist organizations will depend, in large part, to how the administration follows through.

TITLE: Under communications freeze, CDC updates some important health data but not others
SUMMARY: One of the CDC's weekly health publications was not published on its regular schedule, and some data about flu and vaccinations wasn't updated.

TITLE: Lebanese long to return to war-damaged homes, but Israeli troops remain — for now
SUMMARY: Lebanese residents waiting to return to their villages say the Israeli military has destroyed nearly everything.

TITLE: Arrest warrant proposed for Taliban leaders for gender-based crimes
SUMMARY: The International Criminal Court, a U.N. agency, has to approve the warrants. They've been condemned by the Taliban and welcomed by Afghan women and their advocates — with some reservations.

TITLE: UnitedHealthcare names new CEO after Brian Thompson's killing
SUMMARY: The largest U.S. insurer promoted company executive Tim Noel to replace Thompson, whose death sparked a national outcry over the health care industry.

TITLE: Her brother was supposed to enter the U.S. as a refugee. That's on hold now.
SUMMARY: This week the Trump administration suspended the country's refugee resettlement program, leaving thousands of people – who had been cleared and scheduled to come to the U.S. – in a limbo.

TITLE: Trump ends Fauci's security detail, says he'd feel no responsibility if he was harmed
SUMMARY: Fauci is the latest in a string of former Trump aides-turned-critics to see their federal protection canceled.

TITLE: French woman who refused sex with husband not to blame for divorce, rights court says
SUMMARY: Europe's top human rights court ruled the woman's right to respect for private and family life had been violated when French courts found her solely at fault for her divorce because she withheld sex.

TITLE: Photos: See the pandas' official return to the National Zoo
SUMMARY: Giant pandas Bao Li and Qing Bao are out of quarantine and in the spotlight after a three-month wait and 8,000 mile trip from China.

TITLE: How did the newt cross the road? With the help of the Chileno Valley Newt Brigade!
SUMMARY: In northern California, a group of volunteers spend every night from late fall through winter as crossing guards–escorting migrating salamanders across a rural road.

TITLE: A minister was acquitted of a brutal 1832 murder. A new book revisits the case
SUMMARY: In the world of true crime, Fall River, Mass. is known for Lizzie Borden, but another murder 60 years earlier captivated New England. Kate Winkler Dawson tells the story in The Sinners All Bow.

TITLE: Jayden Daniels could make Super Bowl history. Doug Williams says it's about time
SUMMARY: Washington Commanders' Daniels could become the first rookie quarterback to play the Super Bowl. Williams, who led the team to a Super Bowl win, says talented Black QBs are finally getting their due.

TITLE: Jannik Sinner beats Alexander Zverev in 3 sets to win second Australian Open in a row
SUMMARY: Jannik Sinner claimed his second consecutive Australian Open championship on Sunday, never facing a single break point and using his complete game to outplay and frustrate Alexander Zverev for a 6-3, 7-6 (4), 6-3 victory in the final.

TITLE: Want good luck this year? Try these Lunar New Year traditions from NPR readers
SUMMARY: Each culture that celebrates the Lunar New Year has traditions passed down from generation to generation that are thought to bring good luck. NPR readers share theirs.

TITLE: Churches have a long history of being safe havens — for immigrants and others
SUMMARY: For centuries, houses of worship have served as havens for people needing refuge — and, in recent decades, sanctuary from the U.S. government.

TITLE: International peacekeepers killed as fighting rages around eastern Congo's key city
SUMMARY: Fighting with M23 rebels in eastern Congo has left at least 13 peacekeepers and foreign soldiers dead. M23 has made significant territorial gains in recent weeks, encircling the eastern city of Goma.

TITLE: Trump's Q&A on Air Force One goes from the plane's color to TikTok and Canada
SUMMARY: President Donald Trump popped in to the plane's press cabin while flying from Las Vegas to Florida to share his thoughts since taking office in a 20-minute Q&A with reporters.

TITLE: Trump wants Jordan and Egypt to accept more refugees to 'just clean out' Gaza
SUMMARY: President Donald Trump said Saturday he'd like to see Jordan, Egypt and other Arab nations increase the number of Palestinian refugees they are accepting to "just clean out" the war-torn area.

TITLE: In Las Vegas, Trump once again pitches no taxes on tips
SUMMARY: President Trump's pitch to stop taxing tips is popular with everyone -- except for economists.

TITLE: South Korean prosecutors indict impeached President Yoon Suk Yeol over martial law
SUMMARY: South Korean prosecutors on Sunday indicted impeached President Yoon Suk Yeol on rebellion in connection with his short-lived imposition of martial law.

TITLE: Rain gives LA wildfire relief but officials warn of mudslides and toxic ash
SUMMARY: Rainfall could cause mudslides in area burned by wildfires, with officials warning residents of toxic material from debris and ash.

TITLE: Trump says he still wants to buy Greenland, suggests Canada could become a U.S. state
SUMMARY: The newly inaugurated president held forth on multiple foreign policy issues on Saturday, from Greenland to Canada to the war between Israel and Hamas.

TITLE: Israeli troops fire on displaced Palestinians hoping to return to homes, killing 2
SUMMARY: Meanwhile, close to the Israeli border in southern Lebanon, Israeli troops opened fire on protesters, killing 22 and injuring 120, according to Lebanese officials.

TITLE: DeSantis faces pushback by fellow Republicans on his call for an immigration session
SUMMARY: Republican leaders in the state legislature say they support President Trump's pledge to combat illegal immigration but want to deal with it and other issues identified by DeSantis on their schedule, not his.

TITLE: A snowboarder and a skier land the first 2340s in competition
SUMMARY: Japanese snowboarder Hiroto Ogiwara and Italian skier Miro Tabanelli pulled off the six-and-a-half-rotation maneuver in competition for the first time in history.

TITLE: Rwanda-backed rebels claim to have seized key city in Congo
SUMMARY: Rwandan backed rebels have entered the city of Goma, a key city in neighboring Democratic Republic of Congo. Could the mineral rich region be in danger of tipping into all out regional conflict?

TITLE: Chiefs to face Eagles at the Super Bowl for the second time in three years
SUMMARY: Just two years after the Chiefs narrowly defeated the Eagles at the Super Bowl, these two powerhouses will face off once again on the championship stage, with even higher stakes.

TITLE: White House says Colombia agrees to take deported migrants after Trump tariff threat
SUMMARY: The White House claimed victory in a showdown with Colombia over accepting flights of deported migrants from the U.S. on Sunday, hours after President Donald Trump threatened various sanctions.

TITLE: A Republican court candidate in North Carolina wants to toss out thousands of votes
SUMMARY: More than 80 days after Election Day, a race for a seat on the North Carolina Supreme Court remains unresolved. That's because the Republican candidate is contesting some 65,000 ballots.

TITLE: Auschwitz holds observances on the 80th anniversary of the death camp's liberation
SUMMARY: Elderly camp survivors, some wearing striped scarves that recall their prison uniforms, walked to the the Death Wall, where prisoners were executed. Across Europe, officials were pausing to remember.

TITLE: Thousands of Palestinians begin returning home to a devastated Gaza
SUMMARY: The long trek home by Palestinians comes as mediators helped end twin crises over ceasefires in Gaza and Lebanon.

TITLE: A plan to save TikTok. And, Palestinians return to northern Gaza
SUMMARY: Inside the Trump administration's plan to save TikTok. And, tens of thousands of displaced Palestinians are returning home to devastated northern Gaza for the first time in over a year.

TITLE: U.S. stock markets tumble as investors worry about DeepSeek
SUMMARY: The Chinese A.I. company may be about to burst Silicon Valley's bubble.

TITLE: Auschwitz survivors mark Holocaust Remembrance Day 80 years after liberation
SUMMARY: Monday's ceremony in Poland is regarded as the likely last major observance of Auschwitz's liberation that any notable number of survivors will be able to attend, due to their advanced ages.

TITLE: 'The First State of Being' and 'Chooch Helped' win top children's book awards
SUMMARY: This year's Caldecott medal went to a book about an older sister frustrated when her baby brother "helps." The Newbery went to a middle-grade tale about a time traveler at the turn of the century.

TITLE: Trump's immigration orders are a blueprint for sweeping policy changes
SUMMARY: President Trump began his immigration crackdown with a flurry of executive orders. Immigration experts say they lay out how he hopes to transform enforcement at the southern U.S. border and beyond.

TITLE: Elon Musk faces criticism for encouraging Germans to move beyond 'past guilt'
SUMMARY: Musk's comments came two days before International Holocaust Remembrance Day and right after he was criticized for making what many viewers interpreted as a Nazi salute during an inauguration speech.

TITLE: 200 U.K. companies have opted for a four-day workweek, latest data shows
SUMMARY: The industries most represented among the group include marketing and PR, charities and nonprofits, and technology.

TITLE: Oath Keepers founder no longer banned from D.C., U.S. Capitol
SUMMARY: The judge said it was "reasonable" the Justice Department interpreted Trump's Jan. 6 commutations to cover the defendants' prison sentences and wipe away their terms of supervised release.

TITLE: The last of the escaped South Carolina lab monkeys have been recovered
SUMMARY: The female rhesus macaques staged an escape from the Alpha Genesis Primate Research Center in South Carolina last year.

TITLE: Afghans who helped the U.S. are in dangerous limbo after Trump's order on refugees
SUMMARY: Tens of thousands of Afghans who risked their lives working for the U.S. government or military are now in limbo after the Trump administration issued two executive orders targeting refugees.

TITLE: How districts are responding after Trump cleared the way for immigration arrests at schools
SUMMARY: President Trump put an end to a policy that restricted federal agents from making immigration arrests at certain locations, including schools. It's already affecting school staff, kids and parents.

TITLE: Justice Department moves to fire at least 12 officials who investigated Trump
SUMMARY: In termination letters sent to more than a dozen officials, acting Attorney General James McHenry wrote that he did not believe they "could be trusted to faithfully implement the President's agenda."

TITLE: Can Susie Wiles keep Trump on track?
SUMMARY:
Susie Wiles is doing something no woman has done before. She is the first in history to hold the position of White House Chief of Staff.

Now, we will find out if she can do something that no one — man or woman – has ever done before: Impose discipline and order on a Trump White House that was rife with leaks, drama, and by many accounts – chaos – during his first term.

A chief of staff can be the difference between a ground-breaking presidency and chaos. Is Susie Wiles up to the task?
