Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: National Science Foundation freezes grant review in response to Trump executive orders
SUMMARY: The National Science Foundation has canceled all grant review panels this week. It's unclear how long the pause could last.

TITLE: Billionaire investor Scott Bessent is confirmed as Treasury secretary
SUMMARY: Bessent won Senate confirmation with the support of more than two dozen Democrats.

TITLE: Immigration raids have begun. For immigrant and mixed-status families, everyday life has changed.
SUMMARY: The Trump administration has said the raids will focus on criminals who are a public threat. But immigrant communities across the board are bracing, and changing their routines.

TITLE: USAID officials put on leave for allegedly not abiding by executive order
SUMMARY: A message to USAID staff, obtained by NPR, says it will analyze "actions within USAID that appear to be designed to circumvent the President's Executive Order" freezing most foreign aid.

TITLE: Trump signs executive order taking aim at DEI programs in the military
SUMMARY: Trump said the diversity programs discourage merit and leadership, and discriminate on the basis of race and sex. The directive was among a series of orders that seeks to reshape the U.S. military.

TITLE: Ukraine uses souped-up Soviet-era weapons to defend a vital river from Russia
SUMMARY: As Ukraine's line of defense grows thin, this unit is using a modernized Soviet-era vehicle to stop Russian forces from crossing the river and taking Kherson.

TITLE: A museum's confession: why we have looted objects
SUMMARY: An exhibition at San Francisco's Asian Art Museum points to a burgeoning trend: museums are engaging the public more openly around efforts to repatriate artifacts looted from other countries.

TITLE: Big reveals are unlikely in Trump-ordered Kennedy and MLK document drops, experts say
SUMMARY: Historians say the Trump-ordered release of more information on the killings of President John F. Kennedy, Robert F. Kennedy and Martin Luther King Jr., could be interesting but unlikely to rewrite history.

TITLE: News for Trump: Denmark's last envoy to Greenland says U.K. may have first dibs
SUMMARY: Denmark's last minister for Greenland says Britain once claimed right of first refusal over the territory — because of its proximity to Canada, which Britain once ruled.

TITLE: Doctors opposing RFK Jr. rally in the lead-up to his confirmation
SUMMARY: Many health professionals are lining up against Trump's pick for health secretary. They say his anti-vaccine views could cost lives. Some of his supporters embrace his stance.

TITLE: Melania Trump is back in the White House for her second act as first lady
SUMMARY: The role of first lady is unelected, unpaid, and usually comes with zero preparation. But Melania Trump is back in the White House with the most experience someone in her position can have.

TITLE: Danish leader on European tour as nation moves to boost presence around Greenland
SUMMARY: Denmark's prime minister went on a tour of European capitals Tuesday as Europe faces what she called "a more uncertain reality" and her country moves to strengthen its military around Greenland.

TITLE: All the executive orders Trump has signed after 1 week in office
SUMMARY: President Trump signed a slew of orders during his first week in office, impacting policy on immigration, the environment, federal diversity programs and more.

TITLE: DOJ fires officials who investigated Trump. And, what to know about DeepSeek
SUMMARY: At least a dozen Justice Department employees involved in prosecuting President Trump have received dismissal notices. And, why China's DeepSeek AI is such a big deal.

TITLE: If confirmed as HHS secretary, RFK Jr. would have a vast global reach
SUMMARY: As confirmation hearings begin for RFK Jr. nomination as secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services, many are focused on domestic agenda. The agency has a vast global scope as well.

TITLE: A museum's confession: Why we have looted objects
SUMMARY: An exhibition at San Francisco's Asian Art Museum points to a burgeoning trend: museums are engaging the public more openly around efforts to repatriate artifacts looted from other countries.

TITLE: 5 economic papers that lit up our brains — and what they say about our confusing world
SUMMARY: We at Planet Money are constantly reading the work of economists and other social scientists to glean ideas, evidence and insights about the economy, and, more generally, the confusing world around us. Welcome to the inaugural installment of the Planet Money

TITLE: Doctors opposing RFK Jr. rally in the lead-up to his confirmation
SUMMARY: Many health professionals are lining up against Trump's pick for health secretary. They say his anti-vaccine views could cost lives. Some of his supporters embrace his stance.

TITLE: 7 things about RFK Jr. you should know ahead of his Senate hearings
SUMMARY: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has built his fortune and reputation on disparaging the government scientists and institutions he's now in line to lead as HHS secretary.

TITLE: Not your average baby shark: An aquarium welcomes a pup from an all-female tank
SUMMARY: Yoko the swell shark was born in a habitat of all-female sharks who hadn't seen a male in years. The aquarium has two possible explanations — and hopes to get confirmation in the coming months.

TITLE: Trump memo to halt federal funds triggers confusion and constitutional questions
SUMMARY: Washington is scrambling to interpret a new Trump administration memo that appears to halt funding for many programs. The impact of the short memo, released Monday, is causing widespread confusion.

TITLE: Trump fires labor board officials, setting up legal fight
SUMMARY: President Trump fired National Labor Relations Board General Counsel Jennifer Abruzzo. In an unprecedented move, he also ousted Democratic board member Gwynne Wilcox, leaving the board with no quorum.

TITLE: A new book explains what the color blue can teach us about Black history
SUMMARY: Imani Perry traces the history and symbolism of the color blue, from the indigo of the slave trade, to Coretta Scott King's wedding dress, to present day cobalt mining. Her new book is <em>Black in Blues.

TITLE: This shark pup was born in a habitat without any males. How did that happen?
SUMMARY: Yoko the swell shark was born in a habitat of all-female sharks who hadn't seen a male in years. The aquarium has two possible explanations — and hopes to get confirmation in the coming months.

TITLE: Did you plan to buy a home -- but found renting is cheaper? We want to hear from you
SUMMARY: As mortgage rates and home prices have risen, the rent vs. buy calculation has changed. If you're renting when you'd planned to buy, tell us your story.

TITLE: Trump issues order to ban transgender troops from serving openly in the military
SUMMARY: The executive order speaks of transgender identity in sweeping and dismissive terms, and sets the stage for a policy that is more restrictive and punitive than the ban from Trump's first term.

TITLE: DeepSeek: Did a little known Chinese startup cause a 'Sputnik moment' for AI?
SUMMARY: Buzz around DeepSeek built into a wave of concern that hammered tech stocks on Monday.

TITLE: Neymar leaves Saudi team to return to his first soccer club in Brazil
SUMMARY: Neymar struggled through physical injuries for most of his time in the Middle East, with a previous ACL rupture that kept him sidelined for a year.

TITLE: The Louvre will be renovated and the 'Mona Lisa' will have her own room
SUMMARY: French President Emmanuel Macron laid out an ambitious plan for a "reimagined, restored and expanded" Louvre. An art critic says Macron is aiming for another success after restoration of Notre Dame.

TITLE: The company planning a successor to Concorde makes its first supersonic test
SUMMARY: Denver-based Boom Technology's XB-1 demonstrator plane hit Mach 1.122 — 750 mph. It's the first independently developed supersonic jet. The company is also working on a supersonic passenger airliner.

TITLE: The Super Bowl could end in a 'three-peat.' Why that matters to a former NBA coach
SUMMARY: Pat Riley, the current president and former head coach of the Miami Heat, owns half a dozen trademarks related to the word "three-peat." That could affect whether it appears on Super Bowl merch.

TITLE: Trump's 'stop-work' order for PEPFAR cuts off anti-HIV drugs for patients
SUMMARY: As a result of the new administration's actions, health centers funded by PEPFAR, the U.S. President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief, are closing their doors and no longer dispersing medication.

TITLE: Caroline Kennedy calls her cousin, RFK, Jr., a "predator" ahead of his confirmation hearings
SUMMARY: In a letter, Kennedy said RFK Jr. was "unqualified" to be the new U.S. Department of Health and Human Services secretary just hours before he was scheduled to appear for confirmation hearings.

TITLE: Trump has issued a number of orders affecting the military. Here's what they do
SUMMARY: President Trump signed a number of new executive orders Monday night aimed at the U.S. military. Here is a breakdown of what he signed.

TITLE: NJ Attorney General joins suit to stop Trump's federal grant freeze
SUMMARY: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly speaks with New Jersey Attorney General Matthew Platkin about his plans to block a federal funding freeze President Donald Trump ordered Monday.

TITLE: Trump invites nearly all federal workers to quit now, get paid through September
SUMMARY: Through an email blast, federal workers were given the opportunity to resign from their jobs before Feb. 6 and retain full pay and benefits through Sept. 30.

TITLE: Nearly 400 USAID contract employees laid off in wake of Trump's 'stop work' order
SUMMARY: All departments were affected, including offices that address HIV and AIDS, infectious disease and child health.

TITLE: Caroline Kennedy calls her cousin, RFK, Jr., a 'predator' ahead of his confirmation hearings
SUMMARY: In a letter, Kennedy said RFK Jr. was "unqualified" to be the new U.S. Department of Health and Human Services secretary just hours before he was scheduled to appear for confirmation hearings.

TITLE: See you latte: Starbucks plans to cut 30% of its menu
SUMMARY: Starbucks is trying to fix falling sales by changing its vibe back to coffee-house roots. The new CEO says parts of the plan, like free non-dairy milk, are helping bring people back.

TITLE: Trump asks SpaceX to "go get" two stranded ISS astronauts. They're not stranded.
SUMMARY: Two NASA astronauts flew to the International Space Station in June on Boeing's Starliner capsule. The test flight was planned for eight days but technical troubles forced the capsule to return empty.

TITLE: Why members of two of EPA's influential science advisory committees were let go
SUMMARY: Acting EPA Administrator James Payne sent an email to members of the agency's Science Advisory Board and the Clean Air Scientific Advisory Committee informing them that both are being "reset."

TITLE: Trump asks SpaceX to 'go get' two stranded ISS astronauts. They're not stranded
SUMMARY: Two NASA astronauts flew to the International Space Station in June on Boeing's Starliner capsule. The test flight was planned for eight days but technical troubles forced the capsule to return empty.

TITLE: Caroline Kennedy calls her cousin, RFK Jr., a 'predator' ahead of his confirmation hearings
SUMMARY: In a letter, Kennedy said RFK Jr. was "unqualified" to be the new U.S. Department of Health and Human Services secretary just hours before he was scheduled to appear for confirmation hearings.

TITLE: Several people are feared dead in a stampede at massive festival in India
SUMMARY: Millions continued to throng the site even as police urged them to avoid the area. Deadly stampedes are relatively common around Indian religious festivals, where large crowds gather in small areas.

TITLE: 66 million years ago, a fish chewed up and spit out food. It's now a fossil in Denmark
SUMMARY: The fossil was found at a cliff in Denmark. Fossilized vomit is called regurgitalite, and it's a type of trace fossil, which tells scientists about an organism's daily life.

TITLE: Trump signs order restricting gender-affirming care for minors
SUMMARY: President Trump signed an executive order seeking to end gender-affirming medical treatments for children and teenagers under the age of 19.

TITLE: Step inside the secret lab where America tests its nukes
SUMMARY: A thousand feet beneath the desert, the United States conducts experiments to verify that its weapons work. But some fear a live test could come soon.

TITLE: Nearly 5 years after schools closed, the nation gets a new report card
SUMMARY: There's some good news in math, mostly bad news in reading and lots of questions about why students are still struggling.

TITLE: With a new home for DOGE in the White House, here's what you need to know
SUMMARY: The Department of Government Efficiency, a post-election promise brought to life by President Trump via executive order looks different than its original proposal to broadly cut federal spending.

TITLE: Country singer Charley Crockett is 'afraid of getting fenced in'
SUMMARY: Charley Crockett has come a long way from his days busking on the streets of New Orleans. Now, he performs at theaters in front of thousands of people. To cap it all off, he's up for his first Grammy.

TITLE: Here's how climate change fueled the Los Angeles fires
SUMMARY: Extreme conditions helped fuel the fast-moving fires that destroyed thousands of homes. Scientists are working to figure out how climate change played a role in the disaster.

TITLE: Trump signs an order restricting gender-affirming care for minors
SUMMARY: President Trump signed an executive order seeking to end gender-affirming medical treatments for children and teenagers under the age of 19.

TITLE: RFK Jr. says he'll fix the overdose crisis. Critics say his plan is risky
SUMMARY: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. survived heroin addiction and says that if confirmed as head of the Department of Health and Human Services, he'll build treatment "farms" to help people recover.

TITLE: Two ways Trump aims to reshape government. And, how U.S. children are doing in school
SUMMARY: President Trump's actions this week reveal his broad effort to reshape the federal government. And, the new Nation's Report Card shows the pandemic's impact on education nearly five years later.

TITLE: Trump's health secretary pick, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., faces confirmation hearing
SUMMARY: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., President Trump's nominee to lead the Department of Health and Human Services, faces Senate confirmation hearings today. What can we expect?

TITLE: RFK Jr.'s raspy voice is the result of a condition called spasmodic dysphonia. What is it?
SUMMARY: Spasmodic dysphonia is a rare neurological disorder that causes a strained voice. RFK Jr. says he has had the disorder for decades and treats it with Botox injections, a common treatment.

TITLE: Watch live: Confirmation hearing for RFK Jr., Trump's health secretary pick
SUMMARY: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., President Trump's nominee to lead the Department of Health and Human Services, faces Senate confirmation hearings today. What can we expect?

TITLE: The Doomsday Clock has never been closer to metaphorical midnight. What does it mean?
SUMMARY: The Doomsday Clock now stands at 89 seconds to midnight, the closest to catastrophe in its nearly eight-decade history. Here's a look at how — and why — it's moved.

TITLE: The Smithsonian will close its diversity office and freeze federal hiring
SUMMARY: The Smithsonian isn't a federal agency, but it gets much of its funding from federal appropriations.

TITLE: Mona Lisa's roommates may be glad she's moving out
SUMMARY: Now that Leonardo da Vinci's masterpiece is moving to another room at The Louvre, other Renaissance masterpieces hanging in the same space by Titian, Tintoretto and Veronese may finally get their due.

TITLE: Trump rescinds freeze on federal funding
SUMMARY: The development follows a federal judge's order Tuesday that temporarily blocked the effort to pause federal payments for grants and other programs.

TITLE: DOJ asks to dismiss case of 2 men indicted for allegedly helping Trump hide documents
SUMMARY: The DOJ asked a federal court to dismiss its case against two men indicted for allegedly helping Trump conceal classified documents. Prosecutors dropped Trump from the case after his election win.

TITLE: Fearing encounters with ICE, tribal leaders offer guidance to their members
SUMMARY: Tribal leaders are advising members on what to do if they're approached by federal law enforcement. The guidance follows what tribal leaders call concerning encounters with immigration officials.

TITLE: Trump signs first bill of his second presidency, the Laken Riley Act, into law
SUMMARY: The bill is named for a Georgia nursing student who was killed last year by a Venezuelan man without legal status who had a criminal record.

TITLE: Effective immediately: CDC can't talk to WHO. What will that mean for world health?
SUMMARY: Staff at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have been told to halt all communication with the World Health Organization.

TITLE: 'Not a buyout': Attorneys and unions urge federal workers not to resign
SUMMARY: Unions and attorneys who represent federal employees are telling workers not to take the offer from the Trump administration to resign from their jobs by Feb. 6 and still be paid through September.

TITLE: The Federal Reserve holds interest rates steady as inflation remains stubborn
SUMMARY: The Fed held interest rates steady as it continues to combat inflation.  President Trump wants to see lower rates, but some of his policies could fuel more price hikes.

TITLE: White House response adds to confusion on federal funding freeze
SUMMARY: A new OMB memo appeared to say the freeze was reversed, but the White House said only the original memo was rescinded not the freeze itself.

TITLE: Photos: Celebrations commence the Year of the Snake
SUMMARY: For many, the Lunar New Year is a time to reflect on people they have lost. But it's also a time to set intentions and welcome the new energy of the future.

TITLE: Trump ends extension of temporary protected status for hundreds of thousands of Venezuelan migrants
SUMMARY: The move to revoke the extension of temporary protected status would make hundreds of thousands of Venezuelans eligible for deportation.

TITLE: Trump's Mideast envoy visits Gaza before meeting with Netanyahu
SUMMARY: Steve Witkoff helped negotiate the Israel-Hamas ceasefire deal. His visit to Gaza on Wednesday was the first by a senior U.S. official in more than a decade.

TITLE: Hegseth strips Milley of his security detail, orders investigation into his conduct
SUMMARY: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth has ordered an investigation into retired general Mark Milley — who often clashed with President Trump — and determine whether he should be reduced in rank.

TITLE: Ahmed al-Sharaa, who toppled Assad, is named Syria's interim president
SUMMARY: Sharaa was already de facto head of Syria's government ever since a coalition of rebel fighters swept through most of Syria and ousted Assad's regime.

TITLE: New York becomes the first state to close schools for Lunar New Year
SUMMARY: It's the first time New York students will have the day off for the Lunar New Year since a new state law was signed in 2023. In 2024, the holiday fell on a Saturday.

TITLE: Trump's pick for Commerce Secretary is Howard Lutnick. Here's what to know
SUMMARY: The billionaire Wall Street CEO fielded questions about tariffs, China's AI progress, broadband access, allegiance to Trump and the revival of American mining and semiconductor production.

TITLE: Meta agrees to pay Trump $25 million to settle lawsuit over Facebook and Instagram suspensions
SUMMARY: Meta agreed to pay President Trump $25 million to settle a 2021 federal lawsuit alleging First Amendment violations after his suspension from Facebook and Instagram in the wake of the Jan. 6 attack.

TITLE: What would RFK Jr. mean to HHS?
SUMMARY:
Robert F. Kennedy Jr. faced senators today in a contentious confirmation hearing to serve as Health and Human Services Secretary under President Trump. He's a former Democrat — turned independent presidential candidate — turned Trump loyalist.

He's also someone who has pushed vaccine misinformation, something he was repeatedly questioned about during his confirmation hearing on Wednesday.

HHS is a massive system that oversees everything from the Food and Drug Administration to vaccine funding to the Affordable Care Act. What do we know about how Robert F. Kennedy, Jr. would run it?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: Trump orders Education, Labor and other departments to enhance school choice
SUMMARY: The president directed several departments to submit plans for using federal funds to expand school choice.

TITLE: American Airlines plane, helicopter collide midair near D.C.-area airport, FAA says
SUMMARY: Radar tracking sites show the passenger jet appears to have fallen into the frigid Potomac River. Officials at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport say all takeoffs and landings were halted.

TITLE: American Airlines plane, Black Hawk helicopter collide midair near D.C.-area airport
SUMMARY: American Airlines said the jet had 60 passengers and four crew members, while the Pentagon confirmed that three soldiers were aboard the helicopter. There was no immediate word on fatalities.

TITLE: Trump says U.S. will send 'worst criminal illegal aliens' to Guantánamo Bay
SUMMARY: The president says up to 30,000 criminal migrants deported from the United States could be housed at the facility in Cuba, but it wasn't immediately clear how the plan would be implemented.

TITLE: Trump order cracks down on antisemitism and could deport foreign student protesters
SUMMARY: The executive order directs government agencies to use all available tools to prosecute or remove perpetrators of antisemitic harassment and violence, especially on college campuses.

TITLE: After fires, LA students yearn to get back to school, and a normal life
SUMMARY: The historic fires in Los Angeles meant many students lost homes, schools, or both. Now, as some schools reopen, families are trying to find routine.

TITLE: Trans community fears Trump's actions will upend legal precedent on prison protections
SUMMARY: One of President Trump's first executive orders impacts transgender inmates incarcerated in federal facilities. It's just one in a series of actions signed by Trump that target the trans community.

TITLE: Christie Dashiell became a musician at school. Then, she became an artist
SUMMARY: Reflecting on a transformative residency program, the jazz vocalist now nominated for her first Grammy Award says her album <em>Journey in Black

TITLE: Trump's FBI director pick, Kash Patel, faces confirmation hearing
SUMMARY: Kash Patel, President Trump's pick to run the FBI, answers questions Thursday in a public hearing before the Senate Judiciary Committee.

TITLE: Trump's pulling a U-turn on EVs, but not much has changed — yet
SUMMARY: President Trump has charted a new course for electric vehicle policy in the U.S. While the direction is clear, the details aren't.

TITLE: Jesse Eisenberg isn't ambitious — but he does worry about failing
SUMMARY: Actor, writer and director Jesse Eisenberg says he has had more failures than successes. In this week's <em>Wild Card

TITLE: Trump's pick for intel chief, Tulsi Gabbard, faces her confirmation hearing
SUMMARY: Among the topics likely to come up at the hearing: her 2017 meeting with Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, her friendly positions toward Russia and her push to drop charges against Edward Snowden.

TITLE: Criminal records of Jan. 6 rioters pardoned by Trump include rape, domestic violence
SUMMARY: Dozens of Jan. 6 defendants who received pardons from President Trump had past criminal convictions for charges including rape, manslaughter, domestic violence and drug trafficking.

TITLE: As drinks targeting kids have soared, there's new guidance on what's healthy
SUMMARY: As highly caffeinated energy drinks have become popular with kids, a coalition of health organizations has new guidelines on what's a healthy beverage.  Some of the advice may surprise parents.

TITLE: 3 Israeli and 5 Thai hostages freed in Gaza in exchange for Palestinian prisoners
SUMMARY: The exchange is part of a deal between Israel and Hamas that will see a total of 33 hostages returned to Israel in exchange for around 1,900 Palestinian prisoners and detainees.

TITLE: Plane, Black Hawk helicopter collide near D.C. And, Trump's plans for Guantánamo
SUMMARY: An American Airlines plane and a Black Hawk helicopter collided near Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport last night. And, President Trump plans to use Guantánamo as a waystation for deportees.

TITLE: Virginia Senator Tim Kaine reflects on air travel safety following mid-air collision in Washington, D.C.
SUMMARY: NPR's Steve Inskeep talks with Democratic Sen. Tim Kaine of Virginia about airport and air travel safety following the mid-air collision near D.C.'s closest airport.

TITLE: Recipient of pig kidney transplant reaches a milestone
SUMMARY: An Alabama grandmother who was the first patient to receive a new kind of genetically modified pig kidney more than two months ago is now the longest surviving recipient of a pig organ.

TITLE: 3 Israeli and 5 Thai hostages are freed in Gaza in exchange for Palestinian prisoners
SUMMARY: Three more Israeli and five Thai hostages have been released by Palestinian militants from captivity and returned to Israel, after being held for more than 15 months in Gaza.

TITLE: What we know about the midair crash near Washington, D.C.
SUMMARY: There were no survivors in the accident, which happened as a regional passenger jet was attempting to land just before 9 p.m. EST Wednesday at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport.

TITLE: U.S. and Russian figure skaters are among the victims of the D.C.-area plane crash
SUMMARY: At least a dozen figure skaters, coaches and their family members were on the plane that crashed near Washington, D.C., including two teenage competitors and a Russian husband-and-wife coaching duo.

TITLE: The U.S. economy is still doing well as Americans continue to spend
SUMMARY: The U.S. economy grew at an annual rate of 2.3% in the final months of 2024, largely fueled by robust consumer spending.  The economy ended the year 2.5% larger than it was a year earlier.

TITLE: Trump's FCC chief opens investigation into NPR and PBS
SUMMARY: Brendan Carr, the new head of the Federal Communications Commission under President Trump, says the public broadcasters are being investigated for allegedly running commercials.

TITLE: What we know about the midair plane and helicopter crash near Washington, D.C.
SUMMARY: Authorities believe there are no survivors in the accident, which happened as a regional passenger jet was attempting to land Wednesday night at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport.

TITLE: Antidepressants harder to quit than heroin? Fact-checking RFK Jr.
SUMMARY: Fact checking RFK Jr.: No, antidepressants are not harder to quit than heroin.

TITLE: Map: See the aircrafts' paths before they collided near Washington, D.C.
SUMMARY: Investigators say there are likely no survivors in the deadly aircraft collision that occurred Wednesday evening above the icy waters of the Potomac river.

TITLE: Listen: Air traffic controller audio before the midair plane crash near D.C.
SUMMARY: It will be some time before investigators can offer clear answers to the cause of the midair crash at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport but air traffic controller audio and radar reviewed by NPR offer some insight into what happened before.

TITLE: Crash Trump DEI claims
SUMMARY: Without evidence, President Trump and other administration officials claimed that DEI programs led to Wednesday's fatal air crash. DEI has recently become a common talking point to blame disasters on.

TITLE: Crowded airspace has been a concern at Reagan National Airport. Here is what to know
SUMMARY: Lawmakers have expressed concerns about congestion in at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport amid a constricted space.

TITLE: Questions about helicopter's path could prove key in Pentagon probe of midair crash
SUMMARY: Among the unanswered questions about the crash near Washington, D.C., are the flight pattern of the Black Hawk helicopter and the exact nature of its training exercise.

TITLE: FDA upgrades recall of Lay's potato chips to most serious level
SUMMARY: The problem ingredient identified was "undeclared milk," which poses a risk to those with severe sensitivities or allergies.

TITLE: Census Bureau Director Robert Santos is resigning, making way for Trump's pick
SUMMARY: Census Bureau Director Robert Santos is resigning, giving President Trump an early opportunity to nominate an appointee to lead the bureau during key preparations for the 2030 census.

TITLE: Map: See the aircraft's paths before they collided near Washington, D.C.
SUMMARY: Investigators say there are likely no survivors in the deadly aircraft collision that occurred Wednesday evening above the icy waters of the Potomac river.

TITLE: Crowded airspace has been a concern at Reagan National Airport. Here is what to know.
SUMMARY: Lawmakers have expressed concerns about congestion in at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport amid a constricted space.

TITLE: Q&A: OpenAI on rival DeepSeek and partnering with the government
SUMMARY: OpenAI — the company behind ChatGPT and a big part of Stargate — is partnering with the U.S. National Laboratories. NPR's Mary Louise Kelly spoke with OpenAI's Chris LeHane, here are the highlights.

TITLE: RFK Jr., Trump's pick for HHS, grilled about vaccines again in Day 2 hearing
SUMMARY: More dramatic questioning on vaccines in RFK Jr's second confirmation hearing. Bond/Simmons-Duffin/Stone/Webber

TITLE: Trump suggests that deadly airliner crash was the result of diversity hiring
SUMMARY: Without evidence, President Trump and other administration officials claimed that DEI programs led to Wednesday's fatal air crash. DEI has recently become a common talking point to blame disasters on.

TITLE: People with intellectual disabilities do lots of jobs–but they don't direct air traffic
SUMMARY: After the fatal crash over the Potomac River, the President says diversity hiring has made the skies unsafe, but that's not how disability hiring works

TITLE: Senator calls RFK Jr.'s position on race and vaccines dangerous
SUMMARY: In one of the most tense exchanges in a heated confirmation hearing, Senator Angela Alsobrooks called out past comments RFK Jr. made suggesting a different vaccine schedule for Black people.

TITLE: Dick Button, Olympic great and voice of skating, dies at 95
SUMMARY: The winner of two Olympic gold medals and five consecutive world championships, Button died Thursday in North Salem, New York, at age 95.

TITLE: Study finds India doubled its tiger population in a decade
SUMMARY: The study found that some local communities near tiger habitats have also benefited from the increase in tigers because of the foot traffic and revenues brought in by ecotourism.

TITLE: A New Zealand mountain is granted personhood, recognizing it as sacred for Māori
SUMMARY: The recognition acknowledges the mountain's theft from the Māori after New Zealand was colonized. It fulfills an agreement from the country's government to Indigenous people.

TITLE: Did DEI D.I.E.? Welcome to a new kind of 'civil rights' era
SUMMARY:
The new Trump administration is using the language of civil rights but flipping it on its head. If 'diversity' is now being coded as discrimination, what does that mean for the future of civil rights?

Brittany is joined by Columbia Law professor Olatunde Johnson and Pulitzer prize-winning journalist Wesley Lowery to look at how the Trump administration is dismantling federal diversity, equity, and inclusion initiatives and how private businesses are following suit.

Support public media and receive ad-free listening. Join NPR+ today.

TITLE: Going to weddings and birthdays can be pricey. How to cut costs or gracefully decline
SUMMARY: If your social calendar is burning a hole in your wallet, there are steps you can take to spend less while maintaining good relationships.

TITLE: Radhika Veharia reflects on peace — and Grammy acclaim — in a quiet ashram
SUMMARY: In a small ashram nestled on a quiet residential street near Laguna Beach, Radhika Vekaria is finding peace after receiving her first ever Grammy nomination.

TITLE: What is RFK Jr.'s favorite bird? Why is this woman smiling? Find out in the quiz!
SUMMARY: This week was hard on the conflict-averse. But if you're up on nursery rhymes, prehistoric bodily fluids and Renaissance art, you'll get at least three right this week.

TITLE: 8 things to know about Groundhog Day and its big star, Punxsutawney Phil
SUMMARY: The weather-predicting groundhog celebrity has met two presidents and drinks a life-extending elixir: "Our Phil is like, probably 139 years old," Groundhog Club Inner Circle President Tom Dunkel says.

TITLE: Editor's note: Reporting the midair collision will focus on facts and people's stories
SUMMARY: NPR's reporting will continue to focus on what happened and learning what we can about the victims and telling their stories.

TITLE: The latest on the fatal midair plane and helicopter crash
SUMMARY: Video footage of the incident shows the aircraft flying at a low altitude, before an explosion happened at the moment of impact. The National Transportation Safety Board is investigating.

TITLE: Investigation into the fatal plane-helicopter crash. And, future of nuclear testing
SUMMARY: The next steps in the fatal midair plane and helicopter crash investigation. And, why nuclear testing could ramp up in the U.S., as well as a look inside the secret lab where weapons testing happens.

TITLE: Trump wants to cut the federal workforce. Who they are and what that means
SUMMARY: President Trump's efforts to cut the federal workforce by 10% might not save as much money as hoped and could have unintended consequences. NPR explains why.

TITLE: Boston ice skating club reeling after several members killed in D.C.-area plane crash
SUMMARY: A storied Massachusetts skating club lost several members and coaches to the plane crash near Washington, D.C. The club was also affected by the 1961 crash that killed the U.S. Olympic skating team.

TITLE: Radhika Vekaria reflects on peace — and Grammy acclaim — in a quiet ashram
SUMMARY: In a small ashram nestled on a quiet residential street near Laguna Beach, Radhika Vekaria is finding peace after receiving her first ever Grammy nomination.

TITLE: The tech bro who wasn't on Trump's inauguration stage
SUMMARY: Four things NPR's Steve Inskeep learned from LinkedIn co-founder Reid Hoffman in their discussion of his latest book, "Superagency: What Could Possibly Go Right With Our AI Future?"

TITLE: Businesses, shoppers brace for higher prices if tariffs on Mexico and Canada imports start Saturday
SUMMARY: President Trump renewed his threat to impose 25% tariffs on imports from Mexico and Canada as early as this weekend. The move could raise prices on everything from gasoline to guacamole.

TITLE: Legal questions surround Trump's federal worker resignation offer
SUMMARY: More and more questions are being raised about the legality of the Trump administration's offer to nearly all federal workers to resign now and keep their pay through Sept. 30.

TITLE: Search continues for victims and clues behind D.C. plane crash. Here's what to know
SUMMARY: Authorities are combing the Potomac River for a second day in search of victims and more clues behind the deadliest U.S. air crash in over 20 years.

TITLE: The D.C.-area crash recalls some of the deadliest aircraft disasters in U.S. history
SUMMARY: Responders are working to recover the victims of Wednesday night's midair collision over Washington, D.C. It could be the deadliest crash to occur in U.S. airspace in at least 15 years.

TITLE: Costco raises pay above $30 an hour for many, as Teamsters threatens strike
SUMMARY: Costco is raising pay for most workers as Friday night deadline looms on a new contract with its unionized employees.

TITLE: National Science Foundation freezes payments in response to Trump's executive actions
SUMMARY: <em>The National Science Foundation's funding freeze, and wider confusion about the status and future of science funding, is already hampering research.

TITLE: Conflicting signals from Trump could disrupt HIV meds. What's the impact?
SUMMARY: A series of orders from the Trump administration have the potential to disrupt the delivery of life-saving medications to HIV positive people. Here's what a disruption of this drug regimen would mean.

TITLE: International regulators probe how DeepSeek is using data. Is the app safe to use?
SUMMARY: The Chinese chatbot took the world by storm and rattled stock markets. But lost in all the attention was a focus on how the company is collecting and storing data.

TITLE: Rats! Climate change is helping increase their populations in cities
SUMMARY: Winters are getting warmer and shorter as the climate changes. That's helping rat populations grow in several U.S. cities.

TITLE: FAA restricts helicopter flights near DCA airport after mid-air collision
SUMMARY: Federal authorities have restricted helicopter flights near Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport. The move comes days after a deadly collision between a passenger jet and a military helicopter.

TITLE: Costco raises pay above $30 an hour for many, as Teamsters union threatens strike
SUMMARY: Costco is raising pay for most workers as a Friday night deadline looms on a new contract with its unionized employees.

TITLE: Trump administration purges websites across federal health agencies
SUMMARY: Research and basic information on subjects ranging from tuberculosis surveillance to adolescent health disappeared from federal health agency websites.

TITLE: Federal websites down as agencies implement executive order 'defending women'
SUMMARY: After the president singed an executive order "defending women against gender ideology extremism," several federal government websites on gender and sexual health disappear.

TITLE: 5 things to know about the fighting in the Democratic Republic of Congo
SUMMARY: Rwandan-backed M23 rebels say they are now in control of the key eastern Congolese city of Goma. Their fighters continue to claim more territory in one of the world's most mineral-rich territories.

TITLE: Texas is Trump's biggest – and most enthusiastic – partner on immigration overhaul
SUMMARY: Gov. Greg Abbott this week directed state agencies to work with federal immigration authorities to crack down on illegal immigration.

TITLE: Philadelphia plane crash causes fiery scene with multiple homes ablaze
SUMMARY: A small plane crashed in Northeast Philadelphia 30 seconds after it took off, Pennsylvania's governor said Friday. The Federal Aviation Administration said two people were aboard.

TITLE: Map: A look at helicopter traffic patterns over D.C.
SUMMARY: The airspace above Reagan National Airport, where a commercial plane collided with an Army helicopter this week, has become increasingly congested with air traffic, including helicopters.

TITLE: Oscar-nominated actress Karla Sofía Gascón apologizes for old social media posts
SUMMARY: The first openly trans actress to be nominated for an Oscar is facing backlash for old social media posts that denigrate certain marginalized groups. She apologized for the posts through a statement.

TITLE: A 2nd U.S. judge says Trump administration must pause its federal spending freeze
SUMMARY: The decision came in response to a petition by attorneys general in 22 states and Washington, D.C., seeking to block the administration's efforts to freeze payments for grants and other programs.

TITLE: Plane with 6 aboard crashes in Philadelphia, setting homes ablaze
SUMMARY: A medical transport jet crashed in Philadelphia on Friday about 30 seconds after taking off, unleashing a fireball into the night sky and rattling residents after the second U.S. air disaster in as many days.

TITLE: Can Trump's 2nd act work for the working class while giving back to his super donors?
SUMMARY: Trump has shown an affinity with many of the little guys — what he called in 2017 "the forgotten men and women." But he also has shown an affinity with some of the fattest cats of all.

TITLE: Dear Life Kit: My husband is more emotional with his work wife than he is with me
SUMMARY: An NPR listener wonders whether her husband's relationship with a female colleague is too close for comfort. He says she's being competitive for no reason, and that he sees the woman as a 'sister.'

TITLE: 'The Sims,' gaming's ultimate social sandbox, turns 25
SUMMARY: The original launched in February 2000 and spawned one of the most successful franchises in video game history. NPR's Susan Stone went hands-on with <em>The Sims

TITLE: A U.S. dual citizen is among 3 Israeli hostages exchanged for Palestinian prisoners
SUMMARY: Siegel is the first American to be released as part of this deal. A total of 18 hostages have been released since the ceasefire took effect. Hundreds Palestinians have been released so far.

TITLE: An earnest defense of America's silliest holiday: Groundhog Day
SUMMARY: Let's celebrate Groundhog Day, in all its bizarre, quirky strangeness. Let it remind us that we have not subdued nature, but merely made ourselves more comfortable in its domain.

TITLE: Former German President Horst Köhler dies at 81
SUMMARY: Köhler, a onetime head of the International Monetary Fund who became a popular German president before resigning abruptly in a flap over comments about the country's military, has died at 81.

TITLE: Not too hard, not too soft, rotting fruit is just right - for fruit fly maggots
SUMMARY: It turns out, a maggot's preference for rotting fruit has as much to do with texture as taste. Researchers are looking into figuring out why and what neurons are responsible.

TITLE: Prices were a key issue in 2024, but Trump makes clear they're not his top priority
SUMMARY: While prices and the economy were top issues during the campaign, President Trump is making clear that other issues — most notably immigration — are his main focus at the start of his second term.

TITLE: Opinion: Remembering Marianne Faithfull
SUMMARY: NPR's Scott Simon remembers English singer and actor Marianne Faithfull, who died this week at the age of 78.

TITLE: As Trump vows to embrace fossil fuels, U.S. climate policy won't change quickly
SUMMARY: President Trump's first weeks in office included executive orders that aim to stop or roll back former President Biden's ambitious climate agenda and redirect the country's attention to fossil fuels.

TITLE: Three things to know about Rubio's first international trip
SUMMARY: Marco Rubio heads to Latin America on his first trip as secretary of state, including Panama, where President Trump wants control of the canal.

TITLE: Trump fires chief of the federal consumer watchdog agency
SUMMARY: Rohit Chopra had led the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau since 2021. Consumer groups praised his leadership, while Republicans have frequently attacked the agency.

TITLE: Democrats will choose new party leadership today
SUMMARY: Without control of the White House or Congress, the new DNC chair will lead the campaign arm of a Democratic Party that is still figuring out how to move on from rejection at the ballot box.

TITLE: 7 dead, 19 injured after a small medical plane crashes in Philadelphia
SUMMARY: A small plane crashed near a shopping center in northeast Philadelphia on Friday night. The aircraft was carrying a child patient who received medical treatment and was returning home to Mexico.

TITLE: Trump says airstrikes on ISIS in Somalia killed terrorists without 'harming civilians'
SUMMARY: In a Truth Social post Saturday, President Trump announced successful precision airstrikes on the "Senior ISIS Attack Planner," though didn't provide a name for that individual.

TITLE: The Democratic Party votes for new leadership, choosing Minnesota's Ken Martin as chair
SUMMARY: Without control of the White House or Congress, the new DNC chair, Minnesota's Ken Martin, will lead a Democratic Party that is still figuring out its future after a bruising election.

TITLE: Third Black Hawk crew member involved in deadly crash near DC airport identified
SUMMARY: The Army released the identity of the third crew member aboard the Black Hawk helicopter involved in the deadly airport crash near DCA as Capt. Rebecca Lobach, an aviation officer and past ROTC cadet.

TITLE: Trump imposes new tariffs on imports from Mexico, Canada and China in new phase of trade war
SUMMARY: Starting Tuesday, nearly all imports from Canada and Mexico will be charged a 25% tariff,  while goods from China will be charged a 10% tariff.

TITLE: NPR reporters discuss covering the LA wildfires
Investigators search for black box from small plane that crashed in Philadelphia
SUMMARY: NTSB chair Jennifer Homendy said authorities can still complete their investigation without the recording device, but it is a critical piece and its location remains "the biggest question right now."

TITLE: Elon Musk's X sues Lego, Nestlé and more brands, accusing them of advertising boycott
SUMMARY: The new defendants added into the legal filing included Lego, Nestlé, Tyson Foods, Abbott Laboratories, Colgate-Palmolive, Pinterest and Shell International.

TITLE: D.C. crash investigators focus on altitude and vision quality of helicopter crew
SUMMARY: Investigators are still working to piece together key details to determine the cause of the crash that killed 67 people.

TITLE: Did your date give you 'the ick'? Here's the science behind the feeling
SUMMARY: You know that feeling when someone you're dating does this one thing that you just can't look past? Here's what scientists say about why we react this way and whether the feeling is reversible.

TITLE: Israel's Netanyahu heads to U.S. to meet with Trump
SUMMARY: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Sunday he will discuss "victory over Hamas," countering Iran and expanding diplomatic relations with Arab countries in his meeting with President Trump.

TITLE: Astronomers are tracking an asteroid that could hit Earth in 2032
SUMMARY: The odds are about 1% that the football field-sized object could hit the Earth, but that makes it the closest call in more than 20 years.

TITLE: Fidgeting at your desk? Your body may be trying to tell you something
SUMMARY: That spontaneous restless movement plays an important role in our health. Here's what to do the next time you find yourself bouncing your knee or clicking and unclicking your pen.

TITLE: How did racist mass texts bypass some anti-spam guardrails after the election?
SUMMARY: Americans across the country received harmful hate messages via text after the election. The communication industry has been trying to figure out how it happened.

TITLE: On the frontline against bird flu, egg farmers fear they're losing the battle
SUMMARY: The tools the US used to contain previous bird flu outbreaks just aren't working this time, according to some agricultural experts. Some egg farmers have called for vaccinations for poultry.

TITLE: What it's like to party in the native habitat of Groundhog Day star Punxsutawney Phil
SUMMARY: It was a full-on party in Punxsutawney this weekend. "This is my favorite holiday," one local says of the fuss-free day, adding, "You don't have to even see your in-laws."

TITLE: In the LA fires and the NC floods, 'CPR for mental health' treats unseen wounds
SUMMARY: From Altadena to Asheville, people devastated by recent disasters encountered helpers trained in Psychological First Aid. Like CPR, anybody can learn it.

TITLE: Your ears can't prick up, but your ear muscles sure try
SUMMARY: Humans actually have vestigial muscles that activate when listening closely to something, even though people lost the ability to really move their ears about 25 million years ago.

TITLE: Life in Goma, the Congolese city under a new occupation
SUMMARY: A glimpse of life after the siege in the eastern Congolese city of Goma, as some semblance of a tenuous peace returns, as does the fear of reprisals.

TITLE: Why does Musk want USAID 'to die'? And why did its website disappear?
SUMMARY: Under the Trump administration, the U.S. agency that funds aid projects has faced layoffs, a stop action order for most aid efforts and a disruption of its website. Now Elon Musk says it should 'die.'

TITLE: Trump used fentanyl to justify tariffs, but the crisis was already easing
SUMMARY: The White House says fentanyl smuggled to the U.S. justifies tariffs against Canada, China and Mexico. But fentanyl deaths and smuggling have been dropping fast — and Canada plays almost no role.

TITLE: A plane and a tug vehicle collide at Chicago's O'Hare airport, injuring the driver
SUMMARY: The 64-year-old tug driver sustained head and lower body injuries and was transported to the hospital in critical condition but was later stabilized, Chicago police said.

TITLE: Rubio warns of U.S. action if Panama does not curb Chinese influence around the canal
SUMMARY: Secretary of State Marco Rubio threatened unspecified action if Panama does not take steps to lessen Chinese influence over the Panama Canal.

TITLE: Amid high-stakes U.S. diplomatic visit, Panamanians turn to news parodies
SUMMARY: Secretary of State Marco Rubio is in Panama to discuss the Canal. Amid this high-profile visit, Panamanians have been turning to El Gallinazo, an account that posts satirical takes on the news.

TITLE: 55 of the 67 victims have been recovered from the D.C. plane crash
SUMMARY: Rescue and salvage crews are continuing to dig out bodies and debris in the Potomac River, after the deadliest air crash in two decades.

TITLE: Before they were 2025 Grammy Award winners, they were Tiny Desk performers
SUMMARY: Many of the major winners who picked up trophies on music's biggest night have graced the Tiny Desk. Watch their performances here.

TITLE: Africa knew Trump's 'America First' pledge meant it might be last. Then he cut aid.
SUMMARY: Many Africans were caught off guard by the abrupt halt to U.S. foreign aid, stopping money flowing for wide-ranging projects like disease response, girls' education and free school lunches.

TITLE: Vagus nerve stimulation may tame autoimmune diseases
SUMMARY: The next big advance in treating diseases like rheumatoid arthritis could be tiny pulses of electricity delivered to the vagus nerve.

TITLE: Forgotten for 138 years, a Black composer's magnum opus finds a stage
SUMMARY: <em>Morgiane

TITLE: LA Times owner boosts RFK Jr. online, as writer says paper cut his critique
SUMMARY: <em>Los Angeles Times

TITLE: Amid intense grief, a college student is comforted by a stranger on a plane
SUMMARY: When Cara Beth Rogers was studying abroad in college, her brother died in an accident. On the plane ride home, a stranger made her overwhelming grief a bit easier to bear.

TITLE: How corporate America got DEI wrong
SUMMARY: President Trump is accelerating the attacks on diversity-in-business programs. But DEI experts say this may be the wakeup call big companies need.

TITLE: Former Spain soccer official Rubiales goes on trial for unsolicited kiss of player
SUMMARY: The former president of the Spanish soccer federation goes on trial Monday accused of sexual assault for kissing forward Jenni Hermoso after Spain's victory at the Women's World Cup final in 2023.

TITLE: Africa knew Trump's 'America First' pledge meant it might be last. Then he cut aid
SUMMARY: Many Africans were caught off guard by the abrupt halt to U.S. foreign aid, stopping money flowing for wide-ranging projects like disease response, girls' education and free school lunches.

TITLE: How younger generations keep the folk art of lion dancing alive in LA
SUMMARY: At the East Wind Foundation, in the heart of Los Angeles' Chinatown, young people dedicate their after-school hours and weekends to practice the traditional folk art of lion dancing.

TITLE: Two years after derailment, toxic chemicals still roll through East Palestine
SUMMARY: Two years after derailment, toxic chemicals still roll through East Palestine

TITLE: Global stocks slide as Trump imposes tariffs on imports
SUMMARY: Stock markets around the fell as President Trump imposed tariffs on key trading partners, Canada, Mexico and China

TITLE: Changes Trump wants for the Panama Canal. And, the list of Grammy Award winners
SUMMARY: The Trump administration has warned Panamanian leaders that urgent action is required to limit China's influence on the Panama Canal. And, the full list of winners from last night's Grammy Awards.

TITLE: U.S. aid freeze hits secret girls' schools, post-flood repair and much more
SUMMARY: The suspension of foreign aid by the Trump administration is having a worldwide impact. Here's how it has affected projects in Afghanistan and Pakistan.

TITLE: How safe is your weed? Patchy regulations may leave contaminants in the weed supply
SUMMARY: Millions of Americans use cannabis and would like to think the products they buy are safe. But regulation is state by state and full of holes. NPR's new series digs into the risks and solutions.

TITLE: Canadian fans boo U.S. national anthem at NBA matchup as tariff dispute heats up
SUMMARY: Canadians showed their displeasure on Sunday at the Toronto Raptors' game against the LA Clippers in Toronto, Canada. Similar jeers broke out at National Hockey League games over the weekend.

TITLE: Trump has a deal for Netanyahu when they meet Tuesday. Will he take it?
SUMMARY: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu will be the first foreign leader to visit the White House since President Trump's return to office, in a crucial meeting for the future of the Middle East.

TITLE: U.S. stocks, global markets fall on fears of a new trade war
SUMMARY: Stock markets around the fell as President Trump imposed tariffs on key trading partners, Canada, Mexico and China

TITLE: After 138 years, a Black composer's magnum opus finds a stage
SUMMARY: <em>Morgiane

TITLE: Who will call it the Gulf of America? A look at this and other naming disputes
SUMMARY: Google says it will rename the Gulf of Mexico on its U.S. maps, and Mexico is pushing back. This wouldn't be the first body of water to have different names according to different countries.

TITLE: National Science Foundation says it will unfreeze grant money after court order
SUMMARY: While NSF is still reviewing how its grants comply with Trump executive orders, it says it will continue to paying existing grants

TITLE: Trump puts Mexico tariffs on hold for 1 month after a call with the Mexican president
SUMMARY: US tariffs on Mexico to be put on hold for month

TITLE: U.S. stock market recovers some ground on hopes for a trade-war reprieve
SUMMARY: Wall Street is feeling tariff whiplash, plunging and then recovering some ground as President Trump said he would delay at least part of his promised global trade war.

TITLE: Trump targets USAID as Marco Rubio says he's acting head of the embattled agency
SUMMARY: Secretary of State Marco Rubio says he is acting director the U.S. Agency for International Development, following days of upheaval at USAID as the Trump administration froze many of its programs.

TITLE: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent named acting director of consumer watchdog agency
SUMMARY: Bessent, a wealthy Wall Street investor, replaces Rohit Chopra, who was fired on Saturday.

TITLE: These bonobos know what you don't know
SUMMARY: A new study shows that bonobos seem to know a little bit about what's going on in a human companion's mind, and will try to help.

TITLE: What is USAID, the U.S. Agency for International Development?
SUMMARY: Formed in 1961, the agency with a roughly $40 billion budget provides humanitarian assistance abroad and funds other projects to further U.S. interests.

TITLE: 'I wanted to buy her time': A mother looks back on her daughter's terminal cancer
SUMMARY: Sarah Wildman's daughter Orli died at age 14. "She would sometimes ask me, 'What do you think I did to deserve this?' And of course, that's not an answerable question," Wildman says.

TITLE: Trump alleges USAID 'fraud' and puts Rubio in charge as Musk targets the agency
SUMMARY: Secretary of State Marco Rubio says he is acting director the U.S. Agency for International Development, following a pause in foreign assistance and layoffs at USAID.

TITLE: Treasury Secretary Bessent, tapped to run CFPB, orders staff to halt work
SUMMARY: Staff at the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau were instructed by email to cease much of their work. Bessent, a wealthy Wall Street investor, replaces Rohit Chopra, who was fired on Saturday.

TITLE: ACLU sues Trump administration over asylum ban
SUMMARY: The lawsuit alleges Trump's actions go against protections provided by Congress and backed by the courts.

TITLE: Trump pauses tariffs on Canada and Mexico. Here's why it matters to automakers
SUMMARY: The auto industry has built a North American supply chain that ping-pongs parts between the U.S., Mexico and Canada. Tariffs of 25%, if actually imposed, would be costly for buyers and the industry.

TITLE: Navy SEAL was unqualified to lead Tufts lacrosse workout, report finds
SUMMARY: The university will change its approval process for team trainings, among other recommended remedies, after the group workout that left lacrosse players hospitalized in September.

TITLE: Trump puts Canada and Mexico tariffs on hold
SUMMARY: U.S. tariffs on Mexico and Canada will be put on hold for 30 days.

TITLE: Super Bowl ticket prices have been falling, and are down by thousands from last year
SUMMARY: Ticket prices have been dropping over the past few days and many tickets are selling for thousands of dollars less than a year ago.

TITLE: Trump plans to withdraw the U.S. from the United Nations Human Rights Council
SUMMARY: The president's executive order will also cut future funding to the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, which provides aid to Palestinians.

TITLE: The people and the waterway at the center of the Panama Canal
SUMMARY:
The Panama Canal has sat at the center of global trade for more than a century, connecting two oceans. The things Americans use every day pass through here, from gas to food. And now, this spot is also at the center of President Trump's global expansionist agenda.

Secretary of State Marco Rubio has just wrapped up a trip to Panama where he told the President that if China's influence over the canal isn't curbed the United States will take measures to protect its rights.

Trump's threat to take back the Panama Canal has the potential to reshuffle global politics. We're meet the people and the 51-mile waterway in the middle of it all.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: Musk and Trump aim to shut USAID, setting up a showdown with Democrats
SUMMARY: USAID is in the crosshairs of Elon Musk's government efficiency push, sending chills through the humanitarian world and drawing criticism from Democrats and nonpartisan foreign service workers.

TITLE: Elon Musk is barreling into government with DOGE, raising unusual legal questions
SUMMARY: The billionaire's campaign to radically upend federal agencies is stunning former White House officials, even in a political moment when many things are described as unprecedented.

TITLE: Federal judge issues restraining order blocking federal spending freeze
SUMMARY: The order came in response to a memo released by the Office of Management and Budget last week directing agencies to freeze funding for federal grants and other programs.

TITLE: Jail Goodwill store offers job training and a new look on the way out
SUMMARY: At the Elmwood Correctional Facility in Milpitas, Calif., incarcerated women organize and run a Goodwill store, where women nearing release get to shop for clothing.

TITLE: White House defends its 'Fork in the Road' offer to federal employees
SUMMARY: The White House says the federal employees union is doing its members a disservice by urging them not to resign with the promise of administrative leave until September.

TITLE: Trump is weighing big cuts to US Education Department
SUMMARY: While only Congress can shutter the department, the president is reportedly considering executive action to severely scale back its responsibilities and staffing.

TITLE: Rubio says El Salvador will house deportees from U.S., including Americans
SUMMARY: A U.S. official said the Trump administration had no plans to try to deport American citizens. The U.S. government cannot deport American citizens and such a move would be met with legal challenges.

TITLE: Trump is weighing big cuts to the U.S. Education Department
SUMMARY: While only Congress can shutter the department, the president is reportedly considering executive action to severely scale back its responsibilities and staffing.

TITLE: As Trump's new tariffs take effect, China retaliates with a raft of measures
SUMMARY: Trump ordered tariffs against China, Canada and Mexico over the weekend. Canada and Mexico reached last-minute deals to pause those tariffs Monday.

TITLE: China targets U.S. coal, gas, Google as Trump tariffs take effect
SUMMARY: Trump ordered tariffs against China, Canada and Mexico over the weekend. Canada and Mexico reached last-minute deals to pause those tariffs Monday.

TITLE: Pastor pushed out after parishioners complain about focus on racial justice
SUMMARY: Leaders of a Baptist church in North Carolina ousted the pastor after congregants started leaving. A secret tape provides a rare look at the debate when a message threatens a business model.

TITLE: Families buy more sugary cereal if advertising targets kids, not adults
SUMMARY: One of the top sources of added sugar in kids' diets is in their breakfast bowls. A new study shows that advertising drives sales of high-sugar cereals when it's aimed directly at kids under 12.

TITLE: 'Beyond betrayal.' Venezuelans in Florida are angry at Trump immigration policy
SUMMARY: Trump's decision to remove Temporary Protected Status means more than 500,000 Venezuelans may be forced to leave the U.S. Venezuelan Americans, many of whom voted for Trump, call it a betrayal.

TITLE: Why the AI world is suddenly obsessed with a 160-year-old economics paradox
SUMMARY: The primer on Jevons paradox that you didn't know you needed.

TITLE: Syria's new leader denounces Iran, calling its proxies a regional threat
SUMMARY: Syria's interim president says the now departed Iranian forces were damaging to his country and also posed a threat to the wider Middle East.

TITLE: Trump administration adds fine print to "Fork" resignation offer, deepening confusion
SUMMARY: Federal agencies are sending out sample contract agreements to their employees in what appears to be an effort to alleviate doubts. But some of the language differs from the original offer.

TITLE: Even where weed is legal, product safety isn't guaranteed
SUMMARY: Most states allow some sale of cannabis, but testing for pesticides and mold in the weed supply varies from one state to another.

TITLE: Where Trump's tariffs stand. And, the Education Department may see big cuts
SUMMARY: Where President Trump's tariffs stand with Mexico, Canada and China. And, the Education Department may see big cuts to staff and programs.

TITLE: Trump administration adds fine print to 'Fork' resignation offer, deepening confusion
SUMMARY: Federal agencies are sending out sample contract agreements to their employees in what appears to be an effort to alleviate doubts. But some of the language differs from the original offer.

TITLE: The moon's grand canyons were carved in the blink of an eye
SUMMARY: The Earth's Grand Canyon took millions of years to carve, but the moon's grand canyons took about ten minutes.

TITLE: Neil Gaiman's former nanny files rape, human trafficking lawsuit
SUMMARY: The lawsuit alleges that Gaiman coerced sexual services from his former live-in nanny, and that Palmer "knowingly benefited" from Gaiman's actions.

TITLE: RFK Jr. appears on his way to being Trump's health secretary after a party-line vote
SUMMARY: RFK Jr.'s nomination cleared the Senate Finance Committee by a 14-13 party line vote.

TITLE: About 10 people are dead in a shooting at an adult education center in Sweden
SUMMARY: Swedish police said that about 10 people, including the gunman, were killed during a shooting Tuesday at an adult education center.

TITLE: A man was sentenced to 475 years for dogfighting. The sport is surprisingly prevalent
SUMMARY: A man who was arrested with over 100 dogs and equipment at his Georgia home got the maximum sentence last week. Prosecutors hope it sheds light on the prevalence of dogfighting, a felony in the U.S.

TITLE: The first group of migrants has been sent to Guantánamo, but legal challenges loom
SUMMARY: President Trump aims to deport up to 30,000 migrant detainees to a holding facility there, despite the questionable legality of that move.

TITLE: A sense of foreboding hangs over the National Institutes of Health
SUMMARY: There's widespread confusion and fear among scientists and doctors on the sprawling National Institutes of Health campus and at institutions dependent on the agency's funding.

TITLE: Winter storm to move across U.S. but the South will see record high temps
SUMMARY: Parts of the South will see high temperatures while upper parts of the U.S. will see wintry weather.

TITLE: Netanyahu meets Trump with 2nd phase of the ceasefire under negotiation
SUMMARY: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is the first world leader to visit President Trump at the White House since his inauguration.

TITLE: What is the Department of Government Efficiency, or DOGE?
SUMMARY: President Trump said the entity would focus on cutting government waste and slashing federal regulations, and he put tech billionaire and adviser Elon Musk in charge.

TITLE: A guide to what the U.S. Education Department does (and doesn't) do
SUMMARY: The department tracks student achievement, manages college financial aid and sends K-12 schools money to support students with disabilities and lower-income communities, among other things.

TITLE: Miami Beach is continuing to crack down on spring break partiers
SUMMARY: It started last year, when the city launched<strong>

TITLE: Trump administration prepares to withdraw USAID staff from overseas posts by weekend
SUMMARY: "We are being tasked to assist the department in recalling USAID employees to the United States by Saturday," State Department official Seth Green wrote in an email to staff on Tuesday.

TITLE: FBI gives Justice details on employees who worked Jan. 6 cases, FBI agents sue
SUMMARY: The details on FBI employees comes in response to a Justice Department memo last week, asking for names of all current and former FBI personnel who worked on Jan. 6 cases or the prosecution of Hamas leaders.

TITLE: The prospect of immigration agents entering schools is sending shockwaves among communities
SUMMARY: President Trump got rid of a decades-old policy that prevented agents from arresting migrants without legal status in sensitive places, such as schools. Most districts are drawing a line in the sand.

TITLE: Senate votes to confirm Pam Bondi as attorney general
SUMMARY: Bondi was confirmed by a vote of 54 to 46, and will now take the reins at the Justice Department at a moment when it is facing questions about the risk of political influence at the department.

TITLE: DOGE is making major changes to the federal government. Is it legal?
SUMMARY: President Trump said the entity would focus on cutting government waste and slashing federal regulations, and he put tech billionaire and adviser Elon Musk in charge.

TITLE: Trump says he wants the U.S. to take ownership of the Gaza Strip
SUMMARY: Trump said he and Israeli leader Benjamin Netanyahu talked Tuesday about relocating Palestinians and leveling Gaza, which he suggested could be the "Riviera of the Middle East" under U.S. ownership.

TITLE: 'Thank you for your service': Trump administration puts USAID staff on leave
SUMMARY: In a brief note posted on the international development agency's website, almost all employees were told they would be put on leave. The note ended with the words, "Thank you for your service."

TITLE: Greenland bans foreign political donations as Trump seeks the island
SUMMARY: The bill is aimed at protecting "Greenland's political integrity" and will take effect immediately, according to a translation of a parliamentary document in Danish outlining the measure.

TITLE: The Aga Khan, spiritual leader of Ismaili Muslims and a philanthropist, dies at 88
SUMMARY: Considered by followers to be a direct descendant of the Prophet Muhammad, His Highness Prince Karim Aga Khan IV was a student when his grandfather picked him to lead the Shia Ismaili Muslim diaspora.

TITLE: Waffle House is passing along the sky high cost of eggs to diners
SUMMARY: Bird flu is forcing farmers to slaughter millions of chickens a month, pushing U.S. egg prices to more than double their cost in the summer of 2023. And there may be no relief in sight

TITLE: Homeland Security's workforce might not be as big as Trump's immigration goals
SUMMARY: Changes to hiring and retention practices grew the department by 19,000 people in four years. But former officials warn that's still not enough for Trump's ambitious policy goals.

TITLE: Here's how Trump's tariffs could impact you and your wallet
SUMMARY: Tariffs are now in effect on goods from China, and imports from Canada and Mexico could be next (again). Americans are likely to see higher prices on a wide variety of products as a result.

TITLE: Republicans in Congress mostly shrug as Musk and DOGE set sights on spending
SUMMARY: Congress controls the power of the purse, but Republicans on Capitol Hill have put up little resistance to efforts by the administration to suspend spending that they've already approved.

TITLE: A Stradivarius violin could sell for a record sum at auction. Is it worth the hype?
SUMMARY: Stradivarius violins often sell for millions. There's a long history behind them, and violinists who swear they sound better than modern ones.

TITLE: 'We do not exist anymore': New prison rules ban female clothing for trans women
SUMMARY: As federal lawsuits challenge President Trump's executive order impacting trans inmates, the Bureau of Prisons is starting to roll out new policies demanding trans women hand over female-identifying clothing and other items.

TITLE: Philippine vice president impeached by House, faces Senate trial
SUMMARY: Sara Duterte, the daughter of former President Rodrigo Duterte,  has faced at least four impeachment complaints by several legislators and left-wing activist groups over a range of issues.

TITLE: USPS suspends incoming parcels from Hong Kong and China
SUMMARY: Americans are likely to pay more for products from popular Chinese e-commerce platforms like Shein and Temu as the U.S. Postal Service said it would stop accepting parcels from China and Hong Kong.

TITLE: Trump says the U.S. will 'take over' Gaza and relocate its people. What does it mean?
SUMMARY: It wasn't immediately clear what legal authority Trump would have to execute his plans, and they would likely be met by fierce resistance from Palestinians and from regional Arab countries.

TITLE: Trump picks Neil Jacobs to head NOAA, a scientist with 'Sharpiegate' ties
SUMMARY: President Trump has nominated Neil Jacobs to head NOAA. Some former NOAA employees are concerned about Jacobs' scientific integrity after his prior involvement in "Sharpiegate."

TITLE: U.S. cannabis shoppers face a market flush with illegal weed
SUMMARY: In much of the U.S., illegal cannabis outcompetes legal weed sold in licensed shops. For consumers, it can be difficult to find regulated cannabis — but there are tips on how to do that.

TITLE: Trump's proposal for the Gaza Strip. And, what corporations got wrong about DEI
SUMMARY: President Trump announced that he wants the U.S. to take over the Gaza Strip. And, some DEI experts say Trump's attacks on diversity-in-business programs may be the wakeup call big companies need.

TITLE: National Women's Soccer League reaches $5 million settlement over 2021 abuse scandal
SUMMARY: In 2021, revelations about sexual misconduct and racism roiled the NWSL and sparked investigations. Now, the women's soccer league will set aside $5 million for victims and implement other reforms.

TITLE: FireAid concerts raise estimated $100 million for LA wildfire relief
SUMMARY: More than 30 artists, including Olivia Rodrigo, Rod Stewart, Dr. Dre and Joni Mitchell, performed at the benefit concert on Jan. 30.

TITLE: What happens after the 'Fork in the Road'? A lawyer for ex-Twitter employees weighs in
SUMMARY: Shannon Liss-Riordan, who represents thousands of former Twitter employees suing the company, sees many similarities in the predicament of federal workers today. Here's her advice.

TITLE: House Speaker Mike Johnson pledges to support Trump on Gaza
SUMMARY: House Speaker Mike Johnson, R-La., said Wednesday that President Trump is making a bold move by saying the U.S. will "own" Gaza and vowed to stand with Trump on the issue.

TITLE: How a military recruitment crisis is leaving the U.S. vulnerable
SUMMARY: President Trump blames a shortage of recruits on DEI programs, but The New Yorker writer Dexter Filkins says not enough people want to enlist, and many who do don't pass the weight limit or aptitude test.

TITLE: Trump offers deferred resignation to national security and intelligence workers
SUMMARY: The letters are the first examples of the national security and intelligence workforce being included in broader efforts to downsize the federal government by the Trump administration.

TITLE: A brief history of Gaza's tortured role in the Middle East conflict
SUMMARY: Most Gaza residents are the descendants of Palestinian refugees driven to the enclave in a 1948 war. They harbor a deep fear of being uprooted again, and President Trump's remarks struck a raw nerve.

TITLE: DOJ says will not fire FBI agents who acted in 'ethical' way over Jan. 6 cases
SUMMARY: A senior DOJ official in a memo said only agents "who acted with corrupt or partisan intent, who blatantly defied orders from Department leadership, or who exercised discretion in weaponizing the FBI" should be concerned.

TITLE: Judge dismisses case against ex-DA accused of interfering in Arbery murder probe
SUMMARY: A Georgia judge has dismissed a felony case against former Brunswick Judicial Circuit District Attorney Jackie Johnson. She was accused of hindering the investigation into the murder of Ahmaud Arbery.

TITLE: Mass deportations will depend on local police. Only some are offering to help
SUMMARY: Trump's border czar Tom Homan is urging more local law enforcement agencies to support ICE's immigration efforts.

TITLE: U.S. cannabis shoppers face market flush with illegal weed
SUMMARY: In much of the U.S., illegal cannabis outcompetes legal weed sold in licensed shops. For consumers, it can be difficult to find regulated cannabis — but there are tips on how to do that.

TITLE: The Senate has confirmed Scott Turner to lead Housing and Urban Development
SUMMARY: The former NFL player served in the first Trump administration, promoting investment in distressed neighborhoods. Turner has said HUD is "failing at its most basic mission."

TITLE: Would it be legal for Trump to send U.S. citizens to El Salvador's jails?
SUMMARY: President Trump says he would deport American criminals to El Salvador "in a heartbeat" if it were legal. An ACLU attorney tells NPR that such an idea "would be blatantly unconstitutional."

TITLE: Trump's Plan for Gaza: American intervention and mass relocation
SUMMARY:
President Trump floated two stunning ideas about Gaza on Tuesday. The first is he said the U.S. would take over the territory, which has been devastated by the recent war.

And, he said the entire population of Gaza would be relocated to other countries. Trump offered no specifics for his plans sending Palestinians and Israelis scrambling to understand what he means.

President Trump's vague plan to "Make Gaza Beautiful Again" could signal the largest shift in US-Middle East policy in decades and could upend widespread hope for a Palestinian state alongside Israel.
