TITLE: Maryland federal judge blocks Trump's birthright citizenship order
SUMMARY: The preliminary injunction blocks President Trump's efforts to end birthright citizenship. The White House is expected to appeal.

TITLE: China no longer has a de minimis trade exemption. What is it?
SUMMARY: The trade loophole is meant to ease small-scale sales — but critics say it's been abused and gives Chinese firms an unfair advantage.

TITLE: Judge denies Sandy Hook families' deal for a new auction of Alex Jones' Infowars
SUMMARY: The ruling by a U.S. bankruptcy judge in Houston further complicates how and when Jones' bankruptcy case will be resolved and when the families he defamed will be paid.

TITLE: Trump signs order that seeks to ban transgender athletes from women's sports
SUMMARY: President Trump signed an executive order Wednesday aimed at preventing transgender athletes from competing in women's sports. It's the latest in a series of actions focused on "gender ideology."

TITLE: New attorney general moves to align Justice Department with Trump's priorities
SUMMARY: Trump and Attorney General Pam Bondi have both argued the Justice Department under Biden unfairly targeted conservatives, most notably Trump himself.

TITLE: Protesters rally against Trump's stop-work order for USAID
SUMMARY: USAID and nonprofit workers gathered near the Capitol in D.C. to protest Elon Musk's efforts to shut down the aid agency with his Department of Government Efficiency, or DOGE.

TITLE: A new type of bird flu has been found in dairy cows in Nevada
SUMMARY: The strain of bird flu is distinct from what has previously been found in dairy cattle. The finding means the virus has again spilled over from birds to cows, and it raises some worrying questions.

TITLE: Mexico deploys the first National Guard troops to U.S. border after tariff threat
SUMMARY: Trump said he would delay imposing tariffs on Mexico for at least a month. In exchange, Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum promised to send the country's National Guard to reinforce the border.

TITLE: Guatemala gives U.S. another migrant deportation deal
SUMMARY: The agreements potentially help the Trump administration address a key sticking point in immigration enforcement since not everyone in the U.S. illegally can be easily sent back home.

TITLE: Baltic nations count final hours to ending electricity ties to Russia
SUMMARY: The severing of electricity ties to Russia is rich in geopolitical significance. Work on it sped up after Russian President Vladimir Putin ordered the invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: You have more control over your emotions than you think
SUMMARY: In his new book, <em>Shift

TITLE: Why CBS stands at the epicenter of Trump's assault on the media
SUMMARY: CBS News appears likely to settle a lawsuit brought by President Trump in a case that legal observers say it should win. The network is caught up in Trump's broader assault on the media and an owner intent on finalizing a sale.

TITLE: FBI agents, prosecutors fear retribution from Jan. 6 rioters pardoned by Trump
SUMMARY: Officials involved in Jan. 6 prosecutions say the Trump administration isn't protecting them from threats. "We don't think they'll care — unless and until one of us gets killed," an official told NPR.

TITLE: Even now, Ke Huy Quan doesn't feel good enough — but that narrative is changing
SUMMARY: The<em> Everything, Everywhere, All at Once

TITLE: Don't give a hoot about sports? The Superb Owl might be for you
SUMMARY: What began as an accidental misspelling or an online joke has soared into a cultural phenomenon.

TITLE: Here's who will perform at the Super Bowl on Sunday
SUMMARY: Kendrick Lamar is headlining the halftime show with special guest SZA. Jon Batiste will sing the national anthem.

TITLE: Israel defense minister tells army to prepare to relocate Palestinians from Gaza
SUMMARY: He says the military should prepare exit options by land, sea and air so that anyone who wishes to can leave for "any country willing to accept them."

TITLE: Federal resignation deadline looms. And, the implications of  a USAID shutdown
SUMMARY: It's decision day for millions of federal employees who find themselves at a "fork in the road." And, the Trump administration's plans to shut down USAID could have devastating consequences worldwide.

TITLE: As 'Fork' resignation deadline arrives, a federal judge will consider a stay
SUMMARY: The Trump administration has given more than 2 million federal employees until Thursday to decide whether to stay or go. A last-minute court hearing may throw a wrench into the administration's plans.

TITLE: Some federal health websites restored, others still down, after data purge
SUMMARY: While some information has been restored, scientists are still alarmed over the removal of data. It's not clear what has changed, and some pages remain offline.

TITLE: Spinal stimulation restored muscles wasted by rare genetic disorder
SUMMARY: Three patients with spinal muscular atrophy had improved muscle strength and could walk farther after a month of daily spinal stimulation.

TITLE: Trump's calls for U.S. to 'take over' Gaza spurs anger, frustration in Dearborn
SUMMARY: President Trump carried the majority Arab American city in the 2024 election, driven by widespread anger over the Biden administration's handling of the war in Gaza.

TITLE: Trump's anti-trans effort is an agenda cornerstone with echoes in history
SUMMARY: Extremism experts say a now-familiar playbook to scapegoat transgender people in the wake of high-profile tragedies is part of a political strategy to sow division and expand authoritarian control.

TITLE: Israel's defense minister tells the army to prepare to relocate Palestinians from Gaza
SUMMARY: He says the military should prepare exit options by land, sea and air so that anyone who wishes to can leave for "any country willing to accept them."

TITLE: You have more control over your emotions than you think
SUMMARY: In his new book, <em>Shift

TITLE: CISA staffers offered deferred resignations, extending broader cybersecurity fears
SUMMARY: Staff at the key cybersecurity agency were initially excluded from government efforts to leave their jobs, but then on Wednesday they were given deferred resignation offers with just hours to decide.

TITLE: Justice Department sues Chicago and Illinois over 'sanctuary' laws
SUMMARY: The federal lawsuit accuses those jurisdictions of "making it more difficult for, and deliberately impeding, federal immigration officers' ability to carry out their responsibilities."

TITLE: Revenge of the Super Bowl Playlists: Philly Over Everybody
SUMMARY: This Sunday, the Philadelphia Eagles and the Kansas City Chiefs go head-to-head on the championship stage once more. Gear up for the game with this Philly-centric music mix.

TITLE: Today's local history makers: We want to hear who is making Black history near you
SUMMARY: It's Black History Month and the <em>Up First

TITLE: Trump's call for U.S. to 'take over' Gaza spurs anger and frustration in Dearborn
SUMMARY: President Trump carried the majority Arab American city in the 2024 election, driven by widespread anger over the Biden administration's handling of the war in Gaza.

TITLE: Bill Gates is optimistic about the global future, despite a 'scary transition state'
SUMMARY: In a wide-ranging interview with NPR, Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates expressed concern about the new administration's recent steps to pull back from approach to public health but says he's optimistic about the future and wants to find common ground with the White House.

TITLE: Italian politicians allege Donald Trump Jr.'s hunting party killed a protected duck
SUMMARY: Italian politicians want action against a hunting party that included the president's son, who they accuse of allegedly killing a ruddy shelduck. One Italian paper called it the "Donald duck crisis."

TITLE: Bone appétit! Dog treats from lab-grown meat are hitting the U.K. market
SUMMARY: Experts say a fifth of U.K. meat consumption is by pets, not people. If Fido eats lab-grown meat, they say, it could cut the country's carbon footprint.

TITLE: NASA instructs employees to remove pronouns from all work communications
SUMMARY: An e-mail seen by NPR says the move is to comply with a presidential order to "restore biological truth" to the government.

TITLE: U.K.'s foreign office cat Palmerston shows up for duty in Bermuda
SUMMARY: The former rescue feline joined the British diplomatic service in 2016 and gained a large following online for fulfilling his duty with charisma. He retired in 2020 but is back in action now.

TITLE: USAID officials direct staff on 'stunning and irresponsible' cuts to jobs and offices
SUMMARY: Secretary of State Marco Rubio approved less than 300 essential personnel as USAID staff in the U.S. and overseas rush to rapidly close missions and leave jobs by midnight Friday.

TITLE: Historic Black church given 'Proud Boys' trademark calls for stand against hate
SUMMARY: A judge ordered the naming rights of the extremist group the Proud Boys be given to the Metropolitan African Methodist Episcopal Church in Washington, D.C.

TITLE: Bill Gates is optimistic about the global future
SUMMARY: In a wide-ranging interview with NPR, Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates expressed concern about the new administration's recent steps to pull back from approach to public health but says he's optimistic about the future and wants to find common ground with the White House.

TITLE: USAID cut dramatically as officials address 'stunning and irresponsible' changes
SUMMARY: Secretary of State Marco Rubio approved less than 300 essential personnel as USAID staff in the U.S. and overseas rush to rapidly close missions and leave jobs by midnight Friday.

TITLE: Member of Elon Musk's DOGE team resigns after racist posts resurface
SUMMARY: Marko Elez had recently been given special access by a federal judge to highly sensitive payment systems in the Department of Treasury.

TITLE: USAID unions sue Trump administration to halt 'unconstitutional and illegal' cuts
SUMMARY: After Secretary of State Marco Rubio approved less than 300 essential personnel to continue in jobs past Friday, unions representing USAID workers sue the Trump administration over cuts to the agency.

TITLE: Senate Democrats call for answers on health communications freeze and funding delays
SUMMARY: Two letters from different groups of senators call for answers from the Trump administration about pauses in scientific communications and funding.

TITLE: EPA employees who work on environmental justice are put on leave
SUMMARY: In an email obtained by NPR, employees at EPA's Office of Environmental Justice and External Civil Rights were told they were on administrative leave, effective immediately.

TITLE: Alabama puts man to death in the nation's fourth execution using nitrogen gas
SUMMARY: Frazier in his final words criticized Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer for not returning him to serve out a previous life sentence in her state, which doesn't have the death penalty.

TITLE: NCAA bars transgender athletes from women's sports after Trump order
SUMMARY: The move came one day after President Donald Trump signed an executive order intended to ban transgender athletes from girls' and women's sports.

TITLE: Rwanda-backed rebels tell residents of captured eastern Congolese city they are safe
SUMMARY: The rebels continued advances in eastern Congo despite their own announcement of a cease-fire. The U.N. secretary-general called for them to lay down their guns and agree to mediation.

TITLE: Here's how physics could make big crowds safer
SUMMARY:
What do large crowds of people and water have in common? They both act like fluids. When crowds cheer, sway and clump together, the movements look like ripples of water. Researchers hope insights from physics like this one could help officials and engineers create safer crowds at festivals.

Help shape the future of Short Wave by taking our survey: npr.org/shortwavesurvey

Listen to every episode of Short Wave sponsor-free and support our work at NPR by signing up for Short Wave+ at plus.npr.org/shortwave.

TITLE: U.S. education policy is at a crossroads. This congressional hearing shows why
SUMMARY: The House education committee is charged with forging consensus on the nation's education policy. But at a recent meeting, partisan differences were on full display.

TITLE: Do you remember 'Sharpiegate'? What about Roman numerals? Find out in the quiz
SUMMARY: This week calls for some throwback thinking. If you can recall how Roman numerals work, you'll get at least one question correct.

TITLE: Trump's week in review
SUMMARY: An attempt to identify and explain some of the biggest things that happened each week, and draw attention to some that have been overlooked.

TITLE: Trump's executive actions curbing transgender rights focus on 'gender ideology'
SUMMARY: President Trump signed a series of executive actions that would limit transgender and nonbinary people's rights by focusing on "gender ideology." But the term is loaded, without a universal definition.

TITLE: What does Trump mean when he invokes America's 'Manifest Destiny'?
SUMMARY: The 19th century term describes the perceived right of Americans to use force or the threat of force to wrest desireable land from the grasp of others.

TITLE: Here's a Super Bowl riddle: Why are egg prices surging — but not chicken wings?
SUMMARY: There is one economic riddle ahead of Super Bowl Sunday: The egg market has been hit hard by avian flu, but wings are abundant and relatively affordable this year. So what gives?

TITLE: Health care is key for youths getting out of prison. A new law helps them get it
SUMMARY: It's common for young people leaving jails and prisons to end up back behind bars, often after lapses related to untreated mental illness or substance abuse. A new law will help them get Medicaid.

TITLE: Exclusive: GM, Pepsi, Disney, others scrub some DEI references from investor reports
SUMMARY: Some companies have announced diversity rollbacks — but many more are deleting or softening language from their investor disclosures, an NPR analysis finds.

TITLE: Japan's Ishiba to push importance of alliance during visit with Trump
SUMMARY: Trump has long felt that Japan and other wealthy allies take advantage of the U.S., racking up big trade surpluses, while paying too little for the cost of American military protection.

TITLE: Republicans race to release plans to advance Trump policy agenda in Congress
SUMMARY: House Speaker Mike Johnson is working with House Republicans to advance a budget bill that would allow Republicans to pass many of Trump's top policy priorities without threat of a Senate filibuster.

TITLE: It's like 'dead birds flying': How bird flu is spreading in the wild
SUMMARY: That's the way one scientist puts it — referring to how infected wild birds survive long enough to spread it to birds and mammals around the world. And that's a serious risk for human health.

TITLE: Disney, GM and others scrub DEI language, NPR finds. And, unusual virus trends
SUMMARY: Several large U.S. companies deleted some or all DEI references from their most recent annual reports to investors, an NPR analysis finds. And, unusual trends are driving winter respiratory viruses.

TITLE: Flu cases rise again, while COVID takes a back seat
SUMMARY: It's an unusual winter for respiratory illnesses. The flu is peaking twice: once in early January and again in February. Meanwhile, it's the mildest COVID winter since the pandemic began.

TITLE: Why is the Trump administration targeting USAID?
SUMMARY: From Day 1, the Trump team has issued a series of orders and statements aimed at the U.S. Agency for International Development.

TITLE: Trump carries out his 'flood the zone' strategy, creating a week of whiplash
SUMMARY: An attempt to identify and explain some of the biggest things that happened each week, and draw attention to some that have been overlooked.

TITLE: U.S. importers prosecco panic
SUMMARY: President Donald Trump's threats to impose new tariffs on European goods has caused Americans to suddenly stockpile their favorite Italian wines, especially prosecco.

TITLE: The 2025 Super Bowl guide: When is it, who's performing at halftime and how to watch
SUMMARY: From the football field to the halftime stage, here's what to know about the storylines and stakes before Super Bowl 59 kicks off on Sunday.

TITLE:
A search is underway along Alaska's coast for a 
 plane carrying 10 people
SUMMARY: The disappearance marks the third major incident in U.S. aviation in eight days. The Bering Air Caravan, a single-engine turboprop, was heading from Unalakleet to Nome.

TITLE: U.S. Prosecco importers panic as Trump's tariff threat bubbles up
SUMMARY: President Trump's threats to impose new tariffs on European goods has led Americans to suddenly stockpile their favorite Italian wines, especially sparkling Prosecco.

TITLE: "Unprecedented":  White House moves to control science funding worry researchers
SUMMARY: If the Trump administration continues targeting DEI in science and seeking to slash funding, American science will look fundamentally different.

TITLE: Employers added fewer jobs in January -- but the labor market overall remains healthy
SUMMARY: U.S. employers added 143,000 jobs in January — a modest slowdown from the two previous months. The unemployment rate dipped to 4%.

TITLE: Federal election commissioner says Trump is trying to improperly remove her
SUMMARY: Ellen Weintraub, a Democratic member of the Federal Election Commission, says President Trump is trying to improperly remove her from the post.

TITLE: Trump says Japan's Nippon Steel will now invest in U.S. Steel -- not take it over
SUMMARY: The president said Nippon Steel would invest in U.S. Steel rather than take over the storied American manufacturer. He also said DOGE would look for savings at the Pentagon and Education Department.

TITLE: Rape crisis centers see funding delays amid Trump administration spending upheaval
SUMMARY: Groups addressing sexual violence report not getting expected payments from grants that they depend on to keep running.

TITLE: 'Unprecedented':  White House moves to control science funding worry researchers
SUMMARY: If the Trump administration continues targeting DEI in science and seeking to slash funding, American science will look fundamentally different.

TITLE: U.S. prosecco importers panic as Trump's tariff threat bubbles up
SUMMARY: President Trump's threats to impose new tariffs on European goods has led Americans to suddenly stockpile their favorite Italian wines, especially sparkling prosecco.

TITLE: Who is part of Elon Musk's DOGE and what are they doing?
SUMMARY: The scope of DOGE's work and the identities of the people carrying it out isn't fully clear — leaving agencies and government workers in chaos.

TITLE: What's Trump's beef with South Africa?
SUMMARY: Trump has accused South Africa of "human rights violations" and a land grab. The South African government has hit back.

TITLE: Is there a Trump Doctrine for Foreign Policy?
SUMMARY:
A lot of labels have been applied to Trump's foreign policy approach. America First, Isolationist, transactional, imperialist, protectionist. "I'm a nationalist and a globalist" he told the Wall Street Journal during his first term.

In his inaugural address last month, Trump made comments suggesting his foreign policy will be characterized by restraint, saying, in part, success should be defined by the "wars we never get into."

Yet in the same address, he also said, the United States will take back the Panama Canal.

In his first campaign, Trump ran on the idea that the cycle of the United States intervening in the Middle East should come to an end.

And on Tuesday of this week, he said that the U.S. will "take over" the Gaza Strip, after relocating the Palestinians, who live there.

Trump has promised a new approach to American foreign policy. Is there a Trump Doctrine? And what is it?

TITLE: Trump administration pauses $3 billion marked for electric vehicle charging stations
SUMMARY: The Federal Highway Administration said the National Electric Vehicle Infrastructure (NEVI) program is under review. It was part of the Biden administration's clean energy push.

TITLE: Judge pauses Trump order to put USAID employees on administrative leave
SUMMARY: The case, brought by the American Foreign Service Association and the American Federation of Government Employees was intended to block the administration's efforts to dismantle USAID.

TITLE: With the surge in sports betting, the risk of gambling addiction rises too
SUMMARY: Mobile apps have put sportsbooks in the hands of millions, and experts are seeing a surge in betting — and higher risk of problem gambling. As the Super Bowl approaches, a recovering addict shares his story.

TITLE: Chris Jones crying before kickoff? Kansas City Chiefs fans say that's a good sign
SUMMARY: During Chiefs games, defensive tackle Chris Jones is a six-foot-six, 310-pound wrecking ball. But he's become known for showing a softer side during performances of the national anthem.

TITLE: Trump says he is revoking Biden's security clearances
SUMMARY: Former presidents are historically given intelligence briefings after leaving office. But Trump said he was following precedent set by Biden four years ago, when Biden revoked Trump's access.

TITLE: Musk's team takes control of key systems at Consumer Financial Protection Bureau
SUMMARY: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is the latest target of Elon Musk's Department of Government Efficiency.

TITLE: Trump plans to name himself chair of Kennedy Center, fire board members
SUMMARY: The president announced Friday that he would remove multiple board members, including the Chairman, who do not share his vision for a "Golden Age in Arts and Culture."

TITLE: How conspiracy theories about Politico led Trump to cancel subscriptions
SUMMARY: Less than 24 hours after misleading claims started circulating that tied Politico to USAID, the White House vowed to end subscriptions for the insider news outlet's services and others.

TITLE: Morale plummets at the CDC as staff fear job losses
SUMMARY: Staff at the CDC are bracing for a significant reduction in the work force that appears to be targeting staff with the fewest worker protections.

TITLE: 19 states sue to stop DOGE from accessing Americans' personal data
SUMMARY: The case, filed in federal court in New York City, alleges the Trump administration allowed Musk's team access to the Treasury Department's central payment system in violation of federal law.

TITLE: Federal judge blocks DOGE from accessing sensitive US Treasury Department material
SUMMARY: The case, filed in federal court in New York City, alleges the Trump administration allowed Musk's team access to the Treasury Department's central payment system in violation of federal law.

TITLE: 3 Israeli hostages freed for Palestinian detainees and prisoners
SUMMARY: The exchanges are part of a ceasefire agreement between Israel and Hamas.

TITLE: The NFL is removing 'End Racism' from its Super Bowl end zone
SUMMARY: Here's what the decision by America's favorite sports league tells us about "anticipatory obedience."

TITLE: Americans are expected to place more than $1 billion in Super Bowl bets
SUMMARY: Americans are expected to gamble more than $1 billion for Sunday's Super Bowl, according to the American Gaming Association.

TITLE: These researchers have found a scientifically perfect way to cook eggs
SUMMARY: An Italian study published this week has found the way to cook a perfect egg — you'll just need to spend 32 minutes to make it happen.

TITLE: Trump's executive actions are getting challenged as 'arbitrary.' What does that mean?
SUMMARY: At the center of legal challenges against Trump's executive actions is whether he's telling federal agencies to violate a key legal standard established nearly 80 years ago.

TITLE: Trump supporters welcome the first steps in his immigration crackdown
SUMMARY: President Trump kicked off his second term with a dramatic crackdown on immigration. Critics call those moves cruel and unnecessary. But many of Trump's supporters are applauding these early steps.

TITLE: Linda McMahon led WWE and the SBA. The U.S. Education Dept. may be next
SUMMARY: McMahon has a limited background in education, and a long career as a business executive. She'd be stepping into an agency the president hopes to dissolve.

TITLE: Federal judge blocks DOGE from accessing sensitive U.S. Treasury Department material
SUMMARY: The case, filed in federal court in New York City, alleges the Trump administration allowed Musk's team access to the Treasury Department's central payment system in violation of federal law.

TITLE: Opinion: What if football players chose love instead of the game?
SUMMARY: NPR's Scott Simon considers the stenciled messages in the end zones of the Super Bowl — "CHOOSE LOVE" and "IT TAKES ALL OF US" — and imagines how players could take those messages to heart.

TITLE: Stress and uncertainty at Head Start and clinics as federal health funding system sputters
SUMMARY: Many groups that rely on a federal payment portal started experiencing problems accessing funds last week. HHS says "technical issues" are to blame and lag times continue.

TITLE: 2 reasons why a record $1.39B is expected to be bet on the Super Bowl
SUMMARY: Americans are expected to gamble more than $1 billion for Sunday's Super Bowl, according to the American Gaming Association.

TITLE: Russell Vought takes the helm at CFPB as Musk's DOGE accesses key systems
SUMMARY: Vought was an architect of Project 2025. He takes over at the consumer finance watchdog as Elon Musk's representatives gained access to the bureau's systems and accounts, including sensitive data.

TITLE: The American tailgate: Why strangers recreate their living rooms in a parking lot
SUMMARY: There's nothing quite like a tailgate, where fans serve food to strangers who share the same passion. We went to a Philadelphia Eagles tailgate to learn what drives this uniquely American tradition.

TITLE: NIH announces new funding policy that rattles medical researchers
SUMMARY: The National Institutes of Health has dramatically changed its grant-making terms by limiting how much it will disperse for costs such as equipment and administration.

TITLE: Black Altadenans seek hope and resilience in the wake of the LA wildfires
SUMMARY: Residents face the daunting prospect of rebuilding their homes in this once-thriving historically Black community.

TITLE: This Kansas City Chiefs player's Super Bowl outfit carries special meaning
SUMMARY: Many of the players in Sunday's Super Bowl will arrive at the stadium dressed to the nines. But one — Kansas City wide receiver DeAndre Hopkins — will be wearing something extra special.

TITLE: Buffy Sainte-Marie stripped of prestigious Canadian honor
SUMMARY: The Canadian government did not share its reasons for the decision, but it follows an investigation that shed doubt on the Oscar-winning singer's claims of Indigenous roots.

TITLE: What to know about presidents and security clearances
SUMMARY: Both former President Joe Biden and President Trump have barred their predecessor access to classified information. But historically, it wasn't like that.

TITLE: It's not all fur and games. Here's how the Puppy Bowl works
SUMMARY: The Puppy Bowl may look like lawless fun. But there are rules to the annual competition, now in its 21st year. Here's what to know as Team Ruff and Team Fluff hit the turf on Sunday.

TITLE: A Stradivarius violin sells for $11.3 million at auction, falling short of record
SUMMARY: The violin, made over 300 years ago by a legendary luthier, had been expected to sell for a higher price. The proceeds will go toward a scholarship program at the New England Conservatory.

TITLE: Russell Vought takes the helm at CFPB, orders pause in agency activities
SUMMARY: Vought was an architect of Project 2025. He takes over at the consumer finance watchdog as he orders a pause in most of the agency's activities, and promises to cut spending.

TITLE: Sam Nujoma, Namibia's fiery freedom fighter and first president, dies aged 95
SUMMARY: Sam Nujoma, the freedom fighter who led Namibia to independence from apartheid South Africa in 1990 and served as its first president for 15 years, has died. He was 95.

TITLE: The EEOC exists to fight discrimination. Fired official fears a hobbling under Trump
SUMMARY: Jocelyn Samuels was Trump's pick in 2020 to fill a Democratic seat on the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. She was fired in January, accused of embracing "radical ideology."

TITLE: Europe's far-right leaders applaud Trump and downplay threat of possible U.S. tariffs
SUMMARY: The event was organized by Spain's Vox party in Madrid under the banner "Make Europe Great Again." The leaders applauded President Trump's agenda and spoke of the turning point it presented Europe.

TITLE: Super Bowl 2025: The Kansas City Chiefs take on the Philadelphia Eagles in New Orleans
SUMMARY: The Kansas City Chiefs meet the Philadelphia Eagles Sunday for a date with history. The chiefs are trying to become the first NFL team ever to win three Super Bowls in a row.

TITLE: Here are 3 takeaways from Trump's plans to name himself chairman of Kennedy Center
SUMMARY: President Trump plans to fire several Board Members at Washington D.C.'s John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts and indicated that he's naming himself chairman.

TITLE: Egypt to host emergency Arab summit to discuss Palestinian developments
SUMMARY: A statement by the Egyptian foreign ministry said the leaders will gather on Feb. 27 amid alarm in the region over President Trump's proposals regarding the future of Gaza.

TITLE: Searching the entire sky for the secrets to our universe
SUMMARY: A new telescope could launch as early as late February. SPHEREx will look into deep space and also search for organic molecules.

TITLE: Trump plans to become chair of the Kennedy Center. Here are 3 things to know
SUMMARY: President Trump plans to fire several Board Members at Washington D.C.'s John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts and indicated that he's naming himself chairman.

TITLE: Egypt to host Gaza summit as Israel withdraws troops from Netzarim Corridor
SUMMARY: A statement by the Egyptian foreign ministry said the leaders will gather on Feb. 27 amid alarm in the region over President Trump's proposals regarding the future of Gaza.

TITLE: Fired by Trump, EEOC official fears what the anti-discrimination agency will become
SUMMARY: Jocelyn Samuels was Trump's pick in 2020 to fill a Democratic seat on the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. She was fired in January, accused of embracing "radical" ideology.

TITLE: Snow and ice blanket parts of the northern U.S., and more winter weather is on the way
SUMMARY: A mix of snow and ice blanketed a large swath of the northern U.S. over the weekend, after a major winter storm hit parts of the Upper Midwest, the Great Lakes region and the Northeast.

TITLE: Trump 2.0 or Project 2025?
SUMMARY:
Project 2025, is a 900-plus page blueprint for a conservative President. It was unveiled in the spring of 2023, well before Donald Trump had won the republican presidential nomination.

It outlined a suite of very conservative policies that would, for example, outlaw the mailing of abortion pills and abolish the department of education. It even suggests a return to the gold standard.

It became a democratic talking point, so much so that Trump repeatedly distanced himself from the plan and the authors.

But now that Trump is in office, releasing his own detailed plans. A lot of them are strikingly similar to the ones laid out in Project 2025. And one of its chief architects is now the head of the critical Office of Management and Budget.

Trump disavowed Project 2025 during the campaign. Now, as President, is he using it as a playbook?

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: Bestselling novelist Tom Robbins dies at 92
SUMMARY: Robbins dazzled readers with the whimsy and imagination in his books, including Jitterbug Perfume, Skinny Legs and All and Even Cowgirls Get the Blues.

TITLE: Trump defends Elon Musk as 'terrific' during Super Bowl interview
SUMMARY: President Trump calls federal courts blocking Elon Musk "crazy," and predicted the Kansas City Chiefs would win Super Bowl LIX.

TITLE: The best (and worst) Super Bowl commercials... so far
SUMMARY: At a time when every fresh news alert seems to deliver a new seismic jolt about the world – the ads featured in this year's Super Bowl mostly touch on safe subjects we traditionally expect in Big Game commercials: Nostalgia. Comedy. Celebrities. Patriotism. And poignant humanism.

TITLE: Super Bowl 2025: The Philadelphia Eagles lead the Kansas City Chiefs at the end of the first quarter
SUMMARY: The Kansas City Chiefs meet the Philadelphia Eagles Sunday for a date with history. The Chiefs are trying to become the first NFL team ever to win three Super Bowls in a row.

TITLE: See Spot run: Photos from a historic Puppy Bowl
SUMMARY: The pups from Team Fluff weren't the only winners. See freeze-frame highlights from the 21st edition of the Puppy Bowl.

TITLE: Kendrick Lamar and SZA perform at the Super Bowl Halftime Show in New Orleans
SUMMARY: With the biggest captive audience of his career -- around 80,000 fans in the Superdome and millions more at home — Lamar's performance will conjure a medley of hits that could span his 15-year discography, and will feature R&B star SZA as a special guest.

TITLE: The best (and worst) Super Bowl commercials this year
SUMMARY: At a time when every fresh news alert seems to deliver a new seismic jolt about the world – the ads featured in this year's Super Bowl mostly touch on safe subjects we traditionally expect in Big Game commercials: Nostalgia. Comedy. Celebrities. Patriotism. And poignant humanism.

TITLE: Super Bowl 2025: The Philadelphia Eagles lead the Kansas City Chiefs at the end of the 2nd quarter
SUMMARY: The Kansas City Chiefs meet the Philadelphia Eagles Sunday for a date with history. The Chiefs are trying to become the first NFL team ever to win three Super Bowls in a row.

TITLE: Super Bowl 2025: The Philadelphia Eagles rout the Kansas City Chiefs to deny three-peat bid
SUMMARY: The Philadelphia Eagles <a href="https://www.npr.org/2023/02/12/1156401776/super-bowl-57-kansas-city-chiefs-philadelphia-eagles" target="_blank">avenged their 2023 loss

TITLE: Kendrick Lamar brought West Coast hip hop, Uncle Sam and Serena Williams to the Super Bowl
SUMMARY: With the biggest captive audience of his career, Lamar's performance conjures a medley of hits that spans his 15-year discography, and featured R&B star SZA as a special guest.

TITLE: Chinese counter-tariffs to kick in as Trump threatens more to come
SUMMARY: The tariffs from China range from 10% to 15% and are applied to crude oil, liquefied natural gas, farm machinery and select other products from the U.S.

TITLE: Ecuador's conservative incumbent and a leftist lawyer advance to presidential runoff
SUMMARY: Ecuador will choose its next president in a April runoff election after conservative incumbent Daniel Noboa and leftist lawyer Luisa González garnered enough votes Sunday to beat 14 other candidates.

TITLE: Breaking down Trump's pre-Super Bowl interview. And, highlights from the big game
SUMMARY: President Trump became the first sitting president to attend a Super Bowl last night, and fans had mixed reactions. Plus, highlights from the big game and the best (and worst) Super Bowl commercials.

TITLE: Why many Republicans think shrinking Medicaid will make it better
SUMMARY: Republicans proposals to change the public health insurance program for low-income and disabled Americans could amount to more than $2 trillion of cuts over the next decade.

TITLE: Palestinian refugees in Syria have a message for Gazans: Don't leave your land
SUMMARY: Palestinians fled the 1948 Mideast War and took refuge in neighboring Syria. After 77 years, they're still waiting to go back. They are telling Palestinians in Gaza to stay put.

TITLE: Trump says he will impose a 25% tariff on aluminum and steel imports
SUMMARY: Additionally, he plans to announce reciprocal tariffs on "everyone" on Tuesday or Wednesday: "If they charge us, we charge them. That's all," he said. "Every country will be reciprocal."

TITLE: Hamas announces a delay to the next phase of Israeli hostage release
SUMMARY: A Hamas spokesman said it's postponing the release of the next group of Israeli hostages, accusing Israel of preventing Palestinians from returning home in Gaza.

TITLE: Morning news brief
SUMMARY: Trump attends Super Bowl and gives pregame interview, employees at the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau have been told to cease almost all work, Jordan delivers medical aid to Gaza by helicopter.

TITLE: Trump becomes first U.S. president to attend Super Bowl
SUMMARY: President Trump was the first president ever to attend a Superbowl. We catch up on the news from his pregame interview, including his plans to review U.S. military spending.

TITLE: Jordan begins flying medical aid into Gaza by helicopter
SUMMARY: Gaza, devastated after more than a year of war, still has urgent shortages of food and medicine. Jordan has begun flying helicopters into Gaza with medical supplies. NPR joined one of the flights.

TITLE: The Philadelphia Eagles rout the Kansas City Chiefs to deny Super Bowl three-peat
SUMMARY: The Philadelphia Eagles dominated the Kansas City Chiefs to win their second Super Bowl on Sunday. The Eagles vaunted defense stymied Chiefs quarterback Patrick Mahomes and K.C.'s bid to three-peat.

TITLE: New Consumer Financial Protection Bureau chief tells staff to halt almost all work
SUMMARY: It's been a tumultuous few days at the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, the country's consumer finance watchdog, with work grinding to a halt. Hear the latest on what's happened at the bureau.

TITLE: Are pennies worth it? Trump's plan to scrap them didn't come out of nowhere
SUMMARY: President Trump isn't the first politician to call for the end of the penny — but getting rid of it may not be easy. The value of the 1-cent coin has been debated for decades.

TITLE: Three migrants win temporary block from potential transfer to Guantanamo
SUMMARY: It is the first legal hurdle thrown up to the Trump administration as it seeks to send thousands of migrants to a detention facility on the naval base near Cuba.

TITLE: Federal ethics official sues after purported Trump firing
SUMMARY: The head of the independent federal Office of Special Counsel has filed a lawsuit, claiming he was illegally fired by President Trump.

TITLE: Hamas delays next hostage release as it and Israel trade blame for breaking deal
SUMMARY: Hamas said delayed the release of the next group of Israeli hostages, accusing Israel of preventing aid and Palestinians from returning home in Gaza. Israel said Hamas is violating the ceasefire.

TITLE: Judge says Trump administration is not in full compliance with order on spending
SUMMARY: The judge had issued a temporary restraining order against an administration plan to freeze payments for grants and other federal programs, but says the administration has not been fully complying.

TITLE: Judge weighs a longer pause on Trump's resignation offer to federal workers
SUMMARY: A federal judge in Boston is hearing arguments Monday over whether the Trump administration's "Fork in the Road" offer to federal employees can continue. Unions want a temporary restraining order.

TITLE: Top whistleblower advocate sues President Trump, alleging 'unlawful' firing
SUMMARY: The head of the independent Office of Special Counsel claims President Trump illegally fired him, the latest in a string of firings that may violate federal law.

TITLE: Hamas delays the next hostage release, trading blame with Israel for breaking the deal
SUMMARY: Hamas is delaying the release of the next group of Israeli hostages, accusing Israel of preventing aid and Palestinians from returning home in Gaza. Israel said Hamas is violating the ceasefire.

TITLE: What USAID Cuts Look Like Overseas
SUMMARY: The Trump administration is dismantling the United States Agency for International Development, USAID. They had been doing humanitarian work in more than 100 countries. We hear from NPR correspondents around the world about what the agency had been doing on the ground and what it's elimination could mean.

TITLE: Judge further pauses Trump's 'Fork in the Road' resignation offer to federal employees
SUMMARY: A federal judge in Boston extended his pause on the Trump administration's "Fork in the Road" offer to federal employees until he issues a subsequent decision.

TITLE: Congress now has a DOGE Caucus. Here's how its co-chair says it will work
SUMMARY: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly speaks with Rep. Pete Sessions, co-chair of the House DOGE Caucus, on how Congress will work with the Department of Government Efficiency.

TITLE: Trump's ban on gender-affirming care for young people puts hospitals in a bind
SUMMARY: Hospitals and clinics that have offered gender-affirming treatments to transgender youth reacted in a variety of ways to an executive order that aims to halt the care.

TITLE: Bryan Adams concert in Australia is canceled after a 'fatberg' causes sewage overflow
SUMMARY: The blockage was detected near a Perth arena mere hours before Canadian musician Bryan Adams' sold-out show was set to take place. Water authorities warned of wastewater overflow at the venue.

TITLE: Salman Rushdie wrote about his attempted murder. Now he will face his attacker in court
SUMMARY: Hadi Matar, who is on trial for the knife attack against the British author, has also been accused of supporting terrorism and attempting to carry out a fatwa calling for Rushdie's assassination.

TITLE: The Trump administration has stopped work at the CFPB. Here's what the agency does
SUMMARY: It's the main U.S. agency tasked with overseeing the financial products and services used by everyday Americans. The CFPB's new head has closed its offices and told staff to stay home.

TITLE: What DOGE could mean for Medicare and Medicaid?
SUMMARY:
Elon Musk's Department of Government Efficiency is quickly expanding its reach through the federal government.

It recently accessed systems at the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services. Musk and his team now are looking at key payment and contracting systems for Medicare and Medicaid.

That was first reported by the Wall Street Journal.

On X, Musk said he believes quote "big money fraud is happening."

Medicare insures older people. Medicaid offers insurance to low income people and those with disabilities.

These two health insurance programs serve tens of millions of people, and they consume a huge part of federal and state budgets. So how could DOGE impact these services?
