Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: Trump pardons disgraced former Illinois Gov. Rod Blagojevich
SUMMARY: Blagojevich was convicted on corruption charges for trying to sell a Senate seat once held by President Obama. Trump commuted his sentence in 2020.

TITLE: Bill Gates reflects on his youth, beginnings of Microsoft, in new memoir
SUMMARY: In his new memoir, "Source Code," billionaire philanthropist Bill Gates opens up about his adolescence and early adult life.

TITLE: NEW MEXICO BOOK BILL
SUMMARY: Some New Mexico lawmakers are crafting a bill that would withhold state funding from public libraries that remove books for certain reasons — shielding librarians from outside influence.

TITLE: Trump administration targets Education Department research arm in latest cuts
SUMMARY: The Institute of Education Sciences (IES) is responsible for gathering data on a wide range of topics, including research-backed teaching practices and the state of U.S. student achievement.

TITLE: Haitian migrants share stories of abuse as Dominican Republic ramps up deportations
SUMMARY: The alleged human rights violations range from unauthorized home raids to racial profiling to deporting breastfeeding mothers and unaccompanied minors.

TITLE: More than 50 are dead after a bus plunged into a gorge in Guatemala
SUMMARY: At least 55 people are dead after their bus plunged into a gorge and landed under a bridge Monday on the outskirts of Guatemala's capital.

TITLE: Vance to attend international AI and security summits as Ukraine war and tariffs loom
SUMMARY: Vance will likely use the summits to resist further AI regulation while reiterating a common Trump refrain: that military allies need to further ramp up spending that supports NATO and Ukraine.

TITLE: 9 pieces of advice to help you navigate the ups and downs of romance
SUMMARY: Sex and relationship experts share wise words of wisdom on love's thorniest topics, including what to do if a partner cheats and how to talk to your partner about your sex life.

TITLE: Why clearing the brush around Los Angeles won't reduce the wildfire danger
SUMMARY: After thousands of homes were destroyed, many are looking for ways to make Los Angeles safer from wildfires. But clearing dense shrubs on the hillsides could actually make the fire danger worse.

TITLE: As measles cases rise, a new book warns parents not to underestimate the disease
SUMMARY: As childhood vaccinate rates drop in the U.S. outbreaks of measles are rising. In his new book Booster Shots, Dr. Adam Ratner

TITLE: Space telescope finds rare 'Einstein Ring' of light in nearby galaxy
SUMMARY: An Einstein Ring was discovered by the European Space Agency's Euclid space telescope in September 2023.

TITLE: A deep dive on U.S. reading and math scores, and what to do about them
SUMMARY: New research drills down on poor student achievement, and notes some school districts that are beating the odds

TITLE: John Bolton on expanding into Greenland
SUMMARY: John Bolton, Trump's former national security adviser, says making Greenland an American territory or commonwealth could help with security interests of "critical importance" to the United States.

TITLE: Burglary of Joe Burrow's home is linked to a pattern of 'crime tourism,' FBI says
SUMMARY: High-profile burglaries of pro athletes are seen as part of a wider pattern of criminals traveling from South America to target affluent homes in the U.S.

TITLE: Trump and Jordan's king meet on Gaza's future. And, U.S. math and reading scores
SUMMARY: Trump and Jordan's King Abdullah will meet to discuss Gaza's future. And, a deep dive into U.S. reading and math scores — and what schools can do about them.

TITLE: Why economists got free trade with China so wrong
SUMMARY: The "China Shock" is revisited, and it raises questions about why economists failed to see the costs of free trade.

TITLE: Jordan's King Abdullah heads to the White House as Trump pushes a Gaza takeover plan
SUMMARY: It is expected to be one of the toughest meetings of the king's quarter-century reign.

TITLE: Court drops remaining classified documents appeal against Trump's aides
SUMMARY: DOJ had already dropped the case against Trump. Now a federal appeals court has formally dismissed the remainder of that case against Trump's valet Walt Nauta and property manager Carlos De Oliveira.

TITLE: 27 religious groups sue administration over immigration enforcement policy
SUMMARY: 27 religious groups are suing the federal government in response to the Trump administration's policy giving immigration agents more leeway to make arrests at "sensitive locations" like churches.

TITLE: Pope rebukes Trump over migrant deportations and refutes VP Vance's theology
SUMMARY: In a strongly-worded letter to Catholic bishops in the United States, Pope Francis is taking to task the Trump Administration's stance on migrants, and that he's following what he calls a "major crisis" with the initiation of mass deportation.

TITLE: FAA reopens two runways at DCA following helicopter and jet mid-air collision
SUMMARY: The FAA had closed two of DCA's three runways so investigators could piece together how the January accident occurred when an Army Black Hawk helicopter crashed into an American Airlines regional jet.

TITLE: As DOJ drops corruption charges against NYC's mayor, critics see improper influence
SUMMARY: NYC  Mayor Eric Adams praised the DOJ for shelving criminal charges against him.  Critics say the move comes after Adams agreed to partner with Trump on immigration

TITLE: Fort Bragg 2.0: Army base reverts to its old name, but with a new namesake
SUMMARY: A U.S. Army base originally named after a Confederate general, then renamed Fort Liberty, will revert to the name Fort Bragg. Its new namesake is WWII hero Roland Bragg — unbeknownst to his family.

TITLE: Netanyahu threatens to end the Gaza ceasefire unless Hamas releases hostages
SUMMARY: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu threatened to resume hostilities unless Hamas releases hostages under a ceasefire agreement on Saturday. Hamas said Monday it is delaying the hostage release.

TITLE: Russia releases American teacher Marc Fogel from prison
SUMMARY: National Security Adviser Mike Waltz said Fogel was released in what he called "an exchange" with Russia and was on his way back to the United States. Terms of the exchange were unclear.

TITLE: Canned tuna sold at Costco, Trader Joe's recalled over botulism risk
SUMMARY: The voluntary recall covers 13 products sold at major grocery stores in 26 states and the District of Columbia. It was triggered by defective packaging that poses the risk of food poisoning.

TITLE: It's the midweek, and that means more winter storms for much of the U.S.
SUMMARY: Break out those shovels, because storms are about to dump a mess of snow and ice on a large part of the U.S. As of noon Tuesday, at least 20 states were under winter warnings or advisories.

TITLE: GSA staff facing massive cuts and fears of 'nonstop' surveillance
SUMMARY: The remaining employees at the General Services Administration are being warned that their work will be heavily monitored, from their swipes into the office to what they type on their computers.

TITLE: 27 religious groups sue Trump administration over immigration enforcement policy
SUMMARY: 27 religious groups are suing the federal government in response to the Trump administration's policy giving immigration agents more leeway to make arrests at "sensitive locations" like churches.

TITLE: The pope rebukes Trump over migrant deportations and refutes VP Vance's theology
SUMMARY: In a strongly worded letter to Catholic bishops in the United States, Pope Francis is taking to task the Trump administration's stance on migrants, calling it a "major crisis."

TITLE: Two top CFPB officials resign after being ordered to stop all work
SUMMARY: The directors of supervision and enforcement at the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau stepped down, citing the stop work orders issued by Russell Vought, the agency's new acting director.

TITLE: Here we go again: More winter storms are heading for much of the U.S.
SUMMARY: Break out those shovels, because storms are about to dump a mess of snow and ice on a large part of the U.S. As of noon Tuesday, at least 20 states were under winter warnings or advisories.

TITLE: Federal Reserve's Jerome Powell says there's no need to rush on interest rate cuts
SUMMARY: Powell was also asked about the high cost of home ownership and President Trump's trade policies, but as usual, the Fed chair tried to steer clear of politics.

TITLE: Denmark Reacts to Trump's Threats to Take Greenland
SUMMARY: President Trump has made clear his desire for the U.S. to take Greenland saying the territory is vital to U.S. economic security.  Greenland is an autonomous territory of U.S. ally Denmark.  And as we hear, Danes have had a variety of reactions to Trumps words.

TITLE: Jan. 6 video evidence has 'disappeared' from public access, media coalition says
SUMMARY: A coalition of news organizations said in a court filing that video exhibits from a Jan. 6 riot case had "disappeared" from a government platform that provided access to evidence used in court.

TITLE: How the gutting of USAID is reverberating around the world: Worry, despair, praise
SUMMARY: Reactions to the changes in USAID run the gamut. Some leading voices — like Mexico's president — are in favor. Others fear that lives will be lost as health care programs are cut.

TITLE: Judge orders restoration of federal health websites
SUMMARY: The pages that are set to be revived include information for patients about HIV testing and HIV prevention medication, guidance on contraceptives and data on adolescent and youth mental health.

TITLE: Trump says 'we're going back to plastic straws.' Is the paper straw dead?
SUMMARY: President Trump has signed an executive order decrying the "irrational campaign against plastic straws" and directing federal agencies to stop buying paper straws.

TITLE: Trump and Musk appear together in the Oval Office to defend the work of DOGE
SUMMARY: President Trump and Musk stood by their cost-cutting efforts. They said "billions" in waste had already been discovered, but offered few specifics on how they were arriving at those estimates.

TITLE: HUD is bracing as DOGE seeks to cut waste, fraud. Union leaders have a suggestion
SUMMARY: The Trump administration is reviewing contracts across the federal housing agency. Some employees worry about potentially "devastating" cuts, though union leaders also hope some good may come of it.

TITLE: PBS shutters DEI office
SUMMARY: The public broadcaster says it is closing its Diversity Equity and Inclusion (DEI) office to comply with a recent executive order from President Donald Trump.

TITLE: 'Chilling effect': Arts organizations react to end of DEI initiatives from fed agency
SUMMARY: The NEA will no longer fund arts programs that promote DEI or "gender ideology." The federal agency has cancelled grants that have funded programs for underserved communities for more than 20 years.

TITLE: Efforts to fight foreign influence and protect elections in question under Trump
SUMMARY: Staffers at the U.S. cybersecurity agency working on countering foreign disinformation and on election security have been put on leave, according to sources who spoke anonymously for fear of reprisal.

TITLE: White House blocks AP from event for using 'Gulf of Mexico'
SUMMARY: The Associated Press says the White House blocked it from covering an official event on Tuesday because it did not refer to the Gulf of Mexico as the Gulf of America.

TITLE: A giant schnauzer named Monty has won the top prize at the Westminster Kennel Club
SUMMARY: Monty's competition included a bichon frisé called Neal, a Skye terrier named Archer, a whippet and repeat runner-up known as Bourbon and a shih tzu called Comet who's been a finalist before.

TITLE: Trump ally Steve Bannon pleads guilty and avoids jail time in border wall fraud case
SUMMARY: Bannon pleaded guilty in a Manhattan court to one count of scheme to defraud, a low-level felony. The case involved We Build the Wall, a non-profit that Bannon himself once suspected was a scam.

TITLE: Monty the giant schnauzer wins Westminster dog show
SUMMARY: Monty's competition included a bichon frisé called Neal, a Skye terrier named Archer, a whippet and repeat runner-up known as Bourbon and a shih tzu called Comet who's been a finalist before.

TITLE: When her young son was hit by a pickup truck, a stranger ran over to help
SUMMARY: Melissa Barbanell's 7-year-old son was severely injured after being hit by a pickup truck. A stranger, who turned out to be a nurse, let Barbanell know he was going to be OK.

TITLE: She wanted to be a mom. So she chose a cancer treatment that gave her a chance
SUMMARY: New, less damaging treatments are giving some patients the choice to try to preserve their ability to have children after cancer.

TITLE: Elon Musk's DOGE takes aim at agency that had plans of regulating X
SUMMARY: Musk and other Silicon Valley executives have long railed against the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau for its work overseeing the tech industry. Now, Musk hopes to eliminate the agency.

TITLE: Trump funding freeze could leave communities on their own as climate threats grow
SUMMARY: Without federal support, American communities will struggle to deal with a challenge as pervasive as climate change, market analysts and environmental advocates say.

TITLE: Trump official targeting Jan. 6 investigators worked on those cases himself
SUMMARY: The disconnect between Bove's aggressive stance at the time to hold rioters accountable — and his current hostility towards the Jan. 6 probe — has troubled some former colleagues.

TITLE: GSA staff faces massive cuts. And, could NASA launch a Mars mission?
SUMMARY: The General Services Administration plans to cut its budget in half and ramp up monitoring of staff. And, Elon Musk could help propel a NASA Mars program — or delay it for another generation.

TITLE: Republicans split on best path to advance Trump's agenda in Congress
SUMMARY: Republicans may control both chambers of Congress but leaders in the House and Senate have very different ideas about the best way to implement President Trump's agenda.

TITLE: Top Trump administration officials visiting Europe this week
SUMMARY: Top Trump administration officials are in Europe this week, with Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth attending his first NATO meeting and Secretary of State Marco Rubio in Paris to discuss Ukraine.

TITLE: What it would take to send people to Mars
SUMMARY: Proponents of going to Mars see peril and opportunity in Elon Musk's close relationship with Trump. Experts say just getting Americans back to the moon in the near future will be challenging enough.

TITLE: What happens if Trump starts ignoring court rulings? We break it down
SUMMARY: A court finding that the Trump administration did not comply with an earlier order and a recent statement by Vice President JD Vance have some experts warning of a potential constitutional crisis.

TITLE: Trump's Gaza proposal has rattled the Middle East. More surprises are likely
SUMMARY: President Trump has already shaken up the Middle East by suggesting a U.S. takeover of Gaza. More drama could be on the way when the president spells out plans for other parts of the volatile region.

TITLE: Former U.S. ambassador Dennis Ross discusses risks to ceasefire in Gaza
SUMMARY: NPR asks Dennis Ross, a former U.S. ambassador and Middle East Special Envoy, about hostage release deadlines set by President Trump and Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu, as well as other risks to the Gaza ceasefire.

TITLE: His genes forecast Alzheimer's. His brain had other plans.
SUMMARY: Doug Whitney was supposed to develop Alzheimer's by 50. Now scientists are trying to understand why his brain remains healthy at 75.

TITLE: When her young son was hit by a pickup truck, a stranger rushed to help
SUMMARY: Melissa Barbanell's 7-year-old son was severely injured after being hit by a pickup truck. A stranger, who turned out to be a nurse, let Barbanell know he was going to be OK.

TITLE: Modi and Trump's rapport may be tested as Indian prime minister visits Washington
SUMMARY: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi, a nationalist criticized over India's democratic backsliding, has welcomed President Trump's return to the White House. India so far has been spared new tariffs.

TITLE: No relief: Inflation unexpectedly heated up last month
SUMMARY: Inflation remained stubbornly high in January, as grocery, gasoline and shelter costs all rose. Egg prices saw their biggest price hike in almost a decade.

TITLE: January wasn't expected to break global temperature records. But it did.
SUMMARY: The planet has been shattering heat records for the past two years. That was expected to ease in January—and the fact that it didn't has climate researchers worried.

TITLE: Trump defense chief Pete Hegseth rules out a return to Ukraine's prewar borders
SUMMARY: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth says it is "unrealistic" to expect Ukraine to return to its pre-2014 borders and that Europe should take the lead in defending Ukraine.

TITLE: How did Elon Musk became so powerful in the Trump administration?
SUMMARY: New York Times journalist Eric Lipton explains how Musk's companies are benefiting as he cuts federal jobs and agencies, and reporter Teddy Schleifer explains how Musk's political views turned right.

TITLE: Photos: See what happened at the Westminster Dog Show
SUMMARY: A 5-year-old giant schnauzer named, Monty, won the Best In Show title at the 149th Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show.

TITLE: Red, White and Blueland? Trump's Greenland talk sparks some colorful proposals
SUMMARY: President Trump's talk of acquiring Greenland has sparked creative proposals, from a bill to rename the island "Red, White and Blueland" to a satirical petition for Denmark to buy "Califørnia."

TITLE: Tulsi Gabbard confirmed as director of national intelligence, overcoming skepticism
SUMMARY: The former lawmaker faced questions about her level of experience and past comments about autocratic leaders, but ultimately the Senate confirmed her on Wednesday afternoon.

TITLE: How do astronomers track asteroids that could threaten Earth?
SUMMARY: Over the next several weeks, astronomers will be looking closely at an asteroid called 2024 YR4 that could be as big as a football field as they try to determine how likely it is to strike Earth in 2032.

TITLE: Trump says he spoke to Putin about the Ukraine war
SUMMARY: President Trump said he spoke with Russian President Vladimir Putin about the war in Ukraine and other issues, and that they agreed to visit each other's nations and have their teams start negotiations immediately on the conflict.

TITLE: How did Elon Musk become so powerful in the Trump administration?
SUMMARY: New York Times journalist Eric Lipton outlines how Musk's companies are benefiting as he cuts federal jobs and agencies, and reporter Teddy Schleifer explains how Musk's political views turned right.

TITLE: The public lost access to Census Bureau data for days after a Trump order
SUMMARY: After Trump put out an executive order targeting gender identity, the public lost access to many Census Bureau data tables and research reports for days, raising concerns about the data's integrity.

TITLE: Chocolate lovers feel the price pinch this Valentine's Day
SUMMARY: Another cocoa harvest in West Africa has come up short, leading to the worst deficit in decades. That means higher prices for chocolate makers and for shoppers.

TITLE: An asteroid could hit Earth in 7 years. Here's how astronomers are tracking it
SUMMARY: Over the next several weeks, astronomers will be looking closely at an asteroid called 2024 YR4 that could be as big as a football field as they try to determine how likely it is to strike Earth in 2032.

TITLE: Trump spoke with Russia's Putin and Ukraine's Zelenskyy to start talks to end the war
SUMMARY: President Trump says he spoke with the presidents of Russia and Ukraine in separate phone calls Wednesday, discussing the two countries' war and other issues.

TITLE: A hidden Picasso painting from the early Blue Period is revealed by new technology
SUMMARY: Experts analyzing the painting have several theories about why this unidentified woman has remained submerged for more than a century.

TITLE: As judges block broad actions, White House says courts causing constitutional crisis
SUMMARY: Speaking to reporters on Wednesday, White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said that judges blocking Trump administration actions were causing a constitutional crisis.

TITLE: States aim to cut energy costs for low-income households with community solar projects
SUMMARY: Some states are trying to lower electricity costs for low-income households through community solar projects. One solar project in Oregon aims to lower residents' energy bills by up to 45%.

TITLE: Belarus has released 3 from prison, including an American and a journalist
SUMMARY: Andrey Kuznechyk, a journalist with Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, was one of those released from a Belarusian prison after more than three years. The released American has not been named publicly.

TITLE: A second winter storm brings cold, rain and snow to millions
SUMMARY: Heavy West Coast rain means mudslides threaten fire-ravaged California. Millions of Americans elsewhere get snow, rain, extreme cold and some tornadoes.

TITLE: New board elects President Trump chair of Kennedy Center
SUMMARY: "It is a great honor to be chairman of the Kennedy Center, especially with this amazing Board of Trustees. We will make the Kennedy Center a very special and exciting place!" Trump said.

TITLE: Trump says the U.S. will 'own' Gaza — what that could mean for the Middle East
SUMMARY:
The Gaza Strip – ground zero of Israel's war with Hamas – is only about twice the size of Washington, DC. It has about 25 miles of coastline along the Mediterranean Sea, with a population of about 2 million people.

Last week, President Trump proposed relocating those people to other countries in the region, like Egypt and Jordan.

Trump has said the Palestinians would not be allowed to return: UN officials and others say Trump's plan would amount to ethnic cleansing. Despite domestic and international concerns that the U.S. is empire building, Trump continues to double down on his plans for the U.S. to "own" Gaza.

Trump says the U.S. is going to take over Gaza, though he offers few specifics. What could the proposal mean for Palestinians and the broader Middle East?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: Trumps Begins Working to End the War Between Russia and Ukraine
SUMMARY: President Trump had separate phone calls with the leaders of Russia and Ukraine on the same day. Following the calls, Trump posted on social media that both leaders want peace and he said that he wanted negotiations on ending the war between Russia and Ukraine to begin immediately. We hear about what this could mean from NPR's White House correspondent. We also hear about how the U.S. relationship with NATO is expected to change under Trump.

TITLE: Judge declines to block Trump administration's resignation offer to federal employees
SUMMARY: A federal judge ruled that the Trump administration's offer to federal employees to resign now in exchange for pay and benefits through September can go forward.

TITLE: Dozens of CFPB workers are fired as the agency remains shuttered
SUMMARY: Dozens of employees at the bureau were fired by email on Tuesday night amid a stop-work order and closure of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau's headquarters.

TITLE: ACLU and other advocates sue for access to migrants moved to Guantánamo Bay
SUMMARY: The lawsuit alleges the migrants have been "disappeared into a black box" and are unable to communicate with attorneys

TITLE: Trump administration set to purchase $400 million worth of armored Teslas
SUMMARY: That's according to a public State Department procurement document. It comes as ethics experts raise conflict of interest questions about the chief executive of Tesla, Elon Musk, who is a top White House official.

TITLE: As coal plants close, Colorado towns consider nuclear waste storage
SUMMARY: The federal government hopes former coal towns will help the nuclear industry grow, by taking on the decades-long challenge of storing radioactive waste

TITLE: Squeeze into a photo booth for a Valentine's Day smooch
SUMMARY: In honor of Valentine's Day, we stop in at the new Photo Booth Museum in San Francisco to find out how people are using the booths to celebrate their love.

TITLE: 4 decisions that turned SNL into a cultural juggernaut — and 3 mistakes
SUMMARY: Critic Eric Deggans explains how <em>Saturday Night Live

TITLE: Dear Life Kit: My friend kissed me and I liked it. Now he wants to take it back!
SUMMARY: Plus: how to deal with an awful brother-in-law, what to do with a box of mementos you shared with your ex and how to tell a bestie you don't want to go on a couples trip.

TITLE: Some red states report zero abortions. Doctors and researchers say it's not true
SUMMARY: The reports are from 2023, in states where abortion is banned. They contradict what doctors and researchers say is happening on the ground, raising concerns about data integrity.

TITLE: Trump's pick for secretary of education is Linda McMahon. Here's what to know
SUMMARY: McMahon's confirmation proceedings are likely to focus on how she would handle Donald Trump's plans to dissolve the U.S. Education Department.

TITLE: Trump hired Musk as a 'special government employee.' Here's what that means
SUMMARY: Special government employees, or SGEs, are typically hired on a temporary basis as experts or consultants or serve as members of federal advisory committees.

TITLE: Retailers including Trader Joe's and Kroger have begun limiting egg purchases
SUMMARY: Egg farmers have been plagued by widespread outbreaks of bird flu. Experts say it's hard to predict when the industry will bounce back from the illness' effects.

TITLE: New Mexico jury convicts former officer in fatal shooting of Black man at gas station
SUMMARY: Las Cruces police Officer Brad Lunsford's verdict is the latest outcome in cases that prosecutors have linked to systematic brutality against Black people by members of law enforcement.

TITLE: Linda McMahon faces confirmation hearing. And, Trump, Putin agree to meet
SUMMARY: What to know about Trump's pick for education secretary, Linda McMahon, who faces her confirmation hearing today. And, Trump agrees to meet with Putin to kick off talks to end the war in Ukraine.

TITLE: Hamas says it will release hostages as scheduled this weekend
SUMMARY: Israel threatened Tuesday to resume hostilities with Hamas in Gaza unless the militant group releases hostages under the ceasefire agreement.

TITLE: Is Trump the president who will truly set a course for Mars?
SUMMARY: Proponents of going to Mars see peril and opportunity in Elon Musk's close relationship with Trump. Experts say just getting Americans back to the moon in the near future will be challenging enough.

TITLE: Sen. Ted Cruz's list of "woke" science includes self-driving cars, solar eclipses
SUMMARY: Sen. Ted Cruz, R-Texas, says the National Science Foundation has given money to thousands of "Woke DEI" studies. Researchers say that's misrepresenting science and disparaging important research.

TITLE: Trump's pick for secretary of education is Linda McMahon. Here's what to know
SUMMARY: McMahon's confirmation proceedings are likely to focus on how she would handle President Trump's plans to dissolve the U.S. Education Department.

TITLE: Sen. Ted Cruz's list of 'woke' science includes self-driving cars and solar eclipses
SUMMARY: Sen. Ted Cruz, R-Texas, says the National Science Foundation has given money to thousands of "woke DEI" studies. Researchers say that's misrepresenting science and disparaging important research.

TITLE: Trump hired Musk as a 'special government employee.' Here's what that means
SUMMARY: Special government employees, or SGEs, are typically hired on a temporary basis as experts or consultants or serve as members of federal advisory committees.

TITLE: Retailers including Trader Joe's and Kroger have begun limiting egg purchases
SUMMARY: Egg farmers have been plagued by widespread outbreaks of bird flu. Experts say it's hard to predict when the industry will bounce back from the illness' effects.

TITLE: Craft supplier Joann to close 60% of its stores across U.S. as it looks for a buyer
SUMMARY: The move to close 500 stores comes after Joann declared bankruptcy for the second time in less than a year. The closures would leave it with far fewer stores than competitors Hobby Lobby and Michaels.

TITLE: RFK Jr. confirmed as Trump's health secretary, over Democrats' loud objections
SUMMARY: Robert F. Kennedy, Jr. wins confirmation to be President Trump's secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services.  The vote was 52 to 48.

TITLE: As Trump touts Putin talks, NATO allies insist Ukraine and Europe be included
SUMMARY: Several NATO allies stressed that Ukraine and Europe must not be cut out of any peace talks, as Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth denied that the U.S. is betraying Ukraine.

TITLE: After delay, CDC releases data signaling bird flu spread undetected in cows and people
SUMMARY: After going quiet on bird flu, CDC scientists have published a report on its spread among veterinarians. The findings suggest a need for better surveillance.

TITLE: RIP Duo, the Duolingo owl. Why would the company kill its own mascot?
SUMMARY: Duo was fatally hit by a Tesla Cybertruck, the language-learning company announced this week. The snarky owl has been the face of Duolingo for over a decade. Why his sudden demise, and what's next?

TITLE: After Trump announced talks with Russia, Vance to address Munich Security Conference
SUMMARY: In his second major speech in Europe this week, the vice president will address the Munich Security Conference, just after President Trump said he would start talks with Russia over the war in Ukraine.

TITLE: Trump threatens reciprocal tariffs against other countries
SUMMARY: President Trump is threatening to levy taxes on imports to match those other countries charge on U.S. exports.

TITLE: Why Mitch McConnell voted against RFK Jr. for health secretary
SUMMARY: A survivor of childhood polio, Sen. Mitch McConnell was the only Republican in the Senate to vote No. Here's how he explained his vote.

TITLE: A judge extends the pause on Trump's plan to put USAID workers on leave
SUMMARY: A federal judge has ruled to continue for another week the freeze on the Trump administration's plan to put thousands of staffers for the U.S. Agency for International Development on paid leave.

TITLE: Movie Watch: 'Marveling' at the new Captain America, and favorites from Sundance 2025
SUMMARY: Wondering what to watch this weekend? Captain America: Brave New World may have what you're looking for. Plus, two favorites from the Sundance Film Festival.

TITLE: In Panama economic needs threaten to erase a way of life
SUMMARY:
Panama has been looking for solutions to a long-term problem. Every time a ship passes through the Panama Canal, more than 50 million gallons of fresh water from Lake Gatun pour out into the ocean.

Nobody ever thought Panama could run out of water. It is one of the rainiest countries in the world. But a couple years ago, a drought got so bad that the canal had to reduce traffic by more than a third - which had a huge impact on global shipping.

The Panama Canal needs more water. Authorities have decided to get it by building a dam in a spot that would displace more than 2,000 people along the Rio Indio.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: Where is my tax refund?
SUMMARY: If the IRS owes you a tax refund, it should come within 3 weeks of filing. And in a change, 25 states are now participating in the IRS's free online filing program.

TITLE: Thousands of counterfeit Forever postage stamps are seized in Chicago
SUMMARY: Customs and Border Protection agents in Chicago seized nearly 162,000 counterfeit U.S. Forever stamps this past week which the agency said were shipped from China.

TITLE: The Truth Behind Your Valentine's Day Flowers
SUMMARY: Giving a bouquet of flowers to your beloved is a classic Valentine's Day gesture of love. But as we hear from our correspondent in Colombia, growing those flowers comes at a steep environmental cost.

TITLE: 3 top U.S. prosecutors resign over order to drop NYC Mayor Eric Adams corruption case
SUMMARY: The acting U.S. attorney for the Southern District of New York and two top Justice Department officials in Washington, D.C., resigned after the case against New York City's mayor war order dropped.

TITLE: After Trump announced talks with Russia, Vance speaks to European allies
SUMMARY: In his second big speech in Europe this week, the vice president will address the Munich Security Conference, days after President Trump said he would start talks with Russia to end the war in Ukraine.

TITLE: Shonda Rhimes, Issa Rae have cut ties with the Kennedy Center now that Trump is chair
SUMMARY: The Kennedy Center was created by bipartisan legislation signed by former President Eisenhower in 1958. President Trump appointed himself and members of his administration to the board.

TITLE: Sweeping cuts hit recent federal hires as Trump administration slashes workforce
SUMMARY: Employees across several agencies including the U.S. Office of Personnel Management, the Department of Education, the Department of Energy and the General Services Administration have all been affected this week, with many being given notice on Thursday.

TITLE: Digital 2/13: A roller coaster ride for PEPFAR
SUMMARY: The President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief has been the subject of a series of presidential orders and memos that have left uncertainty about how is operates. First: halted as part of the suspension of foreign aid. Then: waivers issued for "life-saving" work. Then: memos issues that would restrict who can receive certain critical HIV prevention medicines -- "pregnant and breastfeeding women" only. We look at the changed landscape of this program, which comes under the auspices of USAID. Melody Schreiber, freelance reporter. Marc Silver, editor. Digital only. Publishing Thursday once Editorial Review weighs in. No radio planned. Grove post: https://app.grovecms.org/cms/content/edit.jsp?id=00000194-fbee-dad6-a1f6-fbfefb9c0000&typeId=d78c02b4-68bd-37b1-b5e7-8c0825a8033e&draftId=00000194-fbf2-d32f-adb7-fbf6e3660000

TITLE: On a second try, Florida Republicans agree on a law to assist Trump's deportations
SUMMARY: The bill passed after Gov. Ron DeSantis and fellow Republicans ended a public dispute. It includes a mandatory death penalty for capital crimes committed by people without legal status.

TITLE: What's happening with the anti-HIV program PEPFAR? It depends whom you ask
SUMMARY: The President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief has been the subject of a series of presidential orders and memos that have left uncertainty about how it operates.

TITLE: Why Aaron Rodgers and the New York Jets broke up
SUMMARY: When you're a Jet you're a Jet all the way … till the Jets decide you're not coming back next season.

TITLE: TikTok is back on the Apple and Google app stores
SUMMARY: Apple and Google removed the app after the Supreme Court upheld a law prohibiting firms from doing business with TikTok as long as it is controlled by China-based ByteDance.

TITLE: Up to 100 more workers are fired at CFPB as staff fear mass layoffs are looming
SUMMARY: About 70-100 employees were terminated at the CFPB, following dozens of recent workers who were fired earlier this week. Agency staff are bracing for even wider layoffs.

TITLE: Unease grows at the CDC as Trump administration keeps grip on research, messaging
SUMMARY: CDC employees can no longer publish documents without review by the executive branch, and must withdraw their names from external papers pending publication.

TITLE: Judge orders Trump administration to temporarily allow funds for foreign aid
SUMMARY: The order allowing funds to flow again applies to existing contracts before Trump issued his Jan. 20 executive order declaring a freeze on foreign assistance.

TITLE: Texas judge fines New York doctor for sending abortion pills to Texas
SUMMARY: The ruling by a Texas judge against a New York doctor for prescribing abortion pills to a woman near Dallas could test "shield laws" in Democratic-controlled states where abortion is legal.

TITLE: Igloo recalls over a million coolers after handle hazard causes fingertip amputations
SUMMARY: Consumers in possession of the coolers are urged to stop using them immediately — and contact Igloo for a free replacement handle.

TITLE: An Israeli raid of a famous Palestinian bookstore stokes censorship fears
SUMMARY: A famous Palestinian-owned bookstore in East Jerusalem was raided by Israeli police, stoking fears of increased censorship.

TITLE: A federal worker tried to take Trump's 'Fork' resignation offer. Here's what happened
SUMMARY: Liz Goggin, a social worker with the Veterans Health Administration, took the offer to resign in exchange for pay and benefits through September.  Then she learned her position was exempt.

TITLE: Which dog breed got robbed — AGAIN — at Westminster? Find out in the quiz!
SUMMARY: This week, we've got little kids, loser dogs, the Super Bowl, '90s power ballads and too much government.

TITLE: This week in DOGE: Elon Musk's role in overhauling 'America, Inc.'
SUMMARY: Elon Musk has emerged as a key figure in President Trump's plans to reshape the government. Here's a recap of this week with the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) team he leads.

TITLE: Parents, are you worried about burnout? Here are 3 red flags to watch out for
SUMMARY: Parenting can keep you on your toes all day. But if you find it so physically and mentally draining you can't enjoy family time, it may be a sign of burnout. Here's what you can do about it.

TITLE: Immigration poll shows growing support for restrictions, but deep divisions remain
SUMMARY: A new NPR/Ipsos poll shows growing support for some restrictions on immigration. Still, many elements of President Trump's sweeping crackdown are unpopular with Democrats and independents.

TITLE: YouTube turns 20 years old today
SUMMARY: Twenty years ago, three former PayPal employees activated the domain name "YouTube.com." The first YouTube video followed soon after.

TITLE: Eating yogurt regularly may reduce the risk of colon cancer, a study finds
SUMMARY: Humans have been eating yogurt for millennia. Ancient texts reference its health-promoting properties. Now a new study finds yogurt may reduce the risk of certain types of colon cancer.

TITLE: New poll shows more support for immigration restrictions. And, this week in DOGE
SUMMARY: Despite divisions over Trump's immigration crackdowns, Americans show growing support for immigration restrictions. And, several top federal prosecutors resign over pressure to drop Eric Adams' corruption case.

TITLE: Rounding up what happened with Elon Musk and DOGE this week
SUMMARY: Elon Musk has emerged as a key figure in President Trump's plans to reshape the government. Here's a recap of this week with the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) team he leads.

TITLE: The next Israeli hostages Hamas will release include U.S. and Russian nationals
SUMMARY: Hamas says it will release three hostages on Saturday, resolving a dispute with Israel that threatened to derail the ceasefire. In exchange, Israel will free dozens of Palestinians from jail.

TITLE: The revolution will be screenshot (hopefully)
SUMMARY: Code Switch's B.A. Parker takes a look at the many ways our digital world is being erased.

TITLE: ICE officers granted access to unaccompanied minors database
SUMMARY: Trump administration officials say the move was necessary "to build a culture of child safety and accountability." But advocates say they fear the administration will use it for immigration enforcement.

TITLE: Did a whale swallow a kayaker? The truth behind the viral video
SUMMARY: A humpback whale briefly engulfed a kayaker off the coast of Chile in an incident caught on camera. Experts say it couldn't have swallowed him even if it wanted to.

TITLE: Elon Musk's team is expected to target the Pentagon soon, pledging cost cuts
SUMMARY: The DOGE team is aiming to cut 8% from next year's defense budget, officials tell NPR.

TITLE: Jordan's military is test-running an air bridge for aid to Gaza
SUMMARY: NPR traveled with Jordan's military on a recent helicopter flight delivering aid to the Gaza Strip, part of a test program since the ceasefire between Israel and Hamas went into effect last month.

TITLE: Layoffs start at CDC, targeting probationary staff
SUMMARY: As many as 1,300 probationary employees at CDC are being let go, at the direction of the Trump administration. The cuts represent around 10% of the agency's workforce.

TITLE: Park Service erases 'transgender' on Stonewall website, uses the term 'LGB' movement
SUMMARY: The website deleted all mentions of "transgender" and "queer" in its history of the Stonewall riots, and only referred to the riots' impact on lesbian, gay and bisexual people.

TITLE: At 74, Wisdom the albatross is welcoming new motherhood once again
SUMMARY: The Laysan Albatross was first banded (or marked) in Hawaii in 1956. Meaning, she could be even older than the current estimate of 74.

TITLE: Will the Eagles visit the White House after Super Bowl win? They didn't last time
SUMMARY: The Eagles pulled out a win over the Kansas City Chiefs this week, but they might opt out of making the traditional visit to 1600 Pennsylvania Ave.

TITLE: President Trump is testing the limits of 'emergency' powers — again
SUMMARY: President Trump has declared multiple national emergencies since taking office. That's helping him act quickly. There are few checks and balances on the emergency powers he's claiming.

TITLE: 'Moss Appreciation Week': a lot of celebration for a very little plant
SUMMARY: Moss Appreciation Week is packed with events both scientific... and also silly. Moss walks, moss talks, moss movies, crafting moss-themed Valentines, and a "gastropod derby" with snails and slugs (for whom moss is a nice moist microclimate).

TITLE: Access to Ukraine's rare earths may help keep U.S. aid flowing
SUMMARY: As the Trump administration publicly hammers out its plans on the Ukraine war, it's also pressing Ukraine for deals in exchange for more aid — including giving the U.S. mining rights for rare earths.

TITLE: Layoffs accelerate at federal agencies with more cuts to come
SUMMARY: Federal agencies continued to lay off workers Friday. The cuts come after President Trump signed an executive order this week directing agencies to prepare for "large-scale" reductions in force.

TITLE: The Iconic Singer of the Syrian Revolution
SUMMARY: Syria is reinventing itself following a 14-year bloody civil war and the rapid crumbling of the regime of Bashar Al-Assad regime in December. As NPR's Emily Feng travelled the country reporting on the new Syria, she kept seeing one man's face on flags, posters and vehicles everywhere she went. So, she decided to find out more about him.

TITLE: Altimeter in Black Hawk helicopter may have malfunctioned before DCA mid-air collision
SUMMARY: The National Transportation Safety Board says altimeter in the Black Hawk helicopter may have malfunctioned before the DCA mid-air collision with an American Airlines jet. All 67 people aboard died.

TITLE: President Trump is testing the limits of emergency powers — again
SUMMARY: President Trump has declared multiple national emergencies since taking office. That's helping him act quickly. There are few checks and balances on the emergency powers he's claiming.

TITLE: A judge orders a temporary thaw to Trump's foreign aid freeze. What will that mean?
SUMMARY: He wrote that there was no explanation "why a blanket suspension of all congressionally appropriated foreign aid" is needed to review programs. But how funds will start flowing again is unclear.

TITLE: Fallout from Eric Adams case continues at the Justice Department
SUMMARY: An order to dismiss the corruption case against New York Mayor Eric Adams has sent the Justice Department into a crisis. Several top prosecutors resigned rather than obey orders to dismiss the case.

TITLE: Former Kennedy Center president speaks out in first interview since her firing
SUMMARY: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly speaks to Deborah Rutter, former head of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, in her first interview since the board installed President Trump as its new chair.

TITLE: Trump firings cause chaos at agency responsible for America's nuclear weapons
SUMMARY: The National Nuclear Security Administration is a semi-autonomous agency within the Department of Energy that oversees the U.S. stockpile of thousands of nuclear weapons. Officials were given hours to fire hundreds of employees.

TITLE: HUD employees are bracing for what they hear will be 'drastic' staff cuts
SUMMARY: As federal layoffs mount, sources say the Trump administration plans a 50% staffing cut at the federal housing agency. The moves come amid an affordable housing shortage and record high homelessness.

TITLE: Federal judge blocks CFPB from laying off more employees
SUMMARY: The ruling from a federal court in Washington, D.C., is a reprieve for CFPB staff who had been bracing for mass layoffs as early as Friday.

TITLE: A Valentine's Day aurora may be visible in the skies of the northern U.S.
SUMMARY: During Valentine's Day weekend, northern parts of America, including Maine, may have a chance of seeing an aurora. But space weather scientists warn that the chances of this happening are slim.

TITLE: Hamas releases three Israeli hostages, the sixth group freed under a ceasefire deal
SUMMARY: In a ceremony surrounded by masked Palestinian militants and rubble from the Gaza war, Hamas released three Israeli hostages holding U.S., Russian and Argentinian citizenships on Saturday.

TITLE: Are immigrants still welcome in Mayor Eric Adams' New York City? We asked New Yorkers.
SUMMARY: New York City's mayor has embraced a more conservative, less immigrant friendly stance. What does that mean for a city that's built it's identity on immigration?

TITLE: Trump officials signal potential changes at NOAA, the weather and climate agency
SUMMARY: Federal workers at the home agency for the National Weather Service are concerned about a potential overhaul by Trump officials focused on cutting government costs.

TITLE: After Watergate, Congress curbed the presidency. Now, Trump is testing those limits
SUMMARY: President Trump's efforts to cut federal programs and fire watchdogs are drawing attention to 1970s-era government reforms.

TITLE: A Valentine's weekend aurora may be visible in the skies of the northern U.S.
SUMMARY: During Valentine's Day weekend, northern parts of America, including Maine, may have a chance of seeing an aurora. But space weather scientists warn that the chances of this happening are slim.

TITLE: How changes to a CDC vaccine panel under Kennedy could reshape policy
SUMMARY: A committee of experts that advises the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is critical in setting national vaccine policy. It's also vulnerable to political interference.

TITLE: Trump's spending cuts target probationary workers. What does the status mean?
SUMMARY: As the Trump administration carries out mass firings of the federal workforce in a push to slash government spending, its targeting probationary workers. Here's what to know about the employee status.

TITLE: Courts block Trump's DOGE actions — chaos, panic not proving to be best legal strategy
SUMMARY: Some legal scholars say that the administration is bungling the chance to expand presidential power.

TITLE: Top federal prosecutor in Washington previously defended Jan. 6 rioters
SUMMARY: Ed Martin advanced bogus claims about election fraud in swing states in 2020, and he spoke at a boisterous rally in Washington the day before the siege on the Capitol.

TITLE: Opinion: Navalny's words of love
SUMMARY: NPR's Scott Simon remembers Russian opposition leader Alexi Navalny, who died a year ago Sunday in a Russian prison.

TITLE: Hamas releases three Israeli hostages, the 6th group freed under a ceasefire deal
SUMMARY: In a ceremony surrounded by masked Palestinian militants and rubble from the Gaza war, Hamas on Saturday released three Israeli hostages holding U.S., Russian and Argentinian citizenships.

TITLE: Tennis' top-ranked Jannik Sinner gets a 3-month ban in doping case settlement
SUMMARY: Sinner accepted the ban in a settlement with the World Anti-Doping Agency. The timing of the ban means the 23-year-old Italian won't miss any Grand Slam tournaments.

TITLE: "Give me the head!" Neuroscientist inspires whale and dolphin research in Brazil
SUMMARY: Time is of the essence for a Brazilian neuroscientist who wants to study whale and dolphin brains before the brains decompose in the heat.

TITLE: Prize-winning pictures: Images from this photo contest show tech changing the world
SUMMARY: The website restofworld got entries from 45 countries for a photo contest focusing on technology. Here are their top picks -- from facial scans for migrants to kids in a Mongolian tent transfixed by of a TV.

TITLE: A 2nd U.S. judge pauses Trump's order against gender-affirming care for trans youth
SUMMARY: A second federal judge paused President Trump's executive order halting federal support for gender-affirming care for transgender youth under 19.

TITLE: 'Give me the head!' Neuroscientist inspires whale and dolphin research in Brazil
SUMMARY: Time is of the essence for a Brazilian neuroscientist who wants to study whale and dolphin brains before the brains decompose in the heat.

TITLE: EEOC seeks to drop gender discrimination case after Trump executive order
SUMMARY: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission moved to drop a suit on behalf of a worker allegedly fired for his sexual orientation and gender identity, arguing the case conflicts with President Trump's executive order.

TITLE: Woman drops suit accusing Sean 'Diddy' Combs and Jay-Z of raping her when she was 13
SUMMARY: The suit was initially filed in October, claiming that the woman was lured by a limousine driver outside the 2000 MTV Video Music Awards and assaulted by the two rappers at an after-party.

TITLE: Doctors order 'absolute rest' for Pope Francis due to respiratory infection
SUMMARY: Doctors prescribed "absolute rest" for Pope Francis, the Vatican said Saturday, a day after the 88-year-old pope was admitted to a hospital following a weeklong bout of bronchitis.

TITLE: German chancellor slams Vance's call for Europe to be inclusive of far-right parties
SUMMARY: Olaf Scholz rebuked U.S. Vice President JD Vance for suggesting that far-right parties should not be shut out of government. Germany's other political parties have refused to work with the far-right AfD.

TITLE: What's it like to report from the Panama Canal?
SUMMARY: A team from NPR's All Things Considered went to Panama to report on the canal there, which has gained attention in recent months due to President Trump's comments about the U.S. taking control of it.

TITLE: Amazon workers vote against unionizing a North Carolina warehouse
SUMMARY: Workers voted against joining a grassroots union called Carolina Amazonians United for Solidarity and Empowerment, or CAUSE

TITLE: Fans in Montreal loudly boo U.S. anthem prior to Americans' 4 Nations game vs. Canada
SUMMARY: It's the second time "The Star-Spangled Banner" drew that reaction in two games the United States has played at the NHL-run international tournament.

TITLE: At least 18 people are dead after a stampede at New Delhi railway station in India
SUMMARY: Many of the victims were Hindu pilgrims who were traveling to the Maha Kumbh festival in northern India. Thousands of people were gathered at the New Delhi railway station waiting to board a train.

TITLE: January 6th ... the board game?
SUMMARY: Fight for America! is a new art installation about democracy that invites audiences to play a war game — battling over the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.

TITLE: Protests are set to take place on Presidents Day. Here is why
SUMMARY: A series of protests against the Trump administration's actions is planned for Presidents Day.

TITLE: Congo says Rwanda-backed rebels occupy a 2nd major city in its mineral-rich east
SUMMARY: Rwanda-backed rebels reached the center of east Congo's second largest city, Bukavu, on Sunday morning in an unprecedented expansion of their reach in their yearslong fighting.

TITLE: Deadly storms sweep through the South, leaving at least nine fatalities
SUMMARY: Kentucky Gov. Andy Beshear said all of the state's 120 counties were impacted by the storm. "The biggest challenge of this event is it's everywhere."

TITLE: Protests are set to take place on Presidents Day. Here's why
SUMMARY: Protests against the Trump administration's actions are planned for Presidents Day. Organizers say they are responding to "the anti-democratic and illegal actions of the Trump administration."

TITLE: Government Accountability official says fraud does exist, but it's not widespread
SUMMARY: President Trump and Elon Musk have vowed to uncover and eliminate fraud in the federal government.

TITLE: Jacob Kiplimo sets new half marathon record, finishes in under 57 minutes
SUMMARY: Kiplimo ran with a vengeance in Barcelona on Sunday — beating the previous fastest half marathon time by a whole 48 seconds.

TITLE: Deadly storms sweep through the South, leaving at least 9 fatalities
SUMMARY: Kentucky Gov. Andy Beshear said all of the state's 120 counties were impacted by the storm. "The biggest challenge of this event is it's everywhere."

TITLE: European leaders scramble ahead of Trump Ukraine summit with Putin
SUMMARY: European leaders were hopeful they could work with the Trump administration on the Ukraine war and other issues. But comments last week by several U.S. officials have poured cold water on such hopes.

TITLE: European leaders scramble ahead of Trump's Ukraine summit with Putin
SUMMARY: European leaders were hopeful they could work with the Trump administration on the Ukraine war and other issues. But comments last week by several U.S. officials have poured cold water on such hopes.

TITLE: She suspected a heart attack, but was diagnosed with broken heart syndrome
SUMMARY: Broken Heart Syndrome mimics symptoms of a heart attack. It can strike after a stressful event, such as the loss of a loved one, a physical shock, or prolonged anxiety. The good news: It's treatable.

TITLE: Some performers canceled their Kennedy Center shows. Here's why W. Kamau Bell didn't
SUMMARY: Comedian W. Kamau Bell speaks with NPR's Michel Martin about his decision to perform at the Kennedy Center after President Donald Trump assumed the organization's chairmanship.

TITLE: A former NASA scientist has big dreams for his small business. Will Trump dash them?
SUMMARY: Ryan Dowdy, a former NASA food scientist, won a USDA innovation grant to further develop a meal replacement bar for first responders. Trump's freeze on government awards has jeopardized those plans.

TITLE: Train hoppers ride the rails across America — and you can tag along
SUMMARY: Civil War-era hobos hopped trains to find work. Content creators hop trains with their GoPros. Hitching rides on the railroad is an American tradition.

TITLE: A fired national park ranger lost his dream job. He says the public is losing more
SUMMARY: Brian Gibbs was an environmental educator at Effigy Mounds National Monument in Iowa. His job was among those nixed by the Trump administration as it pushes to shrink federal spending.

TITLE: A look at Trump's first month in office. And, how to beat parental burnout
SUMMARY: Trump was sworn into his second term four weeks ago. Here's a look at what he's done since then. And, Marco Rubio takes his first trip to the Middle East as secretary of state.

TITLE: Paris Emergency Summit, Marco Rubio in the Middle East, Trump's First Month
SUMMARY:
European leaders meet in Paris to discuss an emerging transatlantic chasm over security and the war in Ukraine. U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio is in the Middle East amplifying President Trump's vision for Gaza. And a review of Trump's first four weeks reshaping the U.S. government.

Want more comprehensive analysis of the most important news of the day, plus a little fun? Subscribe to the Up First newsletter.

Today's episode of Up First was edited by Ryland Barton, Didi Schanche, Krishnadev Calamur Reena Advani and Adriana Gallardo. It was produced by Ziad Buchh, Nia Dumas and Christopher Thomas. We get engineering support from Arthur Laurent and our technical director is Carleigh Strange. Our Executive Producer is Kelley Dickens.

TITLE: Rubio is in Saudi Arabia to discuss the Gaza ceasefire and Ukraine war
SUMMARY: After meetings in Israel, Secretary of State Marco Rubio is in Saudi Arabia to push President Trump's plan for Gaza and to meet with Russian counterparts on steps to ending the war in Ukraine.

TITLE: European leaders to meet about emerging transatlantic rift over security, Ukraine
SUMMARY: European leaders are meeting in Paris to discuss an emerging transatlantic chasm over security and the war in Ukraine, while the U.S. will send negotiators to meet Russian diplomats in Saudi Arabia.

TITLE: Understanding presidential power in the age of Trump
SUMMARY: New York Times writer Charlie Savage discusses the scope of executive power as President Trump circumvents Congress, pushes legal boundaries and fires scores of federal workers, including at the FBI.

TITLE: When online weight-loss drugs are too good to be true
SUMMARY: A telehealth company partnered with a pharmacy that lacked a required license, raising doubts about the safety and efficacy of the weight-loss medicines it mailed to patients.

TITLE: Power lines sparked new fires in LA after the Eaton Fire began, radio traffic shows
SUMMARY: First responder communications show the power company in Altadena was slow to respond to Eaton firefighters — and that live power lines sparked new fires days after flames first broke out.

TITLE: Pope Francis' hospital stay is extended due to 'polymicrobial infection'
SUMMARY: The 88-year-old pontiff was initially admitted to the hospital on Friday for bronchitis. On Monday, the Vatican said test results show Francis has "a polymicrobial infection of the respiratory tract."

TITLE: Frigid temperatures and snow are expected across the U.S. this week
SUMMARY: A high-pressure system is pushing Arctic air into the central U.S. this week. Much of the country will experience plunging temperatures, while states such as Kansas and Missouri could see heavy snow.

TITLE: In Chicago, cognitive behavioral therapy shows promise curbing youth violence
SUMMARY: The program, which focuses on mentoring and therapy, relies on the idea that most violent crimes are emotional, not rational.

TITLE: 4 top aides to New York City Mayor Eric Adams resign
SUMMARY: The news from the longtime aides — Maria Torres-Springer, Anne Williams-Isom, Meera Joshi, and Chauncey Parker — comes after the Justice Department moved to drop corruption charges against Adams.

TITLE: Mexico's President Sheinbaum threatens to take legal action over the Gulf name change
SUMMARY: Earlier this month, Sheinbaum shared a letter addressed to Google with reporters, arguing that the U.S. had no authority to unilaterally rename the Gulf.

TITLE: Peace Talks with Russia; Mexican Street Sweeper Becomes a Star
SUMMARY: Members of the Trump Administration will meet with counterparts from Russia this week to discuss a possible peace deal with Ukraine. Notably, the Ukrainians are absent from these talks. Other European nations are also not invited, even though as a whole Europe gives Ukraine more aid money than the United States. We get updates from three NPR reporters covering various parts of the story.

TITLE: A Delta Air Lines passenger jet flips upside down during turbulent landing in Toronto
SUMMARY: Authorities said that there were no fatalities, but at least eight people sustained injuries when the regional jet overturned while landing at Toronto's Pearson International Airport on Monday.

TITLE: Health agencies lose staff in key areas as Trump firings set in
SUMMARY: As the dust settles from the first wave of firings at health agencies, here's how many people got cut, and the impact of the roles that were lost.

TITLE: Thousands of people protest in Washington, D.C., and across the U.S. on Presidents Day
SUMMARY: The protestors participated in the 50501 Movement, which originated in response to the Trump administration and its efforts to cut government spending. Many chanted "Where is Congress?'"

TITLE: NY Governor Hochul signals she may move to force NYC Mayor Eric Adams from office
SUMMARY: NY Gov Hochul says she'll weigh NYC Mayor Eric Adams' future on Tuesday, after four of his longtime aides resigned over a corruption scandal involving the Trump administration.

TITLE: Leonard Peltier to be released from prison following commutation in FBI killings
SUMMARY: Peltier's imprisonment has symbolized systemic injustice for Native Americans across the country who believe in his innocence.

TITLE: A Delta Air Lines jet flips upside down on a Toronto runway and all 80 aboard survive
SUMMARY: Authorities said that there were no fatalities, but at least 18 people sustained injuries when the regional jet overturned while landing at Toronto's Pearson International Airport on Monday.

TITLE: Can President Trump ignore Congress' spending laws? The debate over 'impoundment'
SUMMARY: Since taking office, the Trump administration and DOGE have been seeking to unilaterally override the spending plans set by Congress. Can they do that under the U.S. Constitution?

TITLE: Ukraine Talks, U.S. Health Agency Cuts, NYC Mayor Eric Adams Fallout
SUMMARY:
American and Russian officials meet in Saudi Arabia for talks on negotiating an end to the war in Ukraine. The Trump administration has started making broad cuts to federal health agencies. Days after the Justice Department moved to drop corruption charges against New York City Mayor Eric Adams, four of his top aides and deputy mayors announced their resignations.
