Today's episode of Up First was edited by Ryland Barton, Jane Greenhalgh, Denice Rios, Reena Advani and Janaya Williams. It was produced by Ziad Buchh, Nia Dumas and Christopher Thomas. We get engineering support from Arthur Laurent and our technical director is Carleigh Strange. Our Executive Producer is Kelley Dickens.

TITLE: An ancient Roman basilica has been discovered below London's financial district
SUMMARY: The basilica, dating back some 1,900 years, was found during excavations that took place as part of the demolition of a building in the heart of London.

TITLE: As sports betting has soared, more people search online for help with gambling addiction
SUMMARY: A study shows more people are looking for help to manage gambling addiction, in the years after a Supreme Court decision allowed online sports betting in 38 states.

TITLE: Trump's allies find signs of respite from scrutiny at the Justice Department
SUMMARY: The department dropped a case against former Rep. Jeff Fortenberry, withdrew from an investigation against Rep. Andy Ogles, and moved to dismiss the case against New York Mayor Eric Adams.

TITLE: Human gene variant alters the voices of mice
SUMMARY: A new study shows that giving mice the human version of a gene changes their squeak, suggesting some of the genetic underpinnings of language.

TITLE: U.S. and Russia discuss ending Ukraine war, without Kyiv
SUMMARY: The talks build on last week's phone call between President Trump and Russian leader Vladimir Putin during which the two leaders agreed to work together towards a negotiated end to the war.

TITLE: NYC mayor could be removed from office. And, concerns over peace talks for Ukraine
SUMMARY: New York Gov. Kathy Hochul signaled she may use her authority to remove New York City Mayor Eric Adams from office. And, high-stakes negotiations to end the war in Ukraine begin today.

TITLE: Is the Justice Department cutting breaks to people who seem loyal to Trump?
SUMMARY: The department dropped a case against former Rep. Jeff Fortenberry, withdrew from an investigation against Rep. Andy Ogles, and moved to dismiss the case against New York Mayor Eric Adams.

TITLE: Health agencies lose staff members in key areas as Trump firings set in
SUMMARY: As the dust settles from the first wave of firings at health agencies, here's how many people got cut and the impact of the roles that were lost.

TITLE: Who is Steve Witkoff? Trump's Middle East envoy is a real estate mogul and old friend
SUMMARY: A real estate developer-turned-Middle East envoy, Witkoff has been credited with helping broker the Israel-Hamas ceasefire and free an American from Russian prison. Here's what to know about him.

TITLE: White House says Elon Musk is not in charge of DOGE -- legally, anyway
SUMMARY: Elon Musk is not the legal administrator in charge of the "Department of Government Efficiency," the White House said in a court filing, and has "no actual or formal authority" to make decisions.

TITLE: From his hospital bed, Pope Francis stays in touch with Catholic parishioners in Gaza
SUMMARY: Even while Pope Francis is hospitalized, he still keeps in touch with a Roman Catholic parish in Gaza City, making near-nightly phone calls to the priest and congregation there.

TITLE: As Trump takes over leadership at Kennedy Center, some protest through dance
SUMMARY: President Trump and his appointees are now solely in charge of the Kennedy Center. Performers protested by dancing.

TITLE: Hamas to hand over 4 Israeli hostages' bodies Thursday and 6 living hostages Saturday
SUMMARY: Hamas says it has agreed to Israel's request to speed up release of Israeli hostages, including two men held around a decade. The bodies of members of a young family are among those it will hand over.

TITLE: Who is the American playing a key role in the U.S.-Russia talks about Ukraine?
SUMMARY: A real estate developer-turned-Middle East envoy, Witkoff has been credited with helping broker the Israel-Hamas ceasefire and free an American from Russian prison. Here's what to know about him.

TITLE: Why did the baby seal cross the road? It's not a riddle for this Connecticut city
SUMMARY: A baby seal was rescued from the streets of downtown New Haven, lethargic and underweight. He is now recovering at a nearby aquarium, which hopes to eventually release him back into the ocean.

TITLE: A pediatrician warns of 'long lasting' consequences of RFK Jr. leading HHS
SUMMARY: Ratner predicts the appointment of Kennedy, a vaccine skeptic, will impact vaccine availability and hesitancy: "It is much easier to scare people than to un-scare them," he says.

TITLE: Privacy advocates file lawsuit to stop DOGE from peeking at IRS taxpayer data
SUMMARY: A coalition of watchdog groups and unions is seeking to block the DOGE team from accessing taxpayer data at the IRS. A similar battle is brewing over Social Security data.

TITLE: What we know about the Toronto plane crash
SUMMARY: Authorities are still investigating what caused a Delta Air Lines regional jet to flip upside down and burst into flames upon landing at Toronto Pearson International Airport on Monday.

TITLE: Pope Francis has pneumonia in both lungs, Vatican says
SUMMARY: Pope Francis has pneumonia in both lungs, according to the Vatican. There's concern about the ability of the 88-year-old pontiff to fight off the infection.

TITLE: Ireland Weighs a Boycott
SUMMARY: Ireland considers becoming the first western country to ban trade with Israeli settlements in the Occupied Palestinian Territories. The move is controversial, but Ireland has a history of leading the way with effective boycotts. We hear about the past and present of Irish activism.

TITLE: Artists protest new NEA restrictions
SUMMARY: Hundreds of artists signed a letter sent to the National Endowment for the Arts asking it to reverse policy changes made  as a result of recent executive orders issued by President Trump.

TITLE: A pediatrician warns of 'long-lasting' consequences of RFK Jr. leading HHS
SUMMARY: Adam Ratner predicts the appointment of Robert F. Kennedy Jr., a vaccine skeptic, will impact vaccine availability and hesitancy: "It is much easier to scare people than to unscare them," he says.

TITLE: National Science Foundation fires roughly 10% of its workforce
SUMMARY: NSF fired 168 employees, leaving the agency less equipped to fund a wide range of scientific research.

TITLE: It's Frankie Muniz's world with both a NASCAR career and sitcom reboot in the works
SUMMARY: For Frankie Muniz, balancing a career as a professional NASCAR driver and a TV actor isn't a fantasy; it'll be his very busy reality this upcoming year.

TITLE: Much of U.S. faces subzero temperatures, snow and high winds in coming days
SUMMARY: In some parts of the Plains region, the National Weather Service expects temperatures to reach as low as the negative 20s and 30s.

TITLE: Hip-hop star A$AP Rocky is found not guilty in firearm case, avoiding prison
SUMMARY: Jurors found A$AP Rocky, a rapper and the longtime partner of Rihanna, not guilty of firing a gun at a former friend on a Hollywood street in 2021. He could have faced up to 24 years in prison.

TITLE: Trump wants to lower the cost of IVF. New executive order seeks ideas to do that
SUMMARY: President Trump campaigned on lowering the cost of IVF, after a controversial ruling made the treatment stop in Alabama for a short time

TITLE: Trump says Elon Musk's $10 million settlement over Twitter suit was 'a big discount'
SUMMARY: It's the second tech company to agree to a payout after the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol prompted Trump to be kicked off numerous social media platforms.

TITLE: Brazil's former president faces charges over alleged coup plot
SUMMARY: Former Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro has been charged for allegedly helping to mastermind far right coup plot to upset the country's 2022 election result.

TITLE: Postmaster General Louis DeJoy says it is time to find his successor
SUMMARY: Louis DeJoy said he plans to step down after a nearly five-year tenure marked by the coronavirus pandemic, surges in mail-in election ballots and efforts to stem losses through cost and service cuts.

TITLE: More than 150 false killer whales stranded on a beach in Australia's Tasmania state
SUMMARY: The reasons for the beachings are unclear. Reasons could include disorientation caused by loud noises, illness, old age, injury, fleeing predators and severe weather.

TITLE: Dominican officials cram thousands of inmates facing no charges into overcrowded prisons
SUMMARY: Despite promises to improve the system, problems within prisons keep mounting. Critics say the Dominican Republic continues to push for pretrial detentions in cases where no charges have been filed.

TITLE: Nearly 300 deportees from U.S. held in Panama hotel
SUMMARY: The migrants hailed from 10 mostly Asian countries the U.S. has difficulty deporting migrants to directly. Panama is being used as a stopover.

TITLE: Is Trump preparing to cancel America's ride back to the moon?
SUMMARY: President Trump launched the Artemis program to return U.S. astronauts to the moon for the first time since Apollo. Now, the plan could be a casualty of the cost-cutting drive overseen by Elon Musk.

TITLE: She worked for years to get a federal job. Within a month, she was fired
SUMMARY: Rose is one of thousands of federal workers who have been terminated by the Trump administration. At 26, she's left wondering what to do now.

TITLE: Lori Chavez-DeRemer, Trump's Labor Department pick, to face questions from senators
SUMMARY: The confirmation hearing for the former Oregon representative nominated to lead the Labor Department is to start Wednesday. The secretary of labor holds the 11th Cabinet position in the presidential line of succession.

TITLE: FDA staff handling drug safety for pets and livestock lost jobs in Trump firings
SUMMARY: The fired staffers were tasked with making sure medications given to animals work well and are safe.

TITLE: Measles spreads in Texas. And, how U.S. funding cuts could benefit China
SUMMARY: A measles outbreak in West Texas has sparked concern as cases have more than doubled since last week. And, China seeks to support pro-democracy groups in the U.S.

TITLE: Trump claims expanded power over independent agencies
SUMMARY: The executive order would affect agencies like the SEC and FDIC, but it excludes the Federal Reserve's Board of Governors and Open Market Committee.

TITLE: Schools, colleges have 2 weeks to ban DEI. An education expert warns it won't be easy
SUMMARY: The Department of Education told schools to stop DEI efforts or risk losing federal dollars. The president of the Council for Higher Education Accreditation warns it won't be quick and easy.

TITLE: Hockey Hall of Famer Bobby Hull died with CTE, researchers say
SUMMARY: Bobby Hull, an electric left-winger known as the 'Golden Jet', marveled hockey fans for his will to win. Named one of the NHL's greatest players, Hull was found to have had CTE after his death.

TITLE: Men die younger than women. Is it time for a focus on men's health?
SUMMARY: Researchers would like to see more study on how stress, the economy and attitudes toward medicine influence the well-being and longevity of men.

TITLE: The USDA fired staffers working on bird flu. Now it's trying to reverse course
SUMMARY: The USDA says "several" staffers working on the bird flu response were terminated over the weekend, and "we are working to swiftly rectify the situation and rescind those letters."

TITLE: Trump backs House's approach to budget plans to implement his agenda
SUMMARY: The chambers are at odds about the best way to approach President Trump's legislative priorities, which could set them up for a showdown.

TITLE: Zelenskyy hits back against Trump's comments blaming Ukraine for the war with Russia
SUMMARY: Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said he wants the U.S. to stop using disinformation when talking about Russia's war on Ukraine, after President Trump accused Ukraine of starting the war.

TITLE: Journalist describes Trump's movements as a 'regime change' towards authoritarianism
SUMMARY: The Atlantic writer Anne Applebaum says President Trump's dismantling of the U.S. civil service system, and his attacks on judges and his opponents, are part of a playbook on undermining democracy.

TITLE: Trump officials will not restart most foreign aid despite court order
SUMMARY: A judge last week ruled that the freeze on foreign aid must be reversed. But Trump's USAID team responded that many contracts give them the right to halt funding.

TITLE: Europe's Biggest Economy is in Trouble
SUMMARY: Germany's economy boomed as the world underwent globalization. But since then, too little investment, too much bureaucracy and a nearby war in Ukraine has cause Europe's largest economy to stagnate. The issue has played a big role in the upcoming German election. Our Berlin correspondent tells takes us to a German factory.

TITLE: Hurricane, the hero Belgian Malinois who protected the Obama White House from intruder, has died
SUMMARY: Hurricane, who was a Special Operations Canine for the Secret Service, became the most decorated dog in U.S. history. He died this week at the age of 16.

TITLE: Trump administration yanks CDC flu vaccine campaign
SUMMARY: As flu rages, the Trump administration has pulled the plug on a Centers for Disease Control and Prevention flu immunization campaign that targeted high-risk groups, including pregnant women.

TITLE: Judge deliberates after Justice Department pushes to end corruption case against NYC Mayor Adams
SUMMARY: During a hearing on Wednesday, Judge Dale Ho questioned federal prosecutors over their decision to suspend criminal charges against Mayor Eric Adams. Judge Ho's ruling is expected soon.

TITLE: GOP senators fact check Trump's Ukraine rhetoric, while still backing his strategy
SUMMARY: Lawmakers sought to dispel Kremlin talking points echoed by the president that Ukraine was responsible for the war with Russia. But they said Trump should be given room to negotiate.

TITLE: Seven Chilean men are charged with stealing millions from high-profile athletes' homes
SUMMARY: Seven Chilean men face federal charges related to a string of burglaries at the homes of six high-profile athletes. NFL quarterbacks Pat Mahomes and Joe Burrows were among the targets.

TITLE: In potential showdown, aid groups demand court find USAID, State officials in contempt
SUMMARY: Aid groups are urging a federal judge to find Trump administration officials in contempt to force them to reopen funding to global programs. USAID says it has a legal right to cancel aid contracts.

TITLE: DOGE released data about federal contract savings. It doesn't add up
SUMMARY: A new government tracker claims DOGE has saved billions from ending federal contracts. But an NPR analysis of the data finds the claimed savings don't add up.

TITLE: Military doctors prepare to deploy to Guantanamo for extended stay
SUMMARY: Orders to deploy medical personnel suggest the Trump administration is contemplating an extended stay for people at the U.S. base in Cuba.

TITLE: Panama sends 97 U.S. deportees to migrant camp after they refused to be repatriated
SUMMARY: The migrants refused to be repatriated to their countries. They will be held in a migration facility near the Darien Gap along the Colombian border until third countries can be found to take them.

TITLE: Hegseth directs Pentagon to find $50 billion in cuts this year
SUMMARY: The cuts would be as drastic as sequestration in 2013, the law passed by Congress that forced the armed services to cut $56 billion in a matter of months.

TITLE: Hamas releases the bodies of four Israeli hostages, including mother and young sons
SUMMARY: Today's release is the first time Hamas has handed over the bodies of hostages during the war, although several have been recovered by Israeli forces in Gaza and returned to Israel.

TITLE: Military doctors prepare to deploy to Guantánamo for extended stay
SUMMARY: Orders to deploy medical personnel suggest the Trump administration is contemplating an extended stay for people at the U.S. base in Cuba.

TITLE: Judge deliberates after DOJ pushes to end corruption case against NYC Mayor Adams
SUMMARY: During a hearing on Wednesday, Judge Dale Ho questioned federal prosecutors over their decision to suspend criminal charges against Mayor Eric Adams. Judge Ho's ruling is expected soon.

TITLE: How Trump's tariffs on steel and aluminum could hit you at the grocery store
SUMMARY: U.S. tariffs could cause the prices of steel and aluminum cans to rise, an increase that may ultimately be passed on to consumers.

TITLE: A military vet and a scientist were securing America's food system. Trump fired them
SUMMARY: More than 10,000 federal employees who had yet to complete their probationary periods have been fired by the Trump administration, including those who work to protect American agriculture.

TITLE: Black farmers among those left in limbo amid federal funding freeze
SUMMARY: The federal government has historically discriminated against Black farmers. The recent funding halt from the Trump administration presents yet another hurdle to those who have spent decades fighting for equity in farming.

TITLE: First known cookbook by a Black American woman gets new edition 160 years later
SUMMARY: Malinda Russell's <em>A Domestic Cookbook

TITLE: China repatriates more than 1,000 online scam workers rescued from Myanmar
SUMMARY: Thailand, China and Myanmar have coordinated efforts over the past month to shut down the scam centers that bilked victims around the world out of billions of dollars.

TITLE: A gold-framed Trump mug shot is hanging just outside of the Oval Office
SUMMARY: President Trump's mug shot is one of the first things visitors will see when approaching the Oval Office.

TITLE: DOGE saved far less than claimed. And, Trump blames Zelenskyy for Russia's invasion
SUMMARY: An online tracker claims DOGE has saved $55 billion in federal spending, but NPR has found this to be false. And, Trump blames the Ukrainian president for Russia's invasion.

TITLE: A gold-framed Trump mug shot is hanging just outside the Oval Office
SUMMARY: President Trump's mug shot is one of the first things visitors will see when approaching the Oval Office.

TITLE: Republican proposals to cut Medicaid could be politically fraught
SUMMARY: Republicans are proposing deep cuts to Medicaid to finance tax cuts and other priorities. Pushback is coming not only from Democrats, but also from hospitals that rely on revenue from the program.

TITLE: Trump order aims to cut benefits for those without legal status. Most already don't qualify.
SUMMARY: A new executive order aims to prevent taxpayer money from supporting people in the U.S. without legal status and targets federal funding for cities and states that support sanctuary policies.

TITLE: Senator Mitch McConnell says he will not seek reelection in 2026
SUMMARY: The Kentucky Republican has served more than 40 years in the chamber, and became one of the most consequential and divisive legislators in recent history.

TITLE: As the U.S. steps back from global health, what role will China play?
SUMMARY: With the U.S. withdrawing from the World Health Organization and rethinking foreign aid, China has an opportunity to play a bigger role — with different goals.

TITLE: Sen. Mitch McConnell says he will not seek reelection in 2026
SUMMARY: The Kentucky Republican has served more than 40 years in the chamber, and became one of the most consequential and divisive legislators in recent history.

TITLE: Trump aims to cut benefits for those without legal status. Most already don't qualify
SUMMARY: A new executive order aims to prevent taxpayer money from supporting people in the U.S. without legal status and targets federal funding for cities and states that support sanctuary policies.

TITLE: A military vet and a scientist were securing America's food system. Trump fired them
SUMMARY: More than 10,000 federal employees who had yet to complete their probationary periods have been fired by the Trump administration, including those who work to protect American agriculture.

TITLE: Everything to know about the MLB's ball-strike challenge system at spring training
SUMMARY: This spring, MLB players can challenge ball and strike calls. The camera-based system is only an experiment for now — but it has the baseball world wondering where to draw the line with technology.

TITLE: Trump wants more power over agencies. Experts worry about campaign finance regulators
SUMMARY: President Trump's effort to "rein in" independent agencies is raising particular concern among those who follow the work of the Federal Election Commission, which enforces campaign finance laws.

TITLE: IRS cuts over 6,000 jobs in the middle of tax season
SUMMARY: The IRS is cutting more than 6,000 jobs this week, as part of the Trump administration's downsizing of the overall federal workforce. The job cuts at the IRS come in the middle of the tax-filing season.

TITLE: Mexico warns the US not to 'invade our sovereignty' in fight against cartels
SUMMARY: As the US officially designates six Mexican cartels as terrorist groups, Mexico's president warns the United States against any violation of its territory.

TITLE: Kennedy Center evacuates due to bomb threat targeting Shen Yun
SUMMARY: A spokesperson for the Kennedy Center says the threat targeted Shen Yun, a touring dance troupe that is banned in China, because it is associated with the religious group Falun Gong.

TITLE: These far-right media figures are getting center stage under Trump
SUMMARY: The Trump administration has welcomed far-right media figures in the White House briefing room and elsewhere, even as it restricts access for established news outlets.

TITLE: NY Governor won't remove NYC Mayor Adams from office, another win for President Trump
SUMMARY: NYC Mayor Eric Adams emerged as a key ally of President Trump on his immigration crackdown after Trump's DOJ agreed to shelve corruption charges.  Governor Hochul says Adams will remain in office.

TITLE: Senate confirms Kash Patel, fierce critic of FBI, to head the bureau
SUMMARY: Republicans welcomed Kash Patel's confirmation, seeing him as someone who can fix the FBI's alleged targeting of conservatives in recent years.

TITLE: Reversing U.S. policy, Trump attacks Zelenskyy, blames Ukraine for war with Russia
SUMMARY: The U.S. has been the strongest supporter of Ukraine in its war with Russia. Yet with a series of blunt comments, President Trump now sounds more aligned with Russia than Ukraine.

TITLE: Exclusive: Trump administration drops work on stronger building codes for disasters
SUMMARY: To help homes survive more intense disasters, FEMA has been developing recommendations for stronger building codes. The Trump Administration has pulled them back.

TITLE: How Will the New Syria Be Governed?
SUMMARY: After 14 years of a devastating civil war, Syria is in the process of reinventing itself. One big question is how the country will be governed now that the more than 50 years of rule by the Assad family has come to an end. For clues on what the future might hold, our correspondent goes to the city that was run by a rebel group during the war. That group led the toppling of the Assad regime and now controls the interim government.

TITLE: First CDC vaccine meeting under Trump administration is postponed
SUMMARY: The panel of vaccine experts were supposed to hold their first meeting under the Trump administration in late February. It's not clear when that meeting will now take place.

TITLE: Venezuelan mothers organize on chat group to fight Guantánamo detentions
SUMMARY: The mothers met in a Whatsapp group. They have vowed to fight until their sons, who they say have not committed crimes and do not have ties to gangs, are released.

TITLE: Greenlandic politician describes struggle to remember 'America has good people'
SUMMARY: NPR's Juana Summers speaks with Greenlandic parliamentary candidate Naaja Nathanielsen about the continued Trump administration push to acquire the territory.

TITLE: Why are 'fireworks' coming from a black hole? This is what scientists say
SUMMARY: A team of astrophysicists have found flares of light in Sagittarius A*, a supermassive black hole in the center of the Milky Way.

TITLE: N.Y. governor won't remove NYC Mayor Adams from office, another win for President Trump
SUMMARY: Mayor Eric Adams emerged as a key ally of President Trump on his immigration crackdown after Trump's DOJ agreed to shelve corruption charges. Gov. Kathy Hochul says Adams will remain in office.

TITLE: Trump's picks to oversee Medicare and biomedical research will divest stock
SUMMARY: Dr. Mehmet Oz,  nominated to run the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services, will sell shares in Eli Lilly and UnitedHealth. Dr. Jay Bhattacharya, NIH nominee, will shed stock in Walmart and Nvidia.

TITLE: Justice Department broadens Jan. 6 pardons to cover gun, drug-related charges
SUMMARY: In a new development, the Department of Justice said Trump's pardon of Jan. 6 defendants should apply more broadly and include separate gun charges, as well.

TITLE: Australia warns airlines to beware of Chinese naval exercises in the Tasman Sea
SUMMARY: China had given notice that its warships could potentially fire live weapons during an exercise in the Tasman Sea, Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said.

TITLE: A far-right influencer is getting invitations to travel with Trump Cabinet members
SUMMARY: Jack Posobiec, a prominent influencer, has a long history of promoting antisemitic and white supremacist content. He traveled to Ukraine with Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent last week.

TITLE: In case you missed it: Here's what happened with Trump this week, from Ukraine to DOGE
SUMMARY: NPR rounds up what happened this week, the fourth week of President Trump's administration, and takes a look at some developments that have been overlooked.

SUMMARY: With a measles outbreak growing in West Texas, and cases popping up across the country, experts say vaccination is your best protection. And it's not just for kids. Some adults may need a booster.

TITLE: What even IS art? The quiz doesn't know — but do you?
SUMMARY: Plus: Why are there so many "Bridget Jones" movies? Who all resigned over the Eric Adams drama? And what phrase originated on "SNL"?

TITLE: What to know about the case against former Spanish soccer head Luis Rubiales
SUMMARY: The former president of Spain's soccer federation was found guilty of sexual assault for kissing player Jenni Hermoso after the 2023 women's World Cup. Here's what to know about the case.

TITLE: Israel says body returned by Hamas not that of hostage
SUMMARY: Israel identified the remains of child hostages but said another body from Hamas was not their mother as claimed. And near Tel Aviv, explosions hit threes buses, but no injuries were reported.

TITLE: Israel says returned body isn't a hostage. And, FEMA cuts building code efforts
SUMMARY: FEMA has cut employees and is now halting efforts to improve building codes. And, Israel says one of the bodies Hamas returned does not belong to any known hostage.

TITLE: From Ukraine to DOGE: Here's everything that happened with Trump this week
SUMMARY: NPR rounds up what happened this week, the fourth week of President Trump's administration, and takes a look at some developments that have been overlooked.

SUMMARY: The North American hockey rivals turned what had been a tune-up for the 2026 Olympics into an geopolitical brawl over anthems and annexation as much as international hockey supremacy.

TITLE: Lab mice may give 'first aid' to unconscious mates
SUMMARY: New research suggests mice may exhibit revival-like behaviors to help unconscious mice recover faster.

TITLE: Can there be peace in Ukraine, or is Putin just playing for time?
SUMMARY: As the Trump administration works toward a halt in the fighting, many experts fear that Ukraine will be forced to accept a ceasefire deal that will only give Russian forces a badly needed breather.

TITLE: After mass layoffs, some federal agencies are trying to bring employees back
SUMMARY: A number of federal agencies, from HHS to the USDA, have laid off employees only to rescind those terminations days later. An expert says it "suggests something about mismanagement of government."

TITLE: Senate adopts budget resolution after marathon vote-a-rama. Now what?
SUMMARY: The Senate's budget framework is at odds with the House's approach, and both chambers ultimately have to be on the same page to get the legislation across the finish line.

TITLE: Federal judge wants 'adversarial' review of NYC Mayor Eric Adams-DOJ deal
SUMMARY: Corruption charges against New York City Mayor Eric Adams are on hold while a judge seeks legal input on whether the DOJ can dismiss them.

TITLE: 'See you in court': Trump and Maine's governor spar over trans athlete order
SUMMARY: The Maine Principal's Association said it would continue to <a href="https://www.mainepublic.org/sports/2025-02-07/governing-body-for-maine-high-school-sports-says-transgender-female-athletes-can-still-compete-under-state-law-gove" target="_blank">allow trans girls to compete

TITLE: Remembering a Musical Giant in Mexico
SUMMARY: We remember Paquita la del Barrio, who sang about romantic heartbreak and the pain of infidelity, spitting out insults with relish, and empowering a whole generation of women. Our correspondent in Mexico explains what she meant to her fans.

TITLE: The Netherlands will return more than 100 bronze artifacts to Nigeria
SUMMARY: The artifacts were stolen by British soldiers in the late 19th century and eventually made their way to a Dutch collection.

TITLE: Man who stabbed Salman Rushdie convicted of attempted murder

SUMMARY: Luigi Mangione, who is accused of killing UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson, had his first court appearance since he was arraigned in December on charges including murder as an act of terrorism.

TITLE: Supreme Court punts on order that blocked Trump's firing of special counsel
SUMMARY: Per Congress' directive, the occupant of the position can only be fired for "inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance in office."

TITLE: Trump's passport policy leaves trans, intersex Americans in the lurch
SUMMARY: President Trump's executive order that the federal government recognizes only two sexes, male and female, is disrupting the lives of some trans, nonbinary and intersex people applying for passports.

TITLE: AP sues Trump White House for denying access over 'Gulf of Mexico' row
SUMMARY: The White House has kept the wire service from covering key events because it refuses to call the body of water between Mexico and Florida the Gulf of America, as the Trump administration prefers.

TITLE: Federal judge hears arguments to decide the future of Trump's federal funding freeze
SUMMARY: The case, brought by attorneys general in 22 states and the District of Columbia, represents a pivotal test for the administration as it pursues a dramatic review of government spending priorities.

SUMMARY: The New York Yankees are changing a nearly 50-year-old policy that banned beards. Here are some things to know about the history of beards in major league baseball.

SUMMARY: Because of a Trump executive order, the Census Bureau is stopping work on statistics that could help protect the rights of transgender people, its recently departed director, Robert Santos, tells NPR.

TITLE: Luigi Mangione's lawyer claims he was searched illegally during arrest
SUMMARY: Luigi Mangione, who is accused of killing UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson, had his first court appearance since he was arraigned in December on charges including murder as an act of terrorism.

SUMMARY: Trump announced the dismissal of Air Force Gen. Charles Q. Brown Jr. and said he would nominate Lt. Gen. Dan Caine, a retired three-star general, to succeed him as the top U.S. military officer.

TITLE: Judge largely blocks Trump's executive orders ending federal support for DEI programs
SUMMARY: A U.S. district judge granted a preliminary injunction blocking the administration from terminating or changing federal contracts they consider equity-related.

SUMMARY: MSNBC had aired stories falsely claiming the doctor performed mass hysterectomies on female detainees at an Immigration and Customs Enforcement facility in Georgia.

SUMMARY: The Bureau of Prisons is moving forward with plans to move transgender inmates out of prisons that align with their gender identity and into facilities that align with their assigned<strong>

TITLE: Arab leaders huddle in Saudi Arabia in pushback to Trump's Gaza plans
SUMMARY: Leaders from Egypt, Jordan and other Arab states met in Saudi Arabia to discuss alternative plans for Gaza's future than the one laid out by President Trump, which calls for displacing Palestinians.

TITLE: Here's what to know about Germany's election this Sunday
SUMMARY: An economic slump, an immigration crisis and the lifting of a security blanket provided for decades by the U.S. are issues on the minds of German voters. The far-right AfD is polling in second place.

TITLE: Want to reduce soreness after a workout? Make time for this 4-step routine
SUMMARY: These simple post-workout activities can help reduce pain and even improve athletic performance. But many people don't prioritize recovery and self-care after exercise.

TITLE: Hamas releases Israeli hostages, returns remains of Shiri Bibas
SUMMARY: Hamas to release the last six live hostages whose freedom they agreed to under the current ceasefire deal.

TITLE: How many fourth-graders does it take to make a podcast? Here's what we learned
SUMMARY: Students in an elementary school broadcasting club in California are among the youngest winners of NPR's Student Podcast Challenge.

TITLE: Elon Musk blurs the line between his government and business roles
SUMMARY: The tech titan and President Trump say they will avoid any conflicts of interest, but it's difficult for the public to verify that.

TITLE: Burnout is a problem for caseworkers serving unhoused people
SUMMARY: People who provide assistance to the unhoused often feel traumatized by their work.

TITLE: Trump administration plans mass firing at office that funds homelessness programs
SUMMARY: Staffing at the HUD office that pays for housing and support services across the country is slated to be cut by 84%. Advocates warn such heavy cuts could make record-high homelessness even worse.

SUMMARY: The National Institutes of Health had to stop considering new grant applications, delaying funding for research into diseases ranging from heart disease and cancer to Alzheimer's and allergies.

TITLE: Pope Francis is in critical condition, the Vatican says
SUMMARY: The 88-year-old Francis has been hospitalized for a week with a complex lung infection.

TITLE: Week in politics: Trump's policy towards Ukraine, mass firings at federal agencies
SUMMARY: We look at President Trump's embrace of Vladimir Putin as he turns his back on U.S. ally, Ukraine, as well as mass firings at government agencies and how that will affect the services they provide.

TITLE: Who is Trump's pick for chairman of Joint Chiefs of Staff, Dan Caine?
SUMMARY: Caine is a career fighter jet pilot who defended Washington, D.C., during the 9/11 attacks and been adored by Trump since they met in Iraq during Trump's first term.

TITLE: Elon Musk tells federal employees to document work in email or be fired

TITLE: Elon Musk says federal employees must document work in email or be fired
SUMMARY: Federal workers across the U.S. government received an email on Saturday, with an apparent ultimatum. Musk has used a similar tactic at companies he owns.

TITLE: Pope Francis rested during a peaceful night following respiratory crisis
SUMMARY: Pope Francis, in critical condition with a complicated lung infection, rested well during a peaceful night following a respiratory crisis and blood transfusions, the Vatican said Sunday.

TITLE: For one husband, caregiving came easier when he learned to 'shut up and listen'
SUMMARY: The advice helped him when his wife was sick with breast cancer. And now 20 years later, he still finds it's still invaluable while supporting her through dementia.

SUMMARY: Israel is delaying the release of Palestinian detainees and prisoners, disrupting the Gaza ceasefire deal, and its military is intensifying an offensive in the occupied West Bank

TITLE: This Black History Month, we're highlighting stories from community changemakers
SUMMARY: Black history happens every day, and the stories from NPR listeners are good examples of that. From becoming the first Black mayor of a town to singing music about change, these stories matter.

TITLE: Elon Musk says federal employees must either document their work — or lose their jobs
SUMMARY: Federal workers across the U.S. government received an email on Saturday, with Musk giving an apparent ultimatum. The billionaire has used a similar tactic at companies he owns.

TITLE: How one community in Chile is blessed and cursed with lithium
SUMMARY: Chile is the world's second-largest lithium producer. It has been a welcome boon to the economy, but local community members consider it a disaster.

TITLE: Huge crowds gather in Lebanon for funeral of slain Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah
SUMMARY: Hezbollah held a long-delayed funeral for former leader Hassan Nasrallah, who was assassinated in September in an Israeli airstrike.

TITLE: The Vatican says Pope Francis, who has double pneumonia, had a 'peaceful' night
SUMMARY: The pontiff, 88, has been hospitalized for a week and a half and is receiving treatment for a complex respiratory infection.

TITLE: Vatican says Pope Francis had a 'peaceful' night but remains in critical condition
SUMMARY: The pontiff, 88, has been hospitalized for a week and a half and is receiving treatment for a complex respiratory infection.

TITLE: 'What did you do last week?' email stokes confusion and anger among federal workers
SUMMARY: Elon Musk's claim that federal workers who ignore a mass email will lose their job isn't supported by the email's request — or OPM guidance that says responses to its mass emails are "voluntary."

TITLE: Trump officials will put 4,700 USAID employees on leave and eliminate 1,600 jobs
SUMMARY: The decision comes in the wake of a judge's ruling that such a move will not cause irreparable harm to the employees. There will be exceptions for several hundred employees in roles deemed critical.

TITLE: Center-right opposition wins German election, with the far right coming in 2nd
SUMMARY: Conservative opposition leader Friedrich Merz won a lackluster victory in a national election Sunday, while the far-right Alternative for Germany doubled its support, projections showed.

TITLE: Trump names conservative media personality Dan Bongino as FBI deputy director
SUMMARY: The selection places two staunch Trump allies atop the nation's premier federal law enforcement agency at a time when Democrats are concerned that the president could seek to target his adversaries.

TITLE: A French surgeon is on trial accused of raping or abusing 299 people, mostly children
SUMMARY: The trial comes as French activists are pushing to lift taboos that surround sexual abuse. The most prominent case was that of Gisèle Pélicot, who was raped by her now ex-husband and dozens of others.

TITLE: A break from your smartphone can reboot your mood. Here's how long you need
SUMMARY: What would happen if you blocked the internet from your cellphone for two weeks? A bunch of millennial researchers wanted to answer that question. Here's what they found.

TITLE: A 10-year-old's story of family immigration that spans three continents
SUMMARY: A California fourth-grader's interview with her grandfather, who was forced out of Uganda before moving to the U.S., is one of our outstanding podcasts.

TITLE: Republicans' love/hate relationship with the Education Department
SUMMARY: President Trump has made clear he wants to close the U.S. Department of Education, but Republicans seem torn on just how far to go.

TITLE: 3 years on, here's what to keep an eye on in the Ukraine war — and efforts to end it
SUMMARY: Thousands of civilians have been killed since Russia launched its full-scale invasion on Feb. 24, 2022. Amid a stark shift in U.S. policy, Ukrainians want the war to end — but not on Russia's terms.

TITLE: Greenpeace faces a $300 million lawsuit after Dakota Access Pipeline protests
SUMMARY: The company behind the controversial Dakota Access Pipeline is suing Greenpeace for at least $300 million for damages the oil pipeline company says it suffered from protests in 2016 and 2017.

TITLE: Federal workers feel betrayed and alone in Trump administration's chaotic purge
SUMMARY: Mike Macans is one of an unknown number of Small Business Administration employees who were fired, unfired and fired again as part of the Trump administration's deep cuts to the federal workforce.

TITLE: Pope rests in his 10th day of hospitalization but remains in critical condition
SUMMARY: Francis, 88, had remained in critical condition throughout the weekend after severe breathing difficulties were reported.

TITLE: Macron, Trump to discuss Ukraine peace plan. And, Greenpeace faces $300 million lawsuit
SUMMARY: French President Emmanuel Macron is set to present the European peace plan for Ukraine to President Trump today. And, Greenpeace faces a lawsuit that could shut it down.

TITLE: Mental health issues ripple through the federal workforce with firings
SUMMARY: The way the terminations have been carried out will undermine the efficiency and productivity of workers left behind, expert says.

TITLE: Fired in Trump's chaotic purge, an Army vet says he's never felt more betrayed
SUMMARY: Mike Macans is one of an unknown number of Small Business Administration employees who were fired, unfired and fired again as part of the Trump administration's deep cuts to the federal workforce.

TITLE: A new document undercuts Trump admin's denials about $400 million Tesla deal
SUMMARY: The State Department claimed a plan to buy thousands of armored Teslas was left over from the Biden administration. A document obtained by NPR shows the Biden plan was far smaller.

TITLE: Mikaela Shiffrin seals legacy as one of skiing's greatest with historic 100 World Cup wins
SUMMARY: After a bruising crash last November, Mikaela Shiffrin dominated the slopes on Sunday and made skiing history once again.

TITLE: 'Jesus Wept' author chronicles the debates roiling the Catholic church
SUMMARY: Philip Shenon talks about the past seven popes, and how efforts to reform the Church with the Second Vatican Council led to power struggles and doctrinal debates that lasted for decades.

TITLE: What to know about Dan Bongino, the media personality tapped as FBI deputy director
SUMMARY: Dan Bongino has been chosen as the FBI's second-in-command, a job that doesn't need Senate confirmation. Here's what to know about the Secret Service agent-turned-conservative media personality.

TITLE: Trump and Macron meet in Washington as Europe pleads for continued help for Ukraine
SUMMARY: In a conversation between President Trump and French President Emmanuel Macron in the Oval Office Monday, the two leaders seemed friendly even then they appeared far apart on the war in Ukraine.

TITLE: U.S. votes against a U.N. resolution urging Russia's withdrawal from Ukraine
SUMMARY: The European-backed resolution that was approved demands Russia immediately withdraw its forces. The Trump administration had offered a competing resolution that did not mention Russian aggression.

TITLE: DHS memo lays out plans to detain migrants at Fort Bliss and other U.S. bases

TITLE: Pope Francis shows slight improvement in the hospital and calls Gaza's parish
