TITLE: Medical research labs brace for possible funding cuts that could disrupt their work
SUMMARY: Researchers say the Trump administration's plan to slash payments for indirect costs will hamper new medical science. One example? A lab studying respiratory viruses faces losing half its staff.

TITLE: Trump and Macron meet in Washington as Europe pleads for continued help with Ukraine
SUMMARY: During a joint press conference President Trump and French President Emmanuel Macron highlighted their friendly relationship, even when they appeared far apart on the war in Ukraine.

TITLE: Court ruling lets White House ban on the Associated Press continue, for now
SUMMARY: The Trump administration may continue — for now —  to keep the AP from covering key events. A federal judge declined to issue a temporary restraining order on Monday.

TITLE: Are Trump's military picks based on merit or loyalty?
SUMMARY:
On Friday, Donald Trump fired Chairman of the Joint Chief's of Staff CQ Brown, along with several other top Pentagon officials.

Now, Senator Jack Reed, a Democrat from Rhode Island, has a question for the man tapped to succeed him, Retired Air Force Lieutenant General Dan Caine.

Quote — "will he have the ability to speak truth to power?"
Senator Reed is the top democrat on the Armed Services Committee.

The Trump administration says it wants a military built on meritocracy. Critics say it's building one governed by political loyalty.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: Germany's historic election. And the impact of 3 years of war in Ukraine
SUMMARY: The man poised to become Germany's new Chancellor says the US administration doesn't care about the fate of Europe. And, on the third anniversary of Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine what has been the impact of the largest conflict in Europe since the second world war?

TITLE: The Panama Canal needs more water. The solution is a dam that could displace thousands
SUMMARY: More than 2,000 people could be displaced by the construction of the Río Indio dam. The Panama Canal Authority says the dam solves a long-term water shortage problem.

TITLE: Trump administration backs off requiring response to 'What did you do last week?' email
SUMMARY: "No one knows what we are supposed to do," said one federal employee amid conflicting and shifting directives on whether to comply with Elon Musk's directive to list five accomplishments.

TITLE: Federal watchdog agency intervenes in Trump's purge of probationary employees
SUMMARY: U.S. Special Counsel Hampton Dellinger has asked the Merit Systems Protection Board to temporarily reinstate six federal employees fired from their jobs and is considering ways to seek relief for others.

TITLE: Federal agencies still can't agree on 'What did you do last week?' email
SUMMARY: "No one knows what we are supposed to do," said one federal employee amid conflicting and shifting directives on whether to comply with Elon Musk's directive to list five accomplishments.

TITLE: Clint Hill, the Secret Service agent who tried to shield the Kennedys, dies at 93
SUMMARY: Hill received Secret Service awards and was promoted for his actions that day, but for decades blamed himself for Kennedy's death, saying he would gladly have given his life to save the president.

TITLE: Trump funding freeze includes payments to keep the  Colorado River flowing
SUMMARY: President Biden promised billions in funds to farmers and others to not take water from the Colorado River. President Trump is halting some of those funds, leaving questions about the river's future.

TITLE: Reconciliation is the key to unlocking Trump's agenda. Here's how it works
SUMMARY: Republicans in Congress are turning to a tool of the budget process to pass major elements of President Trump's agenda without the threat of a filibuster from Senate Democrats.

TITLE: 5 signs that a U.S.-Europe split is widening
SUMMARY: As the Trump administration ramps up its rhetoric against Ukraine and NATO, European countries are taking note — with increasing alarm.

TITLE: Health care workers are rushing to learn about immigration law in case of ICE raids
SUMMARY: A policy change by the Trump administration allows immigration agents to enter and arrest people in health facilities. Some clinics are training health workers to support patients in the event of arrests.

TITLE: Top Ukrainian official says Kyiv will refuse any 'bad' peace deal
SUMMARY: Ihor Brusylo, deputy head of Ukraine's President's Office, tells NPR Trump is a "peacemaker and dealmaker," while expressing hope the U.S. continues to provide aid to Ukraine.

TITLE: Who is Alice Marie Johnson, Trump's newly appointed 'pardon czar'?
SUMMARY: Johnson, now 69, was facing life in prison without the possibility of parole for being a first-time nonviolent drug offender.

TITLE: Trump's funding freeze threatens key river. And, U.S. votes against Ukraine peace plan
SUMMARY: Trump's funding freezes could threaten the Colorado River. Some money was intended to keep the shrinking river flowing. And, the U.S. voted against a U.N. peace resolution for Ukraine.

TITLE: From deportations to health care, state lawmakers are key for much of Trump's domestic agenda
SUMMARY: Federal power only goes so far. State governors and legislatures have wide authority over local law enforcement, schools, health and how cities and counties handle immigration.

TITLE: D.C.'s first Vietnamese American art exhibit subverts what it means to be Vietnamese
SUMMARY: April 2025 marks 50 years since the end of the Vietnam war. Washington, D.C.'s first Vietnamese American art exhibit examines what it means to be Vietnamese and looks forward with hope.

TITLE: Joy Reid fired from MSNBC amid network shakeup
SUMMARY: Reid is a longtime political commentator who has been vocal on progressive issues and sharply critical of President Trump.

TITLE: Why the good news about the mpox outbreak of 2025 isn't really good after all
SUMMARY: The case counts seem to be dropping. But health officials say that's because violence in the Democratic Republic of Congo makes it difficult to get good data. And now U.S. assistance is being disrupted.

TITLE: How is Pope Francis doing? The Vatican says he rested well and met church officials
SUMMARY: Pope Francis "rested well throughout the night" in the hospital, the Vatican says, and even met with Vatican officials to sign several documents linked to sainthood designations on Monday.

TITLE: Supreme Court throws out death sentence, murder conviction of Okla. death row inmate
SUMMARY: The court reversed the state court's judgement and sent the case back for a new trial.

TITLE: 50 years after a seminal conference, big questions about biotechnology remain
SUMMARY: In 1975, researchers met to discuss the emerging field of biotechnology. The issues surrounding the field today are familiar.

TITLE: From tariffs to spending, rounding up the Trump administration's econ-related actions
SUMMARY: Since taking office in late January, the Trump administration has been working at a galloping pace to reshape the government and economy. We have been doing our best to keep up and keep you informed.

TITLE: Fabric giant Joann is going out of business and closing all of its 800 stores
SUMMARY: The crafts retailer formerly known as Jo-Ann Fabrics had been struggling financially for several years following a DIY-driven uptick in sales during the early days of the pandemic.

TITLE: In 'Legends and Soles,' the remarkable career of sports marketer Sonny Vaccaro is unveiled
SUMMARY: NPR's A Martínez speaks with Sonny Vaccaro and Armen Keteyian about their new book, <em>Legends and Soles, The Memoir of An American Original.

TITLE: The odds of a 'city-killer' asteroid hitting Earth have fallen to zero
SUMMARY: After weeks at the top of the Sentry list at the Center for Near-Earth Object Studies, the asteroid 2024 YR4 is no longer considered a threat to Earth.

TITLE: Consumer confidence falls the most since 2021 over fears about inflation and tariffs
SUMMARY: A report from the Conference Board shows Americans are increasingly worried about inflation, driven in part by President Trump's threats to impose new tariffs on imports.

TITLE: Rollback of diversity efforts leaves teachers wondering about effects on Black History Month
SUMMARY: The Education Department's efforts to keep racial diversity out of schools has left educators wondering how and when to teach students about Black history, especially during Black History Month.

TITLE: Upheaval and firings at CDC raise fears about disease outbreak response
SUMMARY: Staff and observers worry that the agency may not be prepared for emerging threats including bird flu and insect-borne diseases.

TITLE: 21 DOGE staffers resign, saying they won't help 'dismantle' public services
SUMMARY: Twenty-one members of the United State DOGE Service have resigned, they said in an anonymous letter, citing DOGE's ongoing work dramatically reshaping the federal government.

TITLE: Inside the Murdoch family's real-life 'Succession' drama
SUMMARY: Rupert Murdoch and his oldest kids are battling over who controls his media empire when the 93-year-old dies. The Atlantic writer McKay Coppins explains the stakes and how it could change Fox News.

TITLE: A snowshoe trek in the Adirondack Mountains on a classic winter day
SUMMARY: Snowshoeing in the Adirondacks on a winter day with chickadees for company

TITLE: How's Pope Francis doing? His condition remains critical but stable, the Vatican says
SUMMARY: Pope Francis' condition remains critical but stable and he was able to do some work while still in the hospital with double pneumonia, the Vatican said in a Tuesday evening update.

TITLE: While sanctions still cripple a shattered Syria, one Jewish leader returns from exile
SUMMARY: During the Assad regimes, Western nations placed crippling economic sanctions on the country. Some have been lifted, but most are still in place, so how does a country shattered by civil war rebuild? And we follow the return to Damascus of one US Syrian Jewish leader, after decades in exile.

TITLE: The view from Greenland: 'We don't want to be Americans'
SUMMARY:
President Trump's calls for the U.S. to take over Greenland have sparked alarm and outrage.

Denmark, which is responsible for Greenland's security, recently announced that it would further boost its defense spending.

And a recent poll found 85 percent of Greenlanders are opposed to being part of the United States.

Parliamentary candidate Naaja Nathanielsen is one of them.

It isn't clear whether Trump's ambitions for Greenland will take. But some politicians in the territory are taking his calls for acquisition more seriously than ever before.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: House budget vote marks a key test for Trump's agenda, with GOP support still unclear
SUMMARY: With a final vote fast approaching, GOP leaders were still working to wrangle support from inside the party for a sweeping multitrillion plan to address defense, energy, immigration and tax policy.

TITLE: Rhiannon Giddens is the latest artist to cancel Kennedy Center gig
SUMMARY: Folk musician Rhiannon Giddens said on social media that she has moved her May concert – originally scheduled for the Kennedy Center – to a different venue in Washington, D.C.

TITLE: Venezuelan men allege mistreatment while in detention in Guantánamo Bay
SUMMARY: The men told NPR they were kept in the dark about why they were in Guantánamo Bay, and were denied access to an attorney or a phone call with loved ones.

TITLE: Judge tells Trump administration it has less than 2 days to resume USAID funding
SUMMARY: A federal judge has ordered the Trump administration to resume hundreds of millions of dollars in payments for U.S. Agency for International Development projects.

TITLE: Diana Taurasi, 6-time Olympic gold medalist and the WNBA's top scorer, will retire
SUMMARY: Taurasi leaves her basketball career as the most decorated woman to ever play, with three WNBA titles, three NCAA titles and six Olympic gold medals to her name.

TITLE: Tell us your story about car insurance premiums
SUMMARY: Car insurance premiums have been soaring. NPR wants to hear about what you've experienced in your premium costs, and why.

TITLE: Southwest 737 and small business jet have 'near collision' at Chicago Midway Airport
SUMMARY: Federal authorities are investigating a near-collision at Chicago's Midway airport between a Southwest 737 and a small business jet. The 737 was landing when the business jet entered the runway.

TITLE: House Republicans pass budget resolution, clearing a key early test for Trump agenda
SUMMARY: The GOP framework that passed Tuesday allows the party to move ahead on a sweeping multitrillion plan to address defense, energy, immigration and tax policy.

TITLE: Trump introduces a green card for the rich: the gold card
SUMMARY: The new visa program would effectively replace the current EB-5 investor visa program, and the proceeds could be used for deficit reduction.

TITLE: Federal board orders government to reinstate six workers fired by Trump
SUMMARY: The Merit Systems Protection Board, the quasi-judicial agency that hears appeals in federal employee labor disputes, has ordered a stay in the firing of six probationary employees.

TITLE: A sweeping power blackout leaves most of Chile in darkness
SUMMARY: Internet and mobile phone services blinkered offline. People complained of water shortages as pumps stopped working. Emergency generators helped hospitals and government offices continue operating.

TITLE: Israel and Hamas agree on a new exchange, leaving a fragile ceasefire intact
SUMMARY: The bodies of four Israeli hostages are to be returned late Wednesday and more than 600 Palestinian prisoners and detainees freed during the last week of the current Gaza ceasefire deal.

TITLE: What if I'm missing a form? Attorneys answer tax questions from NPR's audience
SUMMARY: We asked our listeners to send us their most befuddling questions about the 2025 tax season. What if you can't pay your tax bill? How good is online tax software? Two tax attorneys weigh in.

TITLE: Did an Alzheimer's drug give Sue and Ken Bell more time? Maybe.
SUMMARY: Sue Bell became one of the first Alzheimer's patients in the U.S. to receive the drug now marketed as Leqembi. Her husband isn't sure if it made a difference.

TITLE: Trump White House seeks tighter grip on message with new limits on press
SUMMARY: In the White House briefing room Tuesday, the Trump administration announced its latest steps to tighten its grip on the message it sends out and the news coverage it receives.

TITLE: How 'Anora' breakout star Yura Borisov crafted a sensitive 'brute'
SUMMARY: Borisov, who plays the hired henchman Igor in <em>Anora

TITLE: Some Trump voters want him to rein in health care costs. It's unclear if he will
SUMMARY: In polls and focus groups, Trump voters say they want to the government to do something about big medical bills. It's a big change from 5 years ago, pollsters say, and may not be on Trump's agenda.

TITLE: Pope Francis is still in critical condition, but he had another 'restful night'
SUMMARY: Francis, 88, has been in critical condition for several days and he has remained absent from several regular appearances. The church has encouraged worshippers around the world to pray for his health.

TITLE: Israelis hold a mass funeral for Shiri Bibas and her two sons killed in Gaza
SUMMARY: Crowds gathered in Israel for the funeral procession of the Bibas family, a mother and two young sons killed while being held hostage in Gaza. The story of their killing has enraged Israelis, and Israeli government representatives were not invited to the funeral.

TITLE: For Women's History Month, NPR wants to know who has made an impact in your life
SUMMARY: Is there a woman who has impacted your life in a profound way? NPR wants to hear your story.

TITLE: Tablets for tots? Survey says kids watch videos on their own devices by age 2
SUMMARY: A.I. is the other big change in the media landscape for kids and parents, the report from Common Sense Media finds.

TITLE: Lunar Trailblazer sets out to find water on the moon
SUMMARY: The Lunar Trailblazer orbiter's launch window opens Feb 26. It's catching a ride with Intuitive Machines IM-2 mission which is landing on the moon near the south pole. Both have instruments for looking for water.

TITLE: Did an Alzheimer's drug give Sue and Ken Bell more time? Maybe
SUMMARY: Sue Bell became one of the first Alzheimer's patients in the U.S. to receive the drug now marketed as Leqembi. Her husband isn't sure if it made a difference.

TITLE: The House passed a budget resolution. What's next? And, a tactic to decrease bird flu
SUMMARY: House Republicans rallied together yesterday to pass multitrillion-dollar plan to address defense, immigration and more. And, why farmers don't like the idea of vaccinating poultry for bird flu.

TITLE: Christianity declines among U.S. adults while "religiously unaffiliated" grows, study says
SUMMARY: The percentage of Christians in the U.S. has dropped dramatically, though that loss may have leveled off in recent years.

TITLE: Meet the 'wooly devil,' a new plant species discovered in Big Bend National Park
SUMMARY: The plant, formally known as <em>Ovicula biradiata

TITLE: Trump's social media video garners pushback from Arabs and Muslims in U.S. and Gaza
SUMMARY: In a seemingly AI-generated video that the president posted on social media, images of destruction due to the war in Gaza are transformed into a glitzy resort called "TRUMP GAZA."

TITLE: The U.S. and Ukraine are close to agreeing on a framework deal for critical minerals
SUMMARY: President Trump says Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will come to the U.S. Friday to sign a deal.

TITLE: Child dies in Texas measles outbreak
SUMMARY: More than 130 people in west Texas and New Mexico have been sickened by measles. The outbreak started in a county with a vaccination rate around 80%.

TITLE: How federal layoffs are impacting national parks, from reduced hours to safety fears
SUMMARY: Some 1,000 NPS employees were fired, and hiring for seasonal positions was delayed. Here's what to know about the impacts already being felt at parks, and what it could mean for the busy season.

TITLE: Israelis hold a funeral procession for Shiri Bibas and her two sons killed in Gaza
SUMMARY: Crowds gathered in Israel for the funeral procession of the Bibas family, a mother and two young sons killed while being held hostage in Gaza. The story of their killing has enraged Israelis, and Israeli government representatives were not invited to the funeral.

TITLE: A pattern emerges in Elon Musk's federal shakeup: 'Break first, ask questions later'
SUMMARY: Five weeks in, there's an emerging pattern in how the Trump administration moves to target federal employees. And it begins with Elon Musk bringing in tactics he's employed at his various businesses.

TITLE: Trump suspends the head of 'The Nation's Report Card'
SUMMARY: Peggy Carr, a federal official who leads one of the country's most extensive student testing programs, known as The Nation's Report Card, was placed on administrative leave.

TITLE: U.K. Prime Minister Keir Starmer is set to visit the White House. Here's what to know
SUMMARY: In his visit on Thursday, the prime minister will try to leverage the U.K.'s so-called "special relationship" with U.S. and act as a bridge between the Trump administration and U.S. allies in Europe.

TITLE: NPR's chief diversity officer to retire, with DEI in the political spotlight
SUMMARY: Chief Diversity Officer Keith Woods announced he'll retire after a 46-year career in journalism and 15 years at NPR, as the issue he has championed takes center stage in political discourse.

TITLE: A child has died in the Texas measles outbreak
SUMMARY: It's the first measles death in the U.S. since 2015. More than 130 people in west Texas and New Mexico have been sickened in the outbreak so far.

TITLE: National parks already feel the effects of layoffs, even before the busy season starts
SUMMARY: Some 1,000 NPS employees were fired, and hiring for seasonal positions was delayed. Here's what to know about the impacts already being felt at parks, and what it could mean for the busy season.

TITLE: Christianity declines among U.S. adults while 'religiously unaffiliated' grows, study says
SUMMARY: The percentage of Christians in the U.S. has dropped dramatically, though that loss may have leveled off in recent years.

TITLE: DOGE expects to send another round of emails to federal workers
SUMMARY: President Trump warned federal workers who did not reply to recent emails asking them to describe "five things" they accomplished are "on the bubble" suggesting they are at risk of losing their jobs.

TITLE: Jeff Bezos' revamp of 'Washington Post' opinions leads editor to quit
SUMMARY: Billionaire Jeff Bezos, who owns the <em>Post

TITLE: Why Dean Karlan, chief economist of USAID, resigned on Tuesday
SUMMARY: He was hired in 2022 so the aid agency could get 'more bang for our buck' with its projects. He tried to reach out to help in the rebuilding of the agency. On Tuesday he tendered his resignation.

TITLE: 'Last Seen': After slavery, family members placed ads looking for loved ones
SUMMARY: Formerly enslaved people would placed ads in newspapers hoping to find lost children, parents, spouses and siblings. Historian Judith Giesberg tells the stories of some of those families in a new book.

TITLE: As Elon Musk continues sweeping cuts to the US government: 'People are really scared'
SUMMARY: DOGE has eliminated thousands of federal jobs and canceled more than 1,000 contracts. Harvard professor Elizabeth Linos warns, "We're seeing harms that are not going to be easily undone."

TITLE: Duolingo's owl mascot is alive after all. What did it gain from faking his death?
SUMMARY: Duolingo's mascot faked his death to get users to do their daily lessons, and attention from pop star Dua Lipa. Here's how he masterminded it — and why one expert sees the campaign as a success.

TITLE: How a son spent a year trying to save his father from conspiracy theories
SUMMARY: Zach Mack spent a year attempting to rescue his father from the depths of the conspiracy rabbit hole. Their family was forced to reckon with clashing realities, ideological divides and misinformation.

TITLE: Oscar-nominated Brazilian film sparks debate about country's past
SUMMARY: Brazilians are flocking to the theaters to see its Oscar-nominated film I Am Still Here. It tells the story of a family devastated by the military dictatorship that ruled from 1964. There has never been a truth commission to investigate abuses or prosecutions of those accused of wrongdoing during a two-decade-long rule. Advocates hope the film might lead to a better understanding of that dark past.

TITLE: Is there a deal to end Russia's war with Ukraine?
SUMMARY:
On Friday, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy is scheduled to meet President Donald Trump at the White House.

On the agenda — a deal for Ukraine to share its rich natural resources. The Trump administration wants hundreds of billions of dollars of rare earth metals and other critical minerals. Details are thin on what exactly Ukraine would get in exchange.

The meeting comes as the world marks three years since Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, and as Trump promises to bring an end to the war.

But bringing an end to the war may not be so simple argues Alexander Vindman.

The Ukrainian-born Vindman was the White House staffer and active duty Army officer, who testified against Trump during his first impeachment trial in 2019.

Trump fired Vindman not long after.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

TITLE: 5 minerals in Ukraine that may be part of a deal with the U.S.
SUMMARY: President Trump says Ukraine is ready to sign a deal with the U.S. to share its mineral wealth. We look at five minerals and metals that could be covered by the deal.

TITLE: The search for the missing Malaysian Airlines Flight MH370 has resumed once again
SUMMARY: After 11 years of the plane's untraceable disappearance, authorities have announced that the search is back on.

TITLE: Musk says federal workers should expect another round of 'pulse check' emails
SUMMARY: President Trump warned federal workers who did not reply to recent emails asking them to describe "five things" they accomplished are "on the bubble" suggesting they are at risk of losing their jobs.

TITLE: NIH partially lifts freeze on funding process for medical research
SUMMARY: Thousands of grant applications had been stalled when the Trump administration blocked the National Institutes of Health from posting notices to the <em>Federal Register.

TITLE: Amy Gleason is the acting administrator of DOGE, the White House says. Who is she?
SUMMARY: Gleason is a healthcare technology executive who worked under Presidents Trump and Biden. The White House says Elon Musk still oversees the Department of Government Efficiency.

TITLE: The Trump administration kills nearly all USAID programs
SUMMARY: The Trump administration is terminating thousands of foreign assistance grants and awards, according to a court filing. The move effectively guts the six-decade-old agency.

TITLE: Taiwan condemns China for conducting shooting drills off its coast
SUMMARY: Taiwan said in a 24-hour period it detected 45 aircraft, 14 navy vessels and one ship from the Chinese military operating around Taiwan, of which 34 had crossed into its waters and airspace.

TITLE: Trump cuts financial lifeline for Venezuela by ending permit to export oil to U.S.
SUMMARY: Trump's accused the government of Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro of not meeting democratic conditions for last year's July presidential election as well as of not moving fast enough to transport back immigrants set for deportation.

TITLE: Over 7,000 from scam centers in Myanmar are awaiting repatriation after crackdown
SUMMARY: Trapped in virtual slavery, many are lured to work in scam centers where they exploit people around the world through false romances, bogus investment pitches and illegal gambling schemes.

TITLE: Hamas returns bodies of four hostages and Israel releases hundreds of Palestinians
SUMMARY: Both sides agreed there would be no Hamas ceremonies for the hostage bodies and in exchange Israel would release the Palestinian detainees and prisoners whose freedom had been held up since Saturday.

TITLE: Curious about exploring your spirituality? Ask yourself these 4 questions
SUMMARY: You don't need to be religious to create a meaningful connection to something greater than yourself. If you're interested in examining that relationship, grab a pen and paper and answer these prompts.

TITLE: The FDIC's goal is to prevent another banking crisis. It's now also a Trump target
SUMMARY: President Trump's sweeping cuts to the federal government are also threatening a key banking watchdog.

TITLE: How Trump's crackdown plays into misperceptions about immigrants and crime
SUMMARY: The White House portrays its immigration crackdown as a success. Critics say the administration is trying to look tough for the cameras, and worry about the "tail wagging the dog."

TITLE: A rare 'parade' of all 7 planets will move across the night sky this week
SUMMARY: This phenomenon known as a "planet parade," will feature Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune all present at the same time along a line in the night sky on Friday, NASA says.

TITLE: Language as protagonist in Cristina Rivera Garza's newly translated novel
SUMMARY: Pulitzer winner Cristina Rivera Garza offers new perspective on gender violence through a murder mystery and poetry.

TITLE: How tariffs are (and aren't) the new 'infrastructure week'
SUMMARY: Little about how Trump discusses tariffs is normal — not only because he threatens tariffs on a weekly, even daily, basis, but also because it's often unclear if or when those tariffs will happen.

TITLE: Trump administration cuts most USAID programs. And, the ethics of leaving your job
SUMMARY: Nearly all USAID programs have been eliminated. One official says it's a "global health massacre." And, a federal judge will hear arguments over the decision to fire thousands of probationary workers.

TITLE: Thailand deports dozens of Uyghurs to China, activists say
SUMMARY: The detainees were part of a group of some 300 Uyghurs who fled China and were arrested in Thailand in 2014. Thailand deported more than 100 of them to China in 2015, drawing condemnation.

TITLE: Republican Sen. Josh Hawley discusses his mission to hold big tech accountable
SUMMARY: Republican Senator Josh Hawley of Missouri talks about his mission to hold tech companies accountable even as they try to align themselves with President Donald Trump.

TITLE: Syrian Jews return to Damascus for the first time in decades, hoping to build bridges
SUMMARY: Thousands of Jews left Syria in 1992, when they were allowed to emigrate. The visit by a small delegation of U.S.-based Syrian Jewish religious figures last week was their first time back since then.

TITLE: Trump shifts date for Canada and Mexico tariffs -- again
SUMMARY: Little about how Trump discusses tariffs is normal — not only because he threatens tariffs on a weekly, even daily, basis, but also because it's often unclear if or when those tariffs will happen.

TITLE: Musk says work to stop Ebola was accidentally cut but restored. Experts raise doubts
SUMMARY: Elon Musk said USAID's "Ebola prevention" was "accidentally canceled" but "immediately" restored. Health specialists following the current outbreak in Uganda raise doubts about the restoration.

TITLE: The U.S. resumes hundreds of millions in security aid to Taiwan, annoying China
SUMMARY: The U.S. has unfrozen millions in security assistance for Taiwan, with an eye toward China.

TITLE: Pentagon directs removal of trans service members from military
SUMMARY: Service members and recruits who are diagnosed with or treated for gender dysphoria are to be separated from the U.S. military in accordance with an executive order issued a month ago by President Trump.

TITLE: Gene Hackman, who thrived playing the tough guy, dies at 95
SUMMARY: Hackman epitomized a 1970s, edgy, tightly wound masculinity. He appeared in more than 100 movies and TV shows, and won Oscars for his performances in The French Connection and Unforgiven.

TITLE: Court will consider halting Trump's mass firings of federal employees
SUMMARY: A federal judge in San Francisco hears arguments in a case challenging the Trump administration's firings of thousands of probationary employees — those in their first year or so on the job.

TITLE: ICE will reopen a major detention center in New Jersey as it eyes a broader expansion
SUMMARY: The Trump administration is expanding its immigration detention capacity, reopening a 1,000-bed detention center in New Jersey and adding beds at other privately owned facilities around the country.

TITLE: Martin Marty, leading scholar of American religion, dies at 97
SUMMARY: Martin Marty, one of the foremost interpreters of religion in American public life, died on Tuesday. He was 97 years old.

TITLE: 2 years after Greece's deadliest train crash, victims and families await answers
SUMMARY: On Feb. 28, 2023, a passenger train and freight train collided, leaving 57 dead. New evidence suggests many may not have been killed by the crash itself, but by a fire that followed.

TITLE: Trump says he doesn't see need for U.S. security guarantees to end Ukraine-Russia war
SUMMARY: In a meeting with the British Prime Minister, Trump said reaching a peace deal would be the "difficult part." He said security would be made easier by a U.S. deal with Ukraine on critical minerals.

TITLE: Andrew Tate, facing rape and trafficking charges in Romania, is back in the U.S.
SUMMARY: The Tate brothers have been allowed to leave Romania, where they were charged with human trafficking, rape and forming a criminal group to sexually exploit women. They arrived in Florida on Thursday.

TITLE: DOGE work could 'cross extreme ethical and legal lines,' says former employee
SUMMARY:
On Tuesday, 21 DOGE employees resigned. NPR spoke to one of them who says she felt the new administration was causing "harm to the American people."

As Elon Musk and the Department of Government Efficiency work to remake the federal government, some of the people tasked with executing his vision have serious concerns about what the changes will do.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

TITLE: Katy Perry and Gayle King are heading to space as part of an all-female Blue Origin crew
SUMMARY: The crew was selected by Bezos' fiancée, journalist Lauren Sánchez, who will also be on the brief suborbital flight scheduled for this spring.

TITLE: An abrupt departure as USAID workers return to clear their desks at DC headquarters.
SUMMARY: The Trump administration has been dismantling the US Agency for International Development, and the headquarters have been closed for weeks. But, on Thursday, workers got to go back to their desks - to clean them out and leave.

TITLE: Data show Tesla sales declined sharply in Europe
SUMMARY: New data out this week shows a sharp decline in Tesla sales in Europe. The company is facing multiple headwinds — including consumer pushback to CEO Elon Musk's political pivot to the right.

TITLE: USAID workers return to HQ to clear their desks, as Trump dismantles the agency
SUMMARY: Workers who served in the U.S. Agency for International Development were allowed a final and brief visit back to their offices to clear out their belongings on Thursday.

TITLE: Trump says new tariffs will cut U.S. drug deaths but fatal overdoses were already plummeting
SUMMARY: President Trump cited outdated drug overdose data to justify tariffs against Canada, China, and Mexico. He also offered no evidence Canada is fueling the U.S. drug crisis.

TITLE: Alzheimer's was taking her memory, so she started taking a new drug
SUMMARY: Myra Solano Garcia, who has Alzheimer's, says the drug Kisunla may be one reason she can still drive, cook, and sing.

TITLE: Court considers halting Trump's mass firings of federal employees
SUMMARY: A federal judge in San Francisco hears arguments in a case challenging the Trump administration's firings of thousands of probationary employees — those in their first year or so on the job.

TITLE: The CFPB drops its lawsuit against Capital One, marking a major reversal
SUMMARY: The consumer protection agency also dropped cases against four other companies including Rocket Homes.

TITLE: Court partially halts Trump's mass firings of federal employees
SUMMARY: A federal judge in San Francisco partially halted the Trump administration's firings of thousands of probationary employees — those in their first year or so on the job.

TITLE: Court finds Trump's mass firings of federal employees is likely illegal
SUMMARY: A federal judge in San Francisco issued a temporary restraining order on the Trump administration's firings of thousands of probationary employees after finding the government likely violated the law.

TITLE: A movement is calling for an 'economic blackout' on Friday. Here's what to know
SUMMARY: The People's Union USA, a grassroots group, is calling on Americans to join a national boycott by not shopping for 24 hours on Friday.

TITLE: Judge says Trump's mass firing of federal employees is illegal and should be stopped
SUMMARY: A federal judge in San Francisco issued a temporary restraining order on the Trump administration's firings of thousands of probationary employees, calling the actions illegal.

TITLE: No signs of forced entry or a carbon monoxide leak in Gene Hackman's death
SUMMARY: Hackman and his wife, Betsy Arakawa, were found dead inside a New Mexico home, as well as a dog. The door to the home was open when a maintenance worker discovered their bodies, an affidavit says.

TITLE: Trump administration layoffs hit NOAA, agency that forecasts weather, hurricanes
SUMMARY: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration houses key groups like the National Weather Service. Experts warn the consequences of employee cuts could be drastic.

TITLE: Boris Spassky, Soviet chess champion who lost to Bobby Fischer, dies at 88
SUMMARY: A televised 1972 match between Spassky and Fischer, at the height of the Cold War, became an international sensation and was known as the "Match of the Century."

TITLE: Mexico sends drug lord Caro Quintero and 28 others to the U.S.
SUMMARY: The unprecedented show of security cooperation comes as top Mexican officials are in Washington trying to head off the Trump administration's threat of imposing 25% tariffs on all Mexican imports.

TITLE: Long ignored, Black modernist architects get recognition
SUMMARY: Black architects who helped shape the modern architecture movement have often been overlooked. One effort preserves the structures they designed and tells their stories.

TITLE: In child care centers and on farms, businesses are bracing for more immigration raids
SUMMARY: The Trump administration's immigration positions — including mass deportation — have put businesses that employ people without legal status on notice.

TITLE: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez tells NPR: 'Everything feels increasingly like a scam'
SUMMARY: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, D-N.Y., about how Democrats are addressing President Trump's agenda.

TITLE: Why some EV buyers are getting their tax returns rejected this year
SUMMARY: The federal EV tax credit, worth up to $7,500, saw big changes in 2024. For buyers, the credit typically became easier to get. But if their dealers skipped a step, it was a different story.

TITLE: Who's in charge of DOGE? (It's not these women. Or the owl.) Find out in the quiz
SUMMARY: Which stores closed and which shows were canceled? Who (or what) was reborn after being hit by a Cybertruck? And is that asteroid going to hit us or what?

TITLE: 1 thing that upended years of U.S. foreign policy — and other big Trump developments
SUMMARY: Three years after Russia launched its invasion of Ukraine, the U.S., in a split with its European allies over the war,  sided with Russia at the U.N.

TITLE: Israeli military cites 'fundamental misunderstanding' of Hamas ahead of Oct. 7 attack
SUMMARY: The report is the Israeli military's first official account of mistakes that preceded the 2023 attack, which launched Israel's subsequent war against Hamas in Gaza that killed more than 48,000 Palestinians.

TITLE: Meeting Trump at White House, Zelenksyy hopes for continued aid in war with Russia
SUMMARY: It's the first face-to-face meeting between Zelenskyy and Trump since Trump's inauguration, and it comes about a week after Trump called Zelenskyy a dictator and repeated Kremlin talking points, including suggesting that Ukraine started the war with Russia.

TITLE: Iowa has high cancer rates. Trump's cuts to CDC and NIH are already hitting the state
SUMMARY: Iowa has the second highest incidence rate of cancer in the country, and it is already feeling Trump's cuts to the workforce and research institutions trying to solve the rural cancer problem.

TITLE: As the Texas outbreak grows, how contagious is measles, really?
SUMMARY: Vaccination eliminated measles from the U.S. 25 years ago. But it can still spread in pockets where vaccination rates are low, like the west Texas county with a current outbreak. Here's how fast.

TITLE: Why the U.S. wants Ukraine's minerals. And AOC speaks with NPR's Steve Inskeep
SUMMARY: Trump and Zelenskyy are expected to meet today in Washington, D.C., to sign a preliminary deal. And, AOC tells NPR why she believes the government only works for the wealthy.

TITLE: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez tells NPR: 'Everything feels increasingly like a scam'
SUMMARY: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, D-N.Y., about how Democrats are addressing President Trump's agenda.

TITLE: Meeting Trump at White House, Zelenskyy hopes for continued aid in war with Russia
SUMMARY: The meeting comes about a week after Trump called Zelenskyy a dictator and repeated Kremlin talking points, including suggesting that Ukraine started the war with Russia.

TITLE: 1 thing that upended years of U.S. foreign policy — and other big Trump developments
SUMMARY: Three years after Russia launched its invasion of Ukraine, the U.S., in a split with its European allies over the war,  sided with Russia at the U.N.

TITLE: Bezos' changes at 'Washington Post' lead to mass subscription cancellations — again
SUMMARY: Washington Post owner Jeff Bezos's changes to the opinion pages have led subscribers to cancel in droves. It's the third wave of mass cancellations at the Post

TITLE: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez tells NPR: 'Everything feels increasingly like a scam'
SUMMARY: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, D-N.Y., about how Democrats are addressing President Trump's agenda.

TITLE: Daring train thieves target BNSF Railway, stealing $2M worth of Nike and other goods
SUMMARY: Train heists aren't just a thing of the Old West. A series of brazen train robberies has emerged across the western United States and authorities say the thieves focus on high-value containers.

TITLE: Trump took down police misconduct database, but states can still share background check info
SUMMARY: In the flurry of first-day executive orders, President Trump revoked a 2022 police accountability package, including a system to flag misconduct.

TITLE: Trump and Zelenskyy's meeting turns into a heated argument
SUMMARY: A meeting between President Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy grew contentious, with Trump telling Zelenskyy that "you're not acting at all thankful" for U.S. support.

TITLE: What to know about the Epstein files release, from redactions to 'Rickrolling'
SUMMARY: The Trump administration touted the release of files in the case of Jeffrey Epstein, the late financier and convicted sex offender, on Thursday. But the documents contained no new revelations.

TITLE: Price of Palestinian prisoner release, and gridlock hell in Lagos
SUMMARY: A Palestinian man serving 18 life sentences for a pair of bus bombings in 2004 speaks to NPR days after his release. And, the average person in Lagos, Nigeria, spends over 6 hours of their day in traffic - have new Chinese-backed railways made a difference?

TITLE: 'Significant workforce reductions' are coming to the Social Security Administration
SUMMARY: The move, which is in line with an executive order from President Trump to slash the federal workforce, raises concerns about staffing at the agency that delivers crucial benefits to Americans.

TITLE: Microsoft will end Skype in May, leaving some users upset
SUMMARY: Microsoft says it will wind down the pioneering and once ubiquitous free video calling service so it can streamline its consumer communications offerings, such as Microsoft Teams.

TITLE: Black Gospel Archive fills gaps in gospel music history
SUMMARY: The Black Gospel Archive at Baylor University is the world's largest digital collection of gospel music.  Now it wants to collect oral histories around its rare recordings.

TITLE: USDA unveils a $1 billion plan to address the egg crisis
SUMMARY: Eggs have become the grocery staple that Americans can't stop talking about, whether its fears of widespread bird flu getting worse or the drastic increase in prices.

TITLE: Detroit closes out Black History Month by honoring iconic legends of jazz and blues
SUMMARY: The iconic voices of female jazz & blues legends Billie Holiday, Phyllis Hyman, Nancy Wilson and Bessie Smith were honored at Aretha's Jazz Café in Detroit for Black History Month

TITLE: Pope Francis experiences respiratory relapse
SUMMARY: The Vatican says Pope Francis's condition has worsened after a breathing crisis in hospital  on Friday -  two weeks after he was first admitted to hospital in Rome with bronchitis.

TITLE: Zelenskyy leaves the White House early after Trump meeting gets heated
SUMMARY: A meeting between President Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy grew contentious, with Trump telling Zelenskyy that "you're not acting at all thankful" for U.S. support.

TITLE: The Social Security Administration says it plans to cut some 7,000 jobs
SUMMARY: The move, which is in line with an executive order from President Trump to slash the federal workforce, raises concerns about staffing at the agency that delivers crucial benefits to Americans.

TITLE: Gene Hackman's pacemaker activity suggests he died several days before he was found
SUMMARY: Hackman's pacemaker was last active on Feb. 17, according to the Santa Fe County Sheriff Adan Mendoza. He said Friday it is "a very good assumption" that was his death date.

TITLE: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez Says She's Fighting President Trump's "Illusion of Power"
SUMMARY:
Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, a New York Democrat, says she thinks Republicans have begun making mistakes... and her party is resolved to strike back.

Want more comprehensive analysis of the most important news of the day, plus a little fun? Subscribe to the Up First newsletter.

This bonus episode of Up First was edited by Susan Davis, Kelsey Snell and Reena Advani. It was produced by Adam Bearne. We get engineering support from Neil Tevault and Hannah Gluvna. Our Executive Producer is Kelley Dickens.

TITLE: Federal workers get a new email demanding their accomplishments
SUMMARY: Federal employees have received a second email from the Office of Personnel Management asking them what they did last week.

TITLE: In the federal court system, law clerks find little recourse for bullying and abuse
SUMMARY: An NPR investigation finds federal judges have enormous influence with few checks on their power. Law clerks and other judicial employees are vulnerable to mistreatment and have few job protections.

TITLE: DOGE's savings page fixed old mistakes — and added new ones
SUMMARY: An NPR review of new data added to DOGE's "wall of receipts" finds the group quietly changed previous errors, added new ones and still has little verified savings to show for its work.

TITLE: Voice of America bias inquiry sparks concerns of political meddling
SUMMARY: Voice of America is reviewing the social media posts of a reporter for possible bias against the Trump Administration. The review is sparking concerns of political meddling.

TITLE: Hamas rejects Israel's request to extend phase one of Gaza ceasefire
SUMMARY: Hamas says it is not willing to extend the first phase of the Gaza ceasefire, rejecting an Israeli request to delay negotiations on the second phase.

TITLE: Can Faith Kipyegon break four minutes in the mile? Scientists say yes.
SUMMARY: <em>Faith Kipyegon, the fastest female miler in the world, could dip under 4 minutes with an extra boost from pacers.

TITLE: How to watch the Oscars on Sunday night
SUMMARY: The 97th Academy Awards will air on ABC and stream on Hulu at 7 p.m. ET. Comedian and actor Conan O'Brien is hosting and <em>Wicked

TITLE: Trump will address Congress. Why isn't this first speech called a State of the Union?
SUMMARY: Trump will give his first speech to Congress next Tuesday since his reelection. It has characteristics of what Americans call a State of the Union address, but it's not officially designated as such.

TITLE: Opinion: Remembering Gene Hackman
SUMMARY: NPR's Scott Simon remembers Gene Hackman, who played everymen, cops and villains over his long movie career. The 95 year old actor and his wife were found dead this week in their New Mexico home.

TITLE: These National Park workers say a Trump agency fired them illegally. A judge agrees
SUMMARY: Eileen and James Kramer were fired from their jobs at Lake Clark National Park in Alaska, even though they both recently received promotions. A judge has found the administration's firings illegal.

TITLE: ICE is making more arrests, but critics say some claims don't add up
SUMMARY: Immigration authorities are making more arrests than they did under President Biden. But the Department of Homeland Security's own data shows that they're not keeping pace with White House demands.

TITLE: European leaders renew support for Ukraine after Zelenskyy's stormy meeting with Trump
SUMMARY: Leaders from across Europe came quickly to the defense of Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, after his televised clash with President Trump and Vice President Vance.

TITLE: Alabama governor commutes a death row inmate's sentence to life in prison
SUMMARY: Alabama Gov. Kay Ivey commuted the death sentence of Robin "Rocky" Myers to life in prison, saying there were enough questions about his guilt that she could not move forward with his execution.

TITLE: In the federal court system, law clerks find little recourse for bullying and abuse
SUMMARY: An NPR investigation finds federal judges have enormous influence with few checks on their power. Law clerks and other judicial employees are vulnerable to mistreatment and have few job protections.

TITLE: Legendary former NIH director retires from embattled agency
SUMMARY: Dr. Francis Collins is leaving the National Institutes of Health, where he served as director from 2009 to 2021. The agency is facing cutbacks and restrictions under the Trump administration.

TITLE: Up to 3,000 more U.S. troops are ordered to the border with Mexico
SUMMARY: Up to 3,000 additional troops have been ordered to the U.S.-Mexico border by Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, the latest in President Trump's efforts to prevent illegal crossings.

TITLE: Kurdish militant group PKK declares ceasefire after decades of conflict with Turkey
SUMMARY: Militants from the Kurdistan Workers' Party have declared a ceasefire, in what may represent a significant political breakthrough for Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan.

TITLE: Taking a ride on a freight train to cover migration to the U.S.
SUMMARY: For decades, migrants have been riding north through Mexico aboard a freight train nicknamed "La Bestia." An NPR reporter hopped on board to ask some migrants why they do it.

TITLE: Trump signs executive order making English the official language of the U.S.
SUMMARY: In the nearly 250-year history of the United States, English had never been designated as the nation's official language.

TITLE: Judge rules head of watchdog agency must keep his job, says his firing was unlawful
SUMMARY: A U.S. District judge sided with Hampton Dellinger, who leads the Office of Special Counsel, in a legal battle over the president's authority to oust the head of the independent agency.

TITLE: ACLU and other advocates sue to block migrants from being sent to Guantánamo Bay
SUMMARY: The lawsuit says there is no legitimate reason to send migrants to Guantánamo because the U.S. has ample detention facility.

TITLE: Israel stops the delivery of aid to Gaza until Hamas accepts U.S. ceasefire extension
SUMMARY: Israel says it is stopping the delivery of aid to Gaza until Hamas accepts a U.S. proposal for an extension of the ceasefire deal.

TITLE: UK, France and Ukraine agree to work on ceasefire plan for Russia's war in Ukraine
SUMMARY: Britain, France and Ukraine have agreed to work on a ceasefire plan to present to the U.S., British Prime Minister Keir Starmer said Sunday as he prepared to host a summit of European leaders.

TITLE: What will Trump say in his Tuesday address? We look to the past for some clues
SUMMARY: Delivered the day before he was acquitted in his first impeachment case, and as COVID began to spread, President Trump's 2020 address was part reality TV, part gameshow and part WWE smackdown.

TITLE: Private lunar lander Blue Ghost touches down on the moon
SUMMARY: A private lunar lander carrying a drill and other experiments for NASA touched down on the moon Sunday, the latest in a string of companies looking to kickstart business on the celestial neighbor.

TITLE: Israel halts all aid to Gaza, delays negotiations for phase two of the ceasefire
SUMMARY: As phase one of the ceasefire expires, Israel is halting all aid into Gaza.

TITLE: Pakistan is out of its own cricket tournament, but its fans are still excited to host
SUMMARY: The country is hosting a major international cricket tournament for the first time in a generation. It's a much-needed bright spot in a nation that's confronted recent economic and political crises.

TITLE: GOP congressman Lawler says "only winner" in tense Trump-Zelenskyy summit was Putin
SUMMARY: NPR's Ayesha Rascoe talks with Rep. Mike Lawler, R-N.Y., about U.S.-Ukraine policy following Friday's combative meeting between Presidents Trump and Zelenskyy.

TITLE: How Washington is reacting to the heated Trump-Zelenskyy meeting
SUMMARY: Trump adviser Mike Waltz says the U.S. has "a real issue on our hands" if Ukrainian President Zelenskyy doesn't come back to negotiating table in its war with Russia.

TITLE: "We're on the moon": private Blue Ghost spacecraft makes an historic lunar landing
SUMMARY: A commercial spacecraft carrying NASA experiments successfully touched down on the moon's surface early Sunday morning, ushering in a new phase of private space exploration.

TITLE: UK prime minister unveils steps toward a Ukraine peace deal, urges US cooperation
SUMMARY: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer pledged more military aid, as well as the possibility of weapons and boots on the ground, to secure peace in Ukraine.

TITLE: Oscars 2025: The complete list of winners
SUMMARY: The 97th Academy Awards are underway at the Dolby Theatre in Hollywood, Calif. Find out who is taking home an Oscar.

TITLE: Zoe Saldaña wins Oscar for best supporting actress in 'Emilia Pérez'
SUMMARY: This is Saldaña's first-ever Oscar win, and her first ever Oscar nomination.

TITLE: Angie Stone, soul singer who broke ground in hip-hop, dies at 63
SUMMARY: Stone, a Grammy-nominated R&B singer who rose to fame in the late 1970s, was known for hits like "No More Rain" and "Wish I Didn't Miss You. She was killed in a road collision in Alabama on Saturday.

TITLE: At Oscars, 'No Other Land' co-directors call for national rights for Palestinians
SUMMARY: The Oscar-winning documentary, made by a team of Palestinian-Israeli filmmakers, follows the displacement of rural Palestinian communities in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.

TITLE: Sean Baker wins Oscars for writing, editing and directing 'Anora'
SUMMARY: Baker has said it was a feat just to get his low-budget film funded.

TITLE: Crews battle wildfires in North and South Carolina amid dry conditions
SUMMARY: The National Weather Service warned of increased fire danger in the region due to a combination of critically dry fuels and very low relative humidity.

TITLE: Poll: Majorities say state of the union is not strong, and Trump is rushing change
SUMMARY: How Americans are reacting to the first month of the administration, according to an NPR/PBS News/Marist poll.

TITLE: Foreign students say the threat of Trump's executive orders is getting real
SUMMARY: President Trump warned international students that if they support groups the U.S. deems terrorist organizations, "we will find you, and we will deport you." It's left many student activists anxious.

TITLE: Trump wants Palestinians out of Gaza. Here are Egypt's plans to keep them there
SUMMARY: Arab leaders will meet in Cairo to reject Palestinian displacement from Gaza. NPR looks at Egypt's reconstruction plans for Gaza that counter President Trump's ideas of expulsion.

TITLE: Seeing Washington change course on Ukraine, Taiwan ponders its own fate
SUMMARY: Developments in the Ukraine-U.S. relationship have regularly made headline news in Taiwan lately. Many in Taiwan compare Ukraine's fate to its own, as China continues to threaten an invasion.

TITLE: What you need to know about Trump's address to joint session of Congress
SUMMARY: President Trump will lay out his second term agenda in an address to a joint session of Congress on Tuesday night. From talk on tariffs to the U.S. role in the world, here's what to expect.

TITLE: To solve for doctor shortages, states ease licensing for foreign-trained physicians
SUMMARY: Some states are trying to make it easier for doctors trained in other countries to work in the U.S. Skeptics say other licensing and hiring barriers could hamper this effort.

TITLE: European leaders pledge to back Ukraine. And, takeaways from the Oscars
SUMMARY: Several global leaders pledged support for Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy's efforts to stop Russia's war. And, heartfelt speeches, a big surprise and history were made at the Oscars.

TITLE: Private company's Blue Ghost spacecraft makes historic lunar landing
SUMMARY: For the first time, a private company has successfully landed a probe on the moon.  Firefly Aerospace's "Blue Ghost" lander touched down on the lunar surface early Sunday morning.

TITLE: 'I was devastated': Jordan Chiles recounts 2024 Olympics in new memoir
SUMMARY: Olympic gymnast Jordan Chiles shares her up-and-down journey to the 2024 Paris Games and what happened afterward, in her new memoir, "I'm That Girl: Living the Power of My Dreams."

TITLE: Israel's culture minister calls a Palestinian-Israeli film's Oscar a 'sad moment'
SUMMARY: The Oscar documentary win by the movie <em>No Other Land

TITLE: After an Alzheimer's diagnosis, a new job gave a father 'dignity' and 'purpose'
SUMMARY: When Paul Cotter's father began to show signs of early-onset Alzheimer's disease, he lost job after job. Then a small local company offered him a role that helped rebuild his sense of purpose.

TITLE: James Harrison, whose blood donations saved over 2 million babies, has died
SUMMARY: Harrison, whose plasma contained a rare antibody, rolled up his sleeve 1,173 times from 1954 to 2018. The Australian is credited with helping 2.4 million babies and advancing scientific research.

TITLE: Kroger's longtime CEO resigns abruptly after investigation
SUMMARY: The country's largest grocery chain cited an investigation into conduct "unrelated to the business" but inconsistent with its code of ethics. Rodney McMullen had led Kroger since 2014.

TITLE: The political power of the pope
SUMMARY:
Unlike any other religious leader around the world, the leader of the world's one billion Catholics is also the leader of a sovereign nation. And Pope Francis hasn't been shy about using that political power.

He's pushed for an end to the wars between Hamas and Israel, and Russia and Ukraine.

And he's repeatedly tried to point the world's attention to two ongoing challenges: immigration and climate change.

Much of the world has spent the last two weeks focused on Pope Francis' health. And the reason why has as much to do with the fact that he's a powerful geopolitical force as it does with the fact he's a key religious figure.
