TITLE: New deputy FBI director Dan Bongino previously called for imprisoning Democrats
SUMMARY: Before becoming the second-in-command at the FBI, Dan Bongino used his popular podcast to spread conspiracy theories about the Jan. 6 attack. Here's what else he said.

TITLE: Pope Francis has acute respiratory crises, the Vatican says
SUMMARY: Pope Francis experienced more respiratory problems and went on noninvasive ventilation on Monday, the Vatican said, as the head of the Roman Catholic Church battles double pneumonia in the hospital.

TITLE: Elon Musk's Starship rocket prepares to fly again
SUMMARY: The latest test of Starship comes after an explosion over the Caribbean sent commercial airlines scattering to avoid falling rocket debris

TITLE: Kroger CEO resigns abruptly after 'personal conduct' investigation
SUMMARY: The country's largest supermarket chain is shaking up its leadership after Rodney McMullen had led the company since 2014.

TITLE: With Trump in office, U.S. allies lose standing, security
A Political Dilemma for Israel's Prime Minister
SUMMARY: Our correspondent takes a look at the near future of the the war with Hamas in Gaza through the eyes of Israel's prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu. He is being pulled in opposite directions politically: President Trump wants the ceasefire in Gaza to continue, while influential right-wing members of Netanyahu's political coalition want fighting to resume.

TITLE: This Colombian 'hotel for cows' could help reduce deforestation in the Amazon
SUMMARY: Clearing land for cattle and cows is the single biggest driver of rainforest loss in the Amazon. This "hotel for cows" in Colombia offers a solution.

TITLE: Trump says 25% tariffs on imports from Canada and Mexico will go ahead
SUMMARY: Trump's threats to put tariffs on imports from Canada and Mexico have weighed on markets, even though there has been considerable uncertainty over whether he would make good on his threat.

TITLE: NASA's upcoming telescope launch aims to address some existential questions
SUMMARY: The new 8.5-foot telescope is set to launch this Tuesday by NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory with a clear objective: to explore the origins of the universe.

TITLE: Linda McMahon has been confirmed as Trump's secretary of education
SUMMARY: The White House has been clear that it intends to dismantle the U.S. Department of Education, and that it will be McMahon's job to oversee that effort.

TITLE: Auto industry braces for a blow from 25% tariffs on Canada and Mexico
SUMMARY: The White House describes the tariffs as a response to inadequate border and drug enforcement. They are forecast to add thousands of dollars to the price of vehicles.

TITLE: Severe weather and critical fire risk, ranked 'multi-hazard,' expected nationwide
SUMMARY: A spring storm is bringing various weather conditions across the U.S. Some regions are facing snow, possible tornadoes, and critical fire conditions, according to the National Weather Service (NWS).

TITLE: President Trump pauses Ukraine military aid
SUMMARY: The news comes just days after a disastrous meeting between President Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy.

TITLE: China slaps extra tariffs of up to 15% on imports of major U.S. farm exports
SUMMARY: China will impose additional tariffs of up to 15% on imports of U.S. farm products, including chicken, pork, and soy. They follow Trump's order to raise tariffs on imports of Chinese products to 20%.

TITLE: Canada and China retaliate after Trump's tariffs take effect
SUMMARY: Canada and China hit back swiftly after Trump's sweeping tariffs took effect Tuesday, raising fears of a global trade war. International markets, meanwhile, continued to slide.

TITLE: Rural schools in Alaska are crumbling. The state is the likely culprit
SUMMARY: Rural school districts depend on the state to fund construction and maintenance projects. But over the past 25 years, Alaska lawmakers have ignored hundreds of requests for public schools that primarily serve Indigenous children.

TITLE: From blah to buoyant, these skills can improve your mood and optimism
SUMMARY: Last fall, thousands of people took part in a stress reduction study, learning skills that can improve mood and reduce anxiety. The results are in: Here's what they show.

TITLE: 4 things to know about Trump's plan for a 'crypto strategic reserve'
SUMMARY: The prospect of a federal strategic reserve is a major step in President Trump's vision to establish the U.S. as the crypto capital of the world and could be a game changer for the industry.

TITLE: Celebrated author Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie: 'I have always longed to be known'
SUMMARY: Celebrated Nigerian writer Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie speaks with NPR's Michel Martin about her new book, "Dream Count."

TITLE: Trump agencies drop dozens of Biden-era cases against crypto, other companies
SUMMARY: A Public Citizen report obtained exclusively by NPR shows the new administration has halted or tried to dismiss cases or investigations against at least 89 companies in the last month.

TITLE: Mexico faces off with U.S. gunmakers at the Supreme Court
SUMMARY: The country claims Smith & Wesson and other gunmakers are turning a blind eye to hundreds of thousands of high-powered weapons made in the U.S that are illegally trafficked into in the hands of Mexican cartels.

TITLE: Swing state Sen. Elissa Slotkin to deliver rebuttal to Trump's speech to Congress
SUMMARY: Michigan's first-term senator, Slotkin — a centrist with deep national security credentials — will deliver the Democrats' rebuttal to President Trump's first speech to a joint session of Congress.

TITLE: Tariffs have businesses bracing for change in Trump country
SUMMARY: President Trump's tariff policy is creating uncertainty for places like Tupelo, Miss. with a manufacturing-dependent economy. It's in a conservative county where Trump got nearly 70% of the vote.

TITLE: As Trump shrinks other parts of government, immigration task forces grow
SUMMARY: The Trump administration is tapping several other agencies to help deport and arrest those without legal status — a novel step that is prompting some pushback.

TITLE: After an Alzheimer's diagnosis, a new job gave a father 'dignity' and 'purpose'
SUMMARY: When Paul Cotter's father began to show signs of early-onset Alzheimer's disease, he lost job after job. Then, a small local company offered him a role that helped rebuild his sense of purpose.

TITLE: How to watch Trump's address to Congress. And, Canada retaliates against tariffs
SUMMARY: Trump will deliver a speech to Congress tonight, during which he is expected to discuss steps he has taken to further his agenda since taking office. And, Canada and China retaliate against tariffs.

TITLE: Trump is asserting extraordinary power over independent agencies. Is the Fed next?
SUMMARY: The rise and potential fall of independent agencies.

TITLE: Europe considers a major defense spending package as Trump signals disengagement
SUMMARY: European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen proposed an $840 billion plan to build up the bloc's defense, as President Trump pauses military aid to Ukraine.

TITLE: Hoping to revive mammoths, scientists create 'woolly mice'
SUMMARY: Hoping to bring the giant, ancient animal back from extinction, scientists have created a far smaller woolly creature. Woolly mice have some of the key traits of mammoths, including their thick, hairy coat.

TITLE: Chappy the baby seal has died, weeks after being rescued in a Connecticut city
SUMMARY: The aquarium helping Chappy — a nod to the New Haven, Conn., neighborhood where he was rescued last month — said he died of gastrointestinal issues and "was surrounded by love until the very end."

TITLE: Chinese architect Liu Jiakun wins the 2025 Pritzker Prize
SUMMARY: The jury cited Liu's "reverence for culture, history and nature, chronicling time and comforting users with familiarity through modern interpretations of classic Chinese architecture."

TITLE: 4 things to know about Trump's plan for a 'crypto strategic reserve'
SUMMARY: The prospect of a federal strategic reserve is a major step in President Trump's vision to establish the U.S. as the crypto capital of the world and could be a game changer for the industry.

TITLE: U.S. stock market plunge as Trump's tariffs spark fears about a trade war
SUMMARY: U.S. stock markets plummeted on Tuesday morning as a new global trade war began.

TITLE: Canada, China say fentanyl crisis is only a "pretext" for Trump's new tariffs
SUMMARY: Canadian and Chinese officials say they were already helping reduce fentanyl smuggling.  Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said fentanyl crossing the northern border is "near zero."

TITLE: Vance's comments about European peacekeeping plan for Ukraine draw ire abroad
SUMMARY: Vice President Vance said the best security guarantee for Ukraine is to sign a mineral deal with the United States.

TITLE: U.S. stock markets plunge as Trump's tariffs spark fears about a trade war
SUMMARY: U.S. stock markets plummeted on Tuesday morning as a new global trade war began.

TITLE: Canada and China say the fentanyl crisis is only a 'pretext' for Trump's new tariffs
SUMMARY: Canadian and Chinese officials say they were already helping reduce fentanyl smuggling.  Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said fentanyl crossing the northern border is "near zero."

TITLE: The CFPB drops its case against payment app Zelle, in another sign of a Trump pivot
SUMMARY: It's the latest lawsuit abandoned by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau since Trump appointees have taken over at the bureau.

TITLE: American businesses reel as Trump tariffs start to bite
SUMMARY: Business owners across the country worry they will also suffer the impact from President Trump's tariffs on imports from Mexico, Canada and China.

TITLE: Fired federal workers are among the guests invited to Trump's speech to Congress
SUMMARY: The Trumps and lawmakers from across the aisle have invited guests to Tuesday's joint address, representing some of the administration's top priorities. Here's a look at some of the names on the list.

TITLE: Trump administration again labels the Houthis a 'foreign terrorist organization'
SUMMARY: Trump's first administration similarly designated the Houthis, but the designation was revoked by President Joe Biden's administration over concerns it would affect the delivery of aid to Yemen.

TITLE: An Algerian scientist splits his gaze between microbes and Mars
SUMMARY: Searching for small fossils in big rocks requires specialized tools --tools that scientists could also use to look for evidence of life on Mars in rocks that may be similar on both planets.

TITLE: Trump administration signals it will let Idaho enforce its restrictive abortion ban
SUMMARY: The Justice Department said it would move to dismiss a lawsuit originally filed against Idaho by the Biden administration, according to court papers filed by the state's largest hospital network.

TITLE: Mexico and Canada React to U.S. Tariffs; Ukraine Adjusts to Losing U.S. Support
SUMMARY: The Trump administration has made good on it's threat to apply 25% tariffs to the two biggest U.S. trading partners, Mexico and Canada. China also had its tariff increased from 10 to 20 percent. Canada and China are hitting back with retaliatory tariffs and Mexico has promised to follow suit. We hear about the reaction and impact.

TITLE: At the Supreme Court, justices are skeptical of Mexico's arguments against gunmakers
SUMMARY: Mexico is accusing the gunmakers of aiding and abetting the gushing pipeline of military-style weapons from the U.S. to Mexican cartels.

TITLE: Trump vowed to end surprise medical bills. The team working on that just got slashed
SUMMARY: Trump's first round of staff cuts to federal agencies eliminated dozens of positions at the Center for Consumer Information and Insurance Oversight, in charge of implementing the No Surprises Act.

TITLE: A new collection of Harper Lee's writing is coming later this year
SUMMARY: The beloved author of <em>To Kill a Mockingbird

TITLE: South Carolina plans to carry out a firing squad execution. Is it safe for witnesses?
SUMMARY: South Carolina plans to execute its first prisoner by firing squad on March 7 inside the same death chamber it's used for dozens of other executions. Firearms experts say that could be risky.

TITLE: State Dept. staffers get mixed messages on how to serve international students
SUMMARY: A State Department program meant to convince international students to pursue higher education in the United States can't seem to get answers on whether they're allowed to talk about increasing diversity in U.S. classrooms.

TITLE: OPM alters memo about probationary employees but does not order mass firings reversed
SUMMARY: The Office of Personnel Management has revised a Jan. 20 memo asking federal agencies to identify probationary employees ahead of a mass firing. The reissued memo does not order fired workers reinstated.

TITLE: Follow NPR's annotated fact check of President Trump's address to Congress
SUMMARY: As President Trump addresses a joint session of Congress tonight, reporters from across NPR's newsroom will fact check and offer context as the speech unfolds.

TITLE: Trump will address a joint session of Congress tonight. Here's what to expect
SUMMARY: The president's address to a joint session of Congress is expected to touch on everything from DOGE and immigration, to tariffs and the future of U.S. support for Ukraine.

TITLE: Listen to NPR live coverage of Trump's address and the Democratic response
SUMMARY: President Trump addresses a joint session of Congress tonight. NPR's live special coverage — which includes the Democratic response to Trump's speech — starts at 9 p.m. EST.

TITLE: In a sudden reversal, CDC rescinds some staff firings
SUMMARY: Some employees who were previously fired received emails saying they're "cleared to return to work."

TITLE: Blizzards, wildfires and thunderstorms are expected across the nation on Wednesday
SUMMARY: A major storm sweeps across the U.S., bringing severe weather conditions such as blizzards, wildfires and tornadoes. Blizzard warnings are in effect for Nebraska, Kansas, Missouri, Iowa and Minnesota.

TITLE: Listen to NPR's live coverage of Trump's address and the Democratic response
SUMMARY: President Trump addresses a joint session of Congress tonight. NPR's live special coverage — which includes the Democratic response to Trump's speech — starts at 9 p.m. EST.

TITLE: Watch live: President Trump addresses a joint session of Congress
SUMMARY: The president's address to a joint session of Congress is expected to touch on everything from DOGE and immigration to tariffs and the future of U.S. support for Ukraine.

TITLE: Starting with Rep. Al Green, Democrats protest against Trump's speech to Congress
SUMMARY: The Texas Democrat stood, shouting, as the president addressed a joint session of Congress. After refusing to retake his seat, Speaker Mike Johnson ordered Rep. Green removed from the chamber.

TITLE: Trump says he is 'just getting started,' as he faces vocal protests from Democrats
SUMMARY: Trump addressed a sharply divided Congress, as he claimed an electoral mandate and vowed his administration was "just getting started." Throughout the speech, he faced repeated jeers from Democrats.

TITLE: From cheers to protests, here's a look inside the chamber during Trump's speech
SUMMARY: Partisan divisions were on display as Republican lawmakers gave Trump frequent standing ovations, while Democrats sat stone faced, held signs and walked out of the chamber in protest.

TITLE: Trump's speech is longest joint address to Congress in recent history
SUMMARY: With his address clocking in at more than 90 minutes, President Trump's address to a joint session of Congress is the longest speech of its kind in at least sixty years.

TITLE: Read President Trump's 2025 address to a joint session of Congress
SUMMARY: Read President Trump's address to a joint session of Congress delivered on March 4.

TITLE: Spanish-language rebuttal to Trump's joint address focuses on immigration
SUMMARY: New York Rep. Adriano Espaillat delivered the Democrats' Spanish-language rebuttal to President Trump's joint address, focusing on the president's immigration policy.

TITLE: Cybercrime crew stole then resold hundreds of tickets to Swift shows, prosecutors say
SUMMARY: Prosecutors say the majority of the stolen tickets were for Swift's Eras Tour, but the thieves also boosted ones for Adele and Ed Sheeran concerts, NBA games and the U.S. Open Tennis Championships.

TITLE: Watch NPR's full special coverage of Trump's speech and the Democrats' response
SUMMARY: President Trump addressed a joint session of Congress tonight. Watch NPR's full special coverage — which includes the Democratic response to Trump's speech.

TITLE: China's parliament opens with confidence about the economy despite tariffs, headwinds
SUMMARY: China will aim for economic growth of around 5% this year, the same as last year. This comes despite deep domestic challenges and fresh tariffs on Chinese imports to the U.S.

TITLE: Dear Life Kit: My friend texts me way too much. How do I get her to stop?
SUMMARY: An NPR listener says her friend pings her morning, noon and night, even if she doesn't respond. She'd like to say something, but she's afraid it will hurt her friend's feelings.

TITLE: 6 takeaways from Trump's pointedly partisan address to Congress
SUMMARY: After a firehose of a first six weeks back in the White House, President Trump delivered a boastful and partisan address to a joint session of Congress Tuesday night. Here are six takeaways from the speech.

TITLE: 'God walks with us through the ashes.' A poignant Ash Wednesday after LA wildfires
SUMMARY: On Ash Wednesday, Christians hear the words "Remember that you are dust and to dust you shall return." Those words ring differently for many whose churches and homes burned in the Los Angeles fires.

TITLE: In Key West, testing shows cruise ships stir up as much sediment as a hurricane
SUMMARY: Tests in Key West show sediment stirred up by cruise ships, which can harm marine life, routinely exceed federal standards. Key West has responded by suspending the tests.

TITLE: Consumers can buy Zepbound direct from the drugmaker if they'll pay out of pocket
SUMMARY: Eli Lilly is offering vials of its obesity drug Zepbound to patients at a discount — but only if they skip their insurance.

TITLE: Why a small Colorado town wants to buy its neighboring ski resort
SUMMARY: Big conglomerates dominate ownership of America's ski resorts. When a Colorado ski hill went up for sale, a neighboring town launched a bid to buy it to preserve its relaxed culture and affordability.

TITLE: Takeaways from Trump's address to Congress. And, China projects confidence in economy
SUMMARY: President Trump delivered a partisan address to a joint session of Congress last night, boasting about his accomplishments from the first six weeks. And, China projects confidence in its economy.

TITLE: What went wrong? Israel's spy agency lists failures in preventing Oct. 7 attack
SUMMARY: Israel's domestic security agency had Hamas' battle plans for the Oct. 7, 2023 attacks but didn't take them seriously. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu deflected responsibility for the failure.

TITLE: Meet the Syrians behind the music that inspired a revolution
SUMMARY: Syrian soccer player Abdel Basset al-Sarout became the poster child for the Syrian revolution with his iconic protest anthems. In death, he has become its saint. But he didn't do it alone.

TITLE: Nominee to run NIH faces Senate scrutiny
SUMMARY: Dr. Jay Bhattacharya, a Stanford professor of health policy, appears before the Senate HELP committee, which will vet his nomination to become the next director of the National Institutes of Health.

TITLE: Supreme Court upholds lower court order to force USAID to pay contractors
SUMMARY: In an order, the justices left in place a lower court order that so far has only required the Trump administration to pay contractors for foreign aid work that has already been completed — roughly $2 billion.

TITLE: A star generation of women's soccer has retired. A new series shows who to watch next
SUMMARY: A trailblazing generation of players is retiring. In a new docuseries from Prime Video, we hear from a new group of players and coaches vying to be the next best in American women's soccer.

TITLE: How did 'DEI' become part of a larger political agenda -- and a slur?
SUMMARY: Georgetown professor Ella Washington and Harvard professor Frank Dobbin discuss the beneficiaries and misperceptions of DEI, and who will be hurt as it's dismantled across public and private sectors.

TITLE: Dozens of Canadians are charged for scamming American grandparents out of $21 million
SUMMARY: The 25 Canadians are accused of calling seniors in over 40 states, pretending to be their grandchildren and asking for bail money. Authorities warn such scams are getting increasingly sophisticated.

TITLE: Nearly 6,000 USDA workers fired by Trump ordered back to work for now
SUMMARY: The U.S. Department of Agriculture must temporarily reinstate nearly 6,000 probationary employees fired since Feb. 13, according to a ruling by the Merit Systems Protection Board.

TITLE: Supreme Court upholds a lower court order to force USAID to pay contractors
SUMMARY: In an order, the justices left in place a lower court order that so far has only required the Trump administration to pay contractors for foreign aid work that has already been completed — roughly $2 billion.

TITLE: Consumers can buy Zepbound and Wegovy direct from drugmakers if they pay cash
SUMMARY: Eli Lilly is offering vials of its weight-loss drug Zepbound to patients at a discount — but only if they skip their insurance. Novo Nordisk is now discounting Wegovy for cash customers too.

TITLE: In a policy shift, U.S. and Hamas say they're in direct talks on hostages
SUMMARY: A Hamas official tells NPR that the United States has held direct talks with the Palestinian militant group over the release of several American-Israeli dual citizens taken hostage during the Oct. 7, 2023, attacks in Israel.

TITLE: Sesame Workshop will 'downsize significantly' with layoffs, CEO says
SUMMARY: The layoffs come after 200 Sesame Workshop employees announced they want to form a union.

TITLE: NPS takes down web pages dedicated to transgender activists
SUMMARY: This is part of an ongoing move by the federal government to remove and alter National Park Service webpages related to LGBTQ history.

TITLE: Trump grants automakers temporary relief from tariffs
SUMMARY: The White House said President Trump has given automakers a one-month reprieve from tariffs on imports from Canada and Mexico.

TITLE: Can democrats find their way out of the wilderness?
SUMMARY:
A hundred minutes — that's how long President Trump had the floor — literally — last night.

A hundred minutes he used to lay out his agenda, his grievances and what he argued are the accomplishments of his first six weeks in office.

This all came during his "joint address" to Congress — the State of the Union that's not a State of the Union.

Since Trump returned to office in January, there's been little room left for democrats to make their case to the American people.

Democratic moderates think they have an answer for Trump 2.0. What does their playbook look like?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: What to know about Lesotho, the country Trump said 'nobody has ever heard of'
SUMMARY: President Trump defended his humanitarian aid cuts to countries around the globe, including one nation he joked "nobody has ever heard of." Here are some facts about the African nation of Lesotho.

TITLE: By the numbers: Does LeBron James' new points record shake up the GOAT debate?
SUMMARY: LeBron James has been so good for so long, there's a famous running joke about when he might slow down. At age 40, where does his 50,000 career points record put him in the GOAT debate?

TITLE: In a first, the 2026 World Cup final will include a halftime show
SUMMARY: Like the Super Bowl mid-game spectaculars, the 2026 final game slated to take place at MetLife Stadium in New Jersey will include the World Cup's very first halftime show.

TITLE: Going Back in Time to Soviet Central Asia's Boogie Nights
SUMMARY: Today we take a break from the serious and often depressing international news beat to bring you the sound's of Soviet Central Asia in the 1970's and 80's. Our Moscow correspondent introduces us to an anthology of songs that came out of a record factory in Tashkent documenting a wide variety of music from the silk road in that time period.

TITLE: NPS takes down web pages dedicated to transgender activists and LGBTQ history
SUMMARY: This is part of an ongoing move by the federal government to remove and alter National Park Service webpages related to LGBTQ history.

TITLE: Trump says tariffs will help stop fentanyl. Many of his claims on the crisis are untrue
SUMMARY: Trump continues to link his tariffs to fentanyl and overdose deaths — in his speech to Congress and on social media.  But many of his statements about the fentanyl crisis aren't factual.

TITLE: Volunteers help fired federal workers re-enter the job market
SUMMARY: A "federal employees transition workshop" in Philadelphia drew dozens of newly-unemployed people, many still in shock about losing their jobs.

TITLE: Trump administration can remove head of federal watchdog agency, appeals court rules
SUMMARY: A U.S. appeals court has sided with the administration in allowing the removal of Hampton Dellinger from the Office of Special Counsel. The office investigates actions like whistleblower retaliation.

TITLE: Trump prepares order dismantling the Education Department
SUMMARY: The draft executive action, obtained by NPR, acknowledges the department and its signature responsibilities were created by Congress, and cannot legally be altered without congressional approval.

TITLE: As Canadians cancel trips due to Trump, the U.S. tourism industry could lose billions
SUMMARY: The Trump administration's attacks on its northern neighbor have been met with confusion and anger by some Canadians who are now cancelling their trips to the U.S. in protest.

TITLE: How does the U.S. federal workforce compare with those in other countries?
SUMMARY: President Trump's administration has fired more than 20,000 federal workers. How does the federal workforce compare with those of other countries?

TITLE: DOGE wants to cut $1 trillion this year. But it's not looking at big spending drivers
SUMMARY: Even if you take DOGE's savings claims so far at face value, its moves to cancel contracts, end leases and push federal agencies to reduce head count barely dent the government's balance sheet.

TITLE: Why is Elon Musk so obsessed with 'ghost employees'?
SUMMARY: When Musk took over Twitter, he launched a payroll audit to root out dead workers getting paid. Now, Musk is launching the same campaign across the federal government.

TITLE: State Supreme Court races can be costly, competitive and combative. Why?
SUMMARY: Wisconsin is on track to break spending records once again in a high court contest that's at times turned heated. But these races weren't always like this.

TITLE: Steve Carell announces that a charity will fund proms for students affected by LA fires
SUMMARY: The children's organization, Alice's Kids, will cover the costs for approximately 800 students to enjoy prom night.

TITLE: Layoffs and potential closures of key facilities raise worries about NOAA's future
SUMMARY: The Trump administration may end leases for some of NOAA's offices while the agency terminates several advisory committees at the important weather and climate agency.

TITLE: Automakers granted relief from tariffs. And, fired USDA workers return to work
SUMMARY: President Trump announced a one-month reprieve from import tariffs for automakers after he imposed them on Canada and Mexico. And, thousands of fired USDA workers return to work today.

TITLE: European Union leaders hold emergency summit on Ukraine support
SUMMARY: European Union leaders are expected to discuss rapidly increasing defense budgets. There's new urgency after President Trump paused military supplies and intelligence sharing with Ukraine.

TITLE: Only about 3% of applicants to run in the NYC Marathon will be accepted
SUMMARY: This year's chances of winning a lottery to enter the New York City marathon are roughly equivalent to being accepted to Harvard.

TITLE: Palestinians freed in the ceasefire say Israeli forces harass them and their families
SUMMARY: Several Palestinian prisoners and detainees freed during this ceasefire deal have been harassed by Israeli forces after their release, their homes raided or their family members arrested.

TITLE: Did tariffs contribute to the Great Depression? Here's what to know
SUMMARY: Several factors led to the Great Depression, one of the most severe economic crises in U.S. history. NPR interviewed economists who discussed the causes of the Great Depression.

TITLE: House votes to censure Texas Democrat Al Green for protest during Trump address
SUMMARY: Texas Rep. Al Green, a Democrat, was officially censured Thursday in a vote in the House following his protest on Tuesday during President Trump's address to a joint session of Congress.

TITLE: Fighter jets accidentally drop bombs during exercises, injuring 8 South Koreans
SUMMARY: The air force said the jets were taking part in a drill with the U.S. military in Pocheon, a city close to the border with North Korea, when they dropped bombs just outside a firing range.

TITLE: A second federal judge has ruled to block the Trump administration's spending freeze
SUMMARY: U.S. District Judge John McConnell Jr. said the attempt to pause trillions in federal spending "fundamentally undermines the distinct constitutional roles of each branch of our government."

TITLE: At a housewares expo in Chicago, talk keeps turning to price hikes from tariffs
SUMMARY: The Inspired Home Show in Chicago draws housewares industry insiders from all over the country to network and show off their latest gadgets. This year, they're making plans to cope with tariffs.

TITLE: WATCH LIVE: Intuitive Machines attempts to land probe near lunar south pole
SUMMARY: Commercial company Intuitive Machines is attempting to land a probe near the lunar south pole. If successful, it will be the second time a private company has landed on the moon in less than a week.

TITLE: Trump's latest tariff twist: a one-month break for Mexico
SUMMARY: Trump put 25% tariffs on goods from Canada and Mexico this week. Yesterday, he gave U.S.-made cars a break. Today, he is giving Mexico a broader exemption.

TITLE: 'Hamilton' cancels planned Kennedy Center performances
SUMMARY: The hit musical joins a number of other productions and acts that have pulled out of appearances at the Kennedy Center since President Trump took over the storied venue last month.

TITLE: That galaxy next door? It's home to a monster black hole
SUMMARY: The Large Magellanic Cloud, a close neighbor to the Milky Way, may house a giant black hole. It's the closest supermassive black hole outside of our galaxy.

TITLE: Intuitive Machines probe is on the moon but its status is uncertain
SUMMARY: Commercial company Intuitive Machines has put its second probe on the moon, but it was not immediately clear if the vehicle was upright and fully functioning.

TITLE: Democracy-promoting organization sues the Trump administration over withheld funds
SUMMARY: President Ronald Reagan laid the rhetorical foundations for the National Endowment for Democracy in a 1982 speech to the British Parliament. Support for its creation in Congress was bipartisan.

TITLE: Trump says 'male circumcision in Mozambique' is a 'scam.' What's the program about?
SUMMARY: In his Tuesday address to Congress, President Trump listed U.S.-funded programs that he considers an "appalling waste" — including "$10 million for male circumcision in Mozambique."

TITLE: Trump's latest tariff twist: a break for Mexico and Canada
SUMMARY: Trump put 25% tariffs on goods from Canada and Mexico on Tuesday. Markets tanked. And by Thursday, he had decided to broadly lift them.

TITLE: California man charged after Lego larceny worth $25,000
SUMMARY: The heists occurred in several California counties, where the alleged thief would load his shopping cart with the expensive building toys and disappear into the parking lot in a matter of minutes.

TITLE: 5 takeaways from the confirmation hearing for Trump's FDA nominee
SUMMARY: Dr. Marty Makary, President Trump's pick to run the Food and Drug Administration, faced questions from the Senate HELP Committee on the abortion pill, vaccines, FDA firings and chemicals in food.

TITLE: Butterfly numbers have fallen by nearly a quarter since 2000
SUMMARY: Butterflies of all kinds of species, in all parts of the country, have declined by one to two percent since 2000.

TITLE: Trump's latest tariff twist: A break for Mexico and Canada
SUMMARY: Trump put 25% tariffs on goods from Canada and Mexico on Tuesday. Markets tanked. And by Thursday, he had decided to broadly lift them.

TITLE: A Pentagon press secretary has history of pushing antisemitic, extremist theories
SUMMARY: Members of Congress and civil rights groups are condemning past comments from Deputy Pentagon Press Secretary Kingsley Wilson, including some which critics called antisemitic.

TITLE: Trump says Cabinet secretaries, not Elon Musk, are in charge of agency cuts
SUMMARY: The president's message to his Cabinet secretaries comes amid continuing questions over the role of billionaire adviser Elon Musk in the drastic reshaping of the federal government.

TITLE: The European Union Decides to Rearm
SUMMARY: Leaders of the European Union have voted to approve a plan to dramatically increase defense spending. The move is a reaction to the U.S. reducing its support for Ukraine in the war against Russia's invasion. We go to Brussels to understand the ramifications.

TITLE: When it comes to the economy, it's all about uncertainty
SUMMARY:
Like a lot of economists, Mark Zandi, with Moody's Analytics, thinks President Trump's across-the-board tariffs are a bad idea. Saying, "Tariffs, broad-based tariffs, are a real problem for the economy."

But Zandi says – it's not just the tariffs themselves that are the problem, it's the uncertainty created by Trump's rollout.

Trump threatened 25% Tariffs on Canada and Mexico would start in February. They were paused at the 11th hour, only to eventually go into effect this week.

On Thursday Trump announced the new tariffs would be paused for most products, but potentially only until April 2.

Meanwhile tariffs on China snapped into place in February, and then doubled, to 20%.What happens next is anyone's guess.

Businesses have been optimistic about the economy under Trump. His chaotic tariff rollout threatens that.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

TITLE: SpaceX's latest Starship test flight ends with another explosion
SUMMARY: Nearly two months after an explosion sent flaming debris raining down on the Turks and Caicos, SpaceX launched another mammoth Starship rocket but lost contact minutes into the test flight.

TITLE: Arts groups sue NEA for new 'gender ideology'-related grant restrictions
SUMMARY: The lawsuit pushes back against a recent executive order from President Donald Trump that asks funding applicants to agree not to promote "gender ideology" in their work.

TITLE: Court orders South Korean President Yoon released from jail
SUMMARY: The decision would allow Yoon to stand his criminal trial while not being physically detained. The court is expected to rule soon on whether to uphold his impeachment or remove him from office.

TITLE: Unexploded WWII bomb in Paris halts Eurostar travel to London
SUMMARY: The French transport minister said traffic would be ''strongly disrupted'' throughout the day with only limited service resuming in the afternoon, and urged travelers to postpone their trips.

TITLE: Five takeaways: China's foreign minister slams Trump's 'two-faced' policies
SUMMARY: China's top foreign policy official addressed the escalating trade war with the U.S. and promoted China as an "anchor" on the global stage as America retreats from international involvement.

TITLE: Walgreens agrees to be acquired by private equity firm for almost $10 billion
SUMMARY: A buyout to take the drugstore chain private would give it more flexibility to make changes to improve its business without worrying about Wall Street's reaction.

TITLE: Afghans in Pakistan awaiting U.S. resettlement are stuck in a treacherous limbo
SUMMARY: The Trump administration has halted the U.S. refugee program, Pakistan is taking steps to force Afghans out — and their lives may be at risk if they return to their own country.

TITLE: 'Queen of the Ring' star Emily Bett Rickards on wrestling pioneer Mildred Burke
SUMMARY: In Ash Avildsen's new film <em>Queen of The Ring

TITLE: Trump says nobody has heard of Lesotho. Can you answer our quiz question about it?
SUMMARY: It was another action-packed week, with the Academy Awards, Mardi Gras and the president's address to Congress. Did you pay attention?

TITLE: Don't let daylight saving time mess with your sleep. Sign up for our special newsletter
SUMMARY: Prepare yourself for the time change and sign up for our one-week newsletter series, Life Kit's Guide to Better Sleep. You'll get science-backed strategies to help you get your sleep back on track.

TITLE: The U.S. Postal Service could face substantial change. What comes next?
SUMMARY: The changes Trump reportedly is proposing to the Postal Service, such as a merger with the Department of Commerce, would likely be challenged in federal court, experts say.

TITLE: Why VA mental health workers feel Elon Musk's emails are psychological warfare
SUMMARY: Mental health professionals with the Veterans Health Administration say the stress caused by Elon Musk's "What did you do last week?" emails is hurting veterans' care.

TITLE: Trump is set to speak to crypto founders and investors at the White House on Friday
SUMMARY: President Trump signed an order late Thursday creating a cryptocurrency strategic reserve using bitcoin seized through court proceedings, directing officials to find "budget-neutral" ways to grow it.

TITLE: The short history of Trump's tariff chaos — and more that happened this week
SUMMARY: It was a week that saw not only more twists in the tariffs saga but also Trump's big Hill address, the suspension of aid to Ukraine, more firings at agencies, and more. NPR keeps track, day by day.

TITLE: If you see something (woke), say something
SUMMARY: Code Switch's Gene Demby looks into the Department of Education's new end-DEI portal that asks Americans to narc on their local public schools.

TITLE: Farmers strongly back Trump. A new trade war could test their loyalty
SUMMARY: American farmers have stood firmly behind President Trump even when his trade policies hurt them. The latest trade war, which could be even worse for their sector, promises to test those ties again.

TITLE: Amid a growing measles outbreak, doctors worry RFK is sending the wrong message
SUMMARY: There are now two confirmed deaths in a measles outbreak that has spread from West Texas across the border into New Mexico. And infectious disease doctors are concerned RFK Jr's response is missing the mark.

TITLE: A look at some of the creative ways companies try to dodge high tariffs
SUMMARY: Companies can try to avoid or minimize tariffs by requesting exemptions or legally reclassifying their products. Here's a look at some of the strategies that have worked in the past.

TITLE: Monthly jobs report to be released. And, the White House to host a crypto event
SUMMARY: The Labor Department will release the monthly jobs report card today, which is expected to show solid growth. But that's not the whole picture. And, the White House will host a cryptocurrency summit.

TITLE: How a measles outbreak overwhelmed a small West Texas town
SUMMARY: The kindergarten vaccination rate against the measles in Gaines County is 82%, far below the 95% needed to achieve herd immunity.

TITLE: The job market is still pretty solid -- but there are warning signs ahead
SUMMARY: U.S. employers added 151,000 jobs in February, while the unemployment rate inched up to 4.1% from 4% in January.

TITLE: She got her dream job at CDC back. But she's already moving on
SUMMARY: An unknown number of fired CDC workers got their jobs back this week. Among them was Bri McNulty, who had shared her story with NPR.

TITLE: War heroes are among 26,000 images flagged for removal in Pentagon's DEI purge
SUMMARY: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth had given the military until Wednesday to remove content highlighting diversity efforts following an executive order ending those programs across the government.

TITLE: Trump says nobody has heard of Lesotho. Can you answer our quiz question about it?
SUMMARY: It was another action-packed week, with the Academy Awards, Mardi Gras and the president's address to Congress. Did you pay attention?

TITLE: A former Olympic snowboarder makes the FBI's Most Wanted list
SUMMARY: Ryan Wedding, a former Canadian Olympic snowboarder-turned-alleged-drug trafficker, "went from shredding powder on the slopes at the Olympics to distributing powder cocaine," the FBI says.

TITLE: Syria imposes curfew after its worst clashes since the Assad regime ouster
SUMMARY: Syria's new government sent in security reinforcements and imposed curfews on a coastal area after major clashes with fighters loyal to the deposed Syrian President Bashar al-Assad.

TITLE: Top Democrats ask Rubio for answers on now-canceled $400 million Tesla plan
SUMMARY: A letter from two House Democrats presses Rubio for details about who approved an effort to try to use hundreds of millions of dollars of taxpayer money on armored electric vehicles from Tesla.

TITLE: Trump administration cancels $400 million in federal dollars for Columbia University
SUMMARY: The administration said it was cancelling grants and other federal awards for Columbia for an alleged failure to protect Jewish students from antisemitism.

TITLE: Gene Hackman died of heart disease, his wife died of hantavirus, authorities say
SUMMARY: Actor Gene Hackman died of heart disease a full week after his wife died from hantavirus in their New Mexico hillside home, authorities revealed Friday.

TITLE: A Lagos community, destroyed in one day
SUMMARY: At least 9,000 people have been forcefully evicted from a riverside community in Nigeria's most populous city, Lagos. Like many waterfront communities across the city, it has faced multiple threats and been targeted by luxury real estate developers.

TITLE: President Trump brings back practice of detaining families together
SUMMARY: President Trump — and several other former presidents — also detained families during his first term in an effort to deter migration through the southern border.

TITLE: New research reveals ancient humans used animal bone tools much earlier than thought
SUMMARY: The handcrafted tools found in Tanzania were made 1.5 million years ago and were fashioned primarily from the bones of elephants and hippopotamuses.

TITLE: Florida says its cops are ready to help ICE with deportations
SUMMARY: Florida is going all-in on President Trump's crackdown on illegal immigration. Gov. Ron DeSantis has ushered in a new law that formalizes agreements between all 67 Florida sheriffs and U.S. Immigration and Customs

TITLE: The Dangerous Popularity of Skin Whitening Products in Nigeria
SUMMARY: In many parts of the world skin whitening is a major industry, but women in Nigeria have a particular fondness for creams and lotions that promise to lighten their skin. By one estimate, over 77% of women in the country have used such products. We go to Nigeria and learn that the effects of skin whiteners can be severe and many people who use them are unable to stop.

TITLE: Marco Rubio pivots to America First diplomacy
SUMMARY:
It's been a little more than a week since Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy met with President Donald Trump in the Oval Office.

Vice President JD Vance was in the meeting too. And Secretary of State Marco Rubio, the nation's top diplomat, sat on an Oval Office couch, mostly silent, as Trump and Vance berated the Ukrainian leader.

Along the way, the president and vice president made it clear just how much of the established global order they are ready to upend. An order that for most of his career, Rubio has defended, and worked to help hold up.

So what changed ...and what do those changes mean?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: The soundtrack to King Charles' life features music from Kylie Minogue
SUMMARY: King Charles III has admitted he is not impervious to a generational earworm like Kylie Minogue's "Can't Get You Out of My Head<em>,"

TITLE: Former government watchdog on his decision to end legal fight challenging his firing
SUMMARY: NPR's Juana Summers speaks with Hampton Dellinger, who formerly led an independent watchdog agency, about his decision to drop his lawsuit challenging Trump's attempt to fire him without cause.

TITLE: Trump signs executive action targeting public service loan program
SUMMARY: The program forgives the loans of borrowers who work in public service. The executive action would exclude those who work for certain organizations.

TITLE: D'Wayne Wiggins, founding member of the R&B group Tony! Toni! Tone!, has died at 64
SUMMARY: Wiggins died Friday morning after battling bladder cancer for over the past year, according to a statement released by his family on social media.

TITLE: A South Carolina prisoner is the first executed by a firing squad in 15 years
SUMMARY: A South Carolina man who killed his ex-girlfriend's parents with a baseball bat was executed by firing squad Friday, the first U.S. prisoner in 15 years to die by that method.

TITLE: Not sure where to go next in life? These journal prompts can help you figure it out
SUMMARY: Whether you're thinking about starting a new career or moving to a different city, these exercises can help you make hard decisions with more confidence and clarity.

TITLE: DOGE's effort to slash government is now coming for buildings and people who run them
SUMMARY: The federal government is preparing to shed up to a quarter of its 360 million square feet of real estate, an NPR analysis finds. The agency in charge of federal real estate is also slashing staff.

TITLE: Newly restored photos show the ruin of 'Bloody Sunday' in Selma on its 60th anniversary
SUMMARY: James "Spider" Martin was assigned to photograph the protests in Alabama after civil rights activist Jimmie Lee Jackson was killed by state troopers.

TITLE: Dairy farmers in Wisconsin see federal funding unfrozen as others are left waiting
SUMMARY: Dozens of Wisconsin dairy farmers are breathing a sigh of relief after federal funds they had been awarded were released and payments are now being promised. But anxiety persists for some.

TITLE: Portraits of women who 'shine a light': from an 'analog' astronaut to a watermelon farmer
SUMMARY: The Muhammad Ali Center in Louisville, Kentucky, has a new photo exhibit in honor of International Women's Day: "Iconic Women: From Everyday Life to Global Heroes."

TITLE: 60 years since U.S. troops entered Vietnam, an Army Vet recalls his journey
SUMMARY: As part of our StoryCorps' Military Voices Initiative, we hear from Specialist Henry Smithers who was among the millions of American servicemen and women deployed to Vietnam during the conflict.

TITLE: States sue Trump administration over mass firings of federal employees
SUMMARY: The District of Columbia, Maryland and 18 other states have filed a lawsuit in federal court seeking the reinstatement of tens of thousands of federal employees fired since mid-February.

TITLE: Failure is an option. Here's why some new space ventures go sideways
SUMMARY: Within the span of a few days, another SpaceX Starship broke up on re-entry, and two other space companies faced failures. This reflects a new "fail-fast, learn-fast" ethos of spacecraft development.

TITLE: Opinion: Don't call this coffee an Americano!
SUMMARY: Canadians fed up with tariff threats and suggestions of Canada becoming the 51st state are now calling Americano coffee drinks "Canadianos." NPR's Scott Simon explains.

TITLE: Opinion: Thailand's deportation of Uyghurs to China has echoes of 10 years ago
SUMMARY: Thailand's recent deportations of Uyghurs to China have eerie parallels with a large deportation in 2015, in which the country bowed to Beijing, writes historian Jeffrey Wasserstrom.

TITLE: GOP unveils stopgap bill to avert a government shutdown. They may not have the votes.
SUMMARY: House Republicans released the text of a continuing resolution that would fund the government through Sept. 30. Now, passing it in a narrowly divided chamber is the next hurdle.

TITLE: Vatican says hospitalized Pope Francis is showing 'gradual, slight improvement'
SUMMARY: The 88-year-old pontiff is responding well to the treatment for double pneumonia and has shown a "gradual, slight improvement" in recent days, the Vatican said Saturday.

TITLE: D.C.'s Black Lives Matter mural will be erased. Look back at the iconic street painting
SUMMARY: Over the past five years, Washington, D.C.'s  iconic Black Lives Matter street painting has served as a powerful symbol of activism and a gathering place for joy and resistance.

TITLE: Experts warn that recent school shootings show growth in new radicalization pattern
SUMMARY: Some researchers say these recent attacks are examples of "nonideological" terrorism — the result of several antisocial, decentralized, online networks coming together.

SUMMARY: Fast-moving brush fires fanned by high winds burned through a large swath of land on New York's Long Island on Saturday, prompting the evacuation of a military base and the closure of a major highway.

TITLE: Trump DOJ's limits on FACE Act enforcement fuel concern from abortion providers
SUMMARY: New Justice Department leaders say past enforcement of the Freedom of Access to Clinic Entrances Act is "the prototypical example" of what they call "the weaponization of law enforcement."

SUMMARY: The time change can be hard on our health. There are more car accidents, strokes and heart attacks this week. People eat more junk food and have more migraines. Here's why — plus tips to help you adapt.

TITLE: 60 years after Bloody Sunday in Alabama, elusive racial progress in Selma
SUMMARY: Events in Selma, Ala. six decades ago helped win support for the 1965 Voting Rights Act. Today local activists say they're still fighting stubborn segregation, poverty and gun violence.

SUMMARY: The pandemic decimated the box office and the reshaped the moviegoing experience. NPR's movie critic, Bob Mondello, looks back on how his job changed during the early months of COVID-19.

SUMMARY: Since 1995, presidents have issued a series of proclamations celebrating Women's History in March. NPR readers share stories of the women who have made the biggest impacts on their lives.

SUMMARY: A man who was brandishing a firearm in Washington, D.C., was shot by Secret Service officers near the White House on Sunday morning, the Secret Service said.

SUMMARY: Tzedek Chicago calls itself anti-Zionist congregation, meaning it does not support a Jewish nation-state.

SUMMARY: A man who was brandishing a firearm in Washington, D.C., was shot by Secret Service officers near the White House on Sunday morning, the Secret Service said.

SUMMARY: President Trump says economy is in a "period of transition" and can't predict if U.S. will fall into a recession

SUMMARY: The Holy See Press Office said the pontiff has shown "a good response to the therapies." He was hospitalized on Feb. 14 for a case of bronchitis.

SUMMARY: Carney, 59, will succeed Justin Trudeau, who announced in January that he would step down amid low approval ratings following a decade in office.

SUMMARY: Mahmoud Khalil was inside his university-owned apartment Saturday night when several Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents entered and took him into custody.

SUMMARY: Carney, 59, will succeed Justin Trudeau, who announced in January that he would step down amid low approval ratings following a decade in office.

SUMMARY: The COVID-19 lockdown "felt like solitary confinement," a San Diego resident tells NPR. Even after many pandemic rules lifted, American society remains deeply fractured.

SUMMARY: Police are experimenting with various methods to determine whether drivers are under the influence of marijuana, but unlike alcohol, a number of factors make that difficult to know with certainty.

SUMMARY: The United States said it will resume sending military aid and intelligence to Ukraine, as Ukraine agreed to a Trump administration proposal for a monthlong ceasefire.

But as we learn from an incident in a different Alawite community, this isn't the first episode of violence against the sect.

SUMMARY: The plans include the demolition of Old Trafford, the team's iconic 115-year-old stadium.

SUMMARY: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said Wednesday that U.S. tariffs on Australian steel and aluminum were unjustified, but his government would not retaliate with its own tariffs.

TITLE: Opposition party wins the most votes in Greenland election amid Trump takeover talk
SUMMARY: The Demokraatit Party won the most votes in Greenland's parliamentary elections, a surprise result in an election in the shadow of President Donald Trump's stated goal of taking control of the island.

SUMMARY: TSMC's plan to invest $100 billion into U.S. production facilities raises concerns that its leverage in securing protection from China may be weakened.

SUMMARY: They're pushing for more funding to find effective treatments. Researchers are finally starting to make headway but have a way to go.

SUMMARY: Gretchen Rubin, host of the <em>Happier

TITLE: A Republican-backed bill would upend voter registration. Here are 8 things to know
SUMMARY: Congressional Republicans are pushing legislation that would make sweeping changes to voter registration, including requiring those signing up to present documents proving U.S. citizenship.

TITLE: Trump's policies are destabilizing mental health care for veterans, sources say
SUMMARY: The Department of Veterans Affairs is one of the largest providers of mental health care in the U.S. Its integrated care model means patients are already feeling the cuts and changes that are underway.

TITLE: The European Union retaliates after the U.S. metals tariffs take hold

SUMMARY: The Department of Education said it will cut around 50% of its workforce. And, the U.S. has announced it will be resuming military aid to Ukraine.

SUMMARY: President Trump and Elon Musk claim the Biden administration abandoned two astronauts in space. But the publicly available evidence suggests a different story.

TITLE: Universities across the U.S. freeze hiring as federal funding hangs in the balance
SUMMARY: With uncertainties around federal funding for higher education, some schools are cutting back. Experts say that could hurt not only students and faculty, but ultimately make the U.S. less competitive.

TITLE: Congress reignites a bipartisan effort to ban hair discrimination
SUMMARY: Previous attempts to pass the legislation banning hair discrimination have stalled in Congress.

TITLE: Inflation eased a touch in February -- but Trump's tariffs cloud outlook

TITLE: NIH cuts off more research funding including for vaccine hesitancy. mRNA could be next.
