TITLE: Trump tries to void Biden's pardons, blaming autopen. Many presidents have used it
SUMMARY: Trump claims without evidence that Biden's Jan. 6 panel pardons are void because he allegedly used an autopen. Autopens have been popular with presidents for decades. Here's what to know about them.

TITLE: What Russia and Ukraine want out of talks, as Trump speaks to Putin Tuesday
SUMMARY: President Trump will speak with Russian President Vladimir Putin on Tuesday, as the U.S. pursues a ceasefire deal in Ukraine.

TITLE: Why Are Young Germans Moving to the Extremes?
SUMMARY: In Germany's national elections a few weeks ago, one statistic stood out to our Berlin-based correspondent: almost half of young German voters cast their ballot for either the far-right or far-left parties. And the divide between extreme left and extreme right in young people seems to fall along gender lines. We try to find out why it seems the youth in Germany are moving to the extremes.

TITLE: Navy warship is sent to the southern border to carry out Trump's immigration plans
SUMMARY: Capable of holding over 300 crew members and larger than any Coast Guard vessel, the USS Gravely has been assigned to help tighten border security, operating on both domestic and international waters.

TITLE: A U.S. airman is charged in death of a South Dakota woman who had vanished in August
SUMMARY: Quinterius Chappelle was arrested on a federal charge of second-degree murder in the death of Sahela Sangrait, according to the Pennington County Sheriff's Office.

TITLE: Harvard will be free for students whose families make $100,000 or less
SUMMARY: The expanded financial aid plan will also offer free tuition to families that make $200,000 or less. The move comes after affirmative action was barred from the admissions process.

TITLE: Judge seeks sworn declaration from Justice Department in deportation case
SUMMARY: At issue was whether plane-loads of alleged members of the Tren de Aragua gang were deported despite the judge's order to turn the planes around.

TITLE: The VA will deny gender dysphoria treatment to new patients
SUMMARY: While the VA never offered gender-affirming surgery, it did offer treatments like hormone therapy. The agency says less than than 0.1% of the 9 million veterans it provides care for identify as trans.

TITLE: Pentagon website removes, then restores, page honoring Black Medal of Honor recipient
SUMMARY: Charles C. Rogers was awarded the Medal of Honor by President Richard Nixon in 1970. But a profile of the Vietnam War veteran was caught in an "auto removal process," the Defense Department says.

TITLE: He lost his first LA Marathon medal in the fires -- this weekend he got his second
Israel launches deadly series of attacks on Gaza
SUMMARY: Israel said the early Tuesday attacks were launched after Hamas refused to release more hostages held in Gaza. The strikes appeared to end the current ceasefire that took began in mid-January.

TITLE: He lost his first LA Marathon medal in the fires — this weekend he got his second
SUMMARY: 15-year-old fire survivor Abel Rivera's home in Altadena burned down in January, and he lost everything — including his medal for finishing the 2024 LA Marathon.

TITLE: Trump says he's ending Secret Service protection for Biden's adult children
SUMMARY: President Trump said he was ending "immediately" the Secret Service protection details assigned to Democrat Joe Biden's adult children.

TITLE: Israel launches a deadly series of attacks on Gaza
SUMMARY: Israel said the early Tuesday attacks were launched after Hamas refused to release more hostages held in Gaza. The strikes appeared to end the current ceasefire that took began in mid-January.

TITLE: At 83, Martha Stewart celebrates gardening with her 101st book
SUMMARY: Martha Stewart talks gardening, wanting to be "one of the girls" and her 101st book with NPR <em>Morning Edition

TITLE: This is why Canada has plenty of eggs — and the U.S. doesn't
SUMMARY: While the U.S. grapples with an egg shortage caused by avian flu, eggs remain plentiful and affordable in Canada. There are reasons for that, including that egg farms there tend to be smaller.

TITLE: 'Segregated facilities' are no longer explicitly banned in federal contracts
SUMMARY: <em>The Trump administration cut a clause from federal contracting rules that had been on the books since the 1960s: Companies are no longer explicitly prohibited from having segregated facilities.

TITLE: In the Missouri Ozarks, residents struggle to rebuild after tornadoes
SUMMARY: Twisters that tore through Union County, Missouri killed 6 people. One couple survived against incomprehensible odds in a trailer obliterated by the storm.

TITLE: Hundreds killed as Israel launches a series of air strikes on Gaza
SUMMARY: Israel said the Tuesday attacks were launched after Hamas refused to release more hostages held in Gaza. The strikes raise the prospect of a full resumption of war after a nearly two-month ceasefire.

TITLE: New 'Hunger Games' prequel reminds that sometimes past truths aren't visible
SUMMARY: <em>Sunrise on the Reaping

TITLE: Fast-er food: A productivity surge at U.S. restaurants
SUMMARY: A new study finds that after decades of stagnation, fast-food and other restaurants finally saw a surge in productivity.

TITLE: Trump tests executive power. And, hundreds killed in Israeli airstrikes on Gaza
SUMMARY: A federal judge is requesting the DOJ give a sworn declaration about deportations over the weekend. And, Israel launched surprise airstrikes in Gaza early Tuesday, killing over 400.

TITLE: Hundreds killed as Israel launches a series of airstrikes on Gaza
SUMMARY: Israel said the Tuesday attacks were launched after Hamas refused to release more hostages held in Gaza. The strikes raise the prospect of a full resumption of war after a nearly two-month ceasefire.

TITLE: 4 things to know about the Alien Enemies Act and Trump's efforts to use it
SUMMARY: President Trump invoked the Alien Enemies Act of 1798 against Tren de Aragua members, provoking a legal fight. Here's what to know about the controversial law, which was last used during World War II.

TITLE: New books this week: 'Hunger Games' is back, and young people navigate a new Tanzania
SUMMARY: This week brings a number of promising new reads — but none more eagerly awaited than <em>Sunrise on the Reaping

TITLE: Last of the classified JFK assassination files to be released Tuesday
SUMMARY: About 80,000 documents related to the 1963 assassination of President John F. Kennedy are expected to be released, but presidential historians don't expect any bombshell revelations.

TITLE: New 'Hunger Games' prequel asks: How well do we really know our history?
SUMMARY: <em>Sunrise on the Reaping

TITLE: A cell pulls off one of the 'Holy Grails' of biotechnology
SUMMARY: A new part of an ocean plant cell has been discovered that might revolutionize farming one day. The structure can take nitrogen and convert it into the ingredient that helps all organisms grow.

TITLE: German lawmakers approve huge defense and infrastructure spending
SUMMARY: Germany's would-be next chancellor, Friedrich Merz, won lawmakers' approval to loosen strict debt rules for higher defense spending as doubts mount about the strength of the trans-Atlantic alliance.

TITLE: Does the U.S. deserve the Statue of Liberty? Not anymore, one French politician says
SUMMARY: A French politician suggested the two countries no longer share the values that inspired the gift more than a century ago. The White House sharply rejected his request, which he described as symbolic.

TITLE: 2 NASA astronauts head back to Earth after an unexpectedly long mission in space
SUMMARY: NASA astronauts Suni Williams and Butch Wilmore were on the International Space Station more than nine months, despite launching into space in June for what was expected to be an eight-day mission.

TITLE: Tensions mount as DOJ gives sworn response to judge's questions about deportations
SUMMARY: Trump administration lawyers defended the weekend flights that deported hundreds of alleged Venezuelan gang members despite a federal judge's order to turn the planes around.

TITLE: Kremlin says it will halt strikes on Ukraine energy sector after Trump and Putin talk
SUMMARY: President Trump has said he wants to broker an end to Russia's war in Ukraine. This was his second call with Russian President Vladimir Putin on the issue.

TITLE: A federal judge says the USAID shutdown likely violated the Constitution
SUMMARY: A federal judge has found that the Trump administration likely violated the Constitution when it effectively shuttered the U.S. Agency for International Development.

TITLE: 4 things to know about Judge Boasberg as he battles Trump over deportation flights
SUMMARY: Judge Boasberg's role overseeing a new case that challenges the deportation of alleged Venezuelan gang members to El Salvador<strong>

TITLE: Firing federal employees was swift. Unwinding the terminations is proving complicated
SUMMARY: Two federal judges have ordered the Trump administration to reinstate thousands of  probationary employees it illegally fired. Agencies report they are doing so but placing most of them on paid leave.

TITLE: Tensions mount as judge demands more answers about deportation flights
SUMMARY: Trump administration lawyers defended the weekend flights that deported hundreds of alleged Venezuelan gang members despite a federal judge's order to turn the planes around.

TITLE: Trump and Putin Talk about a Ceasefire in Ukraine
SUMMARY: President Trump and President Vladimir Putin of Russia held a lengthy phone call on Tuesday to discuss a possible ceasefire in Ukraine. This is part of Trump's efforts to end the Russia's war in Ukraine and while he didn't get a ceasefire agreement, some progress was made. We hear the latest.

TITLE: What is the U.S. Institute of Peace and why is Trump trying to shut it down?
SUMMARY: Founded during the Cold War to project American soft power and foreign policy expertise, the federally-funded nonprofit think tank is now in the White House's crosshairs

TITLE: Vice President Vance has a new gig: fundraising for the Republican National Committee
SUMMARY: Vance will be the first sitting vice president to serve as party finance chairman, according to the RNC. The move places a top Trump ally within the party's campaign wing ahead of the 2026 midterms.

TITLE: 2 NASA astronauts return to Earth after an unexpectedly long mission in space
SUMMARY: NASA astronauts Suni Williams and Butch Wilmore were on the International Space Station more than nine months, despite launching into space in June for what was expected to be an eight-day mission.

TITLE: Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty sues Trump administration over canceled contract
SUMMARY: Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, a government-backed overseas broadcaster, sued the Trump administration in an attempt to get it to release funds appropriated by Congress.

TITLE: Trump calls for the impeachment of a judge, as lawsuits pile up
SUMMARY: To date, 127 legal cases have been filed against the Trump administration's actions since President Trump took office. The cases challenge an enormous range of subjects.

TITLE: Federal judge blocks Trump effort to ban transgender troops from military service
SUMMARY: The decision by U.S. District Judge Ana C. Reyes blocks the Department of Defense from carrying through with a policy directive designed to remove transgender servicemembers from the military.

TITLE: Mexico City bans violent bullfighting, sparking fury and celebration
SUMMARY: The decision sparked angry protests from bullfighting supporters and matadors, some of whom tried to breach a police barricade at the local Congress.

TITLE: Sexual misconduct allegations in UN missions topped 100 in 2024
SUMMARY: The United Nations has long been in the spotlight over allegations of child rape and other sexual abuses by its peacekeepers, especially by those based in Congo and the Central African Republic.

TITLE: Professional players' group likens tennis organizers to a 'cartel' in its lawsuit
SUMMARY: The antitrust lawsuit filed by the Professional Tennis Players' Association says the organizations that run the sport hold "complete control over the players' pay and working conditions."

TITLE: Switching from gas to electric? Here's 3 appliances that are easy to install
SUMMARY: Changing from gas to climate-friendly electric appliances often involves expensive retrofits. A growing list of companies offer stoves, heat pumps and water heaters that make it easier and cheaper.

TITLE: How astronauts adjust when back on Earth after being in space
SUMMARY: Astronauts face several risks during spaceflight, including exposure to radiation.

TITLE: After historic indictment, doctors will keep mailing abortion pills over state lines
SUMMARY: Doctors who mail abortion medication pills across state lines have been on alert ever since Louisiana, which bans abortion, indicted a New York doctor for mailing the pills to a woman there.

TITLE: Trump's handling of Ukraine and tariffs has NATO rethinking the U.S.-made F-35 fighter
SUMMARY: The F-35 was meant as a one-size-fits-all fighter that could be used across NATO. But strained U.S.-Europe relations are giving some member countries second thoughts about the U.S.-built plane.

TITLE: Family of U.S. student missing in the Dominican Republic believes she drowned
SUMMARY: Sudiksha Konanki remains missing after she disappeared during a spring break trip with friends.

TITLE: Stargazing, poetry and meditation: What connects NPR readers to their spirituality
SUMMARY: NPR readers of different belief systems share the poignant rituals that make them feel close to their spirituality. For some, it's poetry and gardening, for others, it's meditation and community.

TITLE: Why did Israel resume the war in Gaza?
SUMMARY: Israel launched deadly strikes in Gaza to pressure Hamas to agree to a new ceasefire. Hamas isn't budging, and more than half of recently freed hostages oppose the renewed war. Why is Israel doing it?

TITLE: Musk, DOGE violated Constitution, judge says. And, when egg prices might drop
SUMMARY: A federal judge ruled that Elon Musk and DOGE likely violated the Constitution when shuttering the USAID. And, a look at when egg prices are likely to drop.

TITLE: 5 ways the pandemic changed us for good, for bad and forever
SUMMARY: This month marks five years since the pandemic began, and here are 5 things that changed permanently.

TITLE: Switching from gas to electric? Here are 3 appliances that are easy to install
SUMMARY: Changing from gas to climate-friendly electric appliances often involves expensive retrofits. A growing list of companies offer stoves, heat pumps and water heaters that make it easier and cheaper.

TITLE: Zelenskyy says he plans to discuss Ukraine ceasefire violations in a call with Trump
SUMMARY: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy says he plans to speak with President Trump on Wednesday, following Trump's call on Tuesday with Russian President Vladimir Putin.

TITLE: How vulnerable might humans be to bird flu? Scientists see hope in existing immunity
SUMMARY: Very few humans have gone up against bird flu. But we've all dealt with seasonal flu for years. Some of our immune systems might be primed to fend off a worse case, research finds.

TITLE: Here are all the ways people are disappearing from government websites
SUMMARY: Executive orders from President Trump have agencies across the government scrubbing websites of photos and references to transgender people, women and people of color.

TITLE: Mahmoud Khalil's immigration case moves to New Jersey from New York
SUMMARY: The decision offers a venue compromise in the bellwether case, while Khalil's legal team seeks to release him from detention and block his deportation.

TITLE: Zelenskyy and Trump speak after Trump's call with Putin
SUMMARY: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy spoke for about an hour with President Trump on Wednesday, following Trump's call on Tuesday with Russian President Vladimir Putin.

TITLE: It's your last chance to claim pandemic-era stimulus checks, the IRS says. Here's how
SUMMARY: The IRS says some Americans who have not filed their 2021 tax returns could be eligible for a pandemic-era relief payment, as long as they do so by April 15. Here's what to know as Tax Day approaches.

TITLE: Louisiana has a long history with French. This immersion school aims to keep it alive
SUMMARY: Most Louisianans no longer speak French, but a growing number of schools are now immersing kids in it. At École Pointe-au-Chien, the focus is on teaching local French dialects first.

TITLE: 'AI Valley' author worries there's 'so much power in the hands of few people'
SUMMARY: Author Gary Rivlin says regulation can help control how AI is used: "AI could be an amazing thing around health, medicine, scientific discoveries, education ... as long as we're deliberate about it."

TITLE: Israel has launched a new ground invasion into Gaza after breaking ceasefire
SUMMARY: Israel's military launched a new ground offensive in Gaza, sending troops into areas they retreated from during a two-month ceasefire. This comes a day after airstrikes killed more than 400 people.

TITLE: The Fed holds interest rates steady as Trump's trade agenda sparks uncertainty
SUMMARY: The Fed held rates steady, but left the door open to cut them later this year if inflation continues to ease.  Trump's tariffs, however, could complicate efforts to bring prices under control.

TITLE: Patients scramble as cheaper obesity drug alternatives disappear
SUMMARY: Compounding pharmacies have been allowed to essentially make a cheaper version of Eli Lilly's Zepbound, but they have to stop Wednesday. That's left many patients wondering what to do next.

TITLE: Judge extends deadline for deportation flight details as DOJ continues to resist
SUMMARY: The Justice Department is fighting not to divulge more information about flights that deported alleged gang members to El Salvador. The federal judge is giving lawyers another day to respond.

TITLE: Trump administration extends opioid emergency as fentanyl deaths drop
SUMMARY: U.S. Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. says the Trump administration will continue to treat opioid overdoses as a "national security" emergency even as fentanyl deaths decline.

TITLE: These scientists are building a cat database to understand why they act like that
SUMMARY: The project, called Darwin's Cats, aims to enhance our understanding of feline behavior and genetics.

TITLE: As U.S. foreign aid programs grind to a halt, African health leaders look for a silver lining
SUMMARY: Chad has one of the highest rates of maternal mortality.  A group of midwives helped but now their jobs are on the line — one of many cases where countries must try to keep such programs alive.

TITLE: Miami Beach drops plans to evict a theater for showing 'No Other Land'
SUMMARY: Miami Beach's mayor has dropped an effort to evict and defund an arts cinema after strong opposition from the community and other elected officials.

TITLE: Trump admin. cuts funding for program that tracked Ukrainian children abducted by Russia
SUMMARY: NPR's Ailsa Chang speaks with Rep. Greg Landsman, a lawmaker who signed a letter to Secretary of State Marco Rubio asking whether a database of Ukrainian children abducted by Russia had been deleted.

TITLE: Jury says Greenpeace owes hundreds of millions of dollars for Dakota pipeline protest
SUMMARY: Experts say the verdict has relevance for free speech issues nationwide.

TITLE: Israel Launches a New Offensive in Gaza
SUMMARY: The two month ceasefire in Gaza has come to an end with Israel conducting airstrikes, killing five Hamas officials along with over 400 others, including many children. The Israeli military has also restarted ground operations in Gaza, sending troops back to areas they had withdrawn from. They say they want Hamas to agree to a new ceasefire deal and release more hostages. But many Israelis are opposed to this return to war. We hear what this resumption of fighting sounds like in Gaza from our producer there. Warning, this episode contains graphic descriptions of war.

TITLE: Trump to sign order aiming to close the Education Department
SUMMARY: The Trump administration has already moved to cut the department's staff by half.

TITLE: Canada says China executed four Canadians earlier this year
SUMMARY: Beijing's embassy in Ottawa said the executions were due to drug crimes and noted that China does not recognize dual citizenship.

TITLE: Colorado senator on Schumer: 'It's important for people to know when it's time to go'
SUMMARY: Colorado Democratic Sen. Michael Bennet stopped short Wednesday of calling on Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer to step down from leadership, but came pretty darn close.

TITLE: Malaysia approves a new search for MH370 wreckage in the Indian Ocean
SUMMARY: The Boeing 777 plane vanished from radar shortly after taking off on March 8, 2014, carrying 239 people. The plane headed south to the far-southern Indian Ocean, where it is believed to have crashed.

TITLE: New 'baby pictures' of the cosmos show the universe in its infancy
SUMMARY: If our 13.8 billion-year-old cosmos could be considered middle-aged, researchers note these new images captured around its 380,000th birthday represent a snapshot of the universe as a newborn.

TITLE: How well do you know your March Madness trivia? Take our quiz
SUMMARY: Do you know your saint schools from state schools? Your legendary coaches from your little brothers? Find out if you're in the Final Four — or didn't even get seeded.

TITLE: COMIC: Still cringing about that awkward moment? Here's what to do about it
SUMMARY: Experts demystify the science of awkwardness — and explain how to reduce the emotional intensity of mortifying flashbacks (like that one time you called your teacher "Mommy").

TITLE: With Trump's crackdown on DEI, some women fear a path to good-paying jobs will close
SUMMARY: Some fear a setback for women and people of color after President Trump revoked a 1965 executive order that required federal contractors to identify and address barriers to employment.

TITLE: Ferrets, water testing and future scientists at risk due to DOGE spending cuts
SUMMARY: Interior Department employees say they have been scrambling to keep the lights on and do their jobs as budget cuts driven by the Department of Government efficiency team start to bite.

TITLE: Weaponizing antisemitism makes students 'less safe,' says drafter of definition
SUMMARY: Kenneth Stern, who drafted a widely used definition of antisemitism, says the Trump administration is using antisemitism claims to stifle speech and debate on the Middle East on college campuses.

TITLE: 'Beauty from the ashes.' Texas Panhandle recovering one year after the state's largest wildfire
SUMMARY: The Smokehouse Creek fire tore through the Texas Panhandle early last year, burning over a million acres in just weeks. In the small town of Canadian, where the devastation was severe, residents say the heartbreak lingers and a full recovery could take years.

TITLE: From TV to CMS: How Dr. Oz could shape Medicare and Medicaid
SUMMARY: Dr. Oz lacks policy experience but has TV show chops. Tom Scully, who led Medicare & Medicaid for President George W. Bush, argues that Oz is well-suited to be a spokesman for Trump's health care agenda.

TITLE: The Fed holds interest rates. And, judge denies request to block DOGE's USIP takeover
SUMMARY: The Federal Reserve held interest rates steady yesterday as concerns loom over President Trump's new tariffs. And, a judge denied a request to block DOGE's takeover of the U.S. Institute of Peace.

TITLE: How land-loving iguanas from North America may have ended up in Fiji
SUMMARY: A new study suggests iguanas reached Fiji by rafting around 5,000 miles from North America.

TITLE: Can you look at these 9 photos and not smile on International Day of Happiness?
SUMMARY: March 20 is International Happiness Day — a day that the United Nations had dedicated to the celebration of joy. We asked photographers around the world to share a picture that can bring bliss.

TITLE: Ex-F1 team owner and media personality Eddie Jordan has died at 76
SUMMARY: Jordan ran his own team in the 1990s and 2000s in Formula 1. He became a popular pundit on TV after selling the team in 2005.

TITLE: Ferrets, water testing and future scientists at risk due to DOGE spending cuts
SUMMARY: Interior Department employees say they have been scrambling to keep the lights on and do their jobs as budget cuts driven by the Department of Government efficiency team start to bite.

TITLE: Pentagon restores webpages of Black veterans, Navajo Code Talkers and others after outcry
SUMMARY: A Pentagon official not authorized to speak publicly said its review to scrub websites of DEI content was too hasty and used search terms like "gay," which led to the flagging of Enola Gay images.

TITLE: As young male voters shift Right, can the Left compete in the 'battle for the bros'?
SUMMARY: Popular podcasts in the "manosphere" helped sway young men to go MAGA in the 2024 election. New Yorker writer Andrew Marantz explains how Democrats can win them back.

TITLE: Israel expands its ground offensive in Gaza as Hamas fires rockets back
SUMMARY: The Israeli military expanded its ground offensive in Gaza, and killed at least 80 Palestinians in a new wave of strikes Thursday. Hamas fired its first rockets since Israel broke a recent ceasefire.

TITLE: Do you feel you can exercise your right to free speech? NPR wants to hear from you
SUMMARY: NPR wants to know who is feeling more and less free to exercise their free speech rights in this moment. Have you found yourself letting loose more under President Trump or are you holding back?

TITLE: Dark energy is weakening and the universe could (eventually) collapse, study says
SUMMARY: The <a href="https://www.desi.lbl.gov/" target="_blank">Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument

TITLE: West Bank Palestinians displaced by Israel's military fear they'll never go home again
SUMMARY: Even as the war in Gaza continues, Israel's prime minister says a "larger and more intense front could be opened" in the West Bank, where more than 40,000 have been displaced in the current operation.

TITLE: Ben & Jerry's alleges its CEO was fired over its political activism. Here's the scoop
SUMMARY: Ben & Jerry's alleges its parent company, Unilever, ousted its CEO in retaliation for social media posts supporting progressive causes. The last few years have been a rocky road for the companies.

TITLE: Investigators say a Delta jet descended too quickly before Toronto crash last month
SUMMARY: Canadian investigators released a preliminary report into last month's Delta Air Lines regional jet rollover landing crash in Toronto. The plane was descending too quickly before it hit the runway.

TITLE: Why don't we remember being babies? Brain scans reveal new clues
SUMMARY: Why can't we remember when we were babies? Scientists who scanned infants' brains found that they do make memories. The findings suggest these memories may still exist, but are inaccessible to us.

TITLE: Why a DOJ prosecutor resigned, telling coworkers and bosses 'you serve no man'
SUMMARY: Former Assistant U.S. Attorney Sean Murphy resigned from the Department of Justice, telling NPR, 'It just was not a Department of Justice that I any longer wanted to associate with.'"

TITLE: Trump suspends $175 million in funding to University of Pennsylvania over trans athletes
SUMMARY: The University of Pennsylvania found itself at the center of the trans athlete debate when one of its trans students won a series of events during the 2022 swim season.

TITLE: Hamas fires first rockets since Israel breaks recent ceasefire
SUMMARY: The Israeli military expanded its ground offensive in Gaza, and killed at least 80 Palestinians in a new wave of strikes Thursday. Hamas fired its first rockets since Israel broke a recent ceasefire.

TITLE: 3 people face federal charges for Tesla attacks. Are such acts domestic terrorism?
SUMMARY: Attorney General Pamela Bondi says the accused are part of a "wave of domestic terrorism." Experts say this is a common stance of the federal government and can be used to seek stiffer penalties.

TITLE: Building a Tech Industry in Syria From Scratch
SUMMARY: Recently a few hundred people gathered at a Damascus hotel to discuss how to jump-start Syria's tech industry. That sector was basically non-existent during Syria's long civil war. Our correspondent attended the conference and met a young man who fled Syria during the civil war and now is a graduate student at Stanford. His journey illustrates both the possibilities and challenges that lie ahead for Syria.

TITLE: Judge calls 'woefully insufficient' the Trump administration response to his order
SUMMARY: Judge James Boasberg had earlier asked the Trump administration to provide more details about weekend flights that deported hundreds of alleged Venezuelan gang members to El Salvador — despite his order to turn the planes around.

TITLE: Federal agency responsible for library and museum funding gets a visit from DOGE
SUMMARY: Keith E. Sonderling is the new acting head of The Institute of Museum and Library Services, the main source of federal funding for libraries and museums across the country. President Trump issued an executive order last week saying he aims to close the agency.

TITLE: UK court finds men who stole $6 million gold toilet guilty
SUMMARY: The artwork, titled,<em> America

TITLE: Zimbabwean millennial Kirsty Coventry gets Olympic top job
SUMMARY: Zimbabwean Olympic swimmer Kirsty Coventry has been elected to head the International Olympic Committee. The two-time gold medalist is marking a whole new set of 'firsts.'

TITLE: Hollywood filmmaker charged with defrauding Netflix of $11 million
SUMMARY: Director Carl Erik Rinsch sold Netflix a sci-fi series. Instead of finishing it, prosecutors allege he spent some of the streamer's money on his own investments, luxury rentals, five Rolls-Royces, a Ferrari, and more.

TITLE: Heathrow Airport to close Friday after fire knocks out power to part of London
SUMMARY: Thousands of homes lost power and about 150 people had to be evacuated after a transformer within an electrical substation caught fire in west London.

TITLE: European military leaders discuss Ukraine peacekeeping force
SUMMARY: The number of troops that would help enforce a peace in Ukraine is vague. Officials have cited figures of between 10,000 and 30,000 troops as part of what's been termed a "reassurance force."

TITLE: U.S. government cannot deport Georgetown scholar until court rules, judge orders
SUMMARY: A federal judge on Thursday ordered immigration officials not to deport a Georgetown scholar who was detained by the Trump Administration and accused of spreading Hamas propaganda.

TITLE: Taiwan's president pushes to increase defense budget amid rising threat from China
SUMMARY: Taiwan's military is seeking funds to retain more service people with higher pay and to lengthen compulsory national service from four months to one year as it faces a rising threat from China.

TITLE: Families of deported Venezuelans dispute gang claims after deportations under Alien Enemies Act
SUMMARY: NPR talked to the families of four men believed to be in El Salvador. None of them had a serious criminal record in the U.S. Only some had been charged with illegal entry. Three had signed their voluntary departure.

TITLE: Court hearing to test legality of deportations under 18th century law
SUMMARY: Friday's hearing over the merits of the judge's temporary restraining order comes as the case has become a flashpoint between the judiciary and executive branches.

TITLE: Japanese Breakfast's Michelle Zauner embraces melancholy in new album
SUMMARY: With a new album, Michelle Zauner tells NPR she is finally finding balance between all the things she yearns for: her career goals, a connection to family and a connection to her ancestral home of Korea.

TITLE: How the Education Department cuts could hurt low-income and rural schools
SUMMARY: With cuts to nearly all the staff at the Department of Education's primary data agency, low-income and rural schools may not get the federal funds they rely on in coming years.

TITLE: 5 takeaways from this week — from courts pushing back on Trump to wars overseas
SUMMARY: Here are five takeaways from a week when President Trump moved ahead with deportations and sweeping changes to the federal government — and ran into obstacles in the courts.

TITLE: Survive and advance: First-day upsets set the table for March Madness
SUMMARY: McNeese and Drake universities stun their heavily favored opponents as the NCAA men's and women's basketball tournaments roll into their first weekend of play.

TITLE: What's trending in the world of soap operas? Find out in the quiz
SUMMARY: This week also saw a highly undramatic object cause drama and the happily undramatic return of the two NASA astronauts who had an unexpected stay on the International Space Station.

TITLE: Is planting trees 'DEI'? Trump administration cuts nationwide tree-planting effort
SUMMARY: The Trump administration's efforts to end DEI programs is hitting some unexpected targets, including a nationwide effort planting shade trees in neighborhoods to reduce extreme heat.

TITLE: Trump wants to erase DEI. Researchers worry it will upend work on health disparity
SUMMARY: Cancer researchers working on health disparities say President Trump's actions could hurt rural whites, who lag behind other groups in cancer screening.

TITLE: How Trump's firings could upend a 90-year-old Supreme Court ruling limiting his power
SUMMARY: Already, lower courts have found President Trump's removal of Democratic members of independent agencies to be unlawful. The Trump administration has appealed.

TITLE: Education Dept. cuts could hurt low-income schools. And, an entertainment rundown
SUMMARY: President Trump signed an executive action yesterday to start shutting down the Education Department, which could hurt low-income and rural schools. And, this week's new music, movies and books.

TITLE: A young adult book tackles a tough topic: A teen coping with his dad's mental illness
SUMMARY: Saadia Faruqi, author of the popular Yasmin book series, has written a new book, The Strongest Heart, that mirrors her own life — growing up with a father who likely had undiagnosed schizophrenia.

TITLE: Sudan's army recapture presidential palace in Khartoum
SUMMARY: Sudan's army has taken control of the presidential palace in Khartoum, in a major turning point during the war. The palace and the capital had been occupied by the Rapid Support Force paramilitary since the start of the war, but over the last year the army have been making gradual gains.

TITLE: Remembering award-winning sports journalist John Feinstein
SUMMARY: Feinstein, who died March 13, was known for his insights, and inside portraits, of some of the most talented and temperamental characters in sports. <em>Originally broadcast in 2011.

TITLE: Elon Musk heads to the Pentagon, sparking controversy
SUMMARY: The <em>New York Times

TITLE: Military's DEI purge seen putting its future — and its history — at risk
SUMMARY: Many Pentagon materials now labeled as "DEI" were a bit more like advertisements — aimed at recruits who have shown a willingness to serve, military experts tell NPR.

TITLE: Sudan's army recaptures presidential palace in Khartoum
SUMMARY: Sudan's army has taken control of the presidential palace in Khartoum, in a major turning point during the war. The palace and the capital had been occupied by the Rapid Support Force paramilitary since the start of the war, but over the last year the army have been making gradual gains.

TITLE: Elon Musk's Pentagon visit sparks more questions about his access to sensitive files
SUMMARY: The <em>New York Times

TITLE: Trump says Education Department will no longer oversee student loans, 'special needs'
SUMMARY: The president said federal student loans would move to the Small Business Administration, and hinted that the Department of Health and Human Services would take over special education oversight.

TITLE: Trump wants states to handle disasters. States aren't prepared
SUMMARY: President Trump says he's thinking of getting rid of the country's disaster response agency, FEMA. States say they can't replicate what FEMA does on their own.

TITLE: What we know about the case of detained Georgetown professor Badar Khan Suri
SUMMARY: The Indian national and postdoctoral fellow is the latest scholar detained or deported by the Trump administration for speaking in support of Palestinian rights or criticizing Israel's actions in Gaza.

TITLE: Screens and sleep. Maybe not so bad?
SUMMARY: We hear a lot about how screens impact our sleep, but how significant is the disruption? And how much does exercise predict sleep quality? This story first appeared in the Body Electric newsletter.

TITLE: Whistleblower John Barnett's family files wrongful death suit against Boeing
SUMMARY: The lawsuit includes a photo of a notebook found in John Barnett's truck when he died by suicide, bearing the message, "I pray Boeing Pays!!!" In response to the new lawsuit, Boeing said in a statement, "We are saddened by John Barnett's death and extend our condolences to his family."

TITLE: International Day of Forests arrives amid concerns over Trump's sweeping logging agenda
SUMMARY: The world celebrates International Day of Forests on Friday, but President Trump aims to expand American logging and roll back reforestation efforts.

TITLE: The long history of Russia's broken promises to Ukraine
SUMMARY:
Representatives from Russia and Ukraine will be in meetings to try to hammer out details of a ceasefire on Monday. But peace is still a long way off.

For starters it's only a partial ceasefire—no strikes on energy infrastructure. It's only for 30 days.

And the Ukrainians and Russians aren't even meeting with each other. The U.S. will be a go-between.

One of the biggest things working against a new agreement, is what happened after Ukraine's last agreement with Russia. And the ones before that.

Ukraine says it won't trust a promise from Russia. It needs security guarantees. To understand why, you've got to go back to the birth of independent Ukraine.

TITLE: Homeland Security makes cuts to civil rights and immigration oversight offices
SUMMARY: DHS confirms it is implementing a reduction in force in three oversight offices as part of the effort to cut the federal workforce.

TITLE: What's the ideal age to reach a life milestone? Many Americans say it depends
SUMMARY: Owning a home, starting a family or retiring: If these are things you want, what's the best age to do them? The Pew Research Center surveyed 3,600 U.S. adults to find out.

TITLE: Voice of America staff sue Trump administration for shutting down network
SUMMARY: Six Voice of America journalists and a director at its parent agency have sued the Trump administration, alleging its moves to shut down the U.S.-funded network are unconstitutional.

TITLE: George Foreman, the glowering heavyweight who became a lovable champion, dies at 76
SUMMARY: The heavyweight who lost the "Rumble in the Jungle" to Muhammad Ali before authoring an inspiring second act as a 45-year-old champion and a successful businessman was 76.

TITLE: George Foreman, the fearsome heavyweight who became a beloved champion, dies at 76
SUMMARY: The heavyweight who lost the "Rumble in the Jungle" to Muhammad Ali before authoring an inspiring second act as a 45-year-old champion and a successful businessman was 76.

TITLE: Trump has U.S. Indo-Pacific allies guessing on trade and security
SUMMARY: As with Europe, the Trump administration is sending conflicting signals to America's long-standing allies in Asia, with whom the U.S. has deep-rooted security agreements that date back to the 1950s.

TITLE: Court hearing centers on Newsmax CEO's role in spreading election-fraud claims
SUMMARY: Newsmax is being sued for defamation by Dominion Voting Systems — the same company that sued Fox News over false 2020 election-fraud claims and walked away with a nearly $800 million settlement.

TITLE: Some European countries and Canada issue advisories for travelers to the U.S.
SUMMARY: The advisories come after some citizens from European countries and Canada have been detained and deported by immigration officials while traveling to the United States.<strong>

TITLE: The Social Security Administration's many proposed changes are worrying advocates
SUMMARY: The Trump administration has announced a flurry of changes at the agency that oversees Social Security. Advocates warn these moves could lead to people having a harder time getting help with benefits.

TITLE: Bernie Sanders is drawing record crowds as he pushes Democrats to 'fight oligarchy'
SUMMARY: The populist message of Sen. Bernie Sanders' "Fighting Oligarchy" tour has resonated with voters frustrated by President Trump's agenda — and the Democratic Party's muddled response.

TITLE: Can't-miss interviews: Martha Stewart, Japanese Breakfast and an astronaut
SUMMARY: Rounding up the big interviews you might have missed, from gardening tips with Martha Stewart to a conversation with a former astronaut about what happens to our bodies after that much time in space.

TITLE: Flights resume at London Heathrow after a daylong closure sparked travel chaos
SUMMARY: Heathrow Airport said it was "fully operational" on Saturday, after an almost daylong closure sparked by an electrical substation fire. But airlines warned that severe disruption will last for days.

TITLE: DHS revokes legal protections for 532,000 Cubans, Haitians, Nicaraguans and Venezuelans
SUMMARY: The Department of Homeland Security's new policy, revoking legal protections for hundreds of thousands, impacts people who are already in the U.S. and who came under a humanitarian parole program.

TITLE: South Sudan "on the brink" UN warns amid renewed violence
SUMMARY: The worlds youngest country teetering on the brink of another conflict and the possibility of regional war.

TITLE: Israel strikes multiple sites in southern Lebanon in response to rocket attack
SUMMARY: Lebanese health officials said two people were killed, including a child, and several more were injured.

TITLE: Where is the NCAA basketball tournament game-winning buzzer-beater?
SUMMARY: A wider disparity between major conferences and lesser-known conferences has lent itself to fewer close games in the early rounds of both the men's and women's NCAA tournaments.

TITLE: A VA rescue effort saved 15,000 veterans' homes. Some in Congress want to scrap it
SUMMARY: An NPR investigation uncovered 40,000 vets facing foreclosure due to a VA mistake. A rescue program is helping many of them, but others fear being left out if Congress cuts this new lifeline

TITLE: South Sudan is 'on the brink,' U.N. warns amid renewed violence
SUMMARY: The world's youngest country is teetering on the brink of another conflict as a regional war looms.

TITLE: From Martha Stewart to Japanese Breakfast, 7 can't-miss interviews this week
SUMMARY: Rounding up the big interviews you might have missed, from gardening tips with Martha Stewart to a conversation with a former astronaut about what happens to our bodies after that much time in space.

TITLE: Trump has U.S. Indo-Pacific allies guessing on trade and security
SUMMARY: As with Europe, the Trump administration is sending conflicting signals to America's long-standing allies in Asia, with whom the U.S. has deep-rooted security agreements that date back to the 1950s.

TITLE: Trump revokes classified access for Joe Biden, Hillary Clinton and others
SUMMARY: While mostly symbolic, the move to revoke security clearances for over a dozen former officials has been seen as a warning to President Trump's adversaries.

TITLE: Pope Francis will be discharged from the hospital on Sunday, doctors say
SUMMARY: The pontiff spent over five weeks being treated for bronchitis that evolved into a severe respiratory illness. When he returns to the Vatican, he will need to rest for two months, his doctor said.

TITLE: Trump says Boeing will build the new generation of fighter jets, the F-47
SUMMARY: Trump said Boeing had won the contract to build the U.S. Air Force's next generation of fighter jets. Little is known about the jet's specifications, appearance or capabilities.

TITLE: Hundreds arrested in Turkey in protests against the detention of Istanbul's mayor
SUMMARY: Istanbul Mayor Ekrem Imamoglu, the top challenger to President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, is accused of corruption and terror links. The opposition says Imamoglu's arrest is politically motivated.

TITLE: The U.S. lifts bounties on senior Taliban officials, says Kabul
SUMMARY: The U.S. has lifted bounties on three senior Taliban figures, including the interior minister, officials in Kabul said Sunday.

TITLE: Turkish court orders key Erdogan rival jailed pending trial on corruption charges
SUMMARY: Mayor Ekrem Imamoglu was detained following a raid on his residence earlier this week, sparking the largest wave of street demonstrations in Turkey in more than a decade.

TITLE: Humming along in an old church, the Internet Archive is more relevant than ever
SUMMARY: The Trump administration's erasure of federal data has put the Internet Archive in the spotlight. The organization, with its small but mighty team, is working to help save the world's digital history.

TITLE: Israeli strikes on Gaza kill 19, including Hamas official
SUMMARY: Israeli strikes across the southern Gaza Strip killed at least 19 Palestinians overnight, including a Hamas political leader, as the military ordered new evacuations in the southern city of Rafah.

TITLE: This Harlem pastor fights mental health stigma — and shares his own struggles
SUMMARY: First Corinthian Baptist Church founded a separate nonprofit that employs therapists to bring mental health care to a community where stigma remains a high barrier to healing.

TITLE: As Ovechkin nears the NHL goals record, the hockey world leans in to savor the moment
SUMMARY: For years, Wayne Gretzky's record of 894 career regular-season goals was widely thought to be untouchable. Now, the Washington Capitals star has just a handful to go to claim the record as his own.

TITLE: Israeli strikes on Gaza kill 26, including Hamas official
SUMMARY: Israeli strikes across the southern Gaza Strip killed at least 26 Palestinians overnight, including a Hamas political leader, as the military ordered new evacuations in the southern city of Rafah.

TITLE: Pope Francis makes first public appearance ahead of hospital discharge
SUMMARY: The Pontiff's expected discharge comes after a five-week hospitalization for a severe respiratory infection.

TITLE: Palestinian deaths in Gaza rise above 50,000 as Israel expands its military campaign
SUMMARY: The death toll reached the milestone just days after Israel resumed its military campaign in Gaza, breaking a ceasefire with Hamas.

TITLE: Pope Francis is discharged from the hospital after treatment for respiratory infection
SUMMARY: The pontiff left the hospital on Sunday following treatment for a severe respiratory infection that led to bilateral pneumonia.

TITLE: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney and opponent kick off their election campaigns
SUMMARY: Trump's frequent attacks on Canada's sovereignty have infuriated Canadians and led to a surge in Canadian nationalism that has bolstered Liberal poll numbers.

TITLE: How an obscure legal theory shaped the immunity decision and Trump's second term
SUMMARY:
In Trump v. United States, the Supreme Court held that the president has "absolute immunity from criminal prosecution" for official acts.

To reach that conclusion, the High Court grappled with this question: how much power a president should have?

And some legal scholars say the ruling draws on the unitary executive theory — which, in its most extreme interpretation, gives the president sole authority over the executive branch.

But did it pave the way for Trump's second term and the constitutional questions it's raised: From the dismantling of federal agencies established by Congress to the deportation migrants to third party countries without due process?

TITLE: Venezuela says it will start accepting repatriation flights from the U.S. again
SUMMARY: Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro has called for the return of the Venezuelan migrants sent by the U.S. to El Salvador, where President Nayib Bukele said they were transferred to a mega-prison.

TITLE: Max Frankel, former New York Times top editor, dies at 94
SUMMARY: Frankel was <em>The New York Times'

TITLE: South Korean court reinstates impeached PM Han Duck-soo as acting leader
SUMMARY: Many observers said Monday's ruling on Han Duck-soo doesn't signal much on the upcoming verdict on President Yoon Suk Yeol, as Han wasn't a key figure in Yoon's martial law imposition.

TITLE: Reporter's Notebook: Eight theories why fentanyl deaths are plummeting
SUMMARY: Thirty thousand fewer people are dying every year in the U.S. from fentanyl and other street drugs. This shift has stunned addiction experts, reversing decades of rising death. Here are eight theories on why things are getting better.

TITLE: Could legal weed make you sick? Here's how California tries to keep it safe
SUMMARY: With no help from the federal government, states are trying to regulate recreational marijuana. California's Department of Cannabis Control works to keep contaminants out of joints, vapes and edibles.

TITLE: TikTok is full of ADHD advice — just don't trust it for a diagnosis
SUMMARY: TikTok has become the go-to-source on ADHD for teens and young adults. But a new study finds a lot of the information is misleading and can make people's symptoms worse.

TITLE: Dreams of a three-peat come crashing at the NCAA basketball tournament
SUMMARY: Florida ends UConn's bid to repeat — again — in Sunday action that saw a memorable buzzer-beater. Meanwhile, South Carolina advances in the women's tournament, which rounds out its Sweet 16 on Monday.

TITLE: One family. One attack. 132 names. A Gaza investigation
SUMMARY: More than 50,000 Palestinians have been killed in Israel's war with Hamas, Gaza health officials say. We reconstructed what happened in one of the deadliest Israeli strikes of the war.

TITLE: 'Twain hated bullies.' Conan O'Brien receives Mark Twain Prize at the Kennedy Center
SUMMARY: Comedian Conan O'Brien received the Mark Twain Prize at the Kennedy Center on Sunday night, which David Letterman called "the most entertaining gathering of the resistance ever."

TITLE: Israel's classified military plans for Gaza. And, defining "buy-now, pay-later" loans
SUMMARY: Israel is considering plans for a full-scale ground invasion of Gaza within a few months. And, examining the pros and cons of "buy-now, pay-later" loans.

TITLE: Reporter's notebook: 8 theories why fentanyl deaths are plummeting
SUMMARY: Some 30,000 fewer people are dying every year in the U.S. from fentanyl and other street drugs. This shift has stunned addiction experts, reversing decades of rising death.

TITLE: Things people forget to clean the most, according to cleaning experts
SUMMARY: Kyshawn Lane of Weekly Home Check and Dana K. White, author of<em> Decluttering at the Speed of Life,

TITLE: Israel's latest war plans: to occupy Gaza and rule Palestinians
SUMMARY: Occupying Gaza and establishing military rule there would go beyond Israel's stated war goals to end Hamas rule and free hostages captured in the Oct. 7, 2023 attack.

TITLE: Israel's latest war plans: To occupy Gaza and rule Palestinians
SUMMARY: Occupying Gaza and establishing military rule there would go beyond Israel's stated war goals to end Hamas rule and free hostages captured in the Oct. 7, 2023, attack.

TITLE: A legal scholar talks about 10 laws he says are 'ruining America'
SUMMARY: In<em> Bad Law,

TITLE: The U.S. and Russia are holding talks in Saudi Arabia on a Black Sea ceasefire
SUMMARY: The closed-door talks at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Riyadh follow U.S. consultations with a Ukrainian delegation on stabilizing the front lines and implementing a proposed 30-day armistice.

TITLE: India is hoping its manufacturing industry will profit from Trump's tariffs on China
SUMMARY: India is hoping to attract more manufacturing as the Trump administration's tariff policies make it more expensive to do business in China.

TITLE: How are inflation or tariffs affecting your shopping and budget? NPR wants to know
SUMMARY: Whether you're a shopper or a seller, a worker or a business owner, you likely have a lot on your mind when it comes to budgeting, planning trips or big purchases. And we want to hear all about it.

TITLE: How the Ph.D. Project, and 45 colleges, became a target of the Trump administration
SUMMARY: For about 30 years, the Ph.D. Project has supported students from underrepresented groups who are earning doctoral degrees in business. Now, it's attracted the attention of the Trump administration.

TITLE: Former head of Social Security says Elon Musk and DOGE are wrong about the agency
SUMMARY: Micheal Astrue, former commissioner of Social Security Administration under George W. Bush and Barack Obama, told NPR Elon Musk is wrong about Social Security and that there is no widespread fraud.

TITLE: Democrats in Trump-won districts call on party to rebrand
SUMMARY: Democrats need to flip three seats to take back the House next year – and the path to a majority likely runs through districts President Trump carried. Democrats who won alongside Trump offer their prescription for a party they say needs to make big changes.

TITLE: Speaking into a microphone? Your audio quality can impact the way people view you
SUMMARY: A new study shows that the quality of a person's microphone in a video meeting affects how the speaker is perceived by others.

TITLE: Judge contends Nazis got more due process than Trump deportees did
SUMMARY: The fight over the rarely used wartime power has become central to Trump's immigration crackdown agenda and his efforts to stretch the powers of the executive branch.

TITLE: Lindsay Vonn sets a record straight out of retirement
SUMMARY: The decorated skier returned to the sport after six years away due to an injury and has already made a splash.

TITLE: Supreme Court confronts another challenge to the Voting Rights Act
SUMMARY: The case is nearly identical to a case the court ruled on two years ago from Alabama, though the outcome could make it more difficult for minorities to prevail in redistricting cases.

TITLE: Israel's Powerful Finance Minister and the Future of the Gaza Strip
SUMMARY: NPR has learned that Israel is considering a major ground invasion of Gaza to fully occupy the territory and establish a military rule over Palestinians there. We learn about this plan and hear about the influential minister who has repeatedly called for Israel to resettle the Gaza Strip. Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich has threated to collapse Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's government if the Gaza war ends. Our reporter talked to Smotrich and tells us about his rise to power.

TITLE: USPS head Louis DeJoy steps down as Trump officials consider Postal Service overhaul
SUMMARY: The head of the U.S. Postal Service is stepping down. Louis DeJoy's exit comes after Trump officials floated controversial ideas for overhauling the agency.

TITLE: 23andMe is filing for bankruptcy. Here's what it means for your genetic data
SUMMARY: The California biotech firm said in a statement that it is hoping to find a buyer to address its ongoing financial struggles.

TITLE: Oscar-winning Palestinian director attacked by Israeli settlers, detained by army
SUMMARY: Israeli settlers beat up Hamdan Ballal, one of the Palestinian co-directors of the documentary film <em>No Other Land,

TITLE: The inside story of how a journalist was sent White House war plans
SUMMARY: Jeffrey Goldberg, the editor of <em>The Atlantic,

TITLE: Brazil apologizes to families of victims of military dictatorship's mass grave
SUMMARY: Brazil's government on Monday apologized to families of victims of the country's military dictatorship whose remains could be among those found in a clandestine mass grave 35 years ago.

TITLE: French actor Gérard Depardieu stands trial in Paris for alleged sexual assaults
SUMMARY: Depardieu's long and storied career has turned the trial into a post- #MeToo test of the willingness of France and its movie industry to confront sexual violence and hold influential men accountable.

TITLE: Why Canada is holding an election that will be a first for its prime minister
SUMMARY: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney is running for elected public office for the first time, as the country is roiled by turbulence set in motion by President Trump.

TITLE: Doctors still seeking cure for brain cancer that struck former Utah Rep. Mia Love
SUMMARY: Mia Love, the first Black Republican woman elected to Congress, died three years after being diagnosed with glioblastoma, a brain cancer that is nearly always fatal.

TITLE: Facing a silver tsunami, Nevada home health care workers demand a $20 minimum wage
SUMMARY: Home health care workers in Nevada are lobbying the state legislature to raise caregivers' minimum wage from $16 to $20 an hour.

TITLE: Feeling scatterbrained? 5 ways to focus your attention
SUMMARY: What would you do if you had more hours in a day? Here's how to carve out time for your interests and passions — even when you have a lot of responsibilities.

TITLE: New books this week: Yoko, Elphaba, Amanda Knox and lost connections
SUMMARY: This week's new releases include a memoir from Amanda Knox reflecting on her murder case and exoneration, a biography of Yoko Ono, new fiction from Column McCann, and the latest Wicked book Elphie

TITLE: These churches offer shelter and sanctuary to vulnerable migrants. Here's why
SUMMARY: Some are offering sanctuary to immigrants, others are ministering to families in different ways.

TITLE: NCAA women's tournament reaches the Sweet 16 as one of its biggest stars falls
SUMMARY: Southern California All-American star JuJu Watkins crashed to the floor Monday night against Mississippi State and grabbed her knee. She had to be carried off the floor at the USC Galen Center.

TITLE: What happens when a Chicago hospital bows to federal pressure on trans care for teens
SUMMARY: Patients and parents speak out after Lurie Children's in Chicago joined other hospitals in stopping gender-affirming surgeries. President Trump's executive order threatened their federal funding.

TITLE: How a journalist was sent the U.S. war plans. And, challenging the Alien Enemies Act
SUMMARY: A journalist at <em>The Atlantic

TITLE: USC star Juju Watkins carried off the court as NCAA tournament reaches the Sweet 16
SUMMARY: Southern California All-American star JuJu Watkins crashed to the floor Monday night against Mississippi State and grabbed her knee. She had to be carried off the floor at the USC Galen Center.

TITLE: Trump's back-to-office order will hurt veterans, VA docs and therapists say
SUMMARY: The Department of Veterans Affairs embraced telehealth, especially for mental health care, in recent years. Now, staffers hired to give therapy and other health care remotely are ordered to do it from offices lacking privacy, VA clinicians told NPR.

TITLE: USC star JuJu Watkins carried off the court as NCAA tournament reaches the Sweet 16
SUMMARY: Southern California All-American star JuJu Watkins crashed to the floor Monday night against Mississippi State and grabbed her knee. She had to be carried off the floor at the USC Galen Center.

TITLE: Intelligence leaders will testify before Congress, fresh off the group chat fiasco
SUMMARY: Some of the nation's top intelligence officials are due to appear before Congress in a pair of hearings this week. Two were participants in a widely-criticized war plans group chat on Signal.

TITLE: Pete Marocco tried to upend USAID in 2020 -- and failed. In 2025, he dismantled it
SUMMARY: This Trump administration official was a key figure in the dismantling of the United States Agency for International Development — and will help set the agenda for the future of foreign aid.

TITLE: China releases staff of an American due diligence firm in move to woo investors
SUMMARY: The release of the employees from the firm, the Mintz Group, comes as China is trying to woo back foreign investors to help revive its sagging economy.

TITLE: Watch: Intelligence leaders testify before Congress, fresh off the group chat fiasco
SUMMARY: Some of the nation's top intelligence officials will appear before Congress in a pair of hearings this week. Two were participants in a widely criticized war plans group chat on Signal.

TITLE: How to delete your 23andMe data after the company filed for bankruptcy
SUMMARY: When the California biotech firm filed for bankruptcy, there was one looming question for customers: What's going to happen to my data?

TITLE: NASA website axes a pledge to land a woman and a person of color on the moon
SUMMARY: In deference to President Trump's anti-DEI order, the space agency has removed a promise to send the "the first woman, first person of color" to walk on the moon aboard the Artemis III mission.

TITLE: Why Israel's having some of its biggest protests since the war in Gaza began
SUMMARY: They're demanding a deal between Israel and Hamas to release all the remaining hostages, and also demonstrating against government attempts to weaken the judiciary.

TITLE: Hamdan Ballal, a Palestinian director beaten by Israeli settlers, is now released
SUMMARY: Hamdan Ballal, who won an Oscar for <em>No Other Land

TITLE: Ancient Greek and Roman statues often smelled like roses, a new study says
SUMMARY: Ancient Greek and Roman statues didn't originally look like they do now in museums. A new study says they didn't smell the same, either.

TITLE: A Pentagon-wide email recently went out warning about Signal's vulnerability
SUMMARY: A Pentagon-wide advisory that went out one week ago warns against using the Signal, the messaging app, even for unclassified information.

TITLE: China releases staff of an American due diligence firm in a move to woo investors
SUMMARY: The release of the employees from the Mintz Group comes as China is trying to woo back foreign investors to help revive its sagging economy.

TITLE: Intelligence leaders: We didn't share classified information in Signal chat group
SUMMARY: The CIA Director and the Director of National Intelligence testified that they did not share classified information in a messaging group chat that discussed the U.S. bombing campaign in Yemen.

TITLE: Lavender, citrus and candy: weed's signature aroma changes with the times
SUMMARY: A tour of a grow facility in Maryland reveals the wide variety of scents from different cannabis strains.

TITLE: Skin bleaching is terribly popular -- and takes a terrible toll
SUMMARY: The government in Nigeria is warning about the health risks of skin lightening, where potent chemicals can thin and damage skin. It's a booming business in that country and others.

TITLE: 'Mad House' exposes Congressional disfunction, from petty feuds to physical threats
SUMMARY: The MAGA-controlled 118th House passed only 27 bills that became law — the lowest number since the Great Depression. Journalists Annie Karni and Luke Broadwater examine the chaos in a new book.

TITLE: Long before the Signal leak, the Pentagon warned the app was the target of hackers
SUMMARY: A Pentagon-wide advisory that went out one week ago warned against using Signal, the messaging app, even for unclassified information.

TITLE: The Triumph of a Doctrine of Cruelty in El Salvador
SUMMARY: For three years El Salvador's President Nayib Bukele has proudly shown the world the terrible treatment given to the country's prisoners. The president and his defenders say barbaric treatment is necessary to combat a pervasive gang problem in the country. And now the U.S. is endorsing this view, sending hundreds of people removed from the U.S. to those same prisons. We hear about the triumph of Bukele's style of rule in El Salvador.

TITLE: 5 things to know as Dr. Oz gets one step closer to leading Medicare and Medicaid
SUMMARY: The former TV doctor made it through a tight vote in the Senate Finance committee with only Republican support.

TITLE: 'Heads are exploding': How security experts see the Signal war-plan breach
SUMMARY: The breach left military and intelligence experts asking the same questions as the public: Why would top U.S. officials use a free messaging app to discuss classified military plans?

TITLE: A new study quantifies how a citizenship question would likely hurt census accuracy
SUMMARY: The next U.S. head count's accuracy would likely be undermined by a census question about citizenship status that GOP lawmakers and President Trump have pushed to add, a new peer-reviewed study finds.

TITLE: Days after the Signal leak, the Pentagon warned the app was the target of hackers
SUMMARY: A Pentagon-wide advisory that went out one week ago warned against using Signal, the messaging app, even for unclassified information.

TITLE: In new assessment, Trump team ranks fentanyl as a top threat to U.S.
SUMMARY: Drug deaths are declining but the Trump administration's intelligence team has issued a new report describing street fentanyl as a top threat to the U.S.

TITLE: Hill Republicans aim to rein in judges but divided on strategy
SUMMARY: Following court decisions restricting the Trump administration's policies on immigration enforcement and cuts to federal agencies GOP lawmakers are pushing back. But they're split on how to respond.

TITLE: Vice President Vance is going to Greenland this week. The itinerary has shifted
SUMMARY: Second lady Usha Vance announced on Sunday that she would visit Greenland and watch the territory's famed dog sled race. But now the vice president is joining, and they'll go to a U.S. base instead.

TITLE: Lavender, citrus and candy: Weed's signature aroma changes with the times
SUMMARY: A tour of a grow facility in Maryland reveals the wide variety of scents from different cannabis strains.

TITLE: 'Plain sloppiness': Sen. Mark Warner says on Signal chat fiasco
SUMMARY: During a heated Senate Intelligence Committee hearing on Tuesday, Sen. Mark Warner described the actions of the nation's top intelligence officials as "sloppy, careless, incompetent behavior.

TITLE: Republican lawmakers seek to put PBS and NPR in the hot seat
SUMMARY: A House subcommittee led by Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene and named after Elon Musk's government-efficiency team has set its sights on the public broadcasters.

TITLE: Pilot and 2 children survive a night on airplane wing after crashing into Alaska lake
SUMMARY: A pilot and two girls survived on the wing of a plane for about 12 hours after it crashed and was partially submerged in an icy Alaska lake, then were rescued after being spotted by a good Samaritan.

TITLE: Gunman who killed 23 in Texas Walmart attack can avoid death penalty with plea deal
SUMMARY: El Paso County District Attorney James Montoya said that his decision in the prosecution of Patrick Crusius was driven by a majority of victims' relatives who wanted the case behind them.

TITLE: 'Like a sound from hell:' Was an illegal sonic weapon used on protesters in Serbia?
SUMMARY: The weapons, which are illegal in Serbia, emit sound waves which can trigger sharp ear pain, disorientation, eardrum ruptures or even irreversible hearing damage.

TITLE: Wildfires ravage South Korea, killing 18 and destroying a 1,300-year-old temple
SUMMARY: A 1,300-year-old Buddhist temple, houses, factories and vehicles were among the structures destroyed in the wildfires that have burned 43,330 acres and injured 19 people.

TITLE: Trump's new executive order could upend voting
SUMMARY: The order tests the power of Trump's authority and would require voters using a federal form to show proof of citizenship to register to vote in federal elections. It's sure to be tested in court.

TITLE: Why don't diving seals drown? Scientists finally have an answer
SUMMARY: New research suggests seals sense internal oxygen levels to know when to come up for air. Digital version of story that already aired. Skedded for pub Weds. 3/26 at 6 a.m. Reporter: Lambert. Editor: Khan.

TITLE: 'Felt like a kidnapping': Wrong turn leads to 5-day detention ordeal
SUMMARY: A Guatemalan immigrant without legal status says she took a wrong turn on a highway near the Canadian border and was detained with her two children, who are American citizens. They were held for five days.

TITLE: Buying or selling on StubHub? It's probably not showing you all the available tickets
SUMMARY: StubHub has a "Recommended Tickets" filter that only displays some tickets but not others. It's automatically turned on — and it's upsetting users.

TITLE: March Madness is underway. So is March Napness, the tournament for hibernating bears
SUMMARY: A handful of rescued bears in Europe are competing in March Napness, a bracket-style tournament to see what bear can stay in hibernation the longest.

TITLE: A glimpse into the newly opened archive of Joan Didion and John Gregory Dunne
SUMMARY: The New York Public Library's Joan Didion archive opens March 26. Here's what you'll find inside.

TITLE: Kennedy Center lays off Social Impact employees
SUMMARY: The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, D.C., has dissolved its Social Impact division, which partnered with local organizations to bring in diverse artists and audiences.

TITLE: Why a tiny bit of oil can be a big deal
SUMMARY: More than three-quarters of U.S. wells make just 6% of the country's oil. They're called marginal wells because of their small output. But they're a big deal to oil producers and environmentalists.

TITLE: Federal workers ordered back to office find shortages of desks, Wi-Fi and toilet paper
SUMMARY: As agencies scramble to comply with President Trump's Jan. 20 order terminating remote work, employees say the process has been marked by confusion, changing guidance, and frustrating conditions.

TITLE: As opposition to fluoride grows, rural America risks a new surge of tooth decay
SUMMARY: Many rural counties are short on dentists, and if they lose water fluoridation, tooth decay could surge to levels that have not been seen in decades, experts warn.

TITLE: Colorado is poised to pass some of the toughest gun laws in the country
SUMMARY: A proposal to severely limit guns that use detachable magazines is approaching final passage in the Colorado legislature. The state's Democratic governor, Jared Polis, is expected to sign it into law.

TITLE: Dems want to investigate Signal blunder. And, federal return-to-office complications
SUMMARY: Top Democrats call for an investigation into how war plans were shared with a journalist on Signal. And, federal employees face complications and shortages when returning to the office.

TITLE: Parts of America will experience a partial solar eclipse this weekend
SUMMARY: The partial solar eclipse will be visible in various locations in the U.S. Northeast.

TITLE: March Madness is underway. So is March Napness, the tournament for hibernating bears
SUMMARY: A handful of rescued bears in Europe are competing in March Napness, a bracket-style tournament to see what bear can stay in hibernation the longest.

TITLE: NPR and PBS heads appear on Capitol Hill to answer allegations of bias
SUMMARY: The CEOs of the largest U.S. public broadcasting networks are appearing before a House subcommittee chaired by Republican Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene.

TITLE: DOGE says it needs to know the government's most sensitive data, but can't say why
SUMMARY: DOGE staffers have skirted privacy laws, training and security protocols to gain virtually unfettered access to financial and personal information stored in siloed government databases.

TITLE: Supreme Court upholds Biden-era rule regulating ghost guns
SUMMARY: The court said that ghost guns, which are virtually untraceable weapons that require assembly, are considered "firearms" and subject to ATF regulation.

TITLE: Watch: U.S. intelligence leaders testify in House after Signal flap
SUMMARY: The use of civilian software to discuss sensitive military and government matters came to light after a journalist from <em>The Atlantic

TITLE: 'Grandpas' got together to help kids. Scientists say it boosts the elders' health, too
SUMMARY: Older men can find themselves isolated after retirement. Volunteer groups like Grandpas United are good for both physical and mental health.

TITLE: WATCH LIVE: NPR, PBS heads answer lawmakers' allegations of bias
SUMMARY: The CEOs of the largest U.S. public broadcasting networks are appearing before a House subcommittee chaired by Republican Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene.

TITLE: What's soil blocking? This seeding method helps gardeners use less plastic and peat
SUMMARY: Soil blocking is an environmentally friendly method to prep seedlings. The technique has captured the attention of serious gardeners who'd like to make their growing more sustainable.

TITLE: Trump cuts threaten measurement lab critical for advanced chips and medical devices
SUMMARY: The Atomic Spectroscopy Group provides standardized measurements used across wide swaths of science and industry. The Trump administration plans to cut it.

TITLE: Judge freezes Trump plan to dismantle Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty
SUMMARY: Federal Judge Royce Lamberth ruled the continued operation of Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty was "in the public interest" and froze White House plans to shut it down.

TITLE: 'An unbelievable cocktail of incompetence': a U.S. representative on Signal messages
SUMMARY: Leila Fadel speaks with Congressman Jim Himes (D-Conn.) ahead of a hearing on the Trump administration's inadvertent disclosure of war plans on messaging app Signal.

TITLE: Why Amanda Knox returns to Italy — and how she talks with her daughter about injustice
SUMMARY: Amanda Knox spent nearly four years in an Italian prison for a murder she didn't commit. After her exoneration, she reached out to the man who prosecuted her case. Knox's new memoir is <em>Free

TITLE: What is the 'state secrets privilege' invoked by the Trump administration?
SUMMARY: The state secrets privilege allows the U.S. government to withhold sensitive evidence in court cases. Both Democratic and Republican administrations have invoked it.

TITLE: Trump cuts threaten a measurement lab critical for advanced chips and medical devices
SUMMARY: The Atomic Spectroscopy Group provides standardized measurements used across wide swaths of science and industry. The Trump administration plans to cut it.

TITLE: Supreme Court upholds a Biden-era rule regulating ghost guns
SUMMARY: The court says ghost guns, which are virtually untraceable weapons that require assembly, are considered "firearms" and subject to ATF regulation.

TITLE: U.S. intel leaders are grilled again about the leaked Signal chat as more details emerge
SUMMARY: The use of civilian software to discuss sensitive military and government matters came to light after a journalist from <em>The Atlantic

TITLE: Federal judge who drew Trump's anger picks up new case against administration
SUMMARY: James Boasberg, chief judge of the D.C. District Court, will preside over a case about the Trump administration's use of a Signal group chat to discuss military information.

TITLE: How Europeans are reacting to the Yemen war plans group chat
SUMMARY: In Europe, there's now a sense of a "broken relationship" in discovering "the extent of American hostility," one French analyst said. "But like in love, there is life after a breakup."

TITLE: How NPR covers itself when it's in the news
SUMMARY: When NPR is in the news, its journalists aim to cover what's happening the same way they cover other news or an organization. The newsroom follows a protocol that seeks to ensure only a small number of employees, none of whom are directly involved in the news event, works on the coverage.

TITLE: Brazil's Supreme Court says Bolsonaro must stand trial over alleged coup attempt
SUMMARY: The former far-right populist president, Jair Bolsonaro, will face trial for allegedly attempting to overturn his 2022 reelection loss and stage a violent coup.

TITLE: The Global Race for Rare Earth Minerals
SUMMARY: The race is on for control over deposits of rare earth elements and critical minerals that are necessary in much of the technology we use today. The U.S. is lagging behind it's main rival in this global competition, China. We hear about why these resources are so sought after and the stakes in the race to control them.

TITLE: Judge allows 'New York Times' copyright case against OpenAI to go forward
SUMMARY: The legal fight could have far-reaching implications for the media and artificial intelligence industries.

TITLE: What to know about Pituffik, the only U.S. military base in Greenland
SUMMARY: Vice President JD Vance will travel to Greenland this week, including a stop at Pituffik Space Base, the U.S. Defense Department's northernmost installation and its only outpost on the island.

TITLE: EV buyers who missed out on their tax credits now have a fix from the IRS
SUMMARY: Some car owners couldn't claim the EV tax credit for vehicles purchased in 2024 because dealers skipped a key sales reporting step. The IRS is now offering a fix.

TITLE: Trump announces new 25 percent tariff on all cars made outside the U.S.
SUMMARY: The president's latest action on trade enacts a 25% tariff on cars made outside of the U.S., continuing his trade policies focused on boosting American manufacturing.

TITLE: As U.S. foreign aid grants get slashed, Greenland gets money for a dog race
SUMMARY: Second lady Usha Vance has scrapped a plan to attend Greenland's national dog sled race this week. But American tax dollars will help support the race anyway.

TITLE: Social Security officials partially walk back plans for in-person verification
SUMMARY: Officials said they would now exempt people who apply for Medicare and disability benefits, as well as supplemental income help for the poor, from having to<strong>

TITLE: Appeals court sides with judge who blocked deportations under wartime authority
SUMMARY: The D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals panel denied the Trump administration's push to restart deportations of alleged gang members under a rarely used wartime authority known as the Alien Enemies Act.

TITLE: Trump announces new 25% tariff on imported cars and car parts
SUMMARY: The president's latest action on trade takes effect next week, and will slap a 25% tariff on imported cars and car parts. He says the measure will boost U.S. manufacturing.

TITLE: Exhibit takes visitors inside the annex where Anne Frank lived
SUMMARY: For the first time, a re-creation of the annex where Anne Frank and her family hid is available outside of Amsterdam. Visitors in New York said its themes reverberated in today's political climate.

TITLE: Climate change and overfishing threaten Vietnam's tradition of making fish sauce
SUMMARY: Climate change and overfishing are making it harder to catch the anchovies essential to the condiment that underlies so much of Vietnam and southeast Asia's food.

TITLE: As Bangladesh gears up for election, a new political player emerges
