SUMMARY: Last year, Gen-Z uprising in Bangladesh helped bring down Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina. Student activists continue to be central figures in shaping the future of Bangladesh's political landscape.

TITLE: A new Utah law is Republicans' latest effort to limit mail ballot return
SUMMARY: Utah's new law is part of a larger effort by Republicans to limit the window in which mail ballots can be counted during an election.

TITLE: Legal challenges are expected for President Trump's voter registration executive order
SUMMARY: President Trump has signed an executive order requiring proof of citizenship to register to vote. Voting rights advocates are expecting lawsuits to challenge the order.

TITLE: Trump officials downplay the Signal leak. Some military members see a double standard
SUMMARY: The news of the leak of life-and-death operational details to a reporter lands differently with veterans and active-duty troops, who can be prosecuted for much less significant "spillage" incidents.

TITLE: March Madness and babies: Are the sounds of the game too big for little ears?
SUMMARY: What's the right age to take kids to a loud sporting event? A Johns Hopkins noise expert on protecting babies' ears and when game day noise might be too much for them.

TITLE: Déjà vu all over again? Dodgers are favorites as 2025 MLB season begins
SUMMARY: Major League Baseball's 2025 season gets fully underway Thursday. The scary news for the league: the defending champion Los Angeles Dodgers, favorites to repeat, may be even better this season.

TITLE: Trump's new tariffs could raise car prices. And, Dems demand answers after Signal leak
SUMMARY: Trump announced he'll impose 25% tariffs on imported cars starting next week. The decision received mixed reactions. And, Democrats are demanding answers after bombing plans were discussed on Signal.

TITLE: Ukrainians in front line regions reel from losses, but say hope dies last for them
SUMMARY: Into their fourth year of war, Ukrainians living in or near front line regions of their country grapple with their losses and contemplate an uncertain future.

TITLE: In need of some peace? Take a stroll — or scroll — through D.C.'s cherry blossoms
SUMMARY: Springtime means cherry blossoms in the nation's capital. On a recent breezy morning, with peak bloom still two days away, the Tidal Basin was packed with both blossoms and visitors.

TITLE: There's no rulebook for deep sea mining. Companies want to push forward anyway
SUMMARY: Countries have debated for decades whether to allow mining on the ocean floor, a potential trove of critical minerals. Now, companies are telling regulators they plan to move ahead, whether or not rules are in place.

TITLE: The Trump administration restructures federal health agencies, cuts 20,000 jobs
SUMMARY: The reduction in force comes along with a reorganization of the Department of Health and Human Services, consolidating 28 divisions to 15.

TITLE: A lawyer who represented SpaceX looks to downsize federal contracting watchdog
SUMMARY: The appointment of Catherine Eschbach could raise conflict-of-interest concerns. She will also lead the downsizing of an agency that holds contractors accountable to federal civil rights laws.

TITLE: Photos: Peak bloom in D.C. draws cherry blossom fans from near and far
SUMMARY: Springtime means cherry blossoms in the nation's capital. On a recent breezy morning, with peak bloom still two days away, the Tidal Basin was packed with both blossoms and visitors.

TITLE: There's no rulebook for deep-sea mining. Companies want to push forward anyway
SUMMARY: Countries have debated for decades whether to allow mining on the ocean floor, a potential trove of critical minerals. Now, companies are telling regulators they plan to move ahead, whether or not rules are in place.

TITLE: Sen. Mark Kelly calls for Pete Hegseth to resign after Signal leak
SUMMARY: NPR's Michel Martin speaks with Senator Mark Kelly (D-Ariz.) about the revelation that top intelligence officials discussed military plans on the publicly available messaging app Signal.

TITLE: Syria's transitional leader is a former jihadist. Can he help stabilize the region?
SUMMARY: Ahmed al-Sharaa founded the Syrian branch of Al-Qaeda, but is now advocating unity. The Atlantic's Robert Worth discusses al-Sharaa's leadership and the Trump administration's group chat on Signal.

TITLE: Food is running out in Gaza nearly a month into Israeli blockade
SUMMARY: The World Food Programme says it has just five days left of flour and two weeks left of other food supplies in Gaza.

TITLE: Trump pulls Stefanik nomination for U.N. ambassador because of thin GOP House majority
SUMMARY: The Republican congresswoman's nomination had been expected to easily clear the Senate — but Republicans are concerned about holding on to their thin majority in the House of Representatives.

TITLE: Trump team revokes $11 billion in funding for addiction, mental health care
SUMMARY: The Trump administration says it hopes to save $11.4 billion by freezing and revoking COVID-era grants.  Addiction experts say clawing back the federal funding is risky and could put patients at risk.

TITLE: GOP leaders accused of making threats to block bill to let new moms vote remotely
SUMMARY: Lawmakers from both parties teamed up to force a House vote on a measure allowing new parents to vote by proxy for 12 weeks, but House Speaker Mike Johnson opposes it on Constitutional grounds.

TITLE: China Tries to Reboot Its Economy as Competitors Circle
SUMMARY: China has long been the world's factory, but it's economy is starting to face serious headwinds. Demand for Chinese goods has slumped, China is saddled with too much industrial capacity and heavy debt. And now a tariff war with the United States further darkens China's economic outlook. We have two reports on reactions to China's economic state. We hear how the Chinese government is encouraging business investment, but it's a hard pitch to sell in a communist state that hasn't always been kind to entrepreneurs. And how Vietnam, another communist country, seeks to capitalize on China's uncertain future and is experiencing a manufacturing boom.

TITLE: Judge accuses Trump administration of trying to undermine judiciary
SUMMARY: The Justice Department accused Howell of repeatedly demonstrating "animus" toward President Trump, after she paused enforcement of an executive order.

TITLE: The woman who killed Tejano music icon Selena in 1995 has been denied parole
SUMMARY: Yolanda Saldívar, the woman convicted of killing Selena Quintanilla-Perez, has been denied parole after spending decades behind bars for fatally shooting the young singer at a Texas motel in 1995.

TITLE: Trump's new tariffs on imported cars could have a clear winner: Tesla
SUMMARY: President Trump's newly announced 25% import tariffs on foreign cars will increase vehicle prices by thousands of dollars, experts say, but Tesla is likely to fare better than other carmakers.

TITLE: Trump executive order seeks to 'restore' American history through Smithsonian overhaul
SUMMARY: The "Restoring Truth and Sanity to American History" order removes "divisive, race-centered ideology" from Smithsonian museums, educational and research centers, and the National Zoo.

TITLE: Judge orders government to preserve Signal messages about Houthi military strike
SUMMARY: A federal judge barred administration officials from destroying messages sent over the encrypted messaging app about the sensitive details of plans for a U.S. military strike against Yemen's Houthis.

TITLE: Earthquake rocks Thailand and Myanmar, triggering the collapse of a Bangkok high-rise
SUMMARY: The U.S. Geological Survey said the earthquake was a shallow 10 kilometers (6.2 miles), with an epicenter in Myanmar, according to preliminary reports.

TITLE: As protections expire, Ukrainians who escaped war face an uncertain future
SUMMARY: A U.S. immigration program allowed hundreds of thousands of Ukrainians to escape war. As Trump decides whether or not to renew it, recipients fear being deported.

TITLE: Trump administration advances immigration crackdown on foreign student protesters
SUMMARY: Secretary of State Marco Rubio said that his department has revoked the student visas of hundreds of students so far, with plans to cancel more.

TITLE: Signal chat fallout, tariff tension — and 3 more takeaways from Trump's week
SUMMARY: Here, five takeaways from a week when the Trump administration has had to deal with the Signal chat leak, announced new tariffs and made more deportations.

TITLE: 10 road safety do's and don'ts that might just save your life
SUMMARY: Motor vehicle crashes are a leading cause of death in the U.S. A highway patrol officer explains how drivers should handle emergency scenarios, from extreme weather to aggressive tailgaters.

TITLE: U.S. sees large rise in border seizures of eggs, while fentanyl rate falls
SUMMARY: President Trump cites risks from fentanyl to justify tariffs on Canada and Mexico. U.S. Customs and Border Protection says interceptions of eggs are way up, compared to 63 fentanyl cases last month.

TITLE: Cooper Flagg sends Duke into Elite Eight while Texas Tech wins an overtime thriller
SUMMARY: The Sweet 16 weekend began Thursday night with dramatic late-night games as both men and women roll into action on Friday.

TITLE: NPR speaks to a former Education Secretary about dismantling the department, arrests
SUMMARY: NPR's Emily Kwong speaks with former Education Secretary John B. King Jr. about the dismantling of the education department and recent arrests of international scholars.

TITLE: How a Black kid made his dream of becoming a firefighter come true
SUMMARY: As a kid, Robert Logan lived right down the street from a fire station. He would watch the fire engine pass by his house, and dream of riding that truck one day. Now, he is a decorated firefighter and he talks with a friend and colleague about what it took to make his childhood dream come true, as a Black firefighter.

TITLE: Why Washington has turned its back on the World Trade Organization
SUMMARY: The World Trade Organization has long served as the referee for global trade disputes. But recently, it has been sidelined by the U.S. and others, which means there's no referee to mediate the trade wars.

TITLE: U.S. revokes hundreds of visas to repress student activism. And, HHS cuts jobs
SUMMARY: Secretary of State Marco Rubio says hundreds of visas have been revoked in an effort to repress student activism. And, the Trump administration plans to cut 20,000 jobs from health agencies.

TITLE: Israel says it struck a Beirut suburb to hit a Hezbollah drone depot
SUMMARY: The attack came as cross-border fire has escalated between Israel and militants in Lebanon, raising doubts about the state of a shaky ceasefire.

TITLE: The week's quiz has group chat drama. And don't worry, the answers aren't classified
SUMMARY: This week's news coverage featured more Greenland drama than usual. And if you've been paying attention to it all, you'll get at least one question right.

TITLE: Trump signs order ending union bargaining rights for wide swaths of federal employees
SUMMARY: President Trump's new executive order ends collective bargaining for wide swaths of federal employees, as part of his broader campaign to reshape the government's workforce. Unions are vowing to sue.

TITLE: Karen Read is on trial for murder a 2nd time. Here's what to know about her case
SUMMARY: Read is accused of killing her boyfriend, a Boston cop, in 2022. She maintains she was framed by police. Here's a refresher on the case — and a look at what's happened since last year's mistrial.

TITLE: Israel strikes a Beirut suburb, saying it was targeting a Hezbollah drone depot
SUMMARY: The attack came as cross-border fire has escalated between Israel and militants in Lebanon, raising doubts about the state of a shaky ceasefire.

TITLE: Long wait for a rushed doctor's visit? Maybe you'll get more with a 'membership' fee
SUMMARY: The growing number of concierge medical practices limit the number of patients and charge them membership fees. Will this worsen the ongoing shortage of primary care doctors for everyone else?

TITLE: Two major law firms sue Trump administration over executive orders targeting them
SUMMARY: Jenner and Block and WilmerHale are suing President Trump over executive orders targeting the firms for their clients and work, saying they undermine the overall legal system.

TITLE: Israel will 'strike anywhere in Lebanon against any threat,' Netanyahu warns
SUMMARY: The attack came as cross-border fire has escalated between Israel and militants in Lebanon, raising doubts about the state of a shaky ceasefire.

TITLE: A major earthquake kills at least 144 people in Myanmar. Here's what we know
SUMMARY: A powerful 7.7-magnitude earthquake killed at least 144 people near the epicenter in Myanmar and injured hundreds more. In neighboring Thailand, several were killed when a high-rise tower collapsed.

TITLE: Vance tours U.S. base in Greenland as Trump talks up a takeover of the territory
SUMMARY: Vice President JD Vance landed at a U.S. military base in Greenland on Friday, amid concerns that the U.S. is seeking to seize control of the Danish island territory.

TITLE: Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, has its billion dollar grant cut by Trump administration
SUMMARY: Gavi, which helps countries purchase and distribute vaccines, is among thousands of programs determined to be "inconsistent with the national interest or Agency policy priorities."

TITLE: Trump asks Supreme Court to allow deportations under Alien Enemies Act
SUMMARY: The American Civil Liberties Union and Democracy Forward sued the Trump administration over its use of the wartime law to quickly deport people, which they say violates due process.

TITLE: A guide to the Karen Read case, as she returns to court for her second murder trial
SUMMARY: Read is accused of killing her boyfriend, a Boston cop, in 2022. She maintains she was framed by police. Here's a refresher on the case — and a look at what's happened since last year's mistrial.

TITLE: Authorities say a babysitter checked under the bed for monsters — and found someone
SUMMARY: Kansas authorities say a babysitter went to refute a kid's claims of a monster under their bed, but "came face-to-face with a male suspect who was hiding there." They later arrested a 27-year-old man.

TITLE: What Ramadan has been like this year in Gaza, from ceasefire to war
SUMMARY: For the first week of Ramadan, Palestinians in Gaza marked the holy month with a respite from war. Then Israel broke a ceasefire with Hamas. The fighting and blockade mean there's little to celebrate.

TITLE: How will Trump's executive order affect the Smithsonian?
SUMMARY: The Smithsonian Institution, a vast complex of research centers, museums and galleries, is the latest culture target of President Trump's executive orders.

TITLE: The Sounds of Ramadan in Gaza
SUMMARY: The Muslim holy month of Ramadan is coming to an end. It is a holiday marked with fasting during the day and feasts with family in the evening. In Gaza, the month began with the hope of a continued peace but when the ceasefire with Israel collapsed, things changed. Our producer in Gaza brings us the sounds of this year's Ramadan in Gaza.

TITLE: USAID terminates nearly all its remaining employees
SUMMARY: The remaining USAID employees were given an end-of-employment date in an email sent out today.

TITLE: Vance tells Greenlanders they'd be better off being part of the United States
SUMMARY: Vice President Vance toured a U.S. military base in Greenland on Friday and blasted Denmark for not investing enough in the territory.

TITLE: Federal judge prevents Trump administration from dismantling CFPB
SUMMARY: The temporary injunction issued by Judge Berman Jackson seeks to preserve the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau as a lawsuit filed by the agency's union proceeds.

TITLE: Appeals court rules Trump can fire board members of independent agencies
SUMMARY: The D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled 2-1 that Trump can fire Democratic members of the National Labor Relations Board and the Merit Systems Protection Board after a lower court had them reinstated.

TITLE: Trump wants to restore statues and monuments. Will that happen?
SUMMARY: The President's executive order on "restoring truth and sanity to American history" calls on the Department of the Interior to ensure that any monuments, statues or memorials under its jurisdiction "do not contain descriptions, depictions, or other content that inappropriately disparage Americans past or living (including persons living in colonial times)."

TITLE: Masked officers in Tufts student arrest raise fears among immigrants and bystanders
SUMMARY: Federal agents have been filmed wearing masks while making arrests in public. When is it legal for police and the public to conceal their faces in an age of digital facial recognition and doxxing?

TITLE: Top FDA vaccine advisor forced out, cites RFK Jr.'s "misinformation and lies."
SUMMARY: A top vaccine advisor at the FDA was forced to resign on Friday.  In his resignation letter, Dr. Peter Marks, wrote "truth and transparency are not desired," by HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.

TITLE: Hundreds of anti-Musk protests are planned at Tesla locations worldwide this weekend
SUMMARY: The protests are scheduled to take place at Tesla facilities across the U.S. and in Europe on Saturday, as part of a grassroots campaign against Tesla CEO Elon Musk's work in the Trump administration.

TITLE: Top FDA vaccine official forced out, cites RFK Jr.'s "misinformation and lies."
SUMMARY: A top vaccine advisor at the FDA was forced to resign on Friday.  In his resignation letter, Dr. Peter Marks, wrote "truth and transparency are not desired," by HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.

TITLE: Judicial rulings block Kari Lake's drive to shutter Voice of America
SUMMARY: Trump senior adviser Kari Lake is regrouping after U.S. judges blocked her from taking further actions against the Voice of America and Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty.

TITLE: Myanmar's earthquake death toll jumps to more than 1,000 as more bodies are recovered
SUMMARY: The death toll from a powerful 7.7 magnitude earthquake in Myanmar jumped to more than 1,000 on Saturday as more bodies were pulled from the rubble of the scores of buildings that collapsed.

TITLE: What green card and visa holders should know before traveling abroad
SUMMARY: Recently, green card and visa holders have been facing tougher scrutiny at airports. Immigration attorneys give tips on how reduce the chances of running into problems while traveling.

TITLE: Countries boost recruitment of American scientists amid cuts to scientific funding
SUMMARY: American scientists have long worked abroad, but recruitment efforts are increasing due to cuts by the Trump administration.

TITLE: Through the 4-day Sunrise Dance, Apache girls transition into womanhood
SUMMARY: The Sunrise Dance is a four-day coming-of-age ceremony — a significant and highly spiritual event for the young lady and the Apache community.

TITLE: Jersey Shore Wave to kick off season as one of the newest teams in women's football
SUMMARY: The Women's National Football Conference kicks off its sixth season this weekend. The Jersey Shore Wave is one of the new teams joining the league this year.

TITLE: Can't-miss interviews: The Atlantic's Jeffrey Goldberg, John Green, Amanda Knox
SUMMARY: We spoke to Jeffrey Goldberg about the Signal group chat, author John Green played a game of Wild Card and a columnist explains why critics were so angry about Meghan Markle's new show.

TITLE: Opinion: A Toast to Sarah Lucy Oliver
SUMMARY: NPR's Scott Simon celebrates Weekend Edition's Executive Producer, Sarah Lucy Oliver, who is retiring.

TITLE: The top FDA vaccine official is forced out, cites RFK Jr.'s 'misinformation and lies'
SUMMARY: A top vaccine advisor at the FDA was forced to resign on Friday.  In his resignation letter, Dr. Peter Marks wrote "truth and transparency are not desired," by HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.

TITLE: Alysa Liu ends long U.S. drought at women's figure skating world championships
SUMMARY: "I don't know how to process this," the 19-year-old from Clovis, Calif., said after becoming the first American women's figure skating world champion in nearly two decades.

TITLE: Startup founder convicted of defrauding JPMorgan Chase of $175M by faking firm's success
SUMMARY: Charlie Javice, whose startup claimed to be revolutionizing the way college students apply for financial aid, was convicted of defrauding the banking giant by exaggerating her customer base tenfold.

TITLE: March Madness is a season for betting, but help for problem gambling is hard to find
SUMMARY: For people with gambling disorder, the proliferation of gambling opportunities makes it difficult to fight their addiction. Investment in treatment lags behind other addiction disorders.

TITLE: What green-card and visa holders should know before traveling abroad
SUMMARY: Recently, green-card and visa holders have been facing tougher scrutiny at airports. Immigration attorneys give tips on how reduce the chances of running into problems while traveling.

TITLE: 'Am I going to survive?': Myanmar's quake death toll jumps to more than 1,600
SUMMARY: The death toll from a powerful 7.7 magnitude earthquake in Myanmar jumped to more than 1,600 on Saturday as more bodies were pulled from the rubble of the scores of buildings that collapsed.

TITLE: Delta plane and Air Force jet ordered to maneuver to avoid collision near DCA airport
SUMMARY: A Delta passenger plane and an Air Force jet flew narrowly close to one another outside Washington, D.C., on Friday, prompting a collision warning and "corrective instructions" from air traffic controllers.

TITLE: Photos: See the aftermath of the earthquake in Myanmar and Thailand
SUMMARY: The magnitude 7.7 earthquake struck at midday with the epicenter not far from the city of Mandalay.

TITLE: FCC chair opens investigation into Disney and ABC over DEI practices
SUMMARY: FCC chair Brendan Carr said he wants a review all of Disney's DEI practices — both past and present — to determine whether the company has ever violated any FCC regulations.

TITLE: White House Correspondents' dinner cancels comedian Amber Ruffin's appearance
SUMMARY: Amber Ruffin had been scheduled to perform at the prestigious gathering of political journalists on April 26 in Washington, D.C.

TITLE: Academy apologizes for not adequately supporting Oscar-winning Palestinian director
SUMMARY: The apology appeared after a wave of online protest against the Academy — first for not responding to Ballal's attack, and then for not naming him and his film directly in its initial statement.

TITLE: Rosie the Riveters honored for service in WWII
SUMMARY: The National World War Two Museum and the Gary Sinise Foundation celebrate the trailblazing women who worked in the American defense industry in the 1940s, and preserve their stories for future generations.

TITLE: Police say ICE tactics are eroding public trust in local law enforcement
SUMMARY: Local police leaders have feared the erosion of public trust as a result of the Trump administration's immigration enforcement efforts. Many officials say they're seeing signs that's happening.

TITLE: Medical supplies in great need as aid flows into Myanmar after earthquake
SUMMARY: Emergency aid has streamed into Southeast Asia in the two days since a massive earthquake struck Myanmar and Thailand.

TITLE: As measles cases rise, some parents become vaccine enthusiasts
SUMMARY: Vaccine hesitancy has been growing in the U.S. in recent years. But as Texas measles cases rise and other states report outbreaks too, some parents want their kids to get their shots early.

TITLE: Trump won't rule out military force to take Greenland
SUMMARY: In an interview with NBC News, Trump refused to rule out military force to acquire Greenland. His remarks come a day after Vice President JD Vance's scaled back visit to the island.

TITLE: This may be the most lead polluted place on Earth. Is there any hope?
SUMMARY: The U.N. has identified Kabwe, a city of almost 300,000 people in Zambia, as one of the most polluted places on the planet. Who is to blame? And can justice be done?

TITLE: Iran has rejected direct negotiations with the US in response to Trump's letter
SUMMARY: Iran's president said the Islamic Republic rejected direct negotiations with the United States over its rapidly advancing nuclear program, Tehran's first response to a letter sent by President Trump.

TITLE: Richard Chamberlain, TV actor who starred in 'Dr. Kildare,' dies at 90
SUMMARY: Richard Chamberlain, the handsome hero of the 1960s television series "Dr. Kildare" who found a second career as an award-winning "king of the miniseries," has died. He was 90.

TITLE: Nine home runs for the Yankees lead to questions about their new bats
SUMMARY: Some Yankees players used a new bat during the second game in the Major League Baseball season against the Milwaukee Brewers.

TITLE: U.S. Institute of Peace staff is laid off, escalating legal battle with Trump administration
SUMMARY: The think tank is laying off nearly all of its staff, as its former board sues to stop what it calls a "takeover" by the Trump administration.

TITLE: Trump is 'not joking' about third term, though Constitution says he can't serve
SUMMARY: In remarks to NBC News, Trump also said "there are methods which you could do it." Trump would need either a two-thirds vote in Congress or a constitutional convention to serve a third term.

TITLE: Police say ICE tactics are eroding public trust in local law enforcement
SUMMARY: Local police leaders have feared the erosion of public trust as a result of the Trump administration's immigration enforcement efforts. Many officials say they're seeing signs that's happening.

TITLE: Some progress made in recovering U.S. Army soldiers submerged in Lithuanian swamp
SUMMARY: U.S. Navy divers managed to successfully attach a line to a hoist point on the submerged vehicle. The goal is to hook up more hoists in order to pull the vehicle carrying the soldiers out of the mud.

TITLE: Asian shares are sharply lower as Tokyo tumbles 4% after Wall Street retreat
SUMMARY: Asian shares were sharply lower on Monday as worries are building over a potentially toxic mix of worsening inflation and a U.S. economy slowing because households are cautious to spend.

TITLE: Asian shares are sharply lower over concerns about U.S. economy
SUMMARY: Asian shares were sharply lower on Monday as worries are building over a potentially toxic mix of worsening inflation and a U.S. economy slowing because households are cautious to spend.

TITLE: Asian shares are sharply lower over concerns about the U.S. economy
SUMMARY: Asian shares were sharply lower on Monday as worries are building over a potentially toxic mix of worsening inflation and a U.S. economy slowing because households are cautious to spend.

TITLE: How Much Will That Surgery Cost? Hospital Price Lists Remain Largely Unhelpful
SUMMARY: Health care price transparency is one of the few bipartisan issues in Washington, D.C. But much of the information is not helpful to patients, and there's no evidence  that it's lowering costs.

TITLE: French court finds far-right leader Marine Le Pen guilty in embezzlement case
SUMMARY: A French court found Marine Le Pen guilty on Monday in an embezzlement case but didn't immediately say what her sentence might be and how it might impact the far-right leader's political future.

TITLE: Cesar Chavez Day celebrates a lifetime fight for justice for farmworkers
SUMMARY: Cesar Chavez Day celebrates the life and legacy of the labor rights icon.

TITLE: Hyundai's plans for its new Georgia plant reveal an industry hedging its bets on EVs
SUMMARY: Hyundai just opened a high-tech auto plant in Georgia. Originally meant to just build EVs, it's expanding towards plug-in hybrids — a sign of bigger shifts in the auto industry.

TITLE: 6 things borrowers should know about federal student loans right now
SUMMARY: NPR has spent the past few weeks catching up with student loan experts and asking the Trump administration for clarity on some of borrowers' biggest questions.

TITLE: The Wisconsin Supreme Court vote is getting national attention and millions from Musk
SUMMARY: The court could face cases on abortion, congressional maps and labor unions. With Tesla suing the state, Elon Musk is backing the conservative candidate who's received President Trump's endorsement.

TITLE: Catholic Charities tests Wisconsin's unemployment payment system at Supreme Court
SUMMARY: A chapter of Catholic Charities in Wisconsin contends it should be exempted from the state's unemployment compensation system because it's a charitable organization with a religious mission.

TITLE: Beloved historic landmarks navigate an uncertain future after the LA fires
SUMMARY: In Pasadena, The Gamble House was in a fire evacuation zone and its custodians are trying to safeguard its future. In Altadena, only concrete walls are left from the former home of novelist Zane Grey.

TITLE: What happened when Syria's conservative new leaders tried to shut 60 Damascus bars
SUMMARY: When Syria's new leaders shut 60 Damascus bars, drinkers protested, and the government reversed itself. It's an example of the tussle between secular and Islamist values in the new Syria.

TITLE: Expert says Tesla's best way to rebuild its brand is to ditch Musk
SUMMARY: The Tesla brand is in trouble, according to branding consultant Allen Adamson, who says the car company is facing headwinds due to a lack of innovation and the political activity of CEO Elon Musk.

TITLE: Trump doesn't rule out seeking 3rd term. And, a revamp of the Smithsonian Institution
SUMMARY: President Trump says he isn't ruling out the possibility of seeking a 3rd term in office. And, an executive order targets the Smithsonian Institution to restore "sanity to American history."

TITLE: How much will that surgery cost? Hospital price lists remain largely unhelpful
SUMMARY: Health care price transparency is one of the few bipartisan issues in Washington, D.C. But much of the information is not helpful to patients, and there's no evidence  that it's lowering costs.

TITLE: Catholic Charities tests Wisconsin's unemployment payment system at Supreme Court
SUMMARY: A chapter of Catholic Charities in Wisconsin contends it should be exempted from the state's unemployment compensation system because it's a charitable organization with a religious mission.

TITLE: Charity-seekers from all over Pakistan flock to Karachi at Ramadan to collect alms
SUMMARY: The annual influx of charity-seekers to Pakistan's biggest city has gained increased government attention this year as Pakistan steps up efforts to curb begging.

TITLE: The head of Africa CDC thought news of a U.S. aid freeze must be 'a joke.' Now what?
SUMMARY: Dr. Jean Kaseya is now figuring out how to cope with the new foreign aid landscape.

TITLE: French court bars far-right leader Marine Le Pen from public office for embezzlement
SUMMARY: A French court found Marine Le Pen guilty on Monday in an embezzlement case and barred her from seeking public office for five years, with immediate effect. Le Pen's lawyer said she would appeal.

TITLE: The Wisconsin Supreme Court vote is getting national attention and millions from Musk
SUMMARY: The court could face cases on abortion, congressional maps and labor unions. With Tesla suing the state, Elon Musk is backing the conservative candidate who's received President Trump's endorsement.

TITLE: DOGE staffer who shared Treasury data now has more access to government systems
SUMMARY: New court filings give more details about a small number of DOGE staffers granted sweeping access to sensitive government data systems.

TITLE: 4 astronauts to be the first to orbit the poles on a privately funded SpaceX mission
SUMMARY: SpaceX is planning a launch as early as Monday evening. If successful, it will mark the first crewed mission to polar orbit and the first mission to cultivate mushrooms as a crop

TITLE: White House says it's 'case closed' on the Signal group chat review
SUMMARY: Last week, the White House said the National Security Council, the White House counsel office and President Trump adviser Elon Musk were all looking into the mishap. But now, that probe has wrapped

TITLE: Presidents can be elected twice. Trump could try end runs around that, experts say
SUMMARY: The 22nd Amendment bans a person from being elected U.S. president more than twice. But some legal experts point to plausible strategies that President Trump could try to serve a third term.

TITLE: The woman who ran for president 50 years before she could vote
SUMMARY: NPR animator and illustrator Jackie Lay tells the story of Victoria Woodhull, who wrote a letter to the <em>New York Herald

TITLE: Trump Policies Lead to a Wave of Reverse Migration
SUMMARY: During his campaign, President Trump promised to stem migration to the United States. And since taking office his administration has deported plane loads of people, some of whom were in the U.S. legally. Hundreds of deportees have been sent to prison in El Salvador. And President Trump has essentially closed the door to immigrants seeking to enter the country through the border with Mexico. These policies have provoked so-called reverse migration, where people go back to the places they once fled. And that has knock-on effects for other countries. We go to a tiny island in Panama to see the effects of U.S. immigration policy.

TITLE: Supreme Court seems ready to let religious groups opt out of unemployment compensation laws
SUMMARY: The case was <a href="https://www.npr.org/2025/03/31/nx-s1-5332378/catholic-charities-supreme-court-wisconsin" target="_blank">brought by a chapter of Catholic Charities in Wisconsin

TITLE: Entire staff at federal agency that funds libraries and museums put on leave
SUMMARY: The staff of the Institute of Museum and Library Services was placed on administrative leave this morning, following a meeting between IMLS leadership and DOGE staff.

TITLE: Advocates say flawed 'checklist' targets Venezuelans for deportation under archaic wartime act
SUMMARY: Flawed deportation 'checklist' targets Venezuelans using tattoos as one gang identifier. But experts say Tren de Aragua doesn't use tattoos for member identification.

TITLE: A midwife says of the aid cuts in Afghanistan: 'No one prioritizes women's lives.'
SUMMARY: With the abrupt shutdown of USAID funding, many clinics, including those serving women in remote areas, have shuttered. Midwives are reporting that mothers and babies are dying as a result.

TITLE: Judge pauses Trump administration plans to end deportation protection for Venezuelans
SUMMARY: A federal judge on Monday paused plans by the Trump administration to end temporary legal protections for hundreds of thousands of Venezuelans, a week before they were scheduled to expire.

TITLE: SpaceX launches historic privately funded mission around Earth's poles
SUMMARY: SpaceX launched four people into space Monday evening on a first-ever human mission to orbit Earth's polar regions. If successful, the mission also will be the first to cultivate mushrooms as a crop.

TITLE: China practices attacks and blockades in fresh military exercises around Taiwan
SUMMARY: China launched major military drills around Taiwan on Tuesday, simulating attacks and maritime blockades, in what Beijing called a warning after Taiwan's president labeled China a hostile foreign force.

TITLE: Green card holders, travelers caught in Trump's immigration crackdown
SUMMARY: A lawful permanent resident who has lived in the U.S. for 50 years was detained because of a decades-old conviction amid tougher immigration enforcement at airports and border crossings.

TITLE: 6 tales of mystery and mishap — all hitting book stores on April Fools' Day
SUMMARY: New on the shelves this week: An obit writer writes — and drunkenly publishes — his own obituary. A Hungarian teen stumbles into adulthood. And geriatric sleuth Vera Wong returns.

TITLE: What U.S. tariffs look like from a Chinese trade city
SUMMARY: NPR's Steve Inskeep visited the source of your stuff. And heard how China's manufacturers are handling U.S. tariffs.

TITLE: Do you know the red flags for problem gambling?
SUMMARY: Preoccupation with betting or casino games may be an early sign of  developing an addiction to gambling.

TITLE: Palestinian soap gets UNESCO recognition as Israel's military operation closes in
SUMMARY: An age-old Palestinian tradition of making soap in the Israeli-occupied West Bank was recognized by UNESCO. A visit to one factory tells you why.

TITLE: Caregiving can test you, body and soul. It can also unlock a new sense of self
SUMMARY: Helping a sick family member over months or years can be an enormous strain. It can also disrupt your identity. Psychologists say embracing this change can open up new ways for caregivers to cope.

TITLE: Crumbling trust in American institutions: A MAHA activist takes on Girl Scout cookies
SUMMARY: A controversial study raised the specter that Girl Scout cookies are unsafe. Authorities say they are safe, but the whole saga highlights a breakdown of trust in American institutions.

TITLE: Local elections to watch today. And, concerns over Trump's 'Liberation Day' tariffs
SUMMARY: Florida Democrats believe they have a chance to pick up one of two congressional seats in the special election races. And, Trump is expected to announce new tariffs tomorrow, worrying investors.

TITLE: Thyme for some healing soup recipes from around the world
SUMMARY: Every culture has its own special soup. The belief is that a bowl will make you feel better if you're feeling under the weather, hung over or just in need of a pick-me-up.

TITLE: Cory Booker's anti-Trump speech on the Senate floor has lasted 13 hours and counting
SUMMARY: The New Jersey Democrat has been criticizing the Trump administration's policies on immigration, education, the economy and more since 7 p.m. Monday. Here's what to know about his marathon speech.

TITLE: What kind of support is the U.S. offering in the wake of the Myanmar quake?
SUMMARY: The White House and former USAID staff have differing views on the nature of the U.S. response to the earthquake that struck Myanmar and neighboring countries.

TITLE: Cory Booker's anti-Trump speech on the Senate floor has lasted 14 hours and counting
SUMMARY: The New Jersey Democrat has been criticizing the Trump administration's policies on immigration, education, the economy and more since 7 p.m. Monday. Here's what to know about his marathon speech.

TITLE: Cory Booker's anti-Trump speech on the Senate floor has lasted 15 hours and counting
SUMMARY: The New Jersey Democrat has been criticizing the Trump administration's policies on immigration, education, the economy and more since 7 p.m. Monday. Here's what to know about his marathon speech.

TITLE: Cory Booker's anti-Trump speech on the Senate floor has lasted 17 hours and counting
SUMMARY: The New Jersey Democrat has been criticizing the Trump administration's policies on immigration, education, the economy and more since 7 p.m. Monday. Here's what to know about his marathon speech.

TITLE: More billionaires than ever ranked in Forbes' annual list. Here are the top 10
SUMMARY: There are now more than 3,000 billionaires in the world, according to <em>Forbes

TITLE: Widespread firings start at federal health agencies including many in leadership
SUMMARY: Staffers began receiving termination notices this morning as part of a major restructuring at HHS. Some senior leadership are on their way out too.

TITLE: Cory Booker's anti-Trump speech on the Senate floor has lasted 18 hours and counting
SUMMARY: The New Jersey Democrat has been criticizing the Trump administration's policies on immigration, education, the economy and more since 7 p.m. Monday. Here's what to know about his marathon speech.

TITLE: Trump administration admits Maryland man sent to El Salvador prison by mistake
SUMMARY: This latest case, in which lawyers argue their client had no proven links to MS-13, adds to the growing judicial and public scrutiny about the deportations to El Salvador's notorious mega-prison.

TITLE: Cory Booker's anti-Trump speech on the Senate floor has lasted 19 hours and counting
SUMMARY: The New Jersey Democrat has been criticizing the Trump administration's policies on immigration, education, the economy and more since 7 p.m. Monday. Here's what to know about his marathon speech.

TITLE: 2 mothers bring the House to a halt over push to allow proxy voting for new parents
SUMMARY: GOP leaders tried to block a bipartisan measure to allow proxy voting, but nine Republicans joined with Democrats to overcome it.

TITLE: Top scientists warn that Trump policies are causing a 'climate of fear' in research
SUMMARY: Some 2,000 scientists, including dozens of Nobel Prize winners, have signed an open letter warning that the U.S. lead in science is being "decimated" by the Trump administration's cuts to research.

TITLE: Why gold prices are surging to record highs
SUMMARY: Tariffs are roiling stock markets — but making gold hotter than ever.

TITLE: Say goodbye to chain crews: The NFL will use camera technology to measure 1st downs
SUMMARY: Starting next season, a system of cameras will determine whether to award a first down rather than trot out a 10-yard chain. But humans will still decide where to spot the ball to begin with.

TITLE: China's Global Electric Vehicle Boom
SUMMARY: Sales of electric vehicles worldwide have been growing and the largest manufacturer of EVs is China's BYD. Their global revenue was over $100 billion in 2024, beating Tesla. To keep up that growth and to try to stave off the pain of U.S. tariffs, BYD is expanding in emerging markets. One of the markets where their cars are selling big is Brazil, where BYD is investing nearly a billion dollars in a factory. But as our Brazil correspondent tells us there have been some difficulties along the way.

TITLE: Cory Booker's anti-Trump speech on the Senate floor nears record 24-hour mark
SUMMARY: The New Jersey Democrat has been criticizing the Trump administration's policies on immigration, education, the economy and more since 7 p.m. ET Monday. Here's what to know about his marathon speech.

TITLE: HHS layoffs hit Meals on Wheels and other services for seniors and disabled
SUMMARY: Staff that administer programs to help the elderly, disabled people and poor families with basic needs lost their jobs amid the Trump administration's layoffs.

TITLE: Trump and Musk's backing wasn't enough to flip Wisconsin Supreme Court
SUMMARY: National Democrats sent in millions for the liberal's campaign while Trump endorsed — and Musk financed — the conservative's. Abortion, redistricting and Tesla could come before the court.

TITLE: GOP retains two House seats in Florida, as Democrats claim 'historic' improvement
SUMMARY: Republicans won special elections in two Florida Congressional districts. The margins of victory in the heavily-Republican districts were significantly narrower than in November.

TITLE: Paraguay recalls ambassador to Brazil over espionage revelations
SUMMARY: Brazil's foreign ministry revealed that the administration of Jair Bolsonaro, the right-wing predecessor of current President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, had conducted espionage against Paraguay.

TITLE: Danish prime minister heads to Greenland as Trump seeks control of the territory
SUMMARY: Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen announced plans for her visit after U.S. Vice President JD Vance visited a U.S. air base in Greenland last week and accused Denmark of underinvesting in the territory.

TITLE: Judge orders White House to restore legal aid to unaccompanied migrant children
SUMMARY: A federal judge in California has ordered the Trump administration to temporarily restore legal aid to tens of thousands of migrant children who are in the United States without a parent or guardian.

TITLE: Val Kilmer, 'Top Gun' star with an intense approach, dies at 65
SUMMARY: Val Kilmer died from pneumonia. He had recovered after a 2014 throat cancer diagnosis that required two tracheotomies.

TITLE: Latest Alzheimer's lab tests focus on memory loss, not brain plaques
SUMMARY: New tests of blood and spinal fluid can identify people experiencing memory loss from Alzheimer's disease.

TITLE: Today is Trump's 'Liberation Day.' What does that mean for tariffs?
SUMMARY: President Trump has been promising new "reciprocal tariffs" to punish other countries for their tariffs and trade barriers. Markets are nervous that a trade war could hike prices and hurt the economy.

TITLE: It's been a wild rollout of Trump's tariffs. Here's how we got here
SUMMARY: President Trump's tariff talk has been big — and also unpredictable. He's frequently made threats only to back off or shift deadlines. Here, a look at how the tariff agenda has rolled out.

TITLE: The U.S. already has tariffs on a few sectors. It hasn't gone that great
SUMMARY: The U.S. has generally kept tariffs low, but a few domestic industries have long been protected by import taxes and other trade barriers. They offer clues about how Trump's new tariffs might work out.

TITLE: Here's what to do if you're caught driving in high winds, tornadoes or dust storms
SUMMARY: "Wind is unlike many other hazards because you really can't see it," says AAA's Bill Van Tassel.

TITLE: States say Trump's continued freeze on much-needed FEMA aid violates a judge's order
SUMMARY: Twenty-two states say the Trump administration is illegally freezing money from the Federal Emergency Management Agency. The administration says the funding is just being "reviewed" and isn't frozen.

TITLE: Supreme Court to decide if states can strip Planned Parenthood of Medicaid funds
SUMMARY: At issue is whether a state, in this case, South Carolina, can remove Planned Parenthood clinics from its state Medicaid program, even though Medicaid funds cannot generally be used to fund abortions.

TITLE: How reciprocal tariffs could affect you. And, Maryland man mistakenly deported
SUMMARY: Trump is expected to impose "reciprocal tariffs," which economists believe could be painful for U.S. consumers. And, the Trump administration says it mistakenly deported a man to El Salvador.

TITLE: How do 'torpedo bats' work? We asked baseball physicists to explain
SUMMARY: They look like baseball bats morphing into bowling pins, their ends flaring into an aggressive bulge that suddenly tapers. So how do they work?

TITLE: Federal judge drops corruption case against New York City Mayor Eric Adams
SUMMARY: Adams was scheduled to go on trial in April until new leadership at the Justice Department under the Trump administration ordered prosecutors in New York in February to drop the case, sparking a public outcry and resignations of prosecutors.

TITLE: Legal scholar sees immigrant arrests as a 'struggle for the soul of the country'
SUMMARY: As ICE agents arrest international students at campuses across the U.S., professor Daniel Kanstroom discusses the law — and the human cost. He says the round-ups are designed to "send a message."

TITLE: See the moment Sen. Cory Booker broke Strom Thurmond's record
SUMMARY: As he broke a record set when Thurmond stood against the Civil Rights Act, Booker said, "I'm not here, though, because of his speech. I'm here despite his speech. I'm here because, as powerful as he was, the people were more powerful."

TITLE: 5 takeaways from Tuesday's elections, including bad news for Elon Musk
SUMMARY: Democrats can take yesterday's elections as one of the first bits of good news they've had in months. But there are lots of issues that are still center-right, including immigration.

TITLE: 25 hours? Before Cory Booker, there was 'Mr. Smith'
SUMMARY: In 1939, the character of Mr. Smith — played by Jimmy Stewart — spent 25 hours on the Senate floor railing against corruption.

TITLE: This art exhibition is 'divisive' or 'eye-opening' — it depends who you ask
SUMMARY: A new White House executive order says the exhibition is an example of how the Smithsonian portrays "American and Western values as inherently harmful and oppressive."

TITLE: Tesla's quarterly sales fall 13%. Experts blame Musk
SUMMARY: The disappointing global deliveries of the company's electric car models come as CEO Elon Musk's role as President Trump's cost-cutting czar sparks a backlash among consumers.

TITLE: Syria Struggles to Find Unity
SUMMARY: The new government in Syria, formed after the fall of dictator Bashar al-Assad, is working to disband local militias to form one national army. But some groups are refusing to join. We meet one very well armed religious minority called the Druse. They say they're afraid of sectarian attacks from the new government and will not be giving up their weapons.

TITLE: Parents sue Bucknell alleging hazing led to freshman football player's death
SUMMARY: Freshman Calvin "CJ" Dickey Jr., died after his first practice at the university. His parents are suing the school, also alleging staff neglected to account for his sickle cell trait during training.

TITLE: Central U.S. braces for tornadoes and flash flooding as powerful storm approaches
SUMMARY: The National Weather Service says a "multi-day catastrophic and potentially historic" storm is expected to impact multiple states beginning on Wednesday.

TITLE: Sen. Cory Booker on his marathon, 25-hour speech on the Senate floor
SUMMARY: Sen. Cory Booker, a Democrat from New Jersey, told NPR's Juana Summers he stopped eating and drinking before his record-breaking speech.

TITLE: Senate Republicans move forward with their budget plan to promote Trump's agenda
SUMMARY: If passed, the package could become a hallmark of President Trump's second term. But a number of obstacles remain ahead.

TITLE: Who loses when Trump cuts funding to universities?
SUMMARY:
Eight-point-seven billion.

Four-hundred million.

One-hundred-seventy-five million.

These are just some examples of the money the federal government has withheld or is threatening to withhold from various colleges and universities, including the University of Pennsylvania, Columbia University and Harvard University.

That $8.7 billion figure was announced earlier this week by the Trump administration, which said that it's reviewing federal grants and contracts awarded to Harvard because Harvard has not done enough to curb antisemitism on campus.

Some educators say the administration's moves to cut funding at colleges and universities amounts to a war on higher education. But the loss of those funds will be felt far beyond the college campuses.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

TITLE: Senate rebukes Trump's tariffs on Canada
SUMMARY: A bipartisan group of Senators voted to remove the emergency declaration President Trump used to impose 25 percent tariffs on Canada. The vote was largely symbolic since the House isn't expected to act.

TITLE: White House reviewing TikTok proposal to lease algorithm from China
SUMMARY: President Trump and top officials are considering a deal that would create a new U.S. entity and lease TikTok's algorithm to get around China export regulations.

TITLE: Supreme Court hears case that could see more Planned Parenthood clinics closed
SUMMARY: The Supreme Court heard arguments on whether South Carolina can remove Planned Parenthood clinics from its state Medicaid program, even though those funds cannot generally be used to fund abortions.

TITLE: Grilled by Senate, Boeing CEO admits to "serious missteps" on safety
SUMMARY: Boeing's CEO admits the company "made serious missteps" that hurt the safety of its planes. But denies the company pressures workers to speed up airplane production.

TITLE: Myanmar's military declares a ceasefire as earthquake deaths pass 3,000
SUMMARY: The surprise announcement by the unelected government said the halt in fighting would run until April 22 to show compassion for people affected by last week's quake.

TITLE: Grilled by Senate, Boeing CEO admits to 'serious missteps' on safety
SUMMARY: Boeing's CEO admits the company "made serious missteps" that hurt the safety of its planes. But denies the company pressures workers to speed up airplane production.

TITLE: Violent storms, including tornadoes, strike across the Midwest and South
SUMMARY: The National Weather Service says a "multi-day catastrophic and potentially historic" storm is expected to impact multiple states as violent weather was reported across the South and Midwest Thursday.

TITLE: Misinformation about fentanyl exposure threatens to undermine overdose response
SUMMARY: Fentanyl overdoses occur from ingesting the synthetic opioid. But popular culture has misrepresented the risks to first responders.

TITLE: Markets in Asia and Europe fall following U.S. announcement of global tariffs
SUMMARY: Shares tumbled in Europe and Asia and U.S. futures tumbled Thursday following U.S. President Donald Trump 's announcement of big increases in tariffs on imports of goods from around the world.

TITLE: HHS guts the teams that fulfill public records requests for health agencies
SUMMARY: Despite promises for 'radical transparency,' HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy, Jr. laid off many staff on teams that fulfill public records requests at health agencies.

TITLE: Tariffs are another reason why Americans feel so lousy about the economy
SUMMARY: As President Trump opens a new front in his trade war, U.S. consumers are feeling shaky about the economy. And that's beginning to weigh on their spending, raising the threat of an economic slowdown.

TITLE: What does the shark say? Click, click, click
SUMMARY: Scientists in New Zealand believe they may have the first-ever recording of a shark making noise.

TITLE: How the Education Department helps students with disabilities get an education
SUMMARY: Special education laws and the U.S. Department of Education have evolved together over nearly five decades. Now, the Trump administration seems to want to separate the two.

TITLE: Tariffs threaten to upend markets American farmers depend on
SUMMARY: President Trump said that he is standing up for skilled workers and farmers by slapping tariffs on imports but farmers aren't happy.

TITLE: The key players to watch for in this weekend's Final Four games
SUMMARY: Cooper Flagg and Paige Bueckers, the presumptive top picks in this year's NBA and WNBA drafts, are on deck this weekend with hopes of a national title. But the star power doesn't stop with them.

TITLE: Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu details objectives of Gaza military campaign
SUMMARY: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has new details for Israel's expanded incursion in Gaza, saying Israeli troops are seizing more land there.

TITLE: RFK Jr. wants to stop people using SNAP benefits to buy soda. Will it help?
SUMMARY: Nutritionists agree reducing the amount of sugar people consume would be good for the Nation's health. But the plan to block people from using food assistance to buy soda is getting mixed reviews.

TITLE: World markets respond to Trump's new tariffs. And, TikTok nears its sell-by date
SUMMARY: Trump announced new tariffs on goods from all countries yesterday. Economists are worried about the domestic and worldwide impact this could cause. And, TikTok nears its sell-by date.

TITLE: More homes are finally hitting the spring market. Will buyers take the plunge?
SUMMARY: After a couple extremely slow years, more inventory is finally hitting the market this spring. But buyers might be put off by high prices and an unsteady economy.

TITLE: Dow drops over 1,200 points at open on trade war fears over new tariffs
SUMMARY: President Trump announced sweeping tariffs on imported goods, which were higher and broader than many expected. The new import taxes are expected to raise prices and slow growth in the U.S., while pushing many other countries into recession.

TITLE: We tried out the Nintendo Switch 2 — it's a solid console sequel
SUMMARY: We played hours of Nintendo Switch 2 games the same day President Trump announced new global tariffs. Despite the hefty price tag, it's a solid evolution of one of the world's most popular consoles.

TITLE: Hungary says it will quit the International Criminal Court as Netanyahu visits
SUMMARY: Hungary said it will start the process to withdraw from the International Criminal Court, just as Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who faces an ICC arrest warrant, arrived in Budapest.

TITLE: Dow drops 1,500 points on trade war fears over new tariffs
SUMMARY: President Trump announced sweeping tariffs on imported goods, which were higher and broader than many expected. The new import taxes are expected to raise prices and slow growth in the U.S., while pushing many other countries into recession.

TITLE: U.S. stocks post deep losses on trade war fears over new tariffs
SUMMARY: President Trump announced sweeping tariffs on imported goods, which were higher and broader than many expected. The new import taxes are expected to raise prices and slow growth in the U.S., while pushing many other countries into recession.

TITLE: Judge rules Alabama can't prosecute groups helping patients get abortions elsewhere
SUMMARY: Although most abortions remain illegal in Alabama, the decision allows doctors and advocacy groups to tell patients about abortion options in other states, and help with travel and other costs

TITLE: Trump's tariffs are so far-reaching they include several remote, uninhabited islands
SUMMARY: The global tariffs Trump announced this week include remote territories like Heard and McDonald Islands in the Indian Ocean that don't actually have human populations. Here's what to know about them.

TITLE: How much will tariffs raise prices? Trump's economists just revealed their answer
SUMMARY: The administration revealed how they calculated the tariffs. Buried in that math is a straightforward answer to a question Trump has long refused to answer: How much will his tariffs raise prices?

TITLE: Education Dept. warns schools: Eliminate DEI programs or lose funding
SUMMARY: The department sent a letter to state leaders threatening the loss of funds for K-12 schools that don't follow its interpretation of civil rights laws.

TITLE: Mineral-rich, war-torn DRC first stop for Trump's new Africa czar
SUMMARY: Massad Boulos, Trumps new Senior Advisor for Africa and father-in-law to daughter Tiffany Trump, kicks starts his first official trip on the continent, with a visit to the mineral rich and war wracked Democratic Republic of Congo.

TITLE: Cultural groups across U.S. told that federal humanities grants are terminated
SUMMARY: Among the thousands of groups affected by the sudden cessation of funds are state arts councils, museums, historic sites, archives, libraries, educators and media outlets in all 50 states.

TITLE: R.E.M.'s hometown of Athens, Ga., still welcomes fans 45 years after the band started there
SUMMARY: R.E.M. played its first concert there in 1980 and still draws fans to its hometown. A visit to Athens can be like a pilgrimage of the band's music.

TITLE: A Pentagon inspector general announces investigation into Hegseth's use of Signal
SUMMARY: The announcement comes after lawmakers voiced concern about whether top national security officials discussed classified information on Signal about a military strike against Houthi rebels in Yemen.

TITLE: Deadly spring storms continue to batter the South and Midwest
SUMMARY: Severe storms are predicted to impact large areas of the United States through the weekend.

TITLE: On top of layoffs, HHS ordered to cut 35% of spending on contracts
SUMMARY: Federal health agencies have to slash their spending by more than a third, on top of the 10,000-person staffing cuts.

TITLE: Global Reaction to the U.S. Tariff War
SUMMARY: The world is reacting to President Trump's announcement of new tariffs on nearly every country on the planet. The move is meant to re-shape the global trading order and some countries are being hit harder than others. NPR correspondents around the world are hearing anger, dismay, threats of retaliation and bewilderment.

TITLE: 18 states sue over Trump's voting executive order, arguing it's unconstitutional
SUMMARY: The lawsuit is the fourth legal challenge against Trump's executive order on voting. The attorneys general argue the order is "an unconstitutional attempt to seize control of elections."

TITLE: Trump takes aim at trade deficits. Are they actually bad?
SUMMARY:
Whatever you think of President Trump's tariffs, there's one point you have to concede: his interest in them is not a passing whim.

He noted that on Wednesday, in the Rose Garden, when he was announcing the latest, massive round of tariffs. "I've been talking about this for 40 years," he said.

The use of tariffs are a core belief for Donald Trump. Trade deficits are bad, other countries take advantage of the U.S. and tariffs are the way to fix this.

Since the Rose Garden announcement, markets have plunged, other countries have promised to retaliate, and members of his own party have spoken out against the tariffs.

Trump's tariff plan is designed to eliminate U.S. trade deficits. Are trade deficits actually bad?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

TITLE: Russia escapes Trump Tariffs, as envoy pushes deals with Washington
SUMMARY: A visit by a senior Kremlin envoy to the White House this week may help explain why Russia is not on President Trump's tariffs list - and determine for just how long Russia can stay off the list.

TITLE: Judge considers 'contempt' after Trump officials stonewall ruling on migrant removal flights
SUMMARY: U.S. District Judge James Boasberg Thursday pushed, once again, the Justice Department to explain its use of the Alien Enemies Act and provide key details and the timeline of the flights.

TITLE: Death toll rises as devastating spring storms batter the South and Midwest
SUMMARY: At least six people have died amid severe storms that are predicted to impact large areas of the United States through the weekend.

TITLE: 19 states sue over Trump's voting executive order, arguing it's unconstitutional
SUMMARY: The lawsuit is the fourth legal challenge against Trump's executive order on voting. The attorneys general argue the order is "an unconstitutional attempt to seize control of elections."

TITLE: Trump's VA is ending a rescue program that's saved 17,000 military veterans' homes
SUMMARY: The Department of Veterans Affairs says it will end a mortgage rescue plan that has saved many veterans from needlessly losing their homes, the move could strand thousands of others who need help.

TITLE: Canada trucker protest organizers found guilty of mischief
SUMMARY: The February 2022 protests, dubbed the Freedom Convoy, were sparked by a Canadian government vaccine mandate for truck drivers crossing the U.S.-Canada border.

TITLE: South Korea's president removed from office over ill-fated declaration of martial law
SUMMARY: South Korea's Constitutional Court removed impeached President Yoon Suk Yeol from office on Friday, ending his tumultuous presidency and setting up an election to replace him.

TITLE: Trump downplays the role of far-right activist in firings of NSC staff
SUMMARY: President Trump is downplaying reports that far-right provocateur Laura Loomer influenced National Security Council firings on Thursday.

TITLE: Major deal wipes out $30 billion in medical debt. Even backers say it's not enough
SUMMARY: Undue Medical Debt is retiring unpaid medical bills for 20 million people. The debt trading company that owned them is leaving the market.

TITLE: Microsoft turns 50: A look back at everything from the Altair to the Zune
SUMMARY: The company helped launch the software industry and bring a computer to every desktop. Hit products like Windows and the Xbox became household names – but does anyone remember the Zune?

TITLE: The price of what hit record highs this week? Find out in the quiz
SUMMARY: This week inspired questions of self-reflection, like "could I talk for 25 hours straight?" and "do I feel liberated?" and "can you tell me again why the Wisconsin Supreme Court is important?"

TITLE: A hot seat for Musk, the trade war and third-term talk: Takeaways from the week
SUMMARY: A GOP electoral warning points to Elon Musk in the hot seat, and President Trump employed a third-term distraction. Also, a trade war rages, and there were mass firings at key scientific agencies.

TITLE: Former Costa Rican president says visa may have been revoked over criticism of Trump
SUMMARY: Former Costa Rican President Óscar Arias Sánchez, who likened President Trump to "Roman emperor" earlier this year, says he fears the U.S. revoked his visa over criticisms of Trump.

TITLE: NCAA president on why he supports NIL settlement for college players
SUMMARY: NCAA president Charlie Baker discusses a proposed settlement between college athletes and the NCAA for making direct payments to players for their name, image and likeness.

TITLE: The way brands speak to us has changed a lot in just the last decade
SUMMARY: The tone of voice and personality that brands use to market themselves to consumers has changed a lot in the past decade, with many brands communicating more frequently and in overly familiar ways.

TITLE: The unique genetic change that turned horses into athletic powerhouses
SUMMARY: A new study suggests genetic changes allow horses to produce more energy, while minimizing the toll the energy takes on cells.

TITLE: Word of the Week: The swashbuckling origins and evolution of 'filibuster'
SUMMARY: Sen. Cory Booker's record-breaking Senate speech wasn't technically a filibuster, but it still put the word in focus. Here's what to know about its history, from the swashbuckling to the stonewalling.

TITLE: A 'beacon' or a 'roulette'? Chinese America watchers see opportunities and pitfalls
SUMMARY: Some of China's America watchers see opportunities for their country in the United States' retreat from international institutions. Others see distractions and pitfalls.

TITLE: How new tariffs will impact small retailers. And, key takeaways from Trump's 7th week
SUMMARY: President Trump's new tariffs are expected to take effect tomorrow. Small retailers are bracing for the impact. And, Trump denies reports of Laura Loomer's influence in yesterday's NSC firings.

TITLE: Comedian Russell Brand is charged with rape and assault in U.K.
SUMMARY: The criminal charges were announced one and a half years after Brand was accused of sexual misconduct by four women in the fall of 2023.

TITLE: The job market remains incredibly healthy -- but the tariff storm could upend things
SUMMARY: Employers added 228,000 jobs in March, showcasing a solid labor market. But uncertainty over tariffs and tepid consumer spending may weigh on job growth in the months to come.

TITLE: Trade war escalates as China hits back with 34% tariffs on all U.S. goods
SUMMARY: Analysts say the escalating trade tensions between the U.S and China will make a near-term deal to end the trade war "highly unlikely".

TITLE: Stocks sink in another brutal day, as Trump's tariffs send global shockwaves
SUMMARY: Investors, businesses and consumers all seem terrified of how President Trump's tariffs could upend the global economy.

TITLE: National Security Agency chief fired as Trump ousts another top military officer
SUMMARY: Air Force Gen. Timothy Haugh served just over a year as director of the NSA, the spy agency that collects cyber intelligence worldwide. He's the latest of several senior officers fired by Trump.

TITLE: The job market remains incredibly healthy — but the tariff storm could upend things
SUMMARY: Employers added 228,000 jobs in March, showcasing a solid labor market. But uncertainty over tariffs and tepid consumer spending may weigh on job growth in the months to come.

TITLE: Higher prices are likely for these 10 grocery items when tariffs hit
SUMMARY: A trip to the grocery or liquor store is about to become even more expensive, economists say. From seafood to olive oil, these items will likely cost more under President Trump's tariffs.

TITLE: National Endowment for the Humanities staff put on immediate leave
SUMMARY: A majority of NEH employees received an email placing them on immediate leave. The news comes just days after many humanities councils across the country were told their grants would be terminated.

TITLE: Has a shelter pet changed your life? We want to hear about it
SUMMARY: National Adopt a Shelter Pet Day is on April 30. To celebrate, NPR wants to know how your pet has changed your life. We would also love to see photos of your purr-fect fur-ever friend.

TITLE: Popular brands of liquid eggs are recalled over bleach contamination concerns
SUMMARY: Over 200,000 pounds of Egg Beaters and Bob Evans products were recalled over potential cleaning solution contamination. The USDA says that health risks are low, but consumers should still steer clear.

TITLE: The Opaque War Against the Houthis in Yemen
SUMMARY: We heard a lot about the planning by U.S. national security officials for a bombing campaign against Houthi fighters in Yemen, because a journalist was added to their Signal group chat. That bombing campaign is ongoing and we haven't heard much about how it is going or its goals. Our national security correspondent tells us about what the U.S. military is doing in Yemen and how we're getting more information about that from the Houthis than from the Pentagon.

TITLE: Trump extends TikTok's sell-by deadline again
SUMMARY: On his first day in office, President Trump used an executive order to hit pause on the TikTok ban for 75 days. Now he's pushing back that deadline.

TITLE: Judge orders the Trump administration to return man who was mistakenly deported
SUMMARY: A federal judge in Maryland Friday ordered the Trump administration to take immediate steps to return a Maryland man who was deported to a Salvadoran mega-prison by mistake, setting up another high-stakes clash between the White House and the courts.

TITLE: He's a decorated war vet but a convicted criminal. ICE wants to deport him
SUMMARY: Jose Barco's story is one of battlefield trauma, bureaucratic bumbling and eventually, a serious crime.

TITLE: Supreme Court sides with administration over Education Department grants
SUMMARY: By a 5-4 vote, the justices allowed the administration to freeze millions of dollars in grant funding for diversity and instructional programs at public and private universities.

TITLE: Dow Jones plunges over 2,200 points as tariff carnage roils global markets
SUMMARY: Investors, businesses and consumers all seem terrified of how President Trump's tariffs could upend the global economy.

TITLE: How will the deep cuts at the Centers for Disease Control affect global programs?
SUMMARY: The U.S. agency has not released information on what global programs were cut this week. NPR spoke to current employees who provided exclusive details.

TITLE: Paige Bueckers' moment
SUMMARY: The University of Connecticut's women's basketball team is back in the Final Four thanks in part to Paige Bueckers. Bueckers has done a lot in her amazing career except win the NCAA title. She's ready.

TITLE: Deadly storms devastate parts of the U.S. South and Midwest
SUMMARY: The National Weather Service has issued a warning that the South and Midwest may experience more severe storms, flooding and tornadoes in the days ahead.

TITLE: L.A. Dodgers bound for the White House to celebrate World Series championship
SUMMARY: The Los Angeles Dodgers will be at the White House to celebrate their World Series win. But not everyone is happy that the team will meet with President Trump.

TITLE: Alex Ovechkin has tied Wayne Gretzky's all-time NHL goals record
SUMMARY: The Washington Capitals star came into Friday's game two goals shy of tying the NHL's career record, set decades ago by the great Wayne Gretzky. The Capitals have six games left in the regular season.

TITLE: Want to raise bilingual kids? First, let go of a common myth
SUMMARY: Speech pathologists offer parents real-world advice on how to incorporate a second language with their kids at home — and demystify a misconception about bilingualism.

TITLE: TikTok creators go from sadness and fear to...'whatever!' over app's future
SUMMARY: It's been an emotional rollercoaster for TikTok creators over the past few months, with the app's future uncertain. But there are ways to decompress.

TITLE: Ukrainians face fears during the country's darkest nights
SUMMARY: All over Ukraine, war has made nighttime darker. Satellite imagery shows a significant dimming of lights since 2022. Darkness has spread indoors too, with power cuts becoming common during the war.

TITLE: Don't overthink the torpedo bats
SUMMARY: The Yankees 20-9 win against the Brewers last weekend put the spotlight on torpedo bats. But in baseball, as in life, sometimes a fluke is just what it seems.

TITLE: 'Your RIF notice is not cancelled.' Inside a chaotic week of massive layoffs at HHS
SUMMARY: Health agency staffers describe a week of chaos and continued uncertainty about who still has a job and how the work will get done. To many it's the opposite of 'government efficiency.'

TITLE: Can't-miss interviews: Cory Booker, Elizabeth Olsen and the latest on tariffs
SUMMARY: A lot happened this week, and NPR has you covered. Catch up on the big news and culture moments you might have missed.

TITLE: Opinion: Art fair flyers should showcase human creativity
SUMMARY: Organizers of Oakland's First Fridays art festival made a flyer promoting the event using AI, and are facing backlash for not using an actual artist. NPR's Scott Simon explains.

TITLE: LA Dodgers bound for the White House to celebrate World Series championship
SUMMARY: The Los Angeles Dodgers will be at the White House to celebrate their World Series win. But not everyone is happy that the team will meet with President Trump.

TITLE: Palestinian medics say a video of Gaza rescue crews under fire refutes Israeli claims
SUMMARY: Palestinian medical officials say they obtained video footage that refutes Israel's claims about the killing of 15 rescue and aid workers in the southern Gaza Strip last month.

TITLE: Defrocked former D.C. Cardinal Theodore McCarrick dies at 94
SUMMARY: Theodore McCarrick, a once-powerful Catholic cardinal who was defrocked by Pope Francis in 2019 after a Vatican investigation determined he had molested adults and children, has died.

TITLE: Senate GOP passes budget plan, setting up a critical next phase for Trump agenda
SUMMARY: The vote brings Republicans a step closer to finalizing a sweeping plan to address defense, energy, immigration and tax policy. But a number of potential wildcards must still be sorted out.

TITLE: More torrential rain and flash flooding are expected in waterlogged South and Midwest
SUMMARY: Another round of torrential rain and flash flooding was coming Saturday for parts of the South and Midwest already heavily waterlogged by days of severe storms that also spawned some deadly tornadoes.

TITLE: The Mason bee has become the unsung hero of the honey bee population
SUMMARY: Honey bee populations are again declining, threatening crops. NPR's Scott Simon talks to Dave Hunter, who raises the unsung hero of the orchard (and champion pollinator), the Mason bee.

TITLE: The video game industry at a crossroads
SUMMARY:
The video game industry is huge. Last year alone it generated an estimated $187 billion dollars in revenue.

But it's also facing a host of serious issues: massive layoffs, the advent of A.I., games that take years to be released, and a schism between big and small developers.

This week's Reporter's Notebook takes us inside this evolving industry with NPR's Vincent Acovino, who recently covered the annual Game Developer's Conference in San Francisco.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: More torrential rain and flash flooding threaten waterlogged South and Midwest
SUMMARY: Another round of torrential rain and flash flooding was coming for parts of the South and Midwest. Areas are already waterlogged by days of severe storms that also spawned some deadly tornadoes.

TITLE: 'Oliver and Amanda Pig' series author Jean Van Leeuwen dies at 87
SUMMARY: The children's book author best known for her Oliver and Amanda Pig series has died at 87. Van Leeuwen wrote nearly 60 books, some of which sold millions of copies.

TITLE: Nationwide 'Hands Off' protests erupt against Trump and Musk
SUMMARY: Hundreds of demonstrations took place across the country, uniting a myriad of criticisms of the Trump administration under one message: "Hands off."

TITLE: How automakers are responding to the 25% car tariffs so far
SUMMARY: It's only been a few days since President Trump's 25% tariffs on foreign cars took effect. But the import surcharge has led to some immediate changes, including layoffs and pauses in car shipments.

TITLE: Photos: See demonstrators around the country rally in 'Hands Off!' protests
SUMMARY: NPR member station photographers documented what they saw at the demonstrations against the Trump administration, from cuts and layoffs to federal departments, to mass deportations.

TITLE: Nationwide 'Hands Off!' protests erupt against Trump and Musk
SUMMARY: Demonstrations took place across the country, uniting a myriad of criticisms of the Trump administration under one message: "Hands off!"

TITLE: At least 16 dead in flooding and tornadoes as storms slash from Texas to Ohio
SUMMARY: Another round of torrential rain and flash flooding was coming for parts of the South and Midwest. Areas are already waterlogged by days of severe storms that also spawned some deadly tornadoes.

TITLE: Amadou Bagayoko, one half of Malian duo Amadou & Mariam, dies at 70
SUMMARY: Bagayoko, an acclaimed guitarist and half of the Grammy-nominated blind duo Amadou & Mariam, died in his hometown of Bamako on Friday.

TITLE: For these seniors, DOGE's affordable housing pause means suffering longer without AC
SUMMARY: The Trump administration froze funding for a program to upgrade aging low-income housing and make it energy efficient. The move threatens hundreds of projects around the country.

TITLE: In 'free' Khartoum, the ruined streets smell of perfume and music plays
SUMMARY: Sudanese activist Duaa Tariq, who spoke to NPR throughout the war, shares what its like in the "liberated" capital Khartoum, after two years occupied by the Rapid Support Forces

TITLE: Jaguar and Land Rover maker pauses shipments to US as it develops post-tariff plans
SUMMARY: Jaguar Land Rover Automotive said it was pausing U.S. shipments due to Trump's tariffs as it works on mid- to long-term plans to adapt to the changing trade landscape.

TITLE: 1 killed in Russian attack on Kyiv as death toll from missile strike rises to 19
SUMMARY: One person was killed Sunday as Russian air strikes hit the Ukrainian capital, Kyiv, while the death toll from Friday's deadly attack on the central Ukrainian city of Kryvyi Rih continued to rise.

TITLE: Yemen Houthi rebels say latest US strikes killed 2, day after Trump posted bomb video
