SUMMARY: Suspected U.S. airstrikes killed at least two people in a stronghold of Yemen's Houthi rebels, the group said Sunday.

TITLE: Vietnam asks Trump to delay implementation of tariffs while the two sides negotiate
SUMMARY: Vietnam is actively seeking to negotiate a reduction in the high tariff rate imposed by the Trump Administration.

TITLE: Second child dies from measles-related causes in West Texas, where cases near 500
SUMMARY: A second school-aged child in West Texas has died from a measles-related illness, a hospital spokesman confirmed Sunday, as the outbreak continues to swell.

TITLE: Alex Ovechkin scores goal #895 to break Wayne Gretzky's all-time NHL scoring record
SUMMARY: The Washington Capitals star made history with a power play goal from the left faceoff circle — as Gretzky, who last set the record more than 25 years ago, looked on.

TITLE: Severe storms and floods batter South and Midwest, as death toll rises to at least 18
SUMMARY: Severe storms continued to pound parts of the South and Midwest, as a punishing and slow-moving storm system unleashed life-threatening flash floods and powerful tornadoes from Mississippi to Kentucky.

TITLE: Israeli strikes on Gaza kill at least 32, mostly women and children
SUMMARY: Israeli strikes on Gaza killed at least 32 people, including over a dozen women and children, local health officials said Sunday, as Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu headed to meet President Trump.

TITLE: UConn takes 12th NCAA women's basketball title with dominant win over South Carolina
SUMMARY: UConn is back on top of women's basketball, winning its 12th NCAA national championship by routing defending champion South Carolina 82-59 on Sunday.

TITLE: RFK Jr. visits epicenter of Texas measles outbreak after death of second child
SUMMARY: A second school-aged child in West Texas has died from a measles-related illness, a hospital spokesman confirmed Sunday, as the outbreak continues to swell.

TITLE: Asian markets plunge with Japan's Nikkei diving nearly 8% after big Wall St. meltdown
SUMMARY: Asian shares nosedived on Monday after the meltdown Friday on Wall Street over U.S. President Donald Trump's tariff hikes and the backlash from Beijing.

TITLE: Le Pen supporters rally in Paris, turning a protest into a populist show of force
SUMMARY: Thousands of supporters gathered near the tomb of Napoleon for what was billed as a protest — but observers said it had all the markings of a campaign rally.

TITLE: Forecast of a week of rain adds to Myanmar earthquake woes, as death toll tops 3,500
SUMMARY: Rescuers temporarily shut down electrical equipment and machines used in search operations due to the rain over the weekend, making recovery operations more difficult.

TITLE: World markets plunge with Japan's Nikkei diving nearly 8% after big Wall St. meltdown
SUMMARY: Shares nosedived around the world Monday as higher U.S. tariffs and a backlash from Beijing triggered massive sell-offs. European shares followed Asian markets declining.

TITLE: Colon cancer survivors who exercise regularly live longer
SUMMARY: Colon cancer is on the rise in younger people in the U.S. New research shows regular exercise can help survivors live longer — in some cases even longer than people who didn't have cancer.

TITLE: UAW President Shawn Fain explains why he supports Trump's tariffs
SUMMARY: Shawn Fein supports auto industry tariffs but calls broad tariffs "reckless."

TITLE: How does deportation work, and how much does it cost? We break it down
SUMMARY: NPR spoke to immigration experts and lawyers and reviewed government documents to break down the steps and associated costs of the U.S. deportation process.

TITLE: Freedom of speech is shifting under the Trump administration. We're exploring how
SUMMARY: Many Americans worry freedom of speech is fading, while others feel empowered to say what they want. NPR's <em>Morning Edition

TITLE: Landmark day for college sports as judge holds final hearing on major NCAA settlement
SUMMARY: A class-action lawsuit involving thousands of current and former college athletes, known as House vs. NCAA, would transform college sports by allowing schools to pay players directly.

TITLE: Between tariffs and survival, American business owners are doing alarming math
SUMMARY: Many U.S. shop owners feel like collateral damage in President Trump's trade war, on the hook to pay big new fees and long unable to manufacture in the U.S.

TITLE: The artist behind 'the worst' Trump portrait defends her work
SUMMARY: The painting, which was commissioned by Republicans, has hung in Colorado's state Capitol since 2019. Trump follows other U.S. presidents who weren't flattered by their depictions.

TITLE: The (artificial intelligence) therapist can see you now
SUMMARY: Many AI products claim to deliver mental health therapy, but with little quality control. But new research suggests with the right training, AI can be effective at helping people.

TITLE: Global markets plunge due to trade war. And, 2nd child dies in Texas from measles
SUMMARY: Trump's trade war against most of the world has caused global markets to fall drastically. And, a second child in Texas has died from measles as the outbreak continues to spread.

TITLE: Netanyahu is set to meet Trump to talk tariffs and hostages in Gaza
SUMMARY: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu will meet with President Trump expecting to discuss tariffs, hostages and war in Gaza and other issues.

TITLE: Netanyahu is set to meet Trump to discuss Israeli hostages in Gaza and U.S. tariffs
SUMMARY: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu will meet with President Trump expecting to discuss tariffs, hostages and war in Gaza and other issues.

TITLE: Trump's tariffs complicate the Switch 2 launch, says Nintendo of America president
SUMMARY: Nintendo canceled U.S. preorders for the Switch 2 after President Trump announced sweeping global tariffs. We discuss the challenges facing the console release with Nintendo of America President Doug Bowser.

TITLE: Between tariffs and survival, American business owners are doing alarming math
SUMMARY: Many U.S. shop owners feel like collateral damage in President Trump's trade war, on the hook to pay big new fees and long unable to manufacture in the U.S.

TITLE: Most Americans want to read more books. We just don't.
SUMMARY: When we worry about the declining rates of literacy and a lack of reading skills, it's often about children. But how often are adults reading these days? And what are we reading? A new NPR/Ipsos poll finds out.

TITLE: 'All Boys Aren't Blue' tops the ALA's list of most challenged books
SUMMARY: Organized pressure groups, not individual parents, are leading the fight to remove books from shelves, according to a new report from the American Library Association.

TITLE: Wall Street leaders warn of harsh economic consequences from Trump's tariffs
SUMMARY: The business sector has tried to avoid criticizing Trump in public and welcomed his vows of lower taxes and deregulation, but the market sell-off appears to have loosened more tongues on Wall Street.

TITLE: Transfer to Alaska? Offer to health leaders called 'insult' to Indian Health Service
SUMMARY: NPR obtained emails that went out last week to leaders at health agencies offering to transfer them to postings in tribal communities. Officials close to Dr. Anthony Fauci got the offer.

TITLE: How does deportation work, and how much does it cost? We break it down
SUMMARY: NPR spoke to immigration experts and lawyers and reviewed government documents to break down the steps and associated costs of the U.S. deportation process.

TITLE: Tariffs are fueling fears of a recession. What does it take to actually declare one?
SUMMARY: The Trump administration's tariffs are fueling concerns about a potential recession, with several major banks increasing their forecasts. What is recession and who declares one?

TITLE: Deadline looms in case of Maryland man's wrongful deportation to El Salvador
SUMMARY: The Trump administration is asking the Supreme Court to lift a midnight deadline to return Kilmar Abrego Garcia, the Maryland man who was deported to a prison in El Salvador by mistake, to the U.S.

TITLE: 'Due process does look different': DHS official defends deportation of Maryland man
SUMMARY: The Trump administration has defended the deportation of Maryland man mistakenly sent to El Salvador.

TITLE: They had left their DEI roles. Trump still fired them
SUMMARY: The Trump administration is firing hundreds and perhaps thousands of federal workers as part of a crackdown on diversity, equity and inclusion efforts. Many of the fired weren't in DEI jobs.

TITLE: How a false X post about pausing tariffs led to multi-trillion-dollar market swings
SUMMARY: What began as a misquoted Fox News interview led to a flood of false and misleading posts on X. Before it was corrected, stock markets rallied then plummeted again.

TITLE: They want America to have more babies. Is this their moment?
SUMMARY:
Billionaire Elon Musk told Fox News recently that falling birth rates keep him up at night. It's a drum he's been beating for years.

Musk is one of the world's most visible individuals to elevate this point of view. Vice President JD Vance also talks about wanting to increase birthrates in the U-S.

But it's not just them. There are discussions across the political spectrum about birth rate decline and what it means for the economy.

One response to this decline is a cause that's been taken up by the right, and it has a name – Pronatalism. Many of its advocates met up recently in Austin, Texas, at "Natal Con."

Pronatalists think they have a friendly audience in the White House. How do they want to use it?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: Health secretary RFK Jr. endorses the MMR vaccine — stoking fury among his supporters
SUMMARY: Prominent anti-vaccine activists lined up on social media to denounce the move.

TITLE: War and Peace in Sudan's Capital
SUMMARY: Until very recently Sudan's capital, Khartoum, had spent nearly two years at war. A paramilitary group went to war with the Sudanese army, occupying the city until it was retaken by government forces in the last few weeks. This has meant massive life shifts for residents of Khartoum who have stayed in the city. One resident has been sending our correspondent regular voice notes telling him about what life is like. We hear what it means to have a war break out in your city and what it is like to finally be liberated.

TITLE: Supreme Court backs Trump in controversial deportations case
SUMMARY: The order marks a win for the Trump administration, even if temporary, and it could well be a harbinger of things to come as the administration continues to clash with federal courts.

TITLE: China vows retaliation after Trump's latest tariff threat
SUMMARY: Trump said on Truth Social he would impose the new tariffs on China if Beijing did not retract a 34% retaliatory tariff on U.S. goods that it announced in response to Trump's initial salvo last Wednesday.

TITLE: The U.S. will hold direct, high-level talks with Iran, Trump says
SUMMARY: It's been more than a decade since the two powers have had direct talks. President Trump offered few details about what the talks would entail, or when they'd be scheduled.

TITLE: Florida swamps Houston, winning 3rd NCAA men's basketball national championship
SUMMARY: The Florida Gators downed Houston, denying the Cougars their first-ever title. Florida, one of a record 14 Southeastern Conference teams to make the men's tournament, won its third NCAA championship.

TITLE: Flooding death toll in Congo's capital reaches 33 as officials race to help victims
SUMMARY: Heavy rains began last week, causing the key Ndjili River to overflow on Friday and submerge hundreds of buildings. Many residents blamed the government for not responding quickly enough.

TITLE: Garbage piles up in Birmingham as the U.K. city's sanitation strike enters 5th week
SUMMARY: As heaps of black bags littered sidewalks with their contents spilling out of holes chewed by critters, the city council declared a major incident to bring in additional cleanup crews and vehicles.

TITLE: China vows retaliation and a 'fight to the end' after Trump's latest tariff threat
SUMMARY: Trump said on Truth Social he would impose the new tariffs on China if Beijing did not retract a 34% retaliatory tariff on U.S. goods that it announced in response to Trump's initial salvo last Wednesday.

TITLE: Iran says it will have 'indirect' talks with the U.S. in Oman on Saturday
SUMMARY: Iran says it will have indirect talks with the U.S. Saturday in Oman, opening possible diplomacy over Iran's nuclear program but revealing a potential sticking point about the format for negotiating.

TITLE: How to avoid harmful chemicals in skin care and beauty products
SUMMARY: Some ingredients found in personal care products like lotion and shampoo may be harmful to your health. Here's how to avoid these chemicals and choose healthier alternatives.

TITLE: World markets regain some ground after Trump tariffs shock investors
SUMMARY: After major slides in equity trading across the world, any slight uptick in stock prices will only repair part of the destruction of trillions of dollars in investor wealth over the past few days.

TITLE: It's sexual assault awareness month and HHS just gutted its rape prevention unit
SUMMARY: The CDC teams that supported local sexual assault prevention groups were 'wiped out' in RFK Jr.'s overhaul of the Department of Health and Human Services.

TITLE: Why is Trump sending immigrant university scholars to Louisiana and Texas?
SUMMARY: Lawyers say the government is trying to gain a legal advantage as it tries to expel noncitizens over their pro-Palestinian activism.

TITLE: Trump's election order could jeopardize 'hundreds of thousands' of future mail ballots
SUMMARY: Eighteen states count mail-in ballots that are received after Election Day, but a new order by President Trump challenges the practice.

TITLE: The rise of the influencer as rap artist
SUMMARY: The YouTube star PlaqueBoyMax built his following the usual way, livestreaming opinions on music and news. What's unusual is his latest move, which tests the modern meaning of the word "creator."

TITLE: International students spoke out against the war in Gaza. Now, some face deportation
SUMMARY: The Trump administration has targeted students — both those with visas and those with permanent legal status — who protested the war in Gaza. Free speech advocates warn that these are test cases.

TITLE: Bienvenidos! Some colleges are targeting a long-neglected group: Hispanic students
SUMMARY: Colleges are recognizing the importance of this growing pool of potential students.

TITLE: Trump defends new tariffs. And, Supreme Court backs Trump in deportation case
SUMMARY: President Trump defended his new tariffs and asked for patience as experts warn of economic repercussions. And, immigration advocates worry about SCOTUS' Alien Enemies Act ruling.

TITLE: U.S. stock markets bounce back after Trump tariffs shock -- but nerves abound
SUMMARY: After major slides in equity trading across the world, any slight uptick in stock prices will only repair part of the destruction of trillions of dollars in investor wealth over the past few days.

TITLE: 'Citizenship won't save you': Free speech advocates say student arrests should worry all
SUMMARY: The Trump administration has targeted students — both those with visas and those with permanent legal status — who protested the war in Gaza. Free speech advocates warn that these are test cases.

TITLE: American Giant CEO says China tariffs are 'overdue' but warns of industry confusion
SUMMARY: American Giant sources and makes most of its products in the U.S. Its CEO says tariffs on China were overdue, but he worries the wide range will cause confusion about the global textile supply chain.

TITLE: USAID enabled 208 Afghan women to defy the Taliban ban on college -- until now
SUMMARY: A USAID grant enabled them to either study online or enroll in college in another country. Now the grant has been terminated.

TITLE: A biotech company says it has bred three pups with traits of the extinct dire wolf
SUMMARY: Colossal Biosciences says it used novel gene-editing technology to alter gray wolf DNA to breed the animals. Dire wolves recently featured prominently in the HBO series <em>Game of Thrones

TITLE: Supreme Court lets Trump move forward with firing thousands of federal workers
SUMMARY: The Supreme Court's stay, which allows the administration to execute the firings for now while it litigates in federal court, does not mean the terminations were lawful.

TITLE: HHS guts sexual violence prevention division, leaving local efforts adrift
SUMMARY: The CDC teams that supported local sexual assault prevention groups were 'wiped out' in RFK Jr.'s overhaul of the Department of Health and Human Services.

TITLE: American DRC coup plotters are on their way back to U.S.
SUMMARY: The three young men, who were sentenced to death for their part in an attempted coup in the Democratic Republic of Congo last May, were handed over to U.S. authorities and are on their way to the U.S.

TITLE: Biden's closest advisers were in 'denial' about his decline, 'Uncharted' author says
SUMMARY: Author Chris Whipple says Biden's family and closest advisers operated in a "fog of delusion" regarding his ability to serve another term: "There's no doubt that they were protecting the president."

TITLE: What is Tren de Aragua's footprint in the U.S.? Experts say smaller than federal officials say
SUMMARY: Unreliable federal gang data and a heavy reliance on tattoos and clothing styles can skew the picture of this Venezuelan gang's operations in America.

TITLE: House GOP leaders prep vote on budget despite rift within the party
SUMMARY: Republicans in Congress are closer to passing key elements of President Trump's legislative agenda — like extending tax cuts that expire at the end of the year — but only if the House and Senate can get on the same page.

TITLE: 'We love them': Small N.Y. town embraces a family freed from immigration detention
SUMMARY: "I get goose bumps," said school principal Jamie Cook, thinking about the community rallying to support the family. The three students and their mother were arrested by immigration agents.

TITLE: Israeli Soldiers Refusing to Serve in Gaza
SUMMARY: Following Israel declaring an end to the ceasefire with Hamas in Gaza last month, the Israeli military has called in reservists to return to war. However, this time fewer reserve troops are answering that call to go back into Gaza. Our correspondent in Tel Aviv talked to three officers who commanded troops in Gaza and who have become frustrated with military strategy.

TITLE: Trump trade official signals tariffs are negotiating tool amid GOP skepticism
SUMMARY: Trump's trade representative Jamieson Greer told Senators that President Trump's tariffs prompted more than 50 countries to reach out to negotiate trade deals. But Greer declined to give a timeline.

TITLE: This YouTube show explains climate change to the kids who have to live with it
SUMMARY: Suzie Hicks the Climate Chick is an up-and-coming educator and TV host with a YouTube series tailored to kids ages 4 through 8.

TITLE: Migrants who entered the U.S. via CBP One app should leave 'immediately,' DHS says
SUMMARY: DHS is telling some migrants who entered the U.S. using the CBP One app to leave immediately, part of a broader push to revoke temporary legal protections known as humanitarian parole.

TITLE: Texas' measles outbreak isn't slowing down. How can that change?
SUMMARY: Health experts say driving up vaccination rates in affected areas is the most effective defense against this disease

TITLE: Judge orders White House to allow AP access to news events
SUMMARY: U.S. Judge Trevor N. McFadden rules the White House cannot deny the Associated Press access to news events because the wire service continues to use "Gulf of Mexico" rather than "Gulf of America".

TITLE: New Social Security rules will create hurdles for millions of seniors, report finds
SUMMARY: A new report from a left-leaning Center on Budget and Policy Priorities finds that upcoming changes to Social Security will amount to a "45-mile trip for some 6 million seniors."

TITLE: What will it take to get measles under control?
SUMMARY:
It's been 25 years since measles was officially "eliminated" from the United States.

That's a technical term. In public health, it means measles has not had a steady twelve month spread.

Right now there are measles cases in several states The biggest number of cases are in West Texas where two kids have died.

A quarter of a century after measles was officially eliminated in the US, the disease is once again spreading in West Texas, New Mexico and there are cases in several other states. What can be done to get the virus under control?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: The IRS finalizes a deal to share tax information with immigration authorities
SUMMARY: The Internal Revenue Service reached a deal to share tax information about some immigrants without legal status, marking a major change in how tax records can be used.

TITLE: Mixed messages on tariffs raises scrutiny on Trump aides
SUMMARY: President Trump is boasting about the wheeling and dealing he's doing to cut deals on steep new tariffs. But for weeks, his aides have insisted that tariffs were not a bargaining chip.

TITLE: Fact-check: Who's right in the Musk-Navarro feud over Tesla?
SUMMARY: President Trump's rival advisors Peter Navarro and Elon Musk are in a war of words over whether Tesla relies on imported parts. Musk has the facts on his side.

TITLE: Immigration judge to rule Friday on detained activist Mahmoud Khalil
SUMMARY: An immigration judge in Louisiana has ordered the  government to turn over its evidence against Mahmoud Khalil. She says she will rule Friday on whether the Pro-Palestinian activist can be deported.

TITLE: Asian shares deepen losses, with Nikkei down 5%, as latest US tariffs take effect
SUMMARY: Japan's Nikkei 225 dipped more than 5% and other Asian shares also sank Wednesday as the latest set of U.S. tariffs, including a massive 104% levy on Chinese imports, took effect.

TITLE: Trump officials halt $1 billion in funding for Cornell, $790 million for Northwestern
SUMMARY: More than $1 billion in funding for Cornell University and around $790 million for Northwestern University have been frozen over alleged civil rights violations at both schools, the White House says.

TITLE: The roof collapses at a Dominican Republic nightclub, killing at least 98 people
SUMMARY: The roof of an nightclub in the Dominican capital collapsed early Tuesday during a concert attended by politicians, athletes and others, with at least 98 people dead and 160 injured, authorities said.

TITLE: National Recording Registry adds Tracy Chapman, Hamilton and the Minecraft game soundtrack
SUMMARY: There are 25 new additions to the Library of Congress collection. They include albums by Elton John, Miles Davis, Amy Winehouse, and the original cast recording of <em>Hamilton.

TITLE: Sen. Maria Cantwell says there is bipartisan support to rein Trump's tariffs
SUMMARY: Sen. Maria Cantwell, D-Wash., says a bill that would require Congressional approval for tariffs has bipartisan support because they are an "economic nightmare."

TITLE: Word of the Week: 'Tariff' itself is an import from overseas
SUMMARY: President Trump has repeatedly called tariffs "the most beautiful word in the dictionary." NPR's Word of the Week explores how they got their name.

TITLE: Coal miners' health care hit hard in job cuts to CDC
SUMMARY: The CDC unit that dramatically reduced Black Lung Disease among coal miners has been fired in Trump's sweeping overhaul of health agencies. Mining communities must now grapple with its disappearance.

TITLE: Four critically endangered Galápagos tortoises hatch at the Philadelphia Zoo
SUMMARY: The birth of tortoises native to Santa Cruz Island in the Galápagos increases their U.S. population from 44 to 48. A few thousand remain globally, according to estimates by experts.

TITLE: Americans without a degree still believe in the value of college, a new poll says
SUMMARY: The majority of Americans without degrees still believe in the value of higher education, according to the poll. But not all college degrees are created equal.

TITLE: Trump is getting a physical. What will be included in the report?
SUMMARY: President Trump's past medical reports have been glowing. But at 78, his age puts his health in the spotlight — as it was for his predecessor, President Joe Biden.

TITLE: Asian markets tumble as China mulls response to Trump's 104% tariffs
SUMMARY: Asian markets sank after Trump's 104% tariffs on Chinese goods took effect, with Beijing warning it was ready to defend its economic interests.

TITLE: NOAA contracts are being reviewed one by one. It's throwing the agency into chaos
SUMMARY: NOAA relies on hundreds of contracts to keep the agency running. The new commerce secretary is reviewing many of them individually, causing disruptions to many normal operations within the agency.

TITLE: Trump's new tariffs take effect. And, the firings of federal workers can proceed
SUMMARY: Trump's new sweeping tariffs took effect after midnight. China says it's toughing out the trade war. And, the Supreme Court ruled that firings of thousands of federal workers could proceed.

TITLE: How Trump's immigration policies could worsen the health care worker shortage
SUMMARY: Hospitals and nursing homes rely on the immigrant workforce to fill many key roles, research finds. Trump's crackdown on immigration threatens to exacerbate shortages.

TITLE: Word of the Week: Trump calls tariffs 'the most beautiful word.' Here's its history
SUMMARY: President Trump has repeatedly called tariffs "the most beautiful word in the dictionary." NPR's Word of the Week explores how they got their name.

TITLE: The Israeli troop killing of a U.S. teen in the West Bank sparks outrage
SUMMARY: The killing of a Palestinian American teen by Israeli forces in the occupied West Bank has sparked an outcry from relatives and community members in the Palestinian territory as well as the U.S.

TITLE: If Planet Nine is out there, this telescope might actually find it
SUMMARY: A powerful new observatory is the best hope yet for finding the elusive Planet 9, a large planet that some scientists say is hidden in our solar system.

TITLE: U.S. says it is now monitoring immigrants' social media for antisemitism
SUMMARY: Effective immediately, the government says it will begin screening immigrant social media for activity that officials think indicates support for antisemitism.

TITLE: U.S. stocks gain modestly, attempting a rebound even as tariff war escalates
SUMMARY: U.S. stock indices were modestly higher even as President Trump's latest round of tariffs kicked in. But nerves abounded, with China and the EU announcing they would retaliate with their own tariffs.

TITLE: Druze militias are suspicious of Syria's new leaders -- and are ready to go to battle
SUMMARY: The new leadership vowed to disband all militias. But the fiercely independent Druze have made no agreement, and say they're gathering fighters and making plans to repel government forces if needed.

TITLE: Lori Vallow Daybell starts a new murder trial, acting as her own attorney
SUMMARY: Vallow Daybell is charged with conspiracy to commit first-degree murder in the death of her husband, Charles Vallow, in Arizona in 2019.

TITLE: Trump administration backs off Nvidia's 'H20' chip crackdown after Mar-a-Lago dinner
SUMMARY: The White House was expected to ban sales of the high-performance AI chip to China. Chinese companies had been stockpiling the chip but now the Trump administration is backing off.

TITLE: House GOP leaders prepare budget vote, daring dissenters to oppose Trump
SUMMARY: House GOP leaders are moving ahead with a budget plan that is meant to pave the way for future votes on President Trump's domestic agenda, but members within their own party oppose the bill. Some dissenters have remained opposed to the bill, despite pressure from leaders and Trump himself.

TITLE: This former influencer gave up her smartphone. She says you should, too
SUMMARY: August Lamm became an accidental influencer by posting pictures of her art online – until she reached a breaking point and got rid of her smartphone. Now, she's advocating for others to do the same.

TITLE: Appeals court rules Trump can fire probationary federal workers once again
SUMMARY: The decision from the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals further clears the way for the Trump administration to re-fire, for now, thousands of probationary federal employees.

TITLE: 'The Economist' editor unpacks the 'biggest trade policy shock' of Trump's tariffs
SUMMARY: President Trump's sweeping tariff policy has upended the global economy. Zanny Minton Beddoes, the editor-in-chief of The Economist, likens it to The Art of the Deal

TITLE: Trump says he will pause tariff hikes for 90 days, but not for China
SUMMARY: The president announced he would raise tariffs on China to 125% "effective immediately," but said he was pausing big hikes on other U.S. trading partners to allow time for trade negotiations.

TITLE: U.S. stocks soar after Trump pauses higher tariffs for 90 days except for China
SUMMARY: U.S. stocks surged on Wednesday after President Trump announced a 90-day pause on the higher tariffs he had imposed on most countries — except for China.

TITLE: European Union approves new retaliatory tariffs on the U.S.
SUMMARY: All but one of the 27 EU member countries voted to impose tariffs on specific U.S. products. The vote came before President Trump announced a 90-day pause on U.S. tariffs on goods from most countries.

TITLE: 20 musicians who should get to go to space before Katy Perry
SUMMARY: On April 14, Blue Origin plans to launch a space flight with a crew that includes the singer behind the 2010 hit "Firework." But we can think of many other artists who deserve to be among the stars.

TITLE: Israel's Attacks on Syria
SUMMARY: Since the rule of Syrian dictator Bashar al-Assad ended, Israel has attacked Syria hundreds of times. Israel says they don't trust the new government in Syria and so they are hitting areas in Syria adjacent to Israel in an effort disarm southern Syria. Our correspondent takes us to one of the Syrian villages on the border that was attacked.

TITLE: President Trump has announced a hold on most tariffs, but China faces tariffs of 125%
SUMMARY: President Trump abruptly announced a 90-day pause on the steep tariffs that went into effect Wednesday -- except for China.

TITLE: Attorney representing a student protester detained by federal immigration agents
SUMMARY: Amir Makled sat down with<em> All Things Considered

TITLE: Judge finds Newsmax aired false and defamatory claims about voting-tech company
SUMMARY: A Delaware judge finds the right-wing network aired false and defamatory statements about Dominion Voting Systems' role in the 2020 presidential election. A jury trial is slated for late April.

TITLE: 10 emerging writers win Whiting Awards
SUMMARY: The awards, which come with a $50K purse, have helped launch the writing careers of many now well-known authors, including Colson Whitehead, Ocean Vuong, Alice McDermott and Jia Tolentino.

TITLE: Jury awards $1.68 billion to women who accused director Toback of sexual abuse
SUMMARY: Toback, who wrote Bugsy, faces one of the largest #MeToo verdicts in history after a New York jury ordered him to pay 1.68 billion in damages to 40 women.

TITLE: Pain pathway in a dish could aid search for new analgesic drugs
SUMMARY: Scientists have recreated a pathway that senses pain, using clusters of human nerve cells grown in a dish.

TITLE: Asia markets soar, after President Trump pauses global tariffs
SUMMARY: Asia markets followed Wall Street's gains after Trump announced a pause on higher global tariffs, but investors are still looking to Beijing for reaction.

TITLE: What you need to know as the May 7 Real ID deadline approaches
SUMMARY: Driver's licenses and IDs that are not<strong>

TITLE: As measles spreads, federal budget cuts force closure of vaccine clinics
SUMMARY: Federal funding cuts, though temporarily blocked by a judge, have upended vaccination outreach across the country, including in Arizona, Minnesota, Nevada, Texas, and Washington state.

TITLE: Doggles and dog booties: Anchorage residents prep pets for volcanic explosion
SUMMARY: Mount Spurr, which scientists say is likely to erupt in the coming weeks or months, is about 80 miles west of Anchorage. But ash clouds could reach the state's biggest city.

TITLE: A former hostage struggles with the return home
SUMMARY: Paul Whelan was part of the largest prisoner exchange between the U.S. and Russia since the end of the Cold War. He says bureaucracy in the U.S still has him imprisoned.

TITLE: Where did U.S. humanities grants go? To projects from a baseball film to AI research
SUMMARY: From AI research to historical preservation, programs funded by grants from the National Endowment for the Humanities reach every corner of the U.S. Now the government has terminated those grants.

TITLE: Trump's 90-day pause on tariffs. And, how free speech in public schools has changed
SUMMARY: Yesterday, Trump abruptly announced a pause to big, sweeping tariff hikes for most countries. And, teachers across the U.S. share how freedom of speech is changing in their classrooms.

TITLE: Aging former research chimps move to Chimp Haven
SUMMARY: All of the former research chimpanzees that had been living on an Air Force base in New Mexico have finally arrived at a sanctuary in Louisiana. Many of these chimps are in their 50s and 60s.

TITLE: U.S.-Russia ballerina freed in prisoner swap
SUMMARY: Ksenia Karelina, jailed over a $50 donation to Ukraine, released after U.S.-Russia prisoner swap.

TITLE: Healing soup recipes, Part 2: Definitely not your grandma's chicken soup!
SUMMARY: The second installment of our soup-a-thon. Vicky Hallett and Genevieve Villamora, correspondents. Marc Silver, digital editor. Radio interview ran last week. Digital publishing Thursday at 7 a.m.

TITLE: Asia markets soar after President Trump pauses global tariffs
SUMMARY: Asia markets followed Wall Street's gains after Trump announced a pause on higher global tariffs, but investors are still looking to Beijing for reaction.

TITLE: Global markets soar after President Trump's tariff pause
SUMMARY: Stocks in Europe and Asia followed Wall Street's gains after Trump announced a pause on higher global tariffs, but investors are still waiting on Beijing's next move.

TITLE: U.S. stocks slide again as euphoria over Trump's tariff pause starts to fade
SUMMARY: U.S. stocks fell a day after posting spectacular gains over President Trump's decision to pause many of his tariffs. Now, some of that relief is starting to fade.

TITLE: Jillian Lauren: What we know about police shooting of Weezer bassist's wife
SUMMARY: Jillian Lauren suffered a non-life-threatening injury this week when police shot her in her yard after they say she pointed a gun at them. Details about the incident in Los Angeles are still emerging.

TITLE: House approves budget framework, kickstarting work on Trump's domestic agenda
SUMMARY: House Republicans narrowly adopted a multitrillion dollar budget framework on Thursday, paving the way for lawmakers to begin work on many of President Trump's top policy priorities.

TITLE: Where do tariffs stand? A look at what's in place and what's on pause
SUMMARY: Trump announced a 90-day pause on most country-specific tariffs, but left other duties in place. Here's a look at where things stand and what could happen next.

TITLE: U.S. stocks slide again as euphoria over Trump's tariff pause fades
SUMMARY: U.S. stocks fell a day after posting spectacular gains over President Trump's decision to pause many of his tariffs. Now, some of that relief is fading.

TITLE: Inflation is cooling -- but Trump's tariffs could upend things
SUMMARY: Consumer prices in March were up 2.4% from a year ago — a smaller annual increase than forecasters had expected. While President Trump has suspended many of his new tariffs, import taxes that remain could push prices higher in the months to come.

TITLE: 'No More Tears' author discusses Johnson & Johnson's questionable business practices
SUMMARY: J&J recently lost a bid to settle lawsuits that claimed its talc powder products, including baby powder, caused cancer. Author Gardiner Harris says the company's defense "is beginning to crumble."

TITLE: House approves budget framework, kick-starting work on Trump's domestic agenda
SUMMARY: House Republicans narrowly adopted a multitrillion-dollar budget framework on Thursday, paving the way for lawmakers to begin work on many of President Trump's top policy priorities.

TITLE: Tariff chaos sends some drivers racing to buy, while others pump the brakes
SUMMARY: With tariffs on cars, materials and parts threatening to send auto prices up, some shoppers are racing to lock in vehicles at pre-tariff prices. Others plan to drive their current rides into the ground.

TITLE: Trump administration changes course on in-person requirements for Social Security
SUMMARY: After announcing social security recipients would be required to appear in-person at office locations, the Trump administration is now backtracking.

TITLE: Trump administration lays out its evidence against detained activist Mahmoud Khalil
SUMMARY: Khalil's attorneys say the government's case against their client largely rests on a single letter from Secretary of State Marco Rubio alleging that Khalil participated in "antisemitic" and "disruptive activities."

TITLE: Academics Fleeing the U.S. for Europe
SUMMARY: The United States has long been a center for academic and scientific research. But two phenomena may be changing that and sending talent to Europe instead. The Trump administration has hit many colleges and universities with cuts to federal funding. And at the same time many academics feel like their freedom is under attack. Our correspondent in Rome tells us that European Universities are offering refuge to researchers in the U.S.

TITLE: The Northeast bet big on offshore wind. Trump wants to halt the industry entirely
SUMMARY: Northeast states have bet big on offshore wind to meet spiking power demand and drive economic growth. But the industry's future is much more uncertain under President Trump.

TITLE: HHS will review guidance on the addition of fluoride to drinking water
SUMMARY: HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has blamed the addition of fluoride — a common, naturally occurring mineral — for a host of health issues. The CDC says the policy has reduced cavities by some 25%.

TITLE: Trump administration lays out its evidence for deporting activist Mahmoud Khalil
SUMMARY: Khalil's attorneys say the government's case against their client largely rests on a single letter from Secretary of State Marco Rubio alleging that Khalil participated in "antisemitic" and "disruptive activities."

TITLE: Drowning in tariffs, American businesses try to stay afloat
SUMMARY:
It's pretty rare for one person to do one thing that affects nearly every business in the United States. But that's the power of the presidency and the new tariffs that took effect this week.

Over the last few days, as the tariffs have gone up and down, NPR has been talking to Americans who run different kinds of businesses.

Even though their companies don't have much in common, all of them are doing the same thing right now: Trying to figure out what's going on and how to respond.

Trump's tariff plans affect nearly every company in America. We'll hear from a few business owners about what it means for them

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: Why some are accusing Trump of manipulating stock markets
SUMMARY: Senators Adam Schiff and Ruben Gallego have asked for "an urgent inquiry" into whether President Trump or others engaged in insider trading on advanced knowledge of his tariff policy changes.

TITLE: Supreme Court says Trump officials should help return wrongly deported Maryland man
SUMMARY: The Supreme Court  ordered the administration to "facilitate" the return of Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia, who was mistakenly taken to El Salvador and remains in custody there.

TITLE: Burials begin for victims in the Dominican nightclub collapse that killed 221
SUMMARY: Many people have been anxiously waiting for news of their loved ones, growing frustrated with the drip-drip of information provided by hospitals and the country's forensic institute.

TITLE: The controversial and obscure law being used against immigrant student protestors
SUMMARY: The Trump Administration is using an obscure and controversial immigration law from 1952 to try to deport Pro-Palestinian activist Mahmoud Khalil.

TITLE: What ELSE does the president want to make great again? Find out in the quiz!
SUMMARY: This week was more than tariffs! There were tortoises, genetically engineered animals, smart vacuums and a lot of other news!

TITLE: How DOGE may have improperly used Social Security data to push voter fraud narratives
SUMMARY: A DOGE staffer working in the Social Security Administration has been pushing questionable claims about noncitizens voting — apparently using data that court records suggest DOGE shouldn't have.

TITLE: Lightning strikes usually kill trees. This one just grows stronger
SUMMARY: An author of a recent study about lightning's effect on trees in Panamanian forests says his team has gotten a large, positive response from people, including those who call the trees inspirational.

TITLE: 4 takeaways from the week: In a world that craves stability, Trump brings the chaos
SUMMARY: President Trump's trade war sent global markets reeling this week. How Trump has handled tariffs shows the farthest thing from stability and predictability. A look at this and three other takeaways.

TITLE: Beijing slaps 125% tariffs on U.S. goods in latest U.S.-China trade escalation
SUMMARY: China signals the latest tariff hike will be its last round of tit-for-tat measures, prompting sharp falls in European shares, as Asian stocks end the day mixed.

TITLE: China hits the U.S. with hefty tariff. And, how free speech is shifting at colleges
SUMMARY: China retaliated against the imposed U.S. tariffs with a hefty 125% tariff on U.S. goods. And, how people on college campuses feel about free speech since President Trump has been in office.

TITLE: Chai Jing: China's Lesley Stahl returns to spotlight on YouTube
SUMMARY: Chai Jing's interviews appear to strike a chord back home in China, even as YouTube is blocked in the country and popular platforms have deleted videos repackaging her show.

TITLE: Will tariffs drive more people to shop secondhand? It's a mixed bag, experts say
SUMMARY: This moment of economic uncertainty could drive more Americans to buy used. But experts say secondhand stores won't be immune from tariffs either.

TITLE: How to get what you want without using cash (you read that right)
SUMMARY: Experienced traders share real-world tips on how to barter  with your community. People are more open to the idea than you may realize, they say.

TITLE: What to know about Dan Caine, the nation's newly-confirmed top military adviser
SUMMARY: The Senate voted around 2 a.m. Friday to confirm retired Air Force Lt. Gen. Dan Caine as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Trump plucked him from retirement to be his top military adviser.

TITLE: Pig kidney transplant fails after patient rejection
SUMMARY: Surgeons at NYU Langone Health in New York City had to remove a genetically modified pig kidney from Towana Looney, 53, of Gadsden, Ala., because her body rejected the organ. She's back on dialysis.

TITLE: To instill confidence, China tries to reassure private entrepreneurs of support
SUMMARY: As the country faces slowing economic growth and a trade war with the U.S., China has taken pains to reassure entrepreneurs by telling them they can start businesses, create jobs and benefit society.

TITLE: Jewish students at Georgetown protest detention of professor Badar Khan Suri
SUMMARY: More than 130 Jewish students, staff and alumni from Georgetown University signed a public letter opposing the detention of Badar Khan Suri, saying that President Trump's policies make Jews less safe.

TITLE: Maryland judge again asks government to return man wrongly deported to El Salvador
SUMMARY: A federal judge in Maryland wants the government to "facilitate" Abrego Garcia's return to the U.S. after the Supreme Court largely upheld her original order.

TITLE: Amid deep mistrust, U.S. and Iran try to work out a nuclear deal
SUMMARY: President Trump pulled out of a nuclear deal with Iran in his first term. Now he's trying to negotiate a new agreement that would prevent Iran from acquiring a nuclear weapon.

TITLE: Are Trump's tariffs a bargaining chip for a new global economic order?
SUMMARY: It's not just tariffs. The White House is rethinking the central role of the dollar in the global economy.

TITLE: Judge rules Mahmoud Khalil can be deported
SUMMARY: Khalil was detained last month after Secretary of State Marco Rubio said he had determined that Khalil's activism was antisemitic.

TITLE: Allegations of a Land Grab on Nigeria's Coast
SUMMARY: Many communities have thrived for years on the peninsula and islands in the lagoon around Nigeria's crowded commercial capital Lagos. But the last decade has seen a violent shift, as thousands of people have been evicted by the Nigerian Navy and the government in an apparent effort to make way for luxury developments. We go to the communities and meet the people affected.

TITLE: 'I cannot guarantee complete confidentiality,' VA therapists ordered to tell veterans
SUMMARY: Mental health therapists at Veterans Affairs should begin sessions with patients saying they are in a shared office space, a memo obtained by NPR says. Trump's back-to-office orders start Monday for VA.

TITLE: Major budget cuts proposed for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration
SUMMARY: The agency forecasts weather, manages fisheries, and researches the world's oceans, atmosphere, and climate. The proposed budget cuts would slash the climate work entirely.

TITLE: Dozens of USAID contracts were canceled last weekend. Here's what happened
SUMMARY: The rationale was to address "mismanagement, fraud, and misaligned priorities." Former USAID official Jeremy Konyndyk said reversals and inconsistences in the cancellations created "total whiplash."

TITLE: How Trump's immigration policy changes who gets arrested and detained
SUMMARY:
During his second Presidential campaign, Donald Trump vowed to carry out the largest deportation program the U.S. has ever seen.

And true to his word – Trump's administration is arresting, detaining and deporting immigrants without legal status.

But as part of the crackdown on illegal immigration, legal immigrants are getting caught up in the mix.

And then there's people like Amir Makled – a U.S. Citizen and lawyer. Makled was detained by Border agents at a Detroit airport as he returned from a family vacation in the Caribbean.

How is the Trump administration's immigration policy changing who is getting arrested and detained?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: Trump says he took a cognitive test as part of his latest physical
SUMMARY: President Trump had his first physical of his second term on Friday at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center.

TITLE: Trump administration ends temporary protected status for thousands of Afghans
SUMMARY: As soon as May 20, thousands of Afghans living in the U.S. will lose a protection that shielded them from deportation and allowed them to work.

TITLE: Ecuador's next president faces rampant drug violence and few resources to combat it
SUMMARY: Ecuador's runoff vote pits Trump ally and incumbent Daniel Noboa against leftist challenger Luisa González, in an election dominated by the issue of security in a highly polarized political landscape.

TITLE: A crow's math skills include geometry
SUMMARY: Crows in a lab were able to distinguish shapes that exhibited right angles, parallel lines, and symmetry, suggesting that, like humans, they have a special ability to perceive geometric regularity.

TITLE: China put steep tariffs on U.S. exports. Farmers are worried
SUMMARY: The first Trump administration spent $28 billion bailing out farmers during a trade war with China. The White House has said it's starting to look at how to help this time around.

TITLE: A 3 year legal saga over an inmate's death has its final day in court
SUMMARY: NPR first reported on the case of Charles Givens, a disabled inmate at Virginia's Marion Correctional Treatment Center, in 2023. Four corrections officers were accused of beating him to death and a fifth accused of negligence. Givens' sister, Kymberly Hobbs, sued the five men.

TITLE: Mental health workers go on hunger strike, demanding better pay and benefits
SUMMARY: After months of striking, some therapists with Kaiser Permanente stopped eating for five days to bring attention to their union's demands for parity with how the company's other workers are treated<strong>.

TITLE: Opinion: Alice Tan Ridley and the joy of music
SUMMARY: NPR's Scott Simon takes a moment to remember Alice Tan Ridley, who busked in the New York City subways and reached the semi-finals of "America's Got Talent."

TITLE: 'The lawn giveth and the lawn taketh away': Photos from the 41st Annapolis Cup
SUMMARY: The yearly competition between the small liberal arts college lauded for its "great books" curriculum and the famed school for naval officer training began in the early 1980s. Several attendees recounted the legend that a discussion between a St. John's College student and the Commandant of the Naval Academy led to the latter's challenge that his midshipmen could beat Johnnies at any sport.

TITLE: A 3-year legal saga over an inmate's death has its final day in court
SUMMARY: NPR first reported on the case of Charles Givens, a disabled inmate at Virginia's Marion Correctional Treatment Center, in 2023. Four corrections officers were accused of beating him to death and a fifth accused of negligence. Givens' sister, Kymberly Hobbs, sued the five men.

TITLE: Ukraine's DIY drone makers are helping fighters on the front lines
SUMMARY: The war in Ukraine is now largely being fought with drones. Ukraine made 2 million last year. Drone makers churn them out in factories and mom-and-pop operations like one in a Kyiv basement apartment.

TITLE: Federal judge orders USDA to unfreeze funds to Maine
SUMMARY: The funds had been initially withheld following President Trump's clash with Maine Gov. Janet Mills over the issue of transgender athletes.

TITLE: Big law in Trump's crosshairs
SUMMARY:
For weeks, President Trump has been targeting certain law firms with executive orders. Some have fought back, but others have cut deals to avoid the damage.

For our weekly Reporter's Notebook series, we dive into this legal drama with NPR's Justice Correspondent Ryan Lucas, to see how this use of executive power is changing the landscape of the American legal system.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: Smartphones and computers are now spared from Trump's reciprocal tariffs
SUMMARY: The exemption comes amid worries of how President Trump's steep new tariffs will affect American tech companies that rely on supply chains in China, like Apple.

TITLE: Intellectually disabled teen shot by Idaho police dies after being removed from life support
SUMMARY: An autistic, nonverbal teenage boy who was shot repeatedly by Idaho police from the other side of a chain link fence while he was holding a knife died Saturday after being removed from life support, his family said.

TITLE: Trump urges Congress to make daylight saving time permanent
SUMMARY: President Trump said Congress should "push hard for more Daylight at the end of a day" in a post on Truth Social.

TITLE: Trump admin tells judge man wrongly deported to El Salvador is alive, still detained
SUMMARY: On Friday, federal judge Paula Xinis had ordered the Trump administration to provide daily updates to return Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia to the United States.

TITLE: A retrial of Sarah Palin's case against 'New York Times' begins Monday
SUMMARY: Former Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin has the rare opportunity to retry her defamation case against <em>The New York Times

TITLE: Will the SAVE Act make it harder for married women to vote? We ask legal experts
SUMMARY: Legal experts say states could help married women who have changed their last names by accepting documents like a legal decree or a marriage certificate, but it might not fix the issue for all.

TITLE: Trump attacks on law firms begin to chill pro bono work on causes he doesn't like
SUMMARY: The ripple effects of Trump's actions targeting specific law firms already are being felt beyond boardrooms, in declining interest in pro bono work for causes that are unpopular with the president.

TITLE: Israel strikes a hospital in Gaza, forcing evacuation as strikes intensify
SUMMARY: The strike hit Al-Ahli Hospital in Gaza City, after Israel issued an evacuation warning. Israel said it struck a command and control center used by Hamas at the hospital.

TITLE: More than 20 people killed in Russian missile attack on Ukrainian city of Sumy
SUMMARY: More than 20 people were killed in a Russian missile strike on the Ukrainian city of Sumy on Sunday, officials said.

TITLE: At least one dead after small plane crashes in upstate New York
SUMMARY: A twin-engine plane with six people on board crashed Saturday in a muddy field in upstate New York, authorities said.

TITLE: Convalescing Pope Francis opens Holy Week with greeting in St. Peter's Square
SUMMARY: A convalescing Pope Francis greeted the crowd in St. Peter's Square on Palm Sunday, in yet another reassuring public sign of his recovery from a life-threatening battle with double pneumonia.

TITLE: More than 30 people killed in Russian missile attack on Ukrainian city of Sumy
SUMMARY: More than 30 people were killed in a Russian missile strike on the Ukrainian city of Sumy on Sunday, officials said.

TITLE: The biggest trial in Meta's history starts today. Here's what to know
SUMMARY: The government plans to call Mark Zuckerberg and Sheryl Sandberg to the witness stand. The trial is expected to run nearly two months in a federal courtroom in Washington.

TITLE: Soccer-loving 'grannies' go for the GOOOOAAAALLLL in their version of the World Cup
SUMMARY: The players are women over 50. The oldest this year is 87. They took the field in South Africa for their "World Cup." One team was crowned the winner but all the players consider themselves champions.

TITLE: Can't stop scrolling? Here's how to retrain your brain to crave movement more
SUMMARY: If you're finding yourself glued to your phone these days, scrolling the news, here's how to change your habits and get moving instead.

TITLE: White House doctor says Trump is 'fully fit' in medical report
SUMMARY: President Trump lost 20 pounds, lowered "bad" cholesterol and has "diverticulosis and a benign polyp," according to a medical report released by the White House.

TITLE: Here's how to retrain your brain to crave movement more than screen time
SUMMARY: If you're finding yourself glued to your phone these days, scrolling the news, here's how to change your habits and get moving instead.

TITLE: Bernie Sanders warns of 'extraordinary danger' facing U.S. under Trump at LA rally
SUMMARY: The Vermont independent told a crowd of thousands of supporters that the U.S. was facing a moment of "extraordinary danger."

TITLE: The biggest trial in Meta's history starts Monday. Here's what to know
SUMMARY: The government plans to call Mark Zuckerberg and Sheryl Sandberg to the witness stand. The trial is expected to run nearly two months in a federal courtroom in Washington.

TITLE: Fire at Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro's residence was 'an act of arson,' police say
SUMMARY: Gov. Shapiro says he and his family "woke up to bangs on the door from the Pennsylvania State Police" early Sunday morning. The fire caused significant damage, but fortunately, no one was injured.

TITLE: Trump mulls semiconductor levies after lifting reciprocal tariffs on electronics
SUMMARY: Trump targets Chinese technology with 20% fentanyl tariff and eyes semiconductors in a "National Security Tariff Investigation" over coming months.

TITLE: The 2025 Masters final round is underway, featuring a showdown between two greats
SUMMARY: On Sunday at Augusta National Golf Club in Georgia, all eyes are on Rory McIlroy and Bryson DeChambeau — both of whom are vying for their first green jacket.

TITLE: Rory McIlroy wins the Masters, becoming the 6th golfer to achieve a career Grand Slam
SUMMARY: In a dramatic playoff on Sunday, McIlroy defeated Justin Rose to win all four major titles in golf, joining the esteemed ranks of Gene Sarazen, Ben Hogan, Gary Player, Jack Nicklaus and Tiger Woods.

TITLE: Suspect arrested after fire at Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro's residence, police say
SUMMARY: Cody Balmer, 38, jumped the fence outside the Governor's Residence in Harrisburg early Sunday morning and set a fire, Pennsylvania State Police say. Fortunately, Shapiro and his family escaped injury.

TITLE: Ecuador's President Daniel Noboa wins re-election
SUMMARY: Ecuador's conservative millionaire incumbent handily won Sunday's presidential run off against a leftist challenger.

TITLE: Mario Vargas Llosa, Nobel Prize-winning Peruvian author, dies at age 89
SUMMARY: A giant of Latin American culture, Llosa used powerful imagery and sometimes fantastical storytelling to explore issues of male violence, societal disruption and authoritarian politics.

TITLE: Ecuador's President Daniel Noboa wins reelection
SUMMARY: Ecuador's conservative millionaire incumbent handily won Sunday's presidential run off against a leftist challenger.

TITLE: The 'world's coolest dictator' heads to the White House
SUMMARY: El Salvador's President Bukele heads to the White House to discuss further cooperation with the U.S., including the continued use of El Salvador's supermax prison for deported migrants.

TITLE: Anxiety drugs found in rivers make salmon take more risks
SUMMARY: New research suggests that pharmaceutical pollution can change the behavior of salmon in the wild.

TITLE: Troops arrive at the border to help with enforcement despite fewer migrant crossings
SUMMARY: According to the U.S. Army, soldiers won't be arresting people suspected of being in the country illegally, and instead will offer "logistical support" to Border Patrol agents.

TITLE: Move over Paleo diet, it's Dinosaur Time, a TikTok trend all about devouring veggies
SUMMARY: On social media, people are gobbling up greens like they are giant primeval beasts. Nutritionists say it's not a bad way to get more fiber and micronutrients in.

TITLE: Is it 'Made in USA'? The answer can be complicated
SUMMARY: In a global economy, something called "substantial transformation" comes into play when the U.S. determines where a product is made.

TITLE: Should I stay or go? Immigrants across U.S. consider self-deportation
SUMMARY: In the face of raids and threats to previously safe spaces, some immigrants in the U.S. without legal status are weighing whether to heed Trump's call to voluntarily leave the U.S.

TITLE: DOGE abruptly cut a program for teens with disabilities. This student is 'devastated'
SUMMARY: The program, Charting My Path for Future Success, aimed to help teens with disabilities transition from high school to the real world. It abruptly ended when DOGE terminated its federal contract.

TITLE: How cutting Medicaid would affect long-term care and family caregivers
SUMMARY: The federal program is the biggest source of money for long-term care for the elderly and disabled. Republican proposals to cut its budget could jeopardize supports family and caregivers rely on.

TITLE: In Sudan, hundreds killed in attacks on famine-hit displacement camps
SUMMARY: Sudanese paramilitary group the Rapid Support Forces has claimed it has taken control of  famine-hit Zamzam camp, after days of deadly fighting in the Darfur region.

TITLE: Why Trump exempted electronics from tariffs. And, Meta's biggest trial begins today
SUMMARY: Trump spared electronics from his sweeping tariffs. Here's why he wants to levy semiconductors next. And, the Federal Trade Commission's antitrust case against Meta  begins today.

TITLE: Ukrainians in the U.S. use connections and their art to support the war effort
SUMMARY: Amid concerns over Trump's foreign policy and Russian influence, Ukrainians look for new ways to raise awareness.

TITLE: Haunted by hopelessness: 12 Zambians share their stories as HIV drugs run out
SUMMARY: Mothers and children, husbands and wives, doctors, truck drivers and religious leaders are all grappling with the fallout from the sudden U.S. cuts in aid.

TITLE: WATCH: Katy Perry and star-studded crew launch into space aboard Blue Origin rocket
SUMMARY: Monday's flight features the first all-female crew since 1963 and includes big names like Katy Perry, Gayle King and Lauren Sánchez. Here's what else to know about it.

TITLE: Gaza territory shrinks drastically as Israel seizes huge swaths of land
SUMMARY: Israel's military is expanding buffer zones inside the Gaza Strip and taking over more areas of the territory, shrinking land Palestinians can access by more than half.

TITLE: 'Welcome back to Earth:' Blue Origin sends a star-studded, all-female crew into space
SUMMARY: Monday's 11-minute flight featured the first all-female crew since 1963. Here's what else to know about it.

TITLE: Critics say GOP Medicaid cuts could slash fentanyl addiction treatment
SUMMARY: Republicans hope to save a lot of tax dollars by cutting Medicaid.  Drug policy experts say as many as a million Americans in treatment for addiction could lose coverage.

TITLE: What we know about the arson at Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro's residence
SUMMARY: Prosecutors have charged Cody Balmer, 38, with attempted murder, terrorism, aggravated arson and other crimes. He turned himself in to police later on Sunday.

TITLE: Katy Perry, Gayle King and others reflect on their brief but historic trip to space
SUMMARY: Monday's 11-minute flight featured the first all-female crew since 1963. Here's what else to know about it.

TITLE: El Salvador's Bukele says 'preposterous' to suggest he return Abrego Garcia to U.S.
SUMMARY: El Salvador's President Nayib Bukele and several top Trump administration officials dismissed questions about the fate of a Maryland man wrongfully deported to El Salvador.

TITLE: Millions watch as underwater camera documents daily life on a Miami coral reef
SUMMARY: For five years, the Coral City Camera has been given viewers a live look at aquatic reef life near Miami. It's documented the declining conditions and shown a surprising vitality among some coral species.

TITLE: A 5.2 magnitude earthquake strikes Southern California
SUMMARY: A series of aftershocks followed the initial 5.2 magnitude earthquake that struck Julian, Calif., continuing for several minutes.

TITLE: A day in the life of one migrant seeking to stay in the U.S.
SUMMARY: Yasmelin Velazquez has waited 10 months for her immigration court date. But a last-minute hospitalization and confusion over Trump's changing immigration policies lead to more hurdles and anxiety.

TITLE: Meta and the FTC face off in court over monopoly claims
SUMMARY: Dozens of witnesses are set to take the stand in the trial, including CEO Mark Zuckerberg, who is scheduled to testify for seven hours. The outcome could reshape the future of Meta.

TITLE: Hot off her NCAA title, Paige Bueckers cruises for 1st pick in the WNBA draft
SUMMARY: Monday's WNBA Draft is expected to be the latest jewel in the crown of Bueckers, the 6-foot guard who barely a week ago led her UConn Huskies to their first national championship in a decade.

TITLE: Harvard rejects Trump administration's demands for deep changes
SUMMARY: The university refused to make changes it said would "dictate what private universities can teach" and "whom they can admit and hire," among other things.

TITLE: Big Changes at the U.S. State Department
SUMMARY: The Trump administration is undertaking shifts in U.S. foreign policy and that has meant big shifts at the State Department, which is in charge of that policy. The changes have veteran diplomats worried.

TITLE: Vaccine expert worries child measles deaths are being 'normalized'
SUMMARY:
Measles is an extremely contagious disease. It's also extremely preventable. There's a vaccine. It's highly effective.

For decades it has made measles outbreaks in the U.S. relatively rare, and measles deaths rarer still. But the U.S. has now seen more than 700 measles cases this year, and 3 deaths so far with active outbreaks across six states.

The federal response is under scrutiny because Health and Human Services Secretary, Robert F. Kennedy, Jr. has made a career spreading false information about vaccines.

What are this administration's views on vaccines, and what do they mean for what is already one of the worst U.S. measles outbreaks this century.

Kennedy publicly promised he would support vaccines. Dr. Peter Marks, who was forced out as the nation's top vaccine regulator says his department isn't doing enough.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: The biggest plot twist in a viral 'true crime' story? None of it was real
SUMMARY: A viral "true crime" story was actually made up, generated by A.I. Reporter Henry Larson explores the ethical questions raised by this new frontier of content.

TITLE: Hot off her NCAA title, Paige Bueckers is the 1st pick in the WNBA draft
SUMMARY: Monday's WNBA Draft is the latest jewel in the crown of Bueckers, the 6-foot guard who barely a week ago led her UConn Huskies to their first national championship in a decade.

TITLE: Americans impacted by 2024 natural disasters may qualify for extension to file taxes
SUMMARY: Americans in at least nine states qualify for automatic IRS tax filing extensions, according to the agency.

TITLE: Federal funding freeze halts key infrastructure projects in tribal communities
SUMMARY: Riverbank stabilization, lead and asbestos contamination are just some of the projects tribes planned to address before the Trump administration froze funds.

TITLE: Trump administration freezes more than $2.2 billion after Harvard rejects its demands
SUMMARY: The government announced it is freezing more than $2.2 billion, hours after the university refused to make changes it said would "dictate what private universities can teach."

TITLE: Hungary passes constitutional amendment to ban LGBTQ+ public events
SUMMARY: The amendment bans public events held by LGBTQ+ communities and allows authorities to use facial recognition tools to identify people who attend prohibited events.

TITLE: Attack leaves at least 40 people dead in Nigeria, the country's president says
SUMMARY: Such attacks have become common in north-central Nigeria, where gunmen exploit security lapses to launch deadly raids on farmers in a fight over land resources.

TITLE: Europe deplores America's 'chlorinated chicken.' How safe is our poultry?
SUMMARY: President Trump wants European countries to start buying U.S. chicken and eggs. But the U.K. and E.U. think American poultry is gross and chemically washed. Turns out, chlorine isn't really the issue.

TITLE: Bipartisan senators rebuke White House move to end legal aid for unaccompanied minors
SUMMARY: The letter obtained by NPR marks a rare bipartisan critique from Capitol Hill of the administration's immigration policy.

TITLE: After delays, first vaccine advisory meeting under RFK Jr. set to start
SUMMARY: For the first time since Robert F. Kennedy Jr. became health secretary, vaccine advisers to the CDC are meeting to discuss vaccines for RSV, HPV, COVID and more.

TITLE: A whistleblower's disclosure details how DOGE may have taken sensitive labor data
SUMMARY: A whistleblower tells Congress and NPR that DOGE may have taken sensitive labor data and hid its tracks. "None of that ... information should ever leave the agency," said a former NLRB official.

TITLE: Once again, Harvey Weinstein goes on trial for sex crimes in New York today
SUMMARY: Weinstein's New York conviction was overturned last year. The new trial will retry the case alongside a brand new charge.

TITLE: The man accused in the attempted assassination of Donald Trump to appear in court
SUMMARY: Ryan Routh, accused in the golf course attempted assassination of Donald Trump, will appear in a Florida federal courtroom Tuesday for a hearing involving evidence that will be presented in the case.

TITLE: Climate activists were hacked. There was a link between the victims and an alleged attacker
SUMMARY: Prosecutors say the operation was aimed at gathering information to foil lawsuits against the fossil fuel industry over damage communities have faced from climate change.

TITLE: As special ed students are integrated more at school, teacher training is evolving
SUMMARY: General education teachers are more likely than ever to be working with students who have special needs.

TITLE: 5 takeaways about NPR's reporting on the whistleblower report about DOGE at the NLRB
SUMMARY: Here's a summary of NPR's findings about the report that a whistleblower filed to Congress about how DOGE violated security protocols and could have removed sensitive labor data.

TITLE: Whistleblower says DOGE took sensitive data. And, Harvard rejects Trump's demands
SUMMARY: A whistleblower who works at NLRB says that DOGE may have taken sensitive labor data. And, the Trump administration froze over $2 billion for Harvard after it rejected demands.

TITLE: How Trump's cuts to U.S. foreign aid are imperiling Syria's war crimes investigations
SUMMARY: When former leader Bashar al-Assad fell, new Syria war crimes investigations began. But U.S. budget cuts have halted some work. For families of the disappeared, it means justice delayed or denied.

TITLE: DOGE cut a CDC team as it was about to start a project to help N.C. flood victims
SUMMARY: The National Center for Environmental Health was hollowed out in the cuts of 10,000 federal health workers on April 1. That's the same day an assessment of people hurt in floods was set to begin.

TITLE: Trump plans order to cut funding for NPR and PBS
SUMMARY: HFR: President Trump and GOP members of Congress have accused the public broadcasters of biased and "woke" programming. The president plans a rescission, which would give Congress 45 days to approve the directive or allow funding to be restored.

TITLE: Sudan's war is 2 years in and shows no signs of slowing, as talks take place
SUMMARY: As "pathway to peace talks" are held in London - minus the main protagonists - Sudan tips into a third year of catastrophic civil war, as violence surges in the Darfur region of the west of the country and activists warn of an unfolding genocide.

TITLE: States push Medicaid work rules, but few programs help enrollees find jobs
SUMMARY: Some lawmakers are pushing to require that Medicaid recipients work in order to get or keep coverage, and some states already try to help them find jobs. But the effects of those efforts are unclear.

TITLE: Melinda French Gates on what billionaires with 'absurd' wealth owe back to society
SUMMARY: In a new memoir, French Gates writes about the end of her marriage to Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates, and her ongoing philanthropic work, directing funds and attention to women's health initiatives.

TITLE: A colossal squid is filmed in its natural habitat for the first time
SUMMARY: Colossal squid are known to be elusive and likely avoid the bright and loud research equipment used underwater.

TITLE: Mark Zuckerberg defends Meta in court against monopoly claims
SUMMARY: In Zuckerberg's second day of testifying in the federal antitrust trial, he defended Meta's acquisitions of Instagram and WhatsApp. The U.S. government wants Meta to bust up the two companies.

TITLE: Trump moves to speed up asylum cases without court hearings
SUMMARY: The memo could result in immigration judges deciding someone is not eligible for asylum without a hearing, and based solely on a lengthy and complex asylum request form.

TITLE: Photos: Two years of war in Sudan
SUMMARY: Images of Sudan, after two years of civil war have led to the world biggest humanitarian crisis.

TITLE: Top House Democrat says DOGE data access at NLRB may be 'technological malfeasance'
SUMMARY: A top House Democrat is asking independent agency watchdogs to investigate after NPR reporting revealed DOGE may have taken sensitive data from the National Labor Relations Board.

TITLE: New Israeli ceasefire offer demands Hamas discuss disarming, but group rejects it
SUMMARY: Hamas is rejecting a new Israeli proposal to pause the war in Gaza, a Hamas official told NPR. Earlier, officials mediating talks had expressed optimism that a deal could be reached within weeks.

TITLE: Higher ed war heats up as Trump threatens Harvard's tax-exempt status
SUMMARY: The president's comments came after the administration froze $2 billion in federal grants for Harvard after the university rejected what it saw as illegal government demands.

TITLE: U.S. Army libraries target books with a focus on DEI or 'gender ideology' for removal
SUMMARY: Books "overtly promoting DEI, gender ideology, and critical race theory" are under new scrutiny following a memo issued by acting Assistant Secretary of the Army Derrick Anderson.

TITLE: When an earthquake struck San Diego, these elephants formed an 'alert circle'
SUMMARY: When a 5.2 earthquake hit near San Diego yesterday, the San Diego Zoo Safari Park caught its elephants on video taking action to protect their young, forming what experts call an "alert circle."

TITLE: Dismantling Democracy in Hungary
SUMMARY: In his fifteen years as prime minister of Hungary, Viktor Orban has steadily chipped away at his country's democratic freedoms. We go to Budapest to see what the erosion of democracy looks like and we find that may of Orban's strategies are being studied by politicians elsewhere.

TITLE: Judge demands to know if White House is helping return wrongly deported Maryland man
SUMMARY: The hearing is the first about Abrego Garcia's case since El Salvador's president told reporters he is not going to "smuggle a terrorist into the United States."

TITLE: Trump signs executive action to lower drug prices
SUMMARY: The action is intended to build upon the existing program for Medicare drug price negotiations, which was created by the Inflation Reduction Act that passed during the Biden administration.

TITLE: The White House is starting the process to eliminate funding for public media
SUMMARY: The White House is proposing that virtually all federal funding for public media—that's NPR and PBS—be eliminated, starting a process that will reach Congress later in April.

TITLE: Records show Gene Hackman's wife researched symptoms of illness days before her death
SUMMARY: Photos, hours of footage and other documents were made public Tuesday after a recent court order that mandated any depictions of the deceased couple would be blocked from view.

TITLE: Wink Martindale, the genial game show host and early interviewer of Elvis, dies at 91
SUMMARY: The legendary TV host of game shows "Tic-Tac-Dough" and "Gambit" died at his home in Rancho Mirage, California. He had been battling lymphoma for a year.

TITLE: U.K. Supreme Court to rule on landmark challenge over legal definition of a woman
SUMMARY: The court is scheduled to rule whether a transgender person with a certificate that recognizes them as female can be regarded as a woman under equality laws.

TITLE: Hong Kong post office will stop shipping parcels to the U.S. over tariffs
SUMMARY: Hong Kong is caught in the middle of the trade disputes between the U.S. and China despite being a free port. The former British colony has trade and customs policies different from mainland China's.

TITLE: Study highlights cancer risk from millions of CT scans performed annually
SUMMARY: They can be life-saving but radiation from the scans also contributes to cancer risk. The authors of a new study estimate overuse of CT scans is increasing the U.S. cancer burden.

TITLE: How psychiatric patients get caught in a cycle of homelessness and spotty care
SUMMARY: Montana is investing $300 million to help those with severe mental illness from cycling through ERs, state psychiatric facilities, jails and homelessness. Advocates say they also need stable housing.

TITLE: Photos: Scientists trace a butterfly migration route that is millions of years old
SUMMARY: Scientists have recently mapped the painted lady butterfly's annual flight from equatorial Africa to northern Europe and back, the world's longest butterfly migration. In <em>Constant Bloom

TITLE: Word of the Week: A brief history of Coachella — the festival and the place
SUMMARY: When you think of Coachella, you probably picture the festival. But there's much more to know about the place it calls home.

TITLE: Families say school civil rights investigations have stalled after federal cuts
SUMMARY: The U.S. Education Department's Office for Civil Rights investigates discrimination in schools. It recently lost more than 40% of its staff.

TITLE: Could polio be poised for a comeback?
SUMMARY: Cases have been rising in Afghanistan and Pakistan — and global health specialists are worried that this year's U.S. foreign aid cuts could usher in a wider resurgence.

TITLE: Trump aims to lower drug prices. And, Harvard's tax-exempt status threatened
SUMMARY: Trump has signed an executive action aimed at lowering prescription drug prices. And, the president threatened to revoke Harvard University's tax-exempt status after it rejected government demands.

TITLE: Word of the Week: Coachella began as a typo. Here's what happened next
SUMMARY: When you think of Coachella, you probably picture the festival. But there's much more to know about the place it calls home.

TITLE: U.K. high court says trans women don't meet definition of women under equalities law
SUMMARY: Justice Patrick Hodge said five judges at the court had ruled unanimously that "the terms 'woman' and 'sex' in the Equality Act refer to a biological woman and biological sex."

TITLE: Retail sales jump as people rush to buy cars ahead of tariffs
SUMMARY: The key driver of the economy saw the biggest increase in over two years in March, as car buyers tried to get ahead of President Trump's tariffs on imported autos and auto parts.

TITLE: China reports 5.4% GDP growth in 1st quarter, but analysts say tariffs will bite soon
